Utah Code Annotated - Title 76 - Utah Criminal Code
===================================================

Utah Code Annotated - Title 76 - Chapter 1 - General Provisions
***************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This title shall be known and may be cited as the "Utah Criminal Code."

Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
Unless otherwise provided, as used in this title:Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(1): "Act" means a voluntary bodily movement and includes speech.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(2): "Actor" means a person whose criminal responsibility is in issue in a criminal action.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(3): "Affinity" means a relationship by marriage.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(4): "Bodily injury" means physical pain, illness, or any impairment of physical condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(5): "Conduct" means an act or omission.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(6): "Consanguinity" means a relationship by blood to the first or second degree, including an individual's parent, grandparent, sibling, child, aunt, uncle, niece, or nephew.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(7): "Dangerous weapon" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(7)(a): any item capable of causing death or serious bodily injury; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(7)(b): a facsimile or representation of the item, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(7)(b)(i): the actor's use or apparent intended use of the item leads the victim to reasonably believe the item is likely to cause death or serious bodily injury; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(7)(b)(ii): the actor represents to the victim verbally or in any other manner that the actor is in control of such an item.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(8): 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-402.2; 76-5-402.3; 76-5-403(2); 76-5-403.1; 76-5-404.3; 76-5-405; (8)(a); (h); (8)(a); (i) "Grievous sexual offense" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(8)(a): 76-5-402 rape, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(8)(b): 76-5-402.1 rape of a child, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(8)(c): 76-5-402.2 object rape, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(8)(d): 76-5-402.3 object rape of a child, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(8)(e): 76-5-403(2) forcible sodomy, Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(8)(f): 76-5-403.1 sodomy on a child, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(8)(g): 76-5-404.3 aggravated sexual abuse of a child, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(8)(h): 76-5-405 aggravated sexual assault, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(8)(i): (8)(a); (h) any felony attempt to commit an offense described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(8)(j): (8)(a); (i) an offense in another state, territory, or district of the United States that, if committed in Utah, would constitute an offense described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(9): "Offense" means a violation of any penal statute of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(10): "Omission" means a failure to act when there is a legal duty to act and the actor is capable of acting.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(11): "Person" means an individual, public or private corporation, government, partnership, or unincorporated association.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(12): "Possess" means to have physical possession of or to exercise dominion or control over tangible property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(13): "Public entity" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(13)(a): the state, or an agency, bureau, office, department, division, board, commission, institution, laboratory, or other instrumentality of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(13)(b): a political subdivision of the state, including a county, municipality, interlocal entity, special district, special service district, school district, or school board;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(13)(c): an agency, bureau, office, department, division, board, commission, institution, laboratory, or other instrumentality of a political subdivision of the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(13)(d): another entity that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(13)(d)(i): performs a public function; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(13)(d)(ii): is authorized to hold, spend, transfer, disburse, use, or receive public money.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(14): (13)(a); (c); (13)(d)(i); (14)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(14)(a): (13)(a); (c); (13)(d)(i) "Public money" or "public funds" means money, funds, or accounts, regardless of the source from which they are derived, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(14)(a)(i): (13)(a); (c) are owned, held, or administered by an entity described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(14)(a)(ii): (13)(d)(i) are in the possession of an entity described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(14)(b): (14)(a) "Public money" or "public funds" includes money, funds, or accounts described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(14)(c): "Public money" or "public funds" remains public money or public funds while in the possession of an independent contractor of a public entity for the purpose of providing a program or service for, or on behalf of, the public entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(15): "Public officer" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(15)(a): an elected official of a public entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(15)(b): an individual appointed to, or serving an unexpired term of, an elected official of a public entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(15)(c): a judge of a court of record or not of record, including justice court judges; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(15)(d): a member of the Board of Pardons and Parole.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(16): (16)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(16)(a): "Public servant" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(16)(a)(i): a public officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(16)(a)(ii): an appointed official, employee, consultant, or independent contractor of a public entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(16)(a)(iii): a person hired or paid by a public entity to perform a government function.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(16)(b): (16)(a) Public servant includes a person described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(17): "Serious bodily injury" means bodily injury that creates or causes serious permanent disfigurement, protracted loss or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ, or creates a substantial risk of death.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(18): "Substantial bodily injury" means bodily injury, not amounting to serious bodily injury, that creates or causes protracted physical pain, temporary disfigurement, or temporary loss or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.5(19): "Writing" or "written" includes any handwriting, typewriting, printing, electronic storage or transmission, or any other method of recording information or fixing information in a form capable of being preserved.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.6 Application of definitions to title.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.6(1): 76-1-101.5 For formatting purposes, sections in this title that contain a criminal offense include an express provision that states that the title definitions in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-101.6(2): (1); Title 76, Utah Criminal Code Although a provision described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-102 Effective date.
----------------------------------------------
This code shall become effective on July 1, 1973.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-103 Application of code -- Offense prior to effective date.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-103(1): The provisions of this code shall govern the construction of, the punishment for, and defenses against any offense defined in this code or, except where otherwise specifically provided or the context otherwise requires, any offense defined outside this code; provided such offense was committed after the effective date of this code.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-103(2): Any offense committed prior to the effective date of this code shall be governed by the law, statutory and non-statutory, existing at the time of commission thereof, except that a defense or limitation on punishment available under this code shall be available to any defendant tried or retried after the effective date. An offense under the laws of this state shall be deemed to have been committed prior to the effective date of this act if any of the elements of the offense occurred prior thereto.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-104 Purposes and principles of construction.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
The provisions of this code shall be construed in accordance with these general purposes.Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-104(1): Forbid and prevent the commission of offenses.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-104(2): Define adequately the conduct and mental state which constitute each offense and safeguard conduct that is without fault from condemnation as criminal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-104(3): Prescribe penalties which are proportionate to the seriousness of offenses and which permit recognition or differences in rehabilitation possibilities among individual offenders.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-104(4): Prevent arbitrary or oppressive treatment of persons accused or convicted of offenses.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-105 Common law crimes abolished.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Common law crimes are abolished and no conduct is a crime unless made so by this code, other applicable statute or ordinance.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-106 Strict construction rule not applicable.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
The rule that a penal statute is to be strictly construed shall not apply to this code, any of its provisions, or any offense defined by the laws of this state. All provisions of this code and offenses defined by the laws of this state shall be construed according to the fair import of their terms to promote justice and to effect the objects of the law and general purposes of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-107 Procedure -- Applicable provisions -- Military codes, enforcement of court orders, and liability for civil damages not affected.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-107(1): Except as otherwise provided, the procedure governing the accusation, prosecution, conviction, and punishment of offenders and offenses is not regulated by this act but by the code of criminal procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-107(2): This code does not affect any power conferred by law upon any court-martial or other military authority or officer to impose and inflict punishment upon offenders violating military codes or laws; nor does it affect any power of a court to punish for contempt or to employ any sanction authorized by law for the enforcement of an order or a civil judgment or decree.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-107(3): This act does not bar, suspend, or otherwise affect any right or liability to damages, penalty, forfeiture, impeachment, or other remedy authorized by law to be recovered or enforced in a civil action, administrative proceeding, or otherwise, regardless of whether the conduct involved in the proceeding constitutes an offense defined in this code.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-108 Severability clause.
---------------------------------------------------
If any provision of this act, or the application of any provision to any person or circumstance, is held invalid, the remainder of this act shall not be affected thereby.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201 Jurisdiction of offenses.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(1): A person is subject to prosecution in this state for an offense which he commits, while either within or outside the state, by his own conduct or that of another for which he is legally accountable, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(1)(a): the offense is committed either wholly or partly within the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(1)(b): the conduct outside the state constitutes an attempt to commit an offense within the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(1)(c): the conduct outside the state constitutes a conspiracy to commit an offense within the state and an act in furtherance of the conspiracy occurs in the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(1)(d): the conduct within the state constitutes an attempt, solicitation, or conspiracy to commit in another jurisdiction an offense under the laws of both this state and the other jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(2): An offense is committed partly within this state if either the conduct which is any element of the offense, or the result which is an element, occurs within this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(3): In homicide offenses, the "result" is either the physical contact which causes death or the death itself.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(3)(a): If the body of a homicide victim is found within the state, the death shall be presumed to have occurred within the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(3)(b): If jurisdiction is based on this presumption, this state retains jurisdiction unless the defendant proves by clear and convincing evidence that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(3)(b)(i): the result of the homicide did not occur in this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(3)(b)(ii): the defendant did not engage in any conduct in this state which is any element of the offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(4): 77-41-105(3); 77-43-105(3)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(4)(a): An offense which is based on an omission to perform a duty imposed by the law of this state is committed within the state regardless of the location of the offender at the time of the omission.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(4)(b): 77-41-105(3); 77-43-105(3) For the purpose of establishing venue for a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(4)(b)(i): at the most recent registered primary residence of the offender, if the actual location of the offender at the time of the violation is not known; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(4)(b)(ii): at the location of the offender at the time the offender is apprehended.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(5): (1); (4); (5)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(5)(a): If no jurisdictional issue is raised, the pleadings are sufficient to establish jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(5)(b): The defendant may challenge jurisdiction by filing a motion before trial stating which facts exist that deprive the state of jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(5)(c): (1); (4) The burden is upon the state to initially establish jurisdiction over the offense by a preponderance of the evidence by showing under the provisions of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(5)(d): (5)(c) If after the prosecution has met its burden of proof under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(5)(d)(i): any facts claimed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(5)(d)(ii): why those facts deprive the state of jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(6): 9-9-101 Facts that deprive the state of jurisdiction or prohibit the state from exercising jurisdiction include the fact that the:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(6)(a): defendant is serving in a position that is entitled to diplomatic immunity from prosecution and that the defendant's country has not waived that diplomatic immunity;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(6)(b): defendant is a member of the armed forces of another country and that the crime that he is alleged to have committed is one that due to an international agreement, such as a status of forces agreement between his country and the United States, cedes the exercise of jurisdiction over him for that offense to his country;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(6)(c): 9-9-101 defendant is an enrolled member of an Indian tribe, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(6)(d): offense occurred on land that is exclusively within federal jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(7): Chapter 6, Part 11, Identity Fraud Act; (1)(a); Chapter 6, Part 11, Identity Fraud Act
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(7)(a): Chapter 6, Part 11, Identity Fraud Act The Legislature finds that identity fraud under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(7)(b): (1)(a); Chapter 6, Part 11, Identity Fraud Act For purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-201(8): The judge shall determine jurisdiction.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202 Venue of actions.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1): Chapter 6, Part 11, Identity Fraud Act; 77-41-105(3); 77-43-105(3) Criminal actions shall be tried in the county, district, or precinct where the offense is alleged to have been committed.  In determining the proper place of trial, the following provisions shall apply:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(a): If the commission of an offense commenced outside the state is consummated within this state, the offender shall be tried in the county where the offense is consummated.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(b): When conduct constituting elements of an offense or results that constitute elements, whether the conduct or result constituting elements is in itself unlawful, shall occur in two or more counties, trial of the offense may be held in any of the counties concerned.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(c): If a person committing an offense upon the person of another is located in one county and his victim is located in another county at the time of the commission of the offense, trial may be held in either county.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(d): If a cause of death is inflicted in one county and death ensues in another county, the offender may be tried in either county.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(e): A person who commits an inchoate offense may be tried in any county in which any act that is an element of the offense, including the agreement in conspiracy, is committed.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(f): Where a person in one county solicits, aids, abets, agrees, or attempts to aid another in the planning or commission of an offense in another county, he may be tried for the offense in either county.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(g): When an offense is committed within this state and it cannot be readily determined in which county or district the offense occurred, the following provisions shall be applicable:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(g)(i): When an offense is committed upon any railroad car, vehicle, watercraft, or aircraft passing within this state, the offender may be tried in any county through which such railroad car, vehicle, watercraft, or aircraft has passed.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(g)(ii): When an offense is committed on any body of water bordering on or within this state, the offender may be tried in any county adjacent to such body of water.  The words "body of water" shall include but not be limited to any stream, river, lake, or reservoir, whether natural or man-made.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(g)(iii): A person who commits theft may be tried in any county in which he exerts control over the property affected.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(g)(iv): If an offense is committed on or near the boundary of two or more counties, trial of the offense may be held in any of such counties.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(g)(v): For any other offense, trial may be held in the county in which the defendant resides, or, if he has no fixed residence, in the county in which he is apprehended or to which he is extradited.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(h): Chapter 6, Part 11, Identity Fraud Act A person who commits an offense based on
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(h)(i): where the victim's personal identifying information was obtained;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(h)(ii): where the defendant used or attempted to use the personally identifying information;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(h)(iii): where the victim of the identity fraud resides or is found; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(h)(iv): if multiple offenses of identity fraud occur in multiple jurisdictions, in any county where the victim's identity was used or obtained, or where the victim resides or is found.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(i): 77-41-105(3); 77-43-105(3) For the purpose of establishing venue for a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(i)(i): at the most recent registered primary residence of the offender, if the actual location of the offender at the time of the violation is not known; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(1)(i)(ii): at the location of the offender at the time the offender is apprehended.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-202(2): All objections of improper place of trial are waived by a defendant unless made before trial.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301 Offenses for which prosecution may be commenced at any time.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(1): 76-5-202(2)(a)(iv); (v); 76-5-202(2); 76-5-203(1); 76-2-202 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(1)(a): 76-5-202(2)(a)(iv); (v); 76-5-202(2) "Aggravating offense" means any offense incident to which a homicide was committed as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(1)(b): 76-5-203(1); 76-2-202 "Predicate offense" means an offense described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(2): 76-5-310; 76-10-1306; 76-5-308.5 Notwithstanding any other provisions of this code, prosecution for the following offenses may be commenced at any time:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(2)(a): capital felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(2)(b): aggravated murder;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(2)(c): murder;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(2)(d): manslaughter;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(2)(e): child abuse homicide;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(2)(f): aggravated kidnapping;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(2)(g): child kidnapping;

Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(2)(i): rape of a child;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(2)(j): object rape;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(2)(k): object rape of a child;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(2)(l): forcible sodomy;

Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(2)(o): aggravated sexual abuse of a child;

Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301(2)(q): any predicate offense to a murder or aggravating offense to an aggravated murder;

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The statute of limitations for a felony violation of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301.5 Time limitations for prosecution of misusing public money, falsification or alteration of government records, and bribery.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301.5(1): A prosecution for misusing public money, falsification or alteration of government records, or for a bribery offense shall be commenced within two years after facts constituting the offense have been reported to a prosecutor having responsibility and jurisdiction to prosecute the offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-301.5(2): 76-1-302; 76-1-303(3) This section does not shorten the limitation of actions under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-302 Time limitations for prosecution of offenses -- Provisions if DNA evidence would identify the defendant -- Commencement of prosecution.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-302(1): Except as otherwise provided, a prosecution for:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-302(1)(a): a felony or negligent homicide shall be commenced within four years after it is committed, except that prosecution for:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-302(1)(a)(i): forcible sexual abuse shall be commenced within eight years after the offense is committed, if within four years after its commission the offense is reported to a law enforcement agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-302(1)(a)(ii): incest shall be commenced within eight years after the offense is committed, if within four years after its commission the offense is reported to a law enforcement agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-302(1)(b): a misdemeanor other than negligent homicide shall be commenced within two years after it is committed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-302(1)(c): any infraction shall be commenced within one year after it is committed.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-302(2): (1); 76-3-203.5(1)(c)(i)(A); (CC); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-302(2)(a): (1); 76-3-203.5(1)(c)(i)(A); (CC) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-302(2)(b): (2)(a) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-302(3): (2) If the statute of limitations would have run but for the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-302(4): A prosecution is commenced upon:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-302(4)(a): the finding and filing of an indictment by a grand jury;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-302(4)(b): the filing of a complaint or information; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-302(4)(c): the issuance of a citation.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-303 Time limitations for fraud or breach of fiduciary obligation -- Misconduct of public officer or employee.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-303(1): 76-1-302 If the period prescribed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-303(2): (1); 76-1-302 Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-303(3): 76-1-301.5; 76-1-302; 76-1-301.5; (3) If the period prescribed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-303(3)(a): any offense based upon misconduct in office by a public officer or public employee:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-303(3)(a)(i): at any time during which the defendant holds a public office or during the period of his public employment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-303(3)(a)(ii): within two years after termination of defendant's public office or public employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-303(3)(b): 76-1-301.5; (3) Except as provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-304 Defendant out of state -- Plea held invalid -- New prosecutions.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-304(1): The period of limitation does not run against any defendant during any period of time in which the defendant is out of the state following the commission of an offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-304(2): If the defendant has entered into a plea agreement with the prosecution and later successfully moves to invalidate his conviction, the period of limitation is suspended from the time of the entry of the plea pursuant to the plea agreement until the time at which the conviction is determined to be invalid, and that determination becomes final.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-304(3): For purposes of this section, "final" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-304(3)(a): all appeals have been exhausted;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-304(3)(b): no judicial review is pending; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-304(3)(c): no application for judicial review is pending.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-304(4): (2) When the period of limitation is suspended pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-304(5): (4) Notwithstanding any other limitation, a prosecution may be commenced for charges described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-305 Lesser included offense for which period of limitations has run.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Whenever a defendant is charged with an offense for which the period of limitations has not run and the defendant should be found guilty of a lesser offense for which the period of limitations has run, the finding of the lesser and included offense against which the statute of limitations has run shall not be a bar to punishment for the lesser offense.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-306 Judge to determine.
--------------------------------------------------
When an issue concerning the statute of limitations is raised, the judge shall determine by a preponderance of the evidence whether the prosecution is barred by the limitations in this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-401 "Single criminal episode" defined -- Joinder of offenses and defendants.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In this part unless the context requires a different definition, "single criminal episode" means all conduct which is closely related in time and is incident to an attempt or an accomplishment of a single criminal objective.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-402 Separate offenses arising out of single criminal episode -- Included offenses.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-402(1): A defendant may be prosecuted in a single criminal action for all separate offenses arising out of a single criminal episode; however, when the same act of a defendant under a single criminal episode shall establish offenses which may be punished in different ways under different provisions of this code, the act shall be punishable under only one such provision; an acquittal or conviction and sentence under any such provision bars a prosecution under any other such provision.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-402(2): Whenever conduct may establish separate offenses under a single criminal episode, unless the court otherwise orders to promote justice, a defendant shall not be subject to separate trials for multiple offenses when:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-402(2)(a): The offenses are within the jurisdiction of a single court; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-402(2)(b): The offenses are known to the prosecuting attorney at the time the defendant is arraigned on the first information or indictment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-402(3): A defendant may be convicted of an offense included in the offense charged but may not be convicted of both the offense charged and the included offense. An offense is so included when:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-402(3)(a): It is established by proof of the same or less than all the facts required to establish the commission of the offense charged; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-402(3)(b): It constitutes an attempt, solicitation, conspiracy, or form of preparation to commit the offense charged or an offense otherwise included therein; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-402(3)(c): It is specifically designated by a statute as a lesser included offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-402(4): The court shall not be obligated to charge the jury with respect to an included offense unless there is a rational basis for a verdict acquitting the defendant of the offense charged and convicting him of the included offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-402(5): If the district court on motion after verdict or judgment, or an appellate court on appeal or certiorari, shall determine that there is insufficient evidence to support a conviction for the offense charged but that there is sufficient evidence to support a conviction for an included offense and the trier of fact necessarily found every fact required for conviction of that included offense, the verdict or judgment of conviction may be set aside or reversed and a judgment of conviction entered for the included offense, without necessity of a new trial, if such relief is sought by the defendant.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403 Former prosecution barring subsequent prosecution for offense out of same episode.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(1): 76-1-402(2) If a defendant has been prosecuted for one or more offenses arising out of a single criminal episode, a subsequent prosecution for the same or a different offense arising out of the same criminal episode is barred if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(1)(a): 76-1-402(2) the subsequent prosecution is for an offense that was or should have been tried under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(1)(b): the former prosecution:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(1)(b)(i): resulted in acquittal;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(1)(b)(ii): resulted in conviction;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(1)(b)(iii): was improperly terminated; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(1)(b)(iv): was terminated by a final order or judgment for the defendant that has not been reversed, set aside, or vacated and that necessarily required a determination inconsistent with a fact that must be established to secure conviction in the subsequent prosecution.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(2): There is an acquittal if the prosecution resulted in a finding of not guilty by the trier of facts or in a determination that there was insufficient evidence to warrant conviction.  A finding of guilty of a lesser included offense is an acquittal of the greater offense even though the conviction for the lesser included offense is subsequently reversed, set aside, or vacated.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(3): There is a conviction if the prosecution resulted in a judgment of guilt that has not been reversed, set aside, or vacated; a verdict of guilty that has not been reversed, set aside, or vacated and that is capable of supporting a judgment; or a plea of guilty accepted by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(4): There is an improper termination of prosecution if the termination takes place before the verdict, is for reasons not amounting to an acquittal, and takes place after a jury has been impaneled and sworn to try the defendant, or, if the jury trial is waived, after the first witness is sworn.  However, termination of prosecution is not improper if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(4)(a): the defendant consents to the termination;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(4)(b): the defendant waives his right to object to the termination; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(4)(c): the court finds and states for the record that the termination is necessary because:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(4)(c)(i): it is physically impossible to proceed with the trial in conformity with the law;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(4)(c)(ii): there is a legal defect in the proceeding not attributable to the state that would make any judgment entered upon a verdict reversible as a matter of law;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(4)(c)(iii): prejudicial conduct in or out of the courtroom not attributable to the state makes it impossible to proceed with the trial without injustice to the defendant or the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(4)(c)(iv): the jury is unable to agree upon a verdict; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-403(4)(c)(v): false statements of a juror on voir dire prevent a fair trial.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-404 Concurrent jurisdiction -- Prosecution in other jurisdiction barring prosecution in state.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a defendant's conduct establishes the commission of one or more offenses within the concurrent jurisdiction of this state and of another jurisdiction, federal or state, the prosecution in the other jurisdiction is a bar to a subsequent prosecution in this state if:Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-404(1): 76-1-403 the former prosecution resulted in an acquittal, conviction, or termination of prosecution, as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-404(2): the subsequent prosecution is for the same offense or offenses.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-405 Subsequent prosecution not barred -- Circumstances.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A subsequent prosecution for an offense shall not be barred under the following circumstances:Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-405(1): The former prosecution was procured by the defendant without the knowledge of the prosecuting attorney bringing the subsequent prosecution and with intent to avoid the sentence that might otherwise be imposed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-405(2): The former prosecution resulted in a judgment of guilt held invalid in a subsequent proceeding on writ of habeas corpus, coram nobis, or similar collateral attack.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-501 Presumption of innocence -- "Element of the offense" defined.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-501(1): A defendant in a criminal proceeding is presumed to be innocent until each element of the offense charged against him is proved beyond a reasonable doubt.  In the absence of this proof, the defendant shall be acquitted.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-501(2): As used in this part, "element of the offense" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-501(2)(a): the conduct, attendant circumstances, or results of conduct proscribed, prohibited, or forbidden in the definition of the offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-501(2)(b): the culpable mental state required.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-501(3): The existence of jurisdiction and venue are not elements of the offense but shall be established by a preponderance of the evidence.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-502 Negating defense by allegation or proof -- When not required.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
SectionUtah Code Annotated § 76-1-502(1): By allegation in an information, indictment, or other charge; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-502(2): By proof, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-502(2)(a): The defense is in issue in the case as a result of evidence presented at trial, either by the prosecution or the defense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-502(2)(b): The defense is an affirmative defense, and the defendant has presented evidence of such affirmative defense.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-503 Presumption of fact.
---------------------------------------------------
An evidentiary presumption established by this code or other penal statute has the following consequences:Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-503(1): When evidence of facts which support the presumption exist, the issue of the existence of the presumed fact must be submitted to the jury unless the court is satisfied that the evidence as a whole clearly negates the presumed fact;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-503(2): In submitting the issue of the existence of a presumed fact to the jury, the court shall charge that while the presumed fact must on all evidence be proved beyond a reasonable doubt, the law regards the facts giving rise to the presumption as evidence of the presumed fact.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-1-504 Affirmative defense presented by defendant.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Evidence of an affirmative defense as defined by this code or other statutes shall be presented by the defendant.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 76 - Chapter 2 - Principles of Criminal Responsibility
**********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-101 Requirements of criminal conduct and criminal responsibility.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-101(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-101(1)(a): A person is not guilty of an offense unless the person's conduct is prohibited by law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-101(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-101(1)(b)(i): the person acts intentionally, knowingly, recklessly, with criminal negligence, or with a mental state otherwise specified in the statute defining the offense, as the definition of the offense requires; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-101(1)(b)(ii): the person's acts constitute an offense involving strict liability.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-101(2): Title 41, Chapter 6a, Traffic Code These standards of criminal responsibility do not apply to the violations set forth in


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-102 Culpable mental state required -- Strict liability.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every offense not involving strict liability shall require a culpable mental state, and when the definition of the offense does not specify a culpable mental state and the offense does not involve strict liability, intent, knowledge, or recklessness shall suffice to establish criminal responsibility. An offense shall involve strict liability if the statute defining the offense clearly indicates a legislative purpose to impose criminal responsibility for commission of the conduct prohibited by the statute without requiring proof of any culpable mental state.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-103 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
A person engages in conduct:Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-103(1): Intentionally, or with intent or willfully with respect to the nature of his conduct or to a result of his conduct, when it is his conscious objective or desire to engage in the conduct or cause the result.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-103(2): Knowingly, or with knowledge, with respect to his conduct or to circumstances surrounding his conduct when he is aware of the nature of his conduct or the existing circumstances.  A person acts knowingly, or with knowledge, with respect to a result of his conduct when he is aware that his conduct is reasonably certain to cause the result.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-103(3): Recklessly with respect to circumstances surrounding his conduct or the result of his conduct when he is aware of but consciously disregards a substantial and unjustifiable risk that the circumstances exist or the result will occur.  The risk must be of such a nature and degree that its disregard constitutes a gross deviation from the standard of care that an ordinary person would exercise under all the circumstances as viewed from the actor's standpoint.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-103(4): With criminal negligence or is criminally negligent with respect to circumstances surrounding his conduct or the result of his conduct when he ought to be aware of a substantial and unjustifiable risk that the circumstances exist or the result will occur.  The risk must be of a nature and degree that the failure to perceive it constitutes a gross deviation from the standard of care that an ordinary person would exercise in all the circumstances as viewed from the actor's standpoint.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-104 Culpable mental state -- Higher mental states included.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-104(1): If acting with criminal negligence is sufficient to establish the culpable mental state for an element of an offense, that element is also established if a person acts intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-104(2): If acting recklessly is sufficient to establish the culpable mental state for an element of an offense, that element is also established if a person acts intentionally or knowingly.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-104(3): If acting knowingly is sufficient to establish the culpable mental state for an element of an offense, that element is also established if a person acts intentionally.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-105 Transferred intent.
--------------------------------------------------
Where intentionally causing a result is an element of an offense, that element is established even if a different person than the actor intended was killed, injured, or harmed, or different property than the actor intended was damaged or otherwise affected.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-106 Commission of offense with aid of unmanned aircraft system.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-106(1): 72-10-102; 72-10-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-106(1)(a): 72-10-102 "Unmanned aircraft" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-106(1)(b): 72-10-102 "Unmanned aircraft system" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-106(2): An actor may be found guilty of an offense if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-106(2)(a): the actor commits the offense with the aid of an unmanned aircraft; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-106(2)(b): the unmanned aircraft system for the unmanned aircraft is under the actor's control at the time of the offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-201 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-201(1): "Agent" means any director, officer, employee, or other person authorized to act in behalf of a corporation or association.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-201(2): "High managerial agent" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-201(2)(a): A partner in a partnership;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-201(2)(b): An officer of a corporation or association;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-201(2)(c): An agent of a corporation or association who has duties of such responsibility that his conduct reasonably may be assumed to represent the policy of the corporation or association.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-201(3): Title 16, Chapter 7, Corporations Sole "Corporation" means all organizations required by the laws of this state or any other state to obtain a certificate of authority, a certificate of incorporation, or other form of registration to transact business as a corporation within this state or any other state and shall include domestic, foreign, profit and nonprofit corporations, but shall not include a corporation sole, as such term is used in


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-202 Criminal responsibility for direct commission of offense or for conduct of another.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person, acting with the mental state required for the commission of an offense who directly commits the offense, who solicits, requests, commands, encourages, or intentionally aids another person to engage in conduct which constitutes an offense shall be criminally liable as a party for such conduct.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-203 Defenses unavailable in prosecution based on conduct of another.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In any prosecution in which an actor's criminal responsibility is based on the conduct of another, it is no defense:Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-203(1): That the actor belongs to a class of persons who by definition of the offense is legally incapable of committing the offense in an individual capacity, or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-203(2): That the person for whose conduct the actor is criminally responsible has been acquitted, has not been prosecuted or convicted, has been convicted of a different offense or of a different type or class of offense or is immune from prosecution.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-204 Criminal responsibility of corporation or association.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A corporation or association is guilty of an offense when:Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-204(1): The conduct constituting the offense consists of an omission to discharge a specific duty of affirmative performance imposed on corporations or associations by law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-204(2): The conduct constituting the offense is authorized, solicited, requested, commanded, or undertaken, performed, or recklessly tolerated by the board of directors or by a high managerial agent acting within the scope of his employment and in behalf of the corporation or association.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-205 Criminal responsibility of person for conduct in name of corporation or association.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person is criminally liable for conduct constituting an offense which he performs or causes to be performed in the name of or on behalf of a corporation or association to the same extent as if such conduct were performed in his own name or behalf.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-301 Person under 14 years old not criminally responsible.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person is not criminally responsible for conduct performed before he reaches the age of 14 years. This section shall in no way limit the jurisdiction of or proceedings before the juvenile courts of this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-302 Compulsion.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-302(1): A person is not guilty of an offense when he engaged in the proscribed conduct because he was coerced to do so by the use or threatened imminent use of unlawful physical force upon him or a third person, which force or threatened force a person of reasonable firmness in his situation would not have resisted.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-302(2): The defense of compulsion provided by this section shall be unavailable to a person who intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly places himself in a situation in which it is probable that he will be subjected to duress.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-302(3): (1) A married woman is not entitled, by reason of the presence of her husband, to any presumption of compulsion or to any defense of compulsion except as in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-303 Entrapment.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-303(1): It is a defense that the actor was entrapped into committing the offense. Entrapment occurs when a peace officer or a person directed by or acting in cooperation with the officer induces the commission of an offense in order to obtain evidence of the commission for prosecution by methods creating a substantial risk that the offense would be committed by one not otherwise ready to commit it. Conduct merely affording a person an opportunity to commit an offense does not constitute entrapment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-303(2): The defense of entrapment shall be unavailable when causing or threatening bodily injury is an element of the offense charged and the prosecution is based on conduct causing or threatening the injury to a person other than the person perpetrating the entrapment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-303(3): The defense provided by this section is available even though the actor denies commission of the conduct charged to constitute the offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-303(4): Upon written motion of the defendant, the court shall hear evidence on the issue and shall determine as a matter of fact and law whether the defendant was entrapped to commit the offense. Defendant's motion shall be made at least 10 days before trial except the court for good cause shown may permit a later filing.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-303(5): Should the court determine that the defendant was entrapped, it shall dismiss the case with prejudice, but if the court determines the defendant was not entrapped, such issue may be presented by the defendant to the jury at trial. Any order by the court dismissing a case based on entrapment shall be appealable by the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-303(6): In any hearing before a judge or jury where the defense of entrapment is an issue, past offenses of the defendant shall not be admitted except that in a trial where the defendant testifies he may be asked of his past convictions for felonies and any testimony given by the defendant at a hearing on entrapment may be used to impeach his testimony at trial.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304 Ignorance or mistake of fact or law.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304(1): Unless otherwise provided, ignorance or mistake of fact which disproves the culpable mental state is a defense to any prosecution for that crime.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304(2): Ignorance or mistake concerning the existence or meaning of a penal law is no defense to a crime unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304(2)(a): Due to his ignorance or mistake, the actor reasonably believed his conduct did not constitute an offense, and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304(2)(b): His ignorance or mistake resulted from the actor's reasonable reliance upon:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304(2)(b)(i): An official statement of the law contained in a written order or grant of permission by an administrative agency charged by law with responsibility for interpreting the law in question; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304(2)(b)(ii): A written interpretation of the law contained in an opinion of a court of record or made by a public servant charged by law with responsibility for interpreting the law in question.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304(3): Although an actor's ignorance or mistake of fact or law may constitute a defense to the offense charged, he may nevertheless be convicted of a lesser included offense of which he would be guilty if the fact or law were as he believed.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304.5 Mistake as to victim's age not a defense.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304.5(1): 76-5-301.1; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-402.3; 76-5-403.1; 76-5-404.1; 76-5-404.3 It is not a defense to the crime of child kidnapping, a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304.5(2): 76-5-401; 76-5-401.1 It is not a defense to the crime of unlawful sexual activity with a minor, a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304.5(3): 76-5-310; 76-5-310.1; 76-5-308.5 It is not a defense to the crime of aggravated human trafficking, a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304.5(4): 76-5-401.2(2)(a)(ii) It is not a defense to the crime of unlawful sexual activity with a minor, a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304.5(5): 76-10-1303; 76-10-1306; 76-10-1313 It is not a defense to any of the following crimes that the actor mistakenly believed the victim to be 18 years old or older at the time of the alleged offense or was unaware of the victim's true age:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304.5(5)(a): 76-10-1303 patronizing a prostitute, a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304.5(5)(b): 76-10-1306 aggravated exploitation of a prostitute, a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-304.5(5)(c): 76-10-1313 sexual solicitation, a violation of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-305 Mental condition -- Use as a defense -- Influence of alcohol or other substance voluntarily consumed.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-305(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-305(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-305(1)(a)(i): "Mental condition" means a mental illness or a mental disability that substantially impairs an individual's mental, emotional, or behavioral functioning.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-305(1)(a)(ii): "Mental condition" does not include a mental abnormality that is manifested solely by repeated criminal conduct, anti-social behavior, or a substance use disorder.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-305(1)(b): "Mental disability" means an intellectual disability or a neurodevelopmental disorder as those terms are defined in the current edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders published by the American Psychiatric Association.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-305(1)(c): "Mental illness" means the following mental disorders as described in the most recent edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders published by the American Psychiatric Association:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-305(1)(c)(i): schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-305(1)(c)(ii): other serious mental health conditions with psychotic features.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-305(2): 76-3-207; 76-5-205.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-305(2)(a): It is a defense to a prosecution under any statute or ordinance that the defendant, as a result of a mental condition, lacked the mental state required as an element of the offense charged.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-305(2)(b): 76-3-207; 76-5-205.5 A mental condition is not otherwise a defense, but may be evidence in mitigation of the penalty in a capital felony under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-305(3): The defense defined in this section includes the defenses known as "insanity" and "diminished mental capacity."
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-305(4): A person who asserts a defense of insanity or diminished mental capacity, and who is under the influence of voluntarily consumed, injected, or ingested alcohol, controlled substances, or volatile substances at the time of the alleged offense is not excused from criminal responsibility on the basis of a mental condition if the alcohol or substance caused, triggered, or substantially contributed to the mental condition.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-306 Voluntary intoxication.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-306(1): Voluntary intoxication is not a defense to a criminal charge unless such intoxication negates the existence of the mental state which is an element of the offense.  If recklessness or criminal negligence establishes an element of an offense and the actor is unaware of the risk because of voluntary intoxication, his unawareness is immaterial in a prosecution for that offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-306(2): Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses Voluntary intoxication is not a defense to sexual offenses, as defined in


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-307 Voluntary termination of efforts prior to offense.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is an affirmative defense to a prosecution in which an actor's criminal responsibility arises from his own conduct or from being a party to an offense under SectionUtah Code Annotated § 76-2-307(1): Gave timely warning to the proper law enforcement authorities or the intended victim; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-307(2): Wholly deprives his prior efforts of effectiveness in the commission.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-308 Affirmative defenses.
----------------------------------------------------
Defenses enumerated in this part constitute affirmative defenses.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309 Justified use of force.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309(1): 76-2-402; 76-2-404; 76-2-405; 76-2-406; 76-2-407; 76-2-408 An individual who uses or threatens to use force as permitted in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309(2): (3)(a); (b); 53-13-103; 77-36-1 The pretrial justification hearing process described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309(2)(a): 53-13-103
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309(2)(a)(i): 53-13-103 the individual against whom force was used or threatened is a law enforcement officer, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309(2)(a)(ii): the officer was acting lawfully in the performance of the officer's official duties; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309(2)(a)(iii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309(2)(a)(iii)(A): the officer was identified as an officer by the officer in accordance with applicable law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309(2)(a)(iii)(B): the individual using or threatening to use force knew or reasonably should have known that the officer was a law enforcement officer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309(2)(b): 77-36-1 the charge filed against the defendant for which the defendant seeks a pretrial justification hearing is an infraction, a class B or C misdemeanor, or a domestic violence offense as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309(3): (3)(b); (3)(c)(i); 77-18a-1; (3)(b); (3)(c)(iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309(3)(a): Upon motion of the defendant filed in accordance with Rule 12 of the Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure, the court shall hear evidence on the issue of justification under this section and shall determine as a matter of fact and law whether the defendant was justified in the use or threatened use of force.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309(3)(b): At the pretrial justification hearing, after the defendant makes a prima facie claim of justification, the state has the burden to prove by clear and convincing evidence that the defendant's use or threatened use of force was not justified.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309(3)(c): (3)(b); (3)(c)(i); 77-18a-1; (3)(b); (3)(c)(iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309(3)(c)(i): (3)(b) If the court determines that the state has not met the state's burden described in Subsection
