Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309(3)(c)(iii): (3)(b) If a court determines after the pretrial justification hearing that the state has met the state's burden described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-309(3)(c)(iv): (3)(c)(iii) At trial, a court's determination that the state met the state's burden under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-401 Justification as defense -- When allowed.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-401(1): 76-2-402; 76-2-406; (2) Conduct which is justified is a defense to prosecution for any offense based on the conduct.  The defense of justification may be claimed:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-401(1)(a): 76-2-402; 76-2-406 when the actor's conduct is in defense of persons or property under the circumstances described in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-401(1)(b): when the actor's conduct is reasonable and in fulfillment of his duties as a governmental officer or employee;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-401(1)(c): (2) when the actor's conduct is reasonable discipline of minors by parents, guardians, teachers, or other persons in loco parentis, as limited by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-401(1)(d): when the actor's conduct is reasonable discipline of persons in custody under the laws of the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-401(1)(e): when the actor's conduct is justified for any other reason under the laws of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-401(2): (1)(c); 76-1-101.5; 76-5-109 The defense of justification under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402 Force in defense of person -- Forcible felony defined.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(1): Chapter 5, Offenses Against the Individual; Chapter 6, Offenses Against Property; 76-6-204 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(1)(a): Chapter 5, Offenses Against the Individual; Chapter 6, Offenses Against Property "Forcible felony" means aggravated assault, mayhem, aggravated murder, murder, manslaughter, kidnapping and aggravated kidnapping, rape, forcible sodomy, rape of a child, object rape, object rape of a child, sexual abuse of a child, aggravated sexual abuse of a child, and aggravated sexual assault as defined in
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(1)(b): "Forcible felony" includes any other felony offense that involves the use of force or violence against an individual that poses a substantial danger of death or serious bodily injury.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(1)(c): 76-6-204 "Forcible felony" does not include burglary of a vehicle, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(2)(a): An individual is justified in threatening or using force against another individual when and to the extent that the individual reasonably believes that force or a threat of force is necessary to defend the individual or another individual against the imminent use of unlawful force.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(2)(b): An individual is justified in using force intended or likely to cause death or serious bodily injury only if the individual reasonably believes that force is necessary to prevent death or serious bodily injury to the individual or another individual as a result of imminent use of unlawful force, or to prevent the commission of a forcible felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(3): (2); (3)(a)(iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(3)(a): (2) An individual is not justified in using force under the circumstances specified in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(3)(a)(i): initially provokes the use of force against another individual with the intent to use force as an excuse to inflict bodily harm upon the other individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(3)(a)(ii): is attempting to commit, committing, or fleeing after the commission or attempted commission of a felony , unless the use of force is a reasonable response to factors unrelated to the commission, attempted commission, or fleeing after the commission of that felony ; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(3)(a)(iii): was the aggressor or was engaged in a combat by agreement, unless the individual withdraws from the encounter and effectively communicates to the other individual the intent to withdraw from the encounter and, notwithstanding, the other individual continues or threatens to continue the use of unlawful force.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(3)(b): (3)(a)(iii) For purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(3)(b)(i): voluntarily entering into or remaining in an ongoing relationship; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(3)(b)(ii): entering or remaining in a place where one has a legal right to be.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(4): (3)(a)(iii); (2); (4)(a) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(4)(a): (2) an individual does not have a duty to retreat from the force or threatened force described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(4)(b): (4)(a) the failure of an individual to retreat under the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(5): (2) In determining imminence or reasonableness under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(5)(a): the nature of the danger;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(5)(b): the immediacy of the danger;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(5)(c): the probability that the unlawful force would result in death or serious bodily injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(5)(d): the other individual's prior violent acts or violent propensities;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(5)(e): any patterns of abuse or violence in the parties' relationship; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-402(5)(f): any other relevant factors.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-403 Force in arrest.
-----------------------------------------------
Any person is justified in using any force, except deadly force, which he reasonably believes to be necessary to effect an arrest or to defend himself or another from bodily harm while making an arrest.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-404 Law enforcement officer use of deadly force.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-404(1): 53-13-102; 76-1-101.5 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-404(1)(a): "Deadly force" means force that creates or is likely to create, or that the individual using the force intends to create, a substantial likelihood of death or serious bodily injury to an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-404(1)(b): 53-13-102 "Officer" means an officer described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-404(1)(c): 76-1-101.5 "Serious bodily injury" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-404(2): 77-18-113(2); (3); (4) The defense of justification applies to the use of deadly force by an officer, or an individual acting by the officer's command in providing aid and assistance, when:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-404(2)(a): 77-18-113(2); (3); (4) the officer is acting in obedience to and in accordance with the judgment of a competent court in executing a penalty of death under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-404(2)(b): effecting an arrest or preventing an escape from custody following an arrest, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-404(2)(b)(i): the officer reasonably believes that deadly force is necessary to prevent the arrest from being defeated by escape; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-404(2)(b)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-404(2)(b)(ii)(A): the officer has probable cause to believe that the suspect has committed a felony offense involving the infliction or threatened infliction of death or serious bodily injury; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-404(2)(b)(ii)(B): the officer has probable cause to believe the suspect poses a threat of death or serious bodily injury to the officer or to an individual other than the suspect if apprehension is delayed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-404(2)(c): the officer reasonably believes that the use of deadly force is necessary to prevent death or serious bodily injury to the officer or an individual other than the suspect.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-404(3): (2)(b); (2)(c) If feasible, a verbal warning should be given by the officer prior to any use of deadly force under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-405 Force in defense of habitation.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-405(1): A person is justified in using force against another when and to the extent that he reasonably believes that the force is necessary to prevent or terminate the other's unlawful entry into or attack upon his habitation; however, he is justified in the use of force which is intended or likely to cause death or serious bodily injury only if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-405(1)(a): the entry is made or attempted in a violent and tumultuous manner, surreptitiously, or by stealth, and he reasonably believes that the entry is attempted or made for the purpose of assaulting or offering personal violence to any person, dwelling, or being in the habitation and he reasonably believes that the force is necessary to prevent the assault or offer of personal violence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-405(1)(b): he reasonably believes that the entry is made or attempted for the purpose of committing a felony in the habitation and that the force is necessary to prevent the commission of the felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-405(2): The person using force or deadly force in defense of habitation is presumed for the purpose of both civil and criminal cases to have acted reasonably and had a reasonable fear of imminent peril of death or serious bodily injury if the entry or attempted entry is unlawful and is made or attempted by use of force, or in a violent and tumultuous manner, or surreptitiously or by stealth, or for the purpose of committing a felony.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-406 Force in defense of property -- Affirmative defense.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-406(1): A person is justified in using force, other than deadly force, against another when and to the extent that the person reasonably believes that force is necessary to prevent or terminate another person's criminal interference with real property or personal property:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-406(1)(a): lawfully in the person's possession;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-406(1)(b): lawfully in the possession of a member of the person's immediate family; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-406(1)(c): belonging to a person whose property the person has a legal duty to protect.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-406(2): (1) In determining reasonableness under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-406(2)(a): the apparent or perceived extent of the damage to the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-406(2)(b): property damage previously caused by the other person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-406(2)(c): threats of personal injury or damage to property that have been made previously by the other person; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-406(2)(d): any patterns of abuse or violence between the person and the other person.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-407 Deadly force in defense of persons on real property.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-407(1): 76-2-402 A person is justified in using force intended or likely to cause death or serious bodily injury against another in his defense of persons on real property other than his habitation if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-407(1)(a): he is in lawful possession of the real property;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-407(1)(b): he reasonably believes that the force is necessary to prevent or terminate the other person's trespass onto the real property;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-407(1)(c): the trespass is made or attempted by use of force or in a violent and tumultuous manner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-407(1)(d): 76-2-402
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-407(1)(d)(i): the person reasonably believes that the trespass is attempted or made for the purpose of committing violence against any person on the real property and he reasonably believes that the force is necessary to prevent personal violence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-407(1)(d)(ii): 76-2-402 the person reasonably believes that the trespass is made or attempted for the purpose of committing a forcible felony as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-407(2): (1) The person using deadly force in defense of persons on real property under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408 Officer use of force -- Investigations.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1): 53-13-102; 76-1-101.5 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(a): "Dangerous weapon" means a firearm or an object that in the manner of its use or intended use is capable of causing death or serious bodily injury to an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(b): "Deadly force" means a force that creates or is likely to create, or that the individual using the force intends to create, a substantial likelihood of death or serious bodily injury to an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(c): "In custody" means in the legal custody of a state prison, county jail, or other correctional facility, including custody that results from:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(c)(i): a detention to secure attendance as a witness in a criminal case;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(c)(ii): an arrest for or charging with a crime and committing for trial;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(c)(iii): committing for contempt, upon civil process, or by other authority of law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(c)(iv): sentencing to imprisonment on conviction of a crime.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(d): "Investigating agency" means a law enforcement agency, the county or district attorney's office, or an interagency task force composed of officers from multiple law enforcement agencies.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(e): 53-13-102 "Officer" means an officer described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(f): "Officer-involved critical incident" means any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(f)(i): an officer's use of deadly force;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(f)(ii): an officer's use of a dangerous weapon against an individual who causes injury to any individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(f)(iii): death or serious bodily injury to any individual, other than the officer, resulting from an officer's:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(f)(iii)(A): use of a motor vehicle while the officer is on duty; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(f)(iii)(B): use of a government vehicle while the officer is off duty;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(f)(iv): the death of an individual who is in custody, but excluding a death that is the result of disease, natural causes, or conditions that have been medically diagnosed prior to the individual's death; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(f)(v): the death of or serious bodily injury to an individual not in custody, other than an officer, resulting from an officer's attempt to prevent an individual's escape from custody, to make an arrest, or otherwise to gain physical control of an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(1)(g): 76-1-101.5 "Serious bodily injury" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(2): When an officer-involved critical incident occurs:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(2)(a): upon receiving notice of the officer-involved critical incident, the law enforcement agency having jurisdiction where the incident occurred shall, as soon as practical, notify the county or district attorney having jurisdiction where the incident occurred; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(2)(b): the chief executive of the law enforcement agency and the county or district attorney having jurisdiction where the incident occurred shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(2)(b)(i): jointly designate an investigating agency for the officer-involved critical incident; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(2)(b)(ii): designate which agency is the lead investigative agency if the officer-involved critical incident involves multiple investigations.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(3): (2) The investigating agency under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(4): This section does not preclude the law enforcement agency employing an officer alleged to have caused or contributed to the officer-involved critical incident from conducting an internal administrative investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(5): Each law enforcement agency that is part of or administered by the state or any of the state's political subdivisions shall adopt and post on the agency's publicly accessible website:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(5)(a): the policies and procedures the agency has adopted to select the investigating agency if an officer-involved critical incident occurs in the agency's jurisdiction and one of the agency's officers is alleged to have caused or contributed to the officer-involved incident; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(5)(b): the protocols the agency has adopted to ensure that any investigation of officer-involved incidents occurring in the agency's jurisdiction are conducted professionally, thoroughly, and impartially.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(6): Once a criminal investigation is turned over from law enforcement, the county or district attorney's findings or analyses into an officer's use of force shall be completed within 180 days of the turnover. If the findings or analyses is not published within 180 days of the turnover, the county or district attorney shall post a public statement on the county or district attorney's website stating a reasonable estimate when the findings or analyses will be complete and the reason for the delay.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-408(7): Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act Subject to the requirements of


Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409 Battered person mitigation.
----------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(1)(a): 78B-7-102 "Abuse" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(1)(b): 78B-7-102 "Cohabitant" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(1)(b)(i): 78B-7-102 the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(1)(b)(ii): the relationship of a minor and a natural parent, an adoptive parent, a stepparent, or an individual living with the minor's natural parent as if a stepparent to the minor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(2)(a): An individual is entitled to battered person mitigation if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(2)(a)(i): the individual committed a criminal offense that was not legally justified;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(2)(a)(ii): the individual committed the criminal offense against a cohabitant who demonstrated a pattern of abuse against the individual or another cohabitant of the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(2)(a)(iii): the individual reasonably believed that the criminal offense was necessary to end the pattern of abuse.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(2)(b): (2)(a) A reasonable belief under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(3): (2)(a); (2)(a) An individual claiming mitigation under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(4): (2)(a) Mitigation under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(5): (2)(a); (3); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(5)(a): (2)(a); (3) If the trier of fact is a jury, an individual is not entitled to mitigation under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(5)(a)(i): (3) finds the individual proved, in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(5)(a)(ii): returns a special verdict for the reduced charge at the same time the jury returns the general verdict.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(5)(b): (2)(a) A nonunanimous vote by the jury on the question of mitigation under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-2-409(6): (2)(a); (2)(a) An individual intending to claim mitigation under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated - Title 76 - Chapter 3 - Punishments
********************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-101 Sentencing in accordance with chapter.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-101(1): A person adjudged guilty of an offense under this code shall be sentenced in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-101(2): Penal laws enacted after the effective date of this code shall be classified for sentencing purposes in accordance with this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-102 Designation of offenses.
-------------------------------------------------------
Offenses are designated as felonies, misdemeanors, or infractions.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-103 Felonies classified.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-103(1): Felonies are classified into four categories:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-103(1)(a): Capital felonies;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-103(1)(b): Felonies of the first degree;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-103(1)(c): Felonies of the second degree;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-103(1)(d): Felonies of the third degree.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-103(2): An offense designated as a felony either in this code or in another law, without specification as to punishment or category, is a felony of the third degree.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-104 Misdemeanors classified.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-104(1): Misdemeanors are classified into three categories:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-104(1)(a): Class A misdemeanors;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-104(1)(b): Class B misdemeanors;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-104(1)(c): Class C misdemeanors.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-104(2): 76-3-205 An offense designated as a misdemeanor in this code without specification as to punishment or category is an infraction punishable in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-104(3): (4) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-104(4): 76-3-205 After June 30, 2019, an offense designated as a misdemeanor in a county or municipal ordinance without specification as to punishment or category is an infraction punishable in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-105 Infractions.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-105(1): Infractions are not classified.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-105(2): Any offense which is an infraction within this code is expressly designated and any offense defined outside this code which is not designated as a felony or misdemeanor and for which no penalty is specified is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201 Sentences or combination of sentences allowed -- Restitution and other costs -- Civil penalties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(1): 80-6-701; 77-38b-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(1)(a): 80-6-701
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(1)(a)(i): "Convicted" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(1)(a)(i)(A): having entered a plea of guilty, a plea of no contest, or a plea of guilty with a mental condition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(1)(a)(i)(B): having received a judgment of guilty or a judgment of guilty with a mental condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(1)(a)(ii): 80-6-701 "Convicted" does not include an adjudication of an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(1)(b): 77-38b-102 "Restitution" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(2): 77-18-105 Within the limits provided by this chapter, a court may sentence an individual convicted of an offense to any one of the following sentences, or combination of the following sentences:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(2)(a): to pay a fine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(2)(b): to removal or disqualification from public or private office;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(2)(c): 77-18-105 except as otherwise provided by law, to probation in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(2)(d): to imprisonment;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(2)(e): on or after April 27, 1992, to life in prison without parole; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(2)(f): to death.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(3)(a): This chapter does not deprive a court of authority conferred by law:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(3)(a)(i): to forfeit property;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(3)(a)(ii): to dissolve a corporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(3)(a)(iii): to suspend or cancel a license;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(3)(a)(iv): to permit removal of an individual from office;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(3)(a)(v): to cite for contempt; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(3)(a)(vi): to impose any other civil penalty.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(3)(b): A court may include a civil penalty in a sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(4): Title 77, Chapter 38b, Crime Victims Restitution Act; 77-32b-104; 77-30-24; Title 77, Chapter 30, Extradition; (5); 77-32b-104(2); (3); (4); 17-50-319; 64-13e-104; 77-32b-104 In addition to any other sentence that a sentencing court may impose, the court shall order an individual to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(4)(a): Title 77, Chapter 38b, Crime Victims Restitution Act pay restitution in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(4)(b): 77-32b-104; 77-30-24; Title 77, Chapter 30, Extradition subject to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(4)(b)(i): Title 77, Chapter 30, Extradition was extradited to this state, under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(4)(b)(ii): is convicted of an offense in the county for which the individual is returned;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(4)(c): (5); 77-32b-104(2); (3); (4); 17-50-319; 64-13e-104 subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(4)(c)(i): the individual is convicted of an offense that results in incarceration in the county correctional facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(4)(c)(ii): 64-13e-104
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(4)(c)(ii)(A): the individual is not a state prisoner housed in the county correctional facility through a contract with the Department of Corrections; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(4)(c)(ii)(B): 64-13e-104 the reimbursement does not duplicate the reimbursement under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(4)(d): 77-32b-104 pay any other cost that the court determines is appropriate under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-201(5): (4)(c) The cost of medical care under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202 Paroled individuals -- Termination or discharge from sentence -- Time served on parole -- Discretion of Board of Pardons and Parole.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(1): 63M-7-404; 77-27-5(7) Every individual committed to the state prison to serve an indeterminate term and, after December 31, 2018, released on parole shall complete a term of parole that extends through the expiration of the individual's maximum sentence unless the parole is earlier terminated by the Board of Pardons and Parole in accordance with the supervision length guidelines established by the Utah Sentencing Commission under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(2): (2)(b); 64-13-21; Chapter 5, Offenses Against the Individual
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(2)(a): (2)(b); 64-13-21 Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(2)(b): Chapter 5, Offenses Against the Individual Every individual committed to the state prison to serve an indeterminate term and later released on parole on or after July 1, 2008, but before January 1, 2019, and who was convicted of any felony offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(3): 76-5-404; 76-5-404.1; 76-5-404.3 Every individual convicted of a second degree felony for violating Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(4): (1); (2); (3) An individual who violates the terms of parole, while serving parole, for any offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(5): An individual paroled following a former parole revocation may not be discharged from the individual's sentence until:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(5)(a): the individual has served the applicable period of parole under this section outside of confinement;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(5)(b): the individual's maximum sentence has expired; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(5)(c): the Board of Pardons and Parole orders the individual to be discharged from the sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(6)(a): All time served on parole, outside of confinement and without violation, constitutes service toward the total sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(6)(b): Any time an individual spends outside of confinement after commission of a parole violation does not constitute service toward the total sentence unless the individual is exonerated at a parole revocation hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(6)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(6)(c)(i): Any time an individual spends in confinement awaiting a hearing before the Board of Pardons and Parole or a decision by the board concerning revocation of parole constitutes service toward the total sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(6)(c)(ii): In the case of exoneration by the board, the time spent is included in computing the total parole term.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(7): When a parolee causes the parolee's absence from the state without authority from the Board of Pardons and Parole or avoids or evades parole supervision, the period of absence, avoidance, or evasion tolls the parole period.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(8)(a): While on parole, time spent in confinement outside the state may not be credited toward the service of any Utah sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(8)(b): Time in confinement outside the state or in the custody of any tribal authority or the United States government for a conviction obtained in another jurisdiction tolls the expiration of the Utah sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(9): This section does not preclude the Board of Pardons and Parole from paroling or discharging an inmate at any time within the discretion of the Board of Pardons and Parole unless otherwise specifically provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-202(10): A parolee sentenced to lifetime parole may petition the Board of Pardons and Parole for termination of lifetime parole.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203 Felony conviction -- Indeterminate term of imprisonment.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person who has been convicted of a felony may be sentenced to imprisonment for an indeterminate term as follows:Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203(1): In the case of a felony of the first degree, unless the statute provides otherwise, for a term of not less than five years and which may be for life.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203(2): In the case of a felony of the second degree, unless the statute provides otherwise, for a term of not less than one year nor more than 15 years.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203(3): In the case of a felony of the third degree, unless the statute provides otherwise, for a term not to exceed five years.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1 Offenses committed in concert with three or more persons or in relation to a criminal street gang -- Notice -- Enhanced penalties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1(1): 76-9-802; (4); (5); (6) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1(1)(a): 76-9-802 "Criminal street gang" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1(1)(b): (4); (5); (6) "In concert with three or more persons" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1(1)(b)(i): the defendant was aided or encouraged by at least three other persons in committing the offense and was aware of this aid or encouragement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1(1)(b)(ii): (4); (5); (6) each of the other persons:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1(1)(b)(ii)(A): was physically present; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1(1)(b)(ii)(B): (4); (5); (6) participated as a party to any offense listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1(1)(c): "In concert with three or more persons" means, regarding intent:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1(1)(c)(i): other persons participating as parties need not have the intent to engage in the same offense or degree of offense as the defendant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1(1)(c)(ii): a minor is a party if the minor's actions would cause the minor to be a party if the minor were an adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1(2): (4); (5); (6); 76-9-802; 76-9-802 A person who commits any offense in accordance with this section is subject to an enhanced penalty as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1(2)(a): in concert with three or more persons;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1(2)(b): 76-9-802 for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with any criminal street gang as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1(2)(c): 76-9-802 to gain recognition, acceptance, membership, or increased status with a criminal street gang as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1(3): The prosecuting attorney, or grand jury if an indictment is returned, shall cause to be subscribed upon the information or indictment notice that the defendant is subject to the enhanced penalties provided under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.1(4): (4)(b); (4)(a); 76-6-106; 76-6-106.1; 76-6-107

Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2 Definitions -- Use of dangerous weapon in offenses committed on or about school premises -- Enhanced penalties.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(1): (1)(a)(i); (ii); 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(1)(a): (1)(a)(i); (ii) As used in this section "on or about school premises" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(1)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(1)(a)(i)(A): in a public or private elementary or secondary school; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(1)(a)(i)(B): on the grounds of any of those schools;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(1)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(1)(a)(ii)(A): in a public or private institution of higher education; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(1)(a)(ii)(B): on the grounds of a public or private institution of higher education;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(1)(a)(iii): (1)(a)(i); (ii) within 1,000 feet of any school, institution, or grounds included in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(1)(a)(iv): in or on the grounds of a preschool or child care facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(1)(b)(i): 76-1-101.5 "Dangerous weapon" has the same definition as in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(1)(b)(ii): "Educator" means a person who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(1)(b)(ii)(A): employed by a public school district; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(1)(b)(ii)(B): required to hold a certificate issued by the State Board of Education in order to perform duties of employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(1)(b)(iii): "Within the course of employment" means that an educator is providing services or engaging in conduct required by the educator's employer to perform the duties of employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(2): 76-1-101.5; (4) A person who, on or about school premises, commits an offense and uses or threatens to use a dangerous weapon, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(3): (4); (3)(a); Chapter 5, Offenses Against the Individual; Chapter 6, Part 3, Robbery
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(3)(a): (4) A person who commits an offense against an educator when the educator is acting within the course of employment is subject to an enhanced degree of offense as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(3)(b): (3)(a); Chapter 5, Offenses Against the Individual; Chapter 6, Part 3, Robbery As used in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(3)(b)(i): Chapter 5, Offenses Against the Individual an offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(3)(b)(ii): Chapter 6, Part 3, Robbery an offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(4): If the trier of fact finds beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant, while on or about school premises, commits an offense and in the commission of the offense uses or threatens to use a dangerous weapon, or that the defendant committed an offense against an educator when the educator was acting within the course of the educator's employment, the enhanced penalty for a:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(4)(a): class B misdemeanor is a class A misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(4)(b): class A misdemeanor is a third degree felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(4)(c): third degree felony is a second degree felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(4)(d): second degree felony is a first degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(5): 76-3-203.8; (3) The enhanced penalty for a first degree felony offense of a convicted person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(5)(a): is imprisonment for a term of not less than five years and which may be for life, and imposition or execution of the sentence may not be suspended unless the court finds that the interests of justice would be best served and states the specific circumstances justifying the disposition on the record; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(5)(b): 76-3-203.8; (3) is subject also to the dangerous weapon enhancement provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(6): (4); (5) The prosecuting attorney, or grand jury if an indictment is returned, shall provide notice upon the information or indictment that the defendant is subject to the enhanced degree of offense or penalty under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(7): (4); (5)(a); (2); 76-3-203.8 In cases where an offense is enhanced under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(8): 76-5-301.1; 76-5-302; 76-5-404 The sentencing enhancement described in this section does not apply if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(8)(a): 76-5-301.1; 76-5-302; 76-5-404 the offense for which the person is being sentenced is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(8)(a)(i): a grievous sexual offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(8)(a)(ii): 76-5-301.1 child kidnapping under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(8)(a)(iii): 76-5-302 aggravated kidnapping under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(8)(a)(iv): 76-5-404 forcible sexual abuse under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.2(8)(b): applying the sentencing enhancement provided for in this section would result in a lower maximum penalty than the penalty provided for under the section that describes the offense for which the person is being sentenced.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3 Penalty for hate crimes -- Civil rights violation.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
As used in this section:Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(1): (4) "Primary offense" means those offenses provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(2): (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(2)(a): (2)(b) A person who commits any primary offense with the intent to intimidate or terrorize another person or with reason to believe that his action would intimidate or terrorize that person is subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(2)(b)(i): A class C misdemeanor primary offense is a class B misdemeanor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(2)(b)(ii): a class B misdemeanor primary offense is a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(3): "Intimidate or terrorize" means an act which causes the person to fear for his physical safety or damages the property of that person or another.  The act must be accompanied with the intent to cause or has the effect of causing a person to reasonably fear to freely exercise or enjoy any right secured by the Constitution or laws of the state or by the Constitution or laws of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(4): (1); 76-5-102; 76-5-102.4; 76-5-106; 76-5-107; 76-5-108; 76-6-102; 76-6-104; 76-6-106(2)(a); 76-6-204; 76-6-206; 76-6-412; 76-8-301; 76-8-302; 76-8-305; 76-8-306; 76-8-307; 76-8-308; 76-8-313; Title 76, Chapter 8, Part 7, Colleges and Universities; Title 76, Chapter 9, Part 1, Breaches of the Peace and Related Offenses; Title 76, Chapter 9, Part 2, Electronic Communication and Telephone Abuse; 76-9-301; 76-10-506; 76-9-102 Primary offenses referred to in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(4)(a): 76-5-102; 76-5-102.4; 76-5-106; 76-5-107; 76-5-108 assault and related offenses under Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(4)(b): 76-6-102; 76-6-104; 76-6-106(2)(a) any misdemeanor property destruction offense under Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(4)(c): 76-6-204; 76-6-206 any criminal trespass offense under Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(4)(d): 76-6-412 any misdemeanor theft offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(4)(e): 76-8-301; 76-8-302; 76-8-305; 76-8-306; 76-8-307; 76-8-308; 76-8-313 any offense of obstructing government operations under Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(4)(f): Title 76, Chapter 8, Part 7, Colleges and Universities any offense of interfering or intending to interfere with activities of colleges and universities under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(4)(g): Title 76, Chapter 9, Part 1, Breaches of the Peace and Related Offenses any misdemeanor offense against public order and decency as defined in
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(4)(h): Title 76, Chapter 9, Part 2, Electronic Communication and Telephone Abuse any telephone abuse offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(4)(i): 76-9-301 any cruelty to animals offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(4)(j): 76-10-506 any weapons offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(4)(k): 76-9-102 a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.3(5): This section does not affect or limit any individual's constitutional right to the lawful expression of free speech or other recognized rights secured by the Constitution or laws of the state or by the Constitution or laws of the United States.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.4 Hate crimes -- Aggravating factors.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.4(1): The sentencing judge or the Board of Pardons and Parole shall consider in their deliberations as an aggravating factor the public harm resulting from the commission of the offense, including the degree to which the offense is likely to incite community unrest or cause members of the community to reasonably fear for their physical safety or to freely exercise or enjoy any right secured by the Constitution or laws of the state or by the Constitution or laws of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.4(2): The sentencing judge or the Board of Pardons and Parole shall also consider whether the penalty for the offense is already increased by other existing provisions of law.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.4(3): This section does not affect or limit any individual's constitutional right to the lawful expression of free speech or other recognized rights secured by the Constitution or laws of the state or by the Constitution or laws of the United States.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5 Habitual violent offender -- Definition -- Procedure -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(1): Chapter 6, Part 1, Property Destruction; 76-5-102.5; 76-5-102.8; 76-5-103; 76-5-103.5; 76-5-105; 76-5-106.5(2); 76-5-107.3; 76-5-109.2(3)(a); (b); 76-5-114; 76-5-110; 76-5-111; 76-5-111.2; 76-5-111.3; 76-5-111.4; 76-5-112.5; Chapter 5, Part 2, Criminal Homicide; Chapter 5, Part 3, Kidnapping, Trafficking, and Smuggling; 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-402.2; 76-5-402.3; 76-5-403; 76-5-403.1; 76-5-404; 76-5-404.1; 76-5-404.3; 76-5-405; 76-5b-201; 76-5b-201.1; 76-5b-202; Chapter 6, Part 2, Burglary and Criminal Trespass; Chapter 6, Part 3, Robbery; 76-6-406; 76-6-406(1)(a)(i); (ii); 76-8-508(1); 76-8-508.3; 76-8-508.5(2)(c); 76-8-509; 76-6-406; 76-6-406(1)(a)(i); (ii); (ix); 76-10-306(3); (6); 76-10-307; 76-10-503; 76-10-508; 76-10-1306(1)(a); 76-10-1504; 76-10-1505; (1) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(1)(a): "Felony" means any violation of a criminal statute of the state, any other state, the United States, or any district, possession, or territory of the United States for which the maximum punishment the offender may be subjected to exceeds one year in prison.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(1)(b): "Habitual violent offender" means a person convicted within the state of any violent felony and who on at least two previous occasions has been convicted of a violent felony and committed to either prison in Utah or an equivalent correctional institution of another state or of the United States either at initial sentencing or after revocation of probation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(1)(c): Chapter 6, Part 1, Property Destruction; 76-5-102.5; 76-5-102.8; 76-5-103; 76-5-103.5; 76-5-105; 76-5-106.5(2); 76-5-107.3; 76-5-109.2(3)(a); (b); 76-5-114; 76-5-110; 76-5-111; 76-5-111.2; 76-5-111.3; 76-5-111.4; 76-5-112.5; Chapter 5, Part 2, Criminal Homicide; Chapter 5, Part 3, Kidnapping, Trafficking, and Smuggling; 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-402.2; 76-5-402.3; 76-5-403; 76-5-403.1; 76-5-404; 76-5-404.1; 76-5-404.3; 76-5-405; 76-5b-201; 76-5b-201.1; 76-5b-202; Chapter 6, Part 2, Burglary and Criminal Trespass; Chapter 6, Part 3, Robbery; 76-6-406; 76-6-406(1)(a)(i); (ii); 76-8-508(1); 76-8-508.3; 76-8-508.5(2)(c); 76-8-509; 76-6-406; 76-6-406(1)(a)(i); (ii); (ix); 76-10-306(3); (6); 76-10-307; 76-10-503; 76-10-508; 76-10-1306(1)(a); 76-10-1504; 76-10-1505; (1) "Violent felony" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(1)(c)(i): Chapter 6, Part 1, Property Destruction; 76-5-102.5; 76-5-102.8; 76-5-103; 76-5-103.5; 76-5-105; 76-5-106.5(2); 76-5-107.3; 76-5-109.2(3)(a); (b); 76-5-114; 76-5-110; 76-5-111; 76-5-111.2; 76-5-111.3; 76-5-111.4; 76-5-112.5; Chapter 5, Part 2, Criminal Homicide; Chapter 5, Part 3, Kidnapping, Trafficking, and Smuggling; 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-402.2; 76-5-402.3; 76-5-403; 76-5-403.1; 76-5-404; 76-5-404.1; 76-5-404.3; 76-5-405; 76-5b-201; 76-5b-201.1; 76-5b-202; Chapter 6, Part 2, Burglary and Criminal Trespass; Chapter 6, Part 3, Robbery; 76-6-406; 76-6-406(1)(a)(i); (ii); 76-8-508(1); 76-8-508.3; 76-8-508.5(2)(c); 76-8-509; 76-6-406; 76-6-406(1)(a)(i); (ii); (ix); 76-10-306(3); (6); 76-10-307; 76-10-503; 76-10-508; 76-10-1306(1)(a); 76-10-1504; 76-10-1505 any of the following offenses, or any attempt, solicitation, or conspiracy to commit any of the following offenses punishable as a felony:

Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(1)(c)(ii): (1) any felony violation of a criminal statute of any other state, the United States, or any district, possession, or territory of the United States which would constitute a violent felony as defined in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(2): If a person is convicted in this state of a violent felony by plea or by verdict and the trier of fact determines beyond a reasonable doubt that the person is a habitual violent offender under this section, the penalty for a:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(2)(a): third degree felony is as if the conviction were for a first degree felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(2)(b): second degree felony is as if the conviction were for a first degree felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(2)(c): first degree felony remains the penalty for a first degree penalty except:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(2)(c)(i): the convicted person is not eligible for probation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(2)(c)(ii): the Board of Pardons and Parole shall consider that the convicted person is a habitual violent offender as an aggravating factor in determining the length of incarceration.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(3)(a): The prosecuting attorney, or grand jury if an indictment is returned, shall provide notice in the information or indictment that the defendant is subject to punishment as a habitual violent offender under this section.  Notice shall include the case number, court, and date of conviction or commitment of any case relied upon by the prosecution.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(3)(b)(i): The defendant shall serve notice in writing upon the prosecutor if the defendant intends to deny that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(3)(b)(i)(A): the defendant is the person who was convicted or committed;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(3)(b)(i)(B): the defendant was represented by counsel or had waived counsel; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(3)(b)(i)(C): the defendant's plea was understandingly or voluntarily entered.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(3)(b)(ii): The notice of denial shall be served not later than five days prior to trial and shall state in detail the defendant's contention regarding the previous conviction and commitment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(4): (3)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(4)(a): (3)(b) If the defendant enters a denial under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(4)(a)(i): defendant's previous convictions for violent felonies, except as otherwise provided in the Utah Rules of Evidence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(4)(a)(ii): allegation against the defendant of being a habitual violent offender.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(4)(b): If the jury's verdict is guilty, the defendant shall be tried regarding the allegation of being an habitual violent offender by the same jury, if practicable, unless the defendant waives the jury, in which case the allegation shall be tried immediately to the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(4)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(4)(c)(i): Before or at the time of sentencing the trier of fact shall determine if this section applies.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(4)(c)(ii): The trier of fact shall consider any evidence presented at trial and the prosecution and the defendant shall be afforded an opportunity to present any necessary additional evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(4)(c)(iii): Before sentencing under this section, the trier of fact shall determine whether this section is applicable beyond a reasonable doubt.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(4)(d): If any previous conviction and commitment is based upon a plea of guilty or no contest, there is a rebuttable presumption that the conviction and commitment were regular and lawful in all respects if the conviction and commitment occurred after January 1, 1970.  If the conviction and commitment occurred prior to January 1, 1970, the burden is on the prosecution to establish by a preponderance of the evidence that the defendant was then represented by counsel or had lawfully waived the right to have counsel present, and that the defendant's plea was understandingly and voluntarily entered.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(4)(e): If the trier of fact finds this section applicable, the court shall enter that specific finding on the record and shall indicate in the order of judgment and commitment that the defendant has been found by the trier of fact to be a habitual violent offender and is sentenced under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(5): 76-3-407; (5)(a); (1)(c); Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(5)(a): 76-3-407 The sentencing enhancement provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(5)(b): (5)(a); (1)(c); Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(6): 76-5-301.1; 76-5-302; 76-5-404 The sentencing enhancement described in this section does not apply if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(6)(a): 76-5-301.1; 76-5-302; 76-5-404 the offense for which the person is being sentenced is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(6)(a)(i): a grievous sexual offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(6)(a)(ii): 76-5-301.1 child kidnapping, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(6)(a)(iii): 76-5-302 aggravated kidnapping, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(6)(a)(iv): 76-5-404 forcible sexual abuse, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.5(6)(b): applying the sentencing enhancement provided for in this section would result in a lower maximum penalty than the penalty provided for under the section that describes the offense for which the person is being sentenced.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.7 Increase of sentence for violent felony if body armor used.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.7(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-3-203.5 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.7(1)(a): "Body armor" means any material designed or intended to provide bullet penetration resistance or protection from bodily injury caused by a dangerous weapon.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.7(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 "Dangerous weapon" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.7(1)(c): 76-3-203.5 "Violent felony" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.7(2): 76-3-203 A person convicted of a violent felony may be sentenced to imprisonment for an indeterminate term, as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.7(2)(a): a first degree felony, the court shall sentence the person convicted for a term of not less than six years, and which may be for life;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.7(2)(b): a second degree felony, the court shall sentence the person convicted for a term of not less than two years nor more than 15 years, and the court may sentence the person convicted for a term of not less than two years nor more than 20 years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.7(2)(c): a third degree felony, the court shall sentence the person convicted for a term of not less than one year nor more than five years, and the court may sentence the person convicted for a term of not less than one year nor more than 10 years.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.7(3): 76-5-301.1; 76-5-302; 76-5-404 The sentencing enhancement described in this section does not apply if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.7(3)(a): 76-5-301.1; 76-5-302; 76-5-404 the offense for which the person is being sentenced is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.7(3)(a)(i): a grievous sexual offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.7(3)(a)(ii): 76-5-301.1 child kidnapping, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.7(3)(a)(iii): 76-5-302 aggravated kidnapping, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.7(3)(a)(iv): 76-5-404 forcible sexual abuse, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.7(3)(b): applying the sentencing enhancement provided for in this section would result in a lower maximum penalty than the penalty provided for under the section that describes the offense for which the person is being sentenced.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.8 Increase of sentence if dangerous weapon used.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.8(1): 76-1-101.5 As used in this section, "dangerous weapon" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.8(2): If the trier of fact finds beyond a reasonable doubt that a dangerous weapon was used in the commission or furtherance of a felony, the court:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.8(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.8(2)(a)(i): shall increase by one year the minimum term of the sentence applicable by law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.8(2)(a)(ii): if the minimum term applicable by law is zero, shall set the minimum term as one year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.8(2)(b): may increase by five years the maximum sentence applicable by law in the case of a felony of the second or third degree.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.8(3): (2) A defendant who is a party to a felony offense shall be sentenced to the increases in punishment provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.8(3)(a): a dangerous weapon was used in the commission or furtherance of the felony; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.8(3)(b): the defendant knew that the dangerous weapon was present.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.8(4): (2) If the trier of fact finds beyond a reasonable doubt that a person has been sentenced to a term of imprisonment for a felony in which a dangerous weapon was used in the commission of or furtherance of the felony and that person is subsequently convicted of another felony in which a dangerous weapon was used in the commission of or furtherance of the felony, the court shall, in addition to any other sentence imposed including those in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.9 Violent offense committed in presence of a child -- Aggravating factor.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.9(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.9(1)(a): "In the presence of a child" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.9(1)(a)(i): in the physical presence of a child younger than 14 years of age; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.9(1)(a)(ii): having knowledge that a child younger than 14 years of age is present and may see or hear a violent criminal offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.9(1)(b): "Violent criminal offense" means any criminal offense involving violence or physical harm or threat of violence or physical harm, or any attempt to commit a criminal offense involving violence or physical harm.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.9(2): The sentencing judge or the Board of Pardons and Parole shall consider as an aggravating factor in their deliberations that the defendant committed the violent criminal offense in the presence of a child.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.9(3): The sentencing judge or the Board of Pardons and Parole shall also consider whether the penalty for the offense is already increased by other existing provisions of law.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.9(4): This section does not affect or limit any individual's constitutional right to the lawful expression of free speech or other recognized rights secured by the Constitution or laws of Utah or by the Constitution or laws of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.9(5): This section does not affect or restrict the exercise of judicial discretion under any other provision of Utah law.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.10 Violent offense committed in presence of a child -- Penalties.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.10(1): 77-36-1 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.10(1)(a): "In the presence of a child" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.10(1)(a)(i): in the physical presence of a child younger than 14 years old; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.10(1)(a)(ii): having knowledge that the child is present and may see or hear the commission of a violent criminal offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.10(1)(b): 77-36-1 "Violent criminal offense" means any criminal offense involving violence or physical harm or threat of violence or physical harm, or any attempt to commit a criminal offense involving violence or physical harm that is not a domestic violence offense as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.10(2): 76-5-201; 76-1-101.5; (2)(a); (b) A person commits a violent criminal offense in the presence of a child if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.10(2)(a): 76-5-201 commits or attempts to commit criminal homicide, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.10(2)(b): 76-1-101.5 intentionally causes or attempts to cause serious bodily injury to a third party or uses a dangerous weapon, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.10(2)(c): (2)(a); (b) under circumstances not amounting to a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.10(3): (2) A person who violates Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.11 Reporting an overdose -- Mitigating factor.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is a mitigating factor in sentencing for an offense underUtah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.11(1): reasonably believes that the person or another person is experiencing an overdose event due to the ingestion, injection, inhalation, or other introduction into the human body of a controlled substance or other substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.11(2): 26B-4-101 reports, or assists a person who reports, in good faith the overdose event to a medical provider, an emergency medical service provider as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.11(3): (2) provides in the report under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.11(4): remains at the location of the person experiencing the overdose event until a responding law enforcement officer or emergency medical service provider arrives, or remains at the medical care facility where the person experiencing an overdose event is located until a responding law enforcement officer arrives;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.11(5): cooperates with the responding medical provider, emergency medical service provider, and law enforcement officer, including providing information regarding the person experiencing the overdose event and any substances the person may have injected, inhaled, or otherwise introduced into the person's body; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.11(6): committed the offense in the same course of events from which the reported overdose arose.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.11 Reporting an overdose -- Mitigating factor.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is a mitigating factor in sentencing for an offense underUtah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.11(1): reasonably believes that the person or another person is experiencing an overdose event due to the ingestion, injection, inhalation, or other introduction into the human body of a controlled substance or other substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.11(2): 53-2d-101 reports, or assists a person who reports, in good faith the overdose event to a medical provider, an emergency medical service provider as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.11(3): (2) provides in the report under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.11(4): remains at the location of the person experiencing the overdose event until a responding law enforcement officer or emergency medical service provider arrives, or remains at the medical care facility where the person experiencing an overdose event is located until a responding law enforcement officer arrives;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.11(5): cooperates with the responding medical provider, emergency medical service provider, and law enforcement officer, including providing information regarding the person experiencing the overdose event and any substances the person may have injected, inhaled, or otherwise introduced into the person's body; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.11(6): committed the offense in the same course of events from which the reported overdose arose.
