Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14 Victim targeting penalty enhancement -- Penalties.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1): 53-2b-102; Title 53, Chapter 13, Peace Officer Classifications As used in this section "personal attribute" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(a): age;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(b): ancestry;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(c): disability;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(d): ethnicity;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(e): familial status;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(f): gender identity;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(g): homelessness;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(h): marital status;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(i): matriculation;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(j): national origin;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(k): political expression;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(l): race;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(m): religion;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(n): sex;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(o): sexual orientation;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(p): service in the U.S. Armed Forces;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(q): 53-2b-102 status as an emergency responder, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(1)(r): Title 53, Chapter 13, Peace Officer Classifications status as a law enforcement officer, correctional officer, special function officer, or any other peace officer, as defined in
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(2): (3) A defendant is subject to enhanced penalties under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(2)(a): the victim of the criminal offense because of the defendant's belief or perception regarding the victim's personal attribute or a personal attribute of another individual or group of individuals with whom the victim has a relationship; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(2)(b): the property damaged or otherwise affected by the criminal offense because of the defendant's belief or perception regarding the property owner's, possessor's, or occupant's personal attribute or a personal attribute of another individual or group of individuals with whom the property owner, possessor, or occupant has a relationship.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(3): (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(3)(a): (2) If the trier of fact finds beyond a reasonable doubt that a defendant committed a criminal offense and selected the victim or property damaged or otherwise affected by the criminal offense in the manner described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(3)(a)(i): a class C misdemeanor is a class B misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(3)(a)(ii): a class B misdemeanor is a class A misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(3)(a)(iii): a class A misdemeanor is a third degree felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(3)(a)(iv): a third degree felony is a third degree felony punishable by an indeterminate term of imprisonment for not less than one year nor more than five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(3)(a)(v): a second degree felony is a second degree felony punishable by an indeterminate term of imprisonment for not less than two years nor more than 15 years.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(3)(b): (2) If the trier of fact finds beyond a reasonable doubt that a defendant committed a criminal offense that is a first degree felony and selected the victim or property damaged or otherwise affected by the criminal offense in the manner described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(4): This section does not:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(4)(a): apply if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(4)(a)(i): the penalty for the criminal offense is increased or enhanced under another provision of state law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(4)(a)(ii): the personal attribute of the victim or property owner, possessor, or occupant is an element of a criminal offense under another provision of state law;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(4)(b): prevent the court from imposing alternative sanctions as the court finds appropriate;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(4)(c): affect or limit any individual's constitutional right to the lawful expression of free speech or other recognized rights secured by the Utah Constitution or the laws of the state, or by the United States Constitution or the laws of the United States; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(4)(d): create a special or protected class for any purpose other than a criminal penalty enhancement under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(5)(a): If a final decision of a court of competent jurisdiction holds invalid any provision of this section or the application of any provision of this section to any person or circumstance, the remaining provisions of this section remain effective without the invalidated provision or application.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.14(5)(b): The provisions of this section are severable.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.15 Offenses committed against timber, mining, or agricultural industries -- Enhanced penalties.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.15(1): An actor who commits any criminal offense with the intent to halt, impede, obstruct, or interfere with the lawful management, cultivation, or harvesting of trees or timber, or the management or operations of agricultural or mining industries is subject to an enhanced penalty for the offense as provided below.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.15(2): The prosecuting attorney, or grand jury if an indictment is returned, shall cause to be subscribed upon the complaint in misdemeanor cases or the information or indictment in felony cases notice that the defendant is subject to the enhanced penalties provided under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.15(3): (3) If the trier of fact finds beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant committed any criminal offense with the intent to halt, impede, obstruct, or interfere with the lawful management, cultivation, or harvesting of trees or timber, or the management or operations of agricultural or mining industries, the penalties are enhanced as provided in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.15(3)(a): a class C misdemeanor is a class B misdemeanor, with a mandatory fine of not less than $1,000, which is in addition to any term of imprisonment the court may impose;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.15(3)(b): a class B misdemeanor is a Class A misdemeanor, with a fine of not less than $2,500, which is in addition to any term of imprisonment the court may impose;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.15(3)(c): a class A misdemeanor is a third degree felony, with a fine of not less than $5,000, which is in addition to any term of imprisonment the court may impose;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.15(3)(d): a third degree felony is a second degree felony, with a fine of not less than $7,500, which is in addition to any term of imprisonment the court may impose; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.15(3)(e): a second degree felony is subject to a fine of not less than $10,000, which is in addition to any term of imprisonment the court may impose.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.15(4): This section does not apply to action protected by the National Labor Relations Act, 29 U.S.C. Sec. 151 et seq., or the Federal Railway Labor Act, 45 U.S.C. Sec. 151 et seq.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16 Offenses committed against animal enterprises -- Definitions -- Enhanced penalties.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(1): 4-39-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(1)(a): "Animal enterprise" means a commercial or academic enterprise that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(1)(a)(i): uses animals for food or fiber production;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(1)(a)(ii): is an agricultural operation, including a facility for the production of crops or livestock, or livestock products;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(1)(a)(iii): operates a zoo, aquarium, circus, rodeo, or lawful competitive animal event; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(1)(a)(iv): any fair or similar event intended to advance agricultural arts and sciences.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(1)(b): 4-39-102 "Livestock" means cattle, sheep, goats, swine, horses, mules, poultry, domesticated elk as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(1)(c): "Property" includes any buildings, vehicles, animals, data, records, stables, livestock handling facilities, livestock watering troughs or other watering facilities, and fencing or other forms of enclosure.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(2): (4) A person who commits any criminal offense with the intent to halt, impede, obstruct, or interfere with the lawful operation of an animal enterprise or to damage, take, or cause the loss of any property owned by, used by, or in the possession of a lawful animal enterprise, is subject to an enhanced penalty under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(3): The prosecuting attorney, or grand jury if an indictment is returned, shall cause to be subscribed upon the information or indictment notice that the defendant is subject to the enhanced penalties provided under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(4): (4) If the trier of fact finds beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant committed any criminal offense with the intent to halt, impede, obstruct, or interfere with the lawful operation of an animal enterprise or to damage, take, or cause the loss of any property owned by, used by, or in the possession of a lawful animal enterprise, the penalties are enhanced as provided in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(4)(a): a class C misdemeanor is a class B misdemeanor, with a mandatory fine of not less than $1,000, which is in addition to any term of imprisonment the court may impose;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(4)(b): a class B misdemeanor is a class A misdemeanor, with a fine of not less than $2,500, which is in addition to any term of imprisonment the court may impose;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(4)(c): a class A misdemeanor is a third degree felony, with a fine of not less than $5,000, which is in addition to any term of imprisonment the court may impose;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(4)(d): a third degree felony is a second degree felony, with a fine of not less than $7,500, which is in addition to any term of imprisonment the court may impose; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(4)(e): a second degree felony is subject to a fine of not less than $10,000, which is in addition to any term of imprisonment the court may impose.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-203.16(5): This section does not apply to action protected by the National Labor Relations Act, 29 U.S.C. Sec. 151 et seq., or the Federal Railway Labor Act, 45 U.S.C. Sec. 151 et seq.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-204 Misdemeanor conviction -- Term of imprisonment.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person who has been convicted of a misdemeanor may be sentenced to imprisonment as follows:Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-204(1): In the case of a class A misdemeanor, for a term not exceeding 364 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-204(2): In the case of a class B misdemeanor, for a term not exceeding six months.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-204(3): In the case of a class C misdemeanor, for a term not exceeding 90 days.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-205 Infraction conviction -- Fine, forfeiture, and disqualification.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-205(1): A person convicted of an infraction may not be imprisoned but may be subject to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-205(1)(a): a fine, which may include compensatory service as a method to satisfy the fine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-205(1)(b): forfeiture;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-205(1)(c): disqualification; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-205(1)(d): any combination of the above.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-205(2): 76-3-301.7 Compensatory service shall be considered in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-205(3): Whenever a person is convicted of an infraction and no punishment is specified, the person may be fined as for a class C misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-206 Capital felony -- Penalties.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-206(1): 76-3-207 A person who has pled guilty to or been convicted of a capital felony shall be sentenced in accordance with this section and Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-206(2): (1); (2)(a)(i); (2)(a)(iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-206(2)(a): (1) If the person described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-206(2)(a)(i): death;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-206(2)(a)(ii): an indeterminate prison term of not less than 25 years and that may be for life; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-206(2)(a)(iii): on or after April 27, 1992, life in prison without parole.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-206(2)(b): (2)(a)(i); (2)(a)(iii) Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-206(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-206(3)(a): The judgment of conviction and sentence of death is subject to automatic review by the Utah State Supreme Court within 60 days after certification by the sentencing court of the entire record unless time is extended an additional period not to exceed 30 days by the Utah State Supreme Court for good cause shown.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-206(3)(b): The review by the Utah State Supreme Court has priority over all other cases and shall be heard in accordance with rules promulgated by the Utah State Supreme Court.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207 Capital felony -- Sentencing proceeding.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(1): (6)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(1)(a): When a defendant has pled guilty to or been found guilty of a capital felony, there shall be further proceedings before the court or jury on the issue of sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(1)(b): In the case of a plea of guilty to a capital felony, the sentencing proceedings shall be conducted before a jury or, upon request of the defendant and with the approval of the court and the consent of the prosecution, by the court which accepted the plea.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(1)(c)(i): When a defendant has been found guilty of a capital felony, the proceedings shall be conducted before the court or jury which found the defendant guilty, provided the defendant may waive hearing before the jury with the approval of the court and the consent of the prosecution, in which event the hearing shall be before the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(1)(c)(ii): If circumstances make it impossible or impractical to reconvene the same jury for the sentencing proceedings, the court may dismiss that jury and convene a new jury for the proceedings.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(1)(d): (6) If a retrial of the sentencing proceedings is necessary as a consequence of a remand from an appellate court, the sentencing authority shall be determined as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(2)(a): In capital sentencing proceedings, evidence may be presented on:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(2)(a)(i): the nature and circumstances of the crime;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(2)(a)(ii): the defendant's character, background, history, and mental and physical condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(2)(a)(iii): the victim and the impact of the crime on the victim's family and community without comparison to other persons or victims; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(2)(a)(iv): any other facts in aggravation or mitigation of the penalty that the court considers relevant to the sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(2)(b): Any evidence the court considers to have probative force may be received regardless of its admissibility under the exclusionary rules of evidence.  The state's attorney and the defendant shall be permitted to present argument for or against the sentence of death.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(3): 76-5-202 Aggravating circumstances include those outlined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(4): (4)(d) Mitigating circumstances include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(4)(a): the defendant has no significant history of prior criminal activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(4)(b): the homicide was committed while the defendant was under the influence of mental or emotional disturbance;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(4)(c): the defendant acted under duress or under the domination of another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(4)(d): (4)(d) at the time of the homicide, the capacity of the defendant to appreciate the wrongfulness of his conduct or to conform his conduct to the requirement of law was impaired as a result of a mental condition, intoxication, or influence of drugs, except that "mental condition" under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(4)(e): the youth of the defendant at the time of the crime;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(4)(f): the defendant was an accomplice in the homicide committed by another person and the defendant's participation was relatively minor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(4)(g): any other fact in mitigation of the penalty.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(5): 76-3-207.5(2); 76-3-206(2)(b); 76-3-207.5(2); (5)(b); (c); 76-3-401
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(5)(a): 76-3-207.5(2); 76-3-206(2)(b) The court or jury, as the case may be, shall retire to consider the penalty.  Except as provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(5)(b): The death penalty shall only be imposed if, after considering the totality of the aggravating and mitigating circumstances, the jury is persuaded beyond a reasonable doubt that total aggravation outweighs total mitigation, and is further persuaded, beyond a reasonable doubt, that the imposition of the death penalty is justified and appropriate in the circumstances.  If the jury reports unanimous agreement to impose the sentence of death, the court shall discharge the jury and shall impose the sentence of death.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(5)(c): 76-3-207.5(2) If the jury is unable to reach a unanimous decision imposing the sentence of death, the jury shall then determine whether the penalty of life in prison without parole shall be imposed, except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(5)(d): (5)(b); (c) If the defendant waives hearing before the jury as to sentencing, with the approval of the court and the consent of the prosecution, the court shall determine the appropriate penalty according to the standards of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(5)(e): 76-3-401 If the defendant is sentenced to more than one term of life in prison with or without the possibility of parole, or in addition to a sentence of life in prison with or without the possibility of parole the defendant is sentenced for other offenses which result in terms of imprisonment, the judge shall determine whether the terms of imprisonment shall be imposed as concurrent or consecutive sentences in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(6): (6)(b); (c) Upon any appeal by the defendant where the sentence is of death, the appellate court, if it finds prejudicial error in the sentencing proceeding only, may set aside the sentence of death and remand the case to the trial court for new sentencing proceedings to the extent necessary to correct the error or errors.  An error in the sentencing proceedings may not result in the reversal of the conviction of a capital felony.  In cases of remand for new sentencing proceedings, all exhibits and a transcript of all testimony and other evidence properly admitted in the prior trial and sentencing proceedings are admissible in the new sentencing proceedings, and if the sentencing proceeding was before a:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(6)(a): (6)(b); (c) jury, a new jury shall be impaneled for the new sentencing proceeding unless the defendant waives the hearing before the jury with the approval of the court and the consent of the prosecution, in which case the proceeding shall be held according to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(6)(b): judge, the original trial judge shall conduct the new sentencing proceeding; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(6)(c): judge, and the original trial judge is unable or unavailable to conduct a new sentencing proceeding, then another judge shall be designated to conduct the new sentencing proceeding, and the new proceeding will be before a jury unless the defendant waives the hearing before the jury with the approval of the court and the consent of the prosecution.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(7): If the penalty of death is held to be unconstitutional by the Utah Supreme Court or the United States Supreme Court, the court having jurisdiction over a person previously sentenced to death for a capital felony shall cause the person to be brought before the court, and the court shall sentence the person to life in prison without parole.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(8): 77-15a-101; (8)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(8)(a): 77-15a-101 If the appellate court's final decision regarding any appeal of a sentence of death precludes the imposition of the death penalty due to mental retardation or subaverage general intellectual functioning under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207(8)(b): (8)(a) If the appellate court precludes the imposition of the death penalty under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207.5 Applicability -- Effect on sentencing -- Options of offenders.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207.5(1): 76-3-201; 76-3-207; 76-3-201; 76-3-207
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207.5(1)(a): 76-3-201; 76-3-207 The sentencing option of life without parole provided in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207.5(1)(b): 76-3-201; 76-3-207 The sentencing option of life without parole provided in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207.5(2): 76-3-207; 76-3-201; 76-3-207 An offender, who commits a capital felony prior to April 27, 1992, but is sentenced on or after April 27, 1992, shall be given the option, prior to a sentencing hearing pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207.5(3): The sentencing option of life without parole has no effect on sentences imposed on an offender who was younger than 18 years of age at the time the offense was committed and was sentenced on or after May 10, 2016.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207.7 First degree felony aggravated murder -- Noncapital felony -- Penalties -- Sentenced by court.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207.7(1): 76-5-202 A person who has pled guilty to or been convicted of first degree felony aggravated murder under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207.7(2): (2)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207.7(2)(a): The sentence under this section shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207.7(2)(a)(i): life in prison without parole; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207.7(2)(a)(ii): an indeterminate prison term of not less than 25 years and that may be for life.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-207.7(2)(b): (2)(a)(i) Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-208 Imprisonment -- Custodial authorities.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-208(1): 76-3-204; 77-18-111 Persons sentenced to imprisonment shall be committed to the following custodial authorities:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-208(1)(a): felony commitments shall be to the Utah State Prison;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-208(1)(b): 76-3-204; 77-18-111
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-208(1)(b)(i): 76-3-204 notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-208(1)(b)(ii): 77-18-111 the court may not order the imprisonment of a defendant to the Utah State Prison for a fixed term or other term that is inconsistent with this section and Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-208(1)(c): all other misdemeanor commitments shall be to the jail or other facility designated by the town, city or county where the defendant was convicted.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-208(2): A custodial authority may place a prisoner in a facility other than the one to which the prisoner was committed when:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-208(2)(a): the custodial authority does not have space to accommodate the prisoner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-208(2)(b): the security of the institution or prisoner requires the prisoner to be placed in a facility other than the one to which the prisoner was committed.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209 Limitation on sentencing for crimes committed by juveniles.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(1): Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; 76-9-702; 76-9-702.1; 76-9-702.5 As used in this section, "qualifying sexual offense" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(1)(a): Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses an offense described in
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(1)(b): 76-9-702 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(1)(c): 76-9-702.1 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(1)(d): 76-9-702.5 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(2): (2); (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(2)(a): (2) This Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(2)(b): Notwithstanding any provision of law, an individual may not be sentenced to life without parole if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(2)(b)(i): the individual is convicted of a crime punishable by life without parole; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(2)(b)(ii): at the time the individual committed the crime, the individual was under 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(2)(c): (2)(b) The maximum punishment that may be imposed on an individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(3): (4) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(3)(a): the district court shall impose a sentence consistent with the disposition that would have been made in juvenile court; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(3)(b): the district court may not impose incarceration unless the court enters specific written findings that incarceration is warranted based on a totality of the circumstances, taking into account:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(3)(b)(i): the time that elapsed after the individual committed the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(3)(b)(ii): the age of the individual at the time of the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(3)(b)(iii): the age of the victim at the time of the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(3)(b)(iv): the criminal history of the individual after the individual committed the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(3)(b)(v): any treatment assessments or validated risk tools; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(3)(b)(vi): public safety concerns.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(4): (3); (3); 76-5-405; 80-6-503; 80-6-504 Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(4)(a): (3) before the individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(4)(b): 76-5-405 the individual is convicted in district court, before the victim is 18 years old, of a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(4)(c): 80-6-503; 80-6-504 the conviction occurred in district court after the individual was:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(4)(c)(i): 80-6-503 charged by criminal information in the juvenile court for the qualifying sexual offense in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(4)(c)(ii): 80-6-504 bound over to the district court for the qualifying sexual offense in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(5): (3)(b); 76-5-405; (5)(a); Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; 76-3-204; Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; 76-9-702; 76-9-702.1; 76-9-702.5 If the district court imposes incarceration under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(5)(a): 76-5-405 seven years for a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(5)(b): (5)(a); Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(5)(c): 76-3-204; Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; 76-9-702; 76-9-702.1; 76-9-702.5 the maximum sentence described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-209(5)(c)(iv): 76-9-702.5 a violation of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301 Fines of individuals.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(1): An individual convicted of an offense may be sentenced to pay a fine, not exceeding:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(1)(a): $10,000 for a felony conviction of the first degree or second degree;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(1)(b): $5,000 for a felony conviction of the third degree;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(1)(c): $2,500 for a class A misdemeanor conviction;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(1)(d): $1,000 for a class B misdemeanor conviction;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(1)(e): $750 for a class C misdemeanor conviction or infraction conviction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(1)(f): any greater amounts specifically authorized by statute.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(2): 15-1-4; 78B-6-317
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(2)(a): 15-1-4; 78B-6-317 An individual convicted of a misdemeanor or infraction and sentenced to pay a fine may not be charged by a court:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(2)(a)(i): 15-1-4 notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(2)(a)(ii): 78B-6-317 that issues an order to show cause under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(2)(b): An individual convicted only of an infraction and sentenced to pay a fine may not be charged:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(2)(b)(i): by the Office of State Debt Collection, late fees and interest that in the aggregate are more than 25% of the initial fine; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(2)(b)(ii): by a third-party debt contractor of the Office of State Debt Collection, additional fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(3): (2) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(3)(a): victim restitution; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(3)(b): a felony conviction, even if that felony conviction is later reduced.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301(4): This section does not apply to a corporation, association, partnership, government, or governmental instrumentality.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.5 Uniform fine schedule -- Judicial Council.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.5(1): 76-3-301(1); 77-32b-102; 77-32b-103 The Judicial Council shall establish a uniform recommended fine schedule for each offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.5(1)(a): The fine for each offense shall proportionally reflect the seriousness of the offense and other factors as determined in writing by the Judicial Council.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.5(1)(b): The schedule shall be reviewed annually by the Judicial Council.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.5(1)(c): 77-32b-102; 77-32b-103 The fines shall be collected as part of a criminal accounts receivable, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.5(2): The schedule shall incorporate:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.5(2)(a): criteria for determining aggravating and mitigating circumstances; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.5(2)(b): guidelines for enhancement or reduction of the fine, based on aggravating or mitigating circumstances.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.5(3): Presentence investigation reports shall include documentation of aggravating and mitigating circumstances as determined under the criteria, and a recommended fine under the schedule.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.5(4): The Judicial Council shall also establish a separate uniform recommended fine schedule for the juvenile court and by rule provide for its implementation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.5(5): This section does not prohibit the court from in its discretion imposing no fine, or a fine in any amount up to and including the maximum fine, for the offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7 Compensatory service.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(1): As used in this section, "compensatory service" means service or unpaid work performed by a person, in lieu of the payment of a criminal fine, for:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(1)(a): a state or local government agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(1)(b): an entity that is approved as a nonprofit organization under Section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(1)(c): any other entity or organization if prior approval is obtained from the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(2): When a defendant is sentenced to pay a fine for an infraction, class C or class B misdemeanor, the court shall consider allowing the defendant to complete compensatory service in lieu of the payment of the fine or account receivable, exclusive of any victim restitution imposed.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(3): A defendant who intends to forfeit bail or who is ordered to pay a fine by the court for an infraction, class C or class B misdemeanor, shall be informed by the court of the opportunity to perform compensatory service in lieu of the fine or bail amount.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(4): (5) The court shall credit timely completed compensatory service reported in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(5): (5)(b); 76-8-504
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(5)(a): (5)(b); 76-8-504 The court shall provide the defendant with instructions that inform the organization:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(5)(a)(i): (5)(b) about the requirements in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(5)(a)(ii): 76-8-504 that making a written false statement to the court about the defendant's compensatory service is punishable as a class B misdemeanor pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(5)(b): The defendant shall report compensatory service hours to the court in a letter that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(5)(b)(i): is on the organization's official letterhead and includes contact information for the organization's representative;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(5)(b)(ii): specifies the number of hours for which the defendant provided service;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(5)(b)(iii): contains a brief description of what the service involved; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(5)(b)(iv): is signed by an authorized representative of the organization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(5)(b)(v): is in a form otherwise acceptable to the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(6): The court may refuse to accept compensatory service:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(6)(a): completed prior to the date of sentencing;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(6)(b): that has been submitted to another court for credit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-301.7(6)(c): completed at an agency or organization or is a type of service that is specifically prohibited by the court.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-302 Fines of corporations, associations, partnerships, or government instrumentalities.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A corporation, association, partnership, or governmental instrumentality shall pay a fine for an offense defined in this code for which no special corporate fine is specified.  The fine shall not exceed:Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-302(1): $20,000 for a felony conviction;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-302(2): $10,000 for a class A misdemeanor conviction;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-302(3): $5,000 for a class B misdemeanor conviction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-302(4): $1,000 for a class C misdemeanor conviction or for an infraction conviction.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-303 Additional sanctions against corporation or association -- Advertising of conviction -- Disqualification of officer.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-303(1): When a corporation or association is convicted of an offense, the court may, in addition to or in lieu of imposing other authorized sanctions, require the corporation or association to give appropriate publicity of the conviction by notice to the class or classes of persons or section of the public interested in or affected by the conviction, by advertising in designated areas, or by designated media or otherwise.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-303(2): When an executive or high managerial officer of a corporation or association is convicted of an offense committed in furtherance of the affairs of the corporation or association, the court may include in the sentence an order disqualifying him from exercising similar functions in the same or other corporations or associations for a period of not exceeding five years if it finds the scope or willfulness of his illegal actions make it dangerous or inadvisable for such functions to be entrusted to him.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401 Concurrent or consecutive sentences -- Limitations -- Definition.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(1): A court shall determine, if a defendant has been adjudged guilty of more than one felony offense, whether to impose concurrent or consecutive sentences for the offenses.  The court shall state on the record and shall indicate in the order of judgment and commitment:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(1)(a): if the sentences imposed are to run concurrently or consecutively to each other; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(1)(b): if the sentences before the court are to run concurrently or consecutively with any other sentences the defendant is already serving.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(2): In determining whether state offenses are to run concurrently or consecutively, the court shall consider the gravity and circumstances of the offenses, the number of victims, and the history, character, and rehabilitative needs of the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(3): The court shall order that sentences for state offenses run consecutively if the later offense is committed while the defendant is imprisoned or on parole, unless the court finds and states on the record that consecutive sentencing would be inappropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(4): If a written order of commitment does not clearly state whether the sentences are to run consecutively or concurrently, the Board of Pardons and Parole shall request clarification from the court.  Upon receipt of the request, the court shall enter a clarified order of commitment stating whether the sentences are to run consecutively or concurrently.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(5): 76-1-401 A court may impose consecutive sentences for offenses arising out of a single criminal episode as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(6): (6)(b); (6)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(6)(a): (6)(b) If a court imposes consecutive sentences, the aggregate maximum of all sentences imposed may not exceed 30 years imprisonment, except as provided under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(6)(b): (6)(a) The limitation under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(6)(b)(i): an offense for which the defendant is sentenced authorizes the death penalty or a maximum sentence of life imprisonment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(6)(b)(ii): the defendant is convicted of an additional offense based on conduct which occurs after his initial sentence or sentences are imposed.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(7): (6)(a) The limitation in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(7)(a): is sentenced at the same time for more than one offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(7)(b): is sentenced at different times for one or more offenses, all of which were committed prior to imposition of the defendant's initial sentence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(7)(c): has already been sentenced by a court of this state other than the present sentencing court or by a court of another state or federal jurisdiction, and the conduct giving rise to the present offense did not occur after his initial sentencing by any other court.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(8): (6)(a) When the limitation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(8)(a): if the aggregate maximum term exceeds the 30-year limitation, the maximum sentence is considered to be 30 years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(8)(b): when indeterminate sentences run consecutively, the minimum term, if any, constitutes the aggregate of the validly imposed minimum terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(9): When a sentence is imposed or sentences are imposed to run concurrently with the other or with a sentence presently being served, the term that provides the longer remaining imprisonment constitutes the time to be served.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(10): This section may not be construed to restrict the number or length of individual consecutive sentences that may be imposed or to affect the validity of any sentence so imposed, but only to limit the length of sentences actually served under the commitments.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(11): This section may not be construed to limit the authority of a court to impose consecutive sentences in misdemeanor cases.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401(12): 64-13-1 As used in this section, "imprisoned" means sentenced and committed to a secure correctional facility as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5 Concurrent or consecutive sentence with a juvenile disposition.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(1): 80-5-701; 77-27-2; 80-5-103; 80-6-703(2); 80-6-705(1); 64-13-1; 80-1-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(1)(a): 80-5-701 "Authority" means the Youth Parole Authority created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(1)(b): 77-27-2 "Board" means the Board of Pardons and Parole created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(1)(c): 80-5-103 "Division" means the Division of Juvenile Justice Services created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(1)(d): 80-6-703(2); 80-6-705(1)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(1)(d)(i): 80-6-703(2) "Juvenile disposition" means an order for commitment to the custody of the division under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(1)(d)(ii): 80-6-705(1) "Juvenile disposition" includes an order for secure care under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(1)(e): 64-13-1 "Secure correctional facility" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(1)(f): 80-1-102 "Secure care" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(2): 76-3-201 If a defendant who is 18 years old or older is serving a juvenile disposition, a court may not terminate the juvenile disposition for the defendant when:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(2)(a): the defendant is convicted of an offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(2)(b): 76-3-201 the court imposes a sentence under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(3): (3)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(3)(a): If a defendant who is 18 years old or older is convicted and sentenced for an offense and the defendant is serving a juvenile disposition at the time of sentencing, the court shall determine whether the sentence is to run concurrently or consecutively to the juvenile disposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(3)(b): The court shall state on the record and in the order of judgment and commitment whether the sentence imposed is to run concurrently or consecutively with the juvenile disposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(3)(c): In determining whether a sentence is to run concurrently or consecutively with a juvenile disposition, the court shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(3)(c)(i): the gravity and circumstances of the offense for which the defendant is convicted;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(3)(c)(ii): the number of victims; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(3)(c)(iii): the history, character, and rehabilitative needs of the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(3)(d): If an order of judgment and commitment does not clearly state whether the sentence is to run consecutively or concurrently with the juvenile disposition, the division shall request clarification from the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(3)(e): (3)(d) Upon receipt of the request under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(4): 80-6-804 If a court orders a sentence for imprisonment to run concurrently with a juvenile disposition for secure care, the defendant shall serve the sentence in secure care until the juvenile disposition is terminated by the authority in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(5): If a court orders a sentence for imprisonment in a county jail to run concurrently with a juvenile disposition for secure care and the disposition is terminated before the defendant's sentence for imprisonment in the county jail is terminated, the division shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(5)(a): notify the county jail at least 14 days before the day on which the defendant's disposition is terminated or the defendant is released from secure care; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(5)(b): facilitate the transfer or release of the defendant in accordance with the order of judgment and commitment imposed by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(6): (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(6)(a): (4) If a court orders a sentence for imprisonment in a secure correctional facility to run concurrently with a juvenile disposition for secure care:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(6)(a)(i): the board has authority over the defendant for purposes of ordering parole, pardon, commutation, termination of sentence, remission of fines or forfeitures, restitution, and any other authority granted by law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(6)(a)(ii): (4) the court and the division shall immediately notify the board that the defendant will remain in secure care as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(6)(b): If a court orders a sentence for imprisonment in a secure correctional facility to run concurrently with a juvenile disposition for secure care and the juvenile disposition is terminated before the defendant's sentence is terminated, the division shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(6)(b)(i): notify the board and the Department of Corrections at least 14 days before the day on which the defendant's disposition is terminated or the defendant is released from the secure care; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-401.5(6)(b)(ii): facilitate a release or transfer of the defendant in accordance with the order of judgment and commitment imposed by the court.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402 Conviction of lower degree of offense -- Procedure and limitations.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1): 77-40a-101; 62A-2-101; 13-53-102; 62A-2-101; 62A-2-101; 62A-2-101; 64-13-25; (1)(c)(ii)(A); (G); 77-40a-101; (1)(f)(ii); 76-3-203.5; 76-10-306(3); (5); (6); 76-10-503 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(a): "Lower degree of offense" includes an offense for which:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(a)(i): a statutory enhancement is charged in the information or indictment that would increase either the maximum or the minimum sentence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(a)(ii): the court removes the statutory enhancement in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(b): 77-40a-101 "Minor regulatory offense" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(c): 62A-2-101; 13-53-102; 62A-2-101; 62A-2-101; 62A-2-101; 64-13-25; (1)(c)(ii)(A); (G)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(c)(i): "Rehabilitation program" means a program designed to reduce criminogenic and recidivism risks.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(c)(ii): 62A-2-101; 13-53-102; 62A-2-101; 62A-2-101; 62A-2-101; 64-13-25; (1)(c)(ii)(A); (G) "Rehabilitation program" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(c)(ii)(A): 62A-2-101 a domestic violence treatment program, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(c)(ii)(B): 13-53-102 a residential, vocational, and life skills program, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(c)(ii)(C): 62A-2-101 a substance abuse treatment program, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(c)(ii)(D): 62A-2-101 a substance use disorder treatment program, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(c)(ii)(E): 62A-2-101 a youth program, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(c)(ii)(F): 64-13-25 a program that meets the standards established by the Department of Corrections under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(c)(ii)(G): a drug court, a veterans court, or a mental health court certified by the Judicial Council; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(c)(ii)(H): (1)(c)(ii)(A); (G) a program that is substantially similar to a program described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(d): "Serious offense" means a felony or misdemeanor offense that is not a minor regulatory offense or a traffic offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(e): 77-40a-101 "Traffic offense" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(f): (1)(f)(ii); 76-3-203.5; 76-10-306(3); (5); (6); 76-10-503
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(f)(i): (1)(f)(ii); 76-3-203.5 Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(f)(ii): 76-10-306(3); (5); (6); 76-10-503 "Violent felony" does not include an offense, or any attempt, solicitation, or conspiracy to commit an offense, for:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(f)(ii)(A): 76-10-306(3); (5); (6) the possession, use, or removal of explosive, chemical, or incendiary devices under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(1)(f)(ii)(B): 76-10-503 the purchase or possession of a dangerous weapon or handgun by a restricted person under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(2): The court may enter a judgment of conviction for a lower degree of offense than established by statute and impose a sentence at the time of sentencing for the lower degree of offense if the court:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(2)(a): takes into account:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(2)(a)(i): the nature and circumstances of the offense of which the defendant was found guilty; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(2)(a)(ii): the history and character of the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(2)(b): gives any victim present at the sentencing and the prosecuting attorney an opportunity to be heard; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(2)(c): concludes that the degree of offense established by statute would be unduly harsh to record as a conviction on the record for the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(3): (7) Upon a motion from the prosecuting attorney or the defendant, the court may enter a judgment of conviction for a lower degree of offense than established by statute:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(3)(a): after the defendant is successfully discharged from probation or parole for the conviction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(3)(b): (7) if the court finds that entering a judgment of conviction for a lower degree of offense is in the interest of justice in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(4): (4)(b); (7) Upon a motion from the prosecuting attorney or the defendant, the court may enter a judgment of conviction for a lower degree of offense than established by statute if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(4)(a): the defendant's probation or parole for the conviction did not result in a successful discharge but the defendant is successfully discharged from probation or parole for a subsequent conviction of an offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(4)(b)(i): at least five years have passed after the day on which the defendant is sentenced for the subsequent conviction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(4)(b)(ii): at least three years have passed after the day on which the defendant is sentenced for the subsequent conviction and the prosecuting attorney consents to the reduction;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(4)(c): (4)(b) the defendant is not convicted of a serious offense during the time period described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(4)(d): there are no criminal proceedings pending against the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(4)(e): the defendant is not on probation, on parole, or currently incarcerated for any other offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(4)(f): if the offense for which the reduction is sought is a violent felony, the prosecuting attorney consents to the reduction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(4)(g): (7) the court finds that entering a judgment of conviction for a lower degree of offense is in the interest of justice in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(5): (5)(b); (7) Upon a motion from the prosecuting attorney or the defendant, the court may enter a judgment of conviction for a lower degree of offense than established by statute if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(5)(a): the defendant's probation or parole for the conviction did not result in a successful discharge but the defendant is successfully discharged from a rehabilitation program;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(5)(b): at least three years have passed after the day on which the defendant is successfully discharged from the rehabilitation program;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(5)(c): (5)(b) the defendant is not convicted of a serious offense during the time period described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(5)(d): there are no criminal proceedings pending against the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(5)(e): the defendant is not on probation, on parole, or currently incarcerated for any other offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(5)(f): if the offense for which the reduction is sought is a violent felony, the prosecuting attorney consents to the reduction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(5)(g): (7) the court finds that entering a judgment of conviction for a lower degree of offense is in the interest of justice in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(6): (6)(a); (7) Upon a motion from the prosecuting attorney or the defendant, the court may enter a judgment of conviction for a lower degree of offense than established by statute if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(6)(a): at least five years have passed after the day on which the defendant's probation or parole for the conviction did not result in a successful discharge;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(6)(b): (6)(a) the defendant is not convicted of a serious offense during the time period described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(6)(c): there are no criminal proceedings pending against the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(6)(d): the defendant is not on probation, on parole, or currently incarcerated for any other offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(6)(e): if the offense for which the reduction is sought is a violent felony, the prosecuting attorney consents to the reduction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(6)(f): (7) the court finds that entering a judgment of conviction for a lower degree of offense is in the interest of justice in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(7): (3); (4); (5); (6) In determining whether entering a judgment of a conviction for a lower degree of offense is in the interest of justice under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(7)(a): the court shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(7)(a)(i): the nature, circumstances, and severity of the offense for which a reduction is sought;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(7)(a)(ii): the physical, emotional, or other harm that the defendant caused any victim of the offense for which the reduction is sought; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(7)(a)(iii): any input from a victim of the offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(7)(b): the court may consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(7)(b)(i): any special characteristics or circumstances of the defendant, including the defendant's criminogenic risks and needs;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(7)(b)(ii): the defendant's criminal history;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(7)(b)(iii): the defendant's employment and community service history;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(7)(b)(iv): whether the defendant participated in a rehabilitative program and successfully completed the program;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(7)(b)(v): any effect that a reduction would have on the defendant's ability to obtain or reapply for a professional license from the Department of Commerce;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(7)(b)(vi): whether the level of the offense has been reduced by law after the defendant's conviction;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(7)(b)(vii): any potential impact that the reduction would have on public safety; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(7)(b)(viii): any other circumstances that are reasonably related to the defendant or the offense for which the reduction is sought.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(8): (3); (4); (5); (6); (3); (4); (5); (6); (3); (4); (5); (6); (3); (4); (5); (6)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(8)(a): (3); (4); (5); (6) A court may only enter a judgment of conviction for a lower degree of offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(8)(a)(i): notice is provided to the other party;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(8)(a)(ii): reasonable efforts have been made by the prosecuting attorney to provide notice to any victims; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(8)(a)(iii): a hearing is held if a hearing is requested by either party.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(8)(b): (3); (4); (5); (6) A prosecuting attorney is entitled to a hearing on a motion seeking to reduce a judgment of conviction for a lower degree of offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(8)(c): (3); (4); (5); (6); (3); (4); (5); (6) In a motion under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(9): (3); (4); (5); (6) A court has jurisdiction to consider and enter a judgment of conviction for a lower degree of offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(10)(a): An offense may be reduced only one degree under this section, unless the prosecuting attorney specifically agrees in writing or on the court record that the offense may be reduced two degrees.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(10)(b): An offense may not be reduced under this section by more than two degrees.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(11): Title 77, Chapter 40a, Expungement This section does not preclude an individual from obtaining or being granted an expungement of the individual's record in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(12): The court may not enter a judgment for a conviction for a lower degree of offense under this section if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(12)(a): the reduction is specifically precluded by law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(12)(b): any unpaid balance remains on court-ordered restitution for the offense for which the reduction is sought.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(13): When the court enters a judgment for a lower degree of offense under this section, the actual title of the offense for which the reduction is made may not be altered.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(14): Title 77, Chapter 41, Sex and Kidnap Offender Registry; 77-41-105(3)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(14)(a): Title 77, Chapter 41, Sex and Kidnap Offender Registry An individual may not obtain a reduction under this section of a conviction that requires the individual to register as a sex offender until the registration requirements under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(14)(b): 77-41-105(3)(c) An individual required to register as a sex offender for the individual's lifetime under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(15)(a): Title 77, Chapter 43, Child Abuse Offender Registry An individual may not obtain a reduction under this section of a conviction that requires the individual to register as a child abuse offender until the registration requirements under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-402(15)(b): 77-43-105(3)(c) An individual required to register as a child abuse offender for the individual's lifetime under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-403 Credit for good behavior against jail sentence for misdemeanors and certain felonies.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In any commitment for incarceration in a county jail or detention facility, other than the Utah State Prison, the custodial authority may in its discretion and upon good behavior of the inmate allow up to 10 days credit against the sentence to be served for every 30 days served or up to two days credit for every 10 days served when the period to be served is less than 30 days if:Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-403(1): the incarceration is for a misdemeanor offense, and the sentencing judge has not entered an order to the contrary; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-403(2): the incarceration is part of a probation agreement for a felony offense, and the sentencing district judge has not entered an order to the contrary.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-403.5 Work or school release from county jail or facility -- Conditions.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When an inmate is incarcerated in a county jail or in a detention facility, the custodial authority may, in accordance with the release policy of the facility, allow the inmate to work outside of the jail or facility as part of a jail or facility supervised work detail, to seek or work at employment, or to attend an educational institution, if the inmate's incarceration:Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-403.5(1): is not for an offense for which release is prohibited under state law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-403.5(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-403.5(2)(a): is for a misdemeanor offense, and the sentencing judge has not entered an order prohibiting release under this section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-403.5(2)(b): is part of a probation agreement for a felony offense, and the sentencing district judge has not entered an order prohibiting release under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-405 Limitation on sentence where conviction or prior sentence set aside.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-405(1): Where a conviction or sentence has been set aside on direct review or on collateral attack, the court shall not impose a new sentence for the same offense or for a different offense based on the same conduct which is more severe than the prior sentence less the portion of the prior sentence previously satisfied.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-405(2): This section does not apply when:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-405(2)(a): the increased sentence is based on facts which were not known to the court at the time of the original sentence, and the court affirmatively places on the record the facts which provide the basis for the increased sentence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-405(2)(b): a defendant enters into a plea agreement with the prosecution and later successfully moves to invalidate his conviction, in which case the defendant and the prosecution stand in the same position as though the plea bargain, conviction, and sentence had never occurred.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
