Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-409 Child abuse or sex offense against child -- Treatment of offender or victim -- Payment of costs.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-409(1): Any person convicted in the district court of child abuse, or a sexual offense if the victim is under 18 years of age, may be ordered to participate in treatment or therapy under the supervision of the adult probation and parole section of the Department of Corrections, in cooperation with the division of children, youth, and families until the court is satisfied that such treatment or therapy has been successful or that no further benefit to the convicted offender would result if such treatment or therapy were continued.  The court may also order treatment of the victim if it believes the same would be beneficial under the circumstances.  Nothing in this section shall preclude the court from imposing any additional sentence as provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-409(2): The convicted offender shall be ordered to pay, to the extent that he or she is able, the costs of his or her treatment, together with treatment costs incurred by the victim and any administrative costs incurred by the appropriate state agency in the supervision of such treatment.  If the convicted offender is unable to pay all or part of the costs of treatment, the court may order the appropriate state agency to pay such costs to the extent funding is provided by the Legislature for such purpose and shall order the convicted offender to perform public service work as compensation for the cost of treatment.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-410 Compensatory service -- Graffiti penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-410(1): 76-6-106; 76-6-106.1; 76-6-107; 76-6-206; 77-18-105(6) If an actor uses graffiti and is convicted under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-410(1)(a): For a first conviction or adjudication, the court may require the actor to clean up graffiti for not less than eight hours.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-410(1)(b): For a second conviction or adjudication, the court may require the actor to clean up graffiti for not less than 16 hours.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-410(1)(c): For a third conviction or adjudication, the court may require the actor to clean up graffiti for not less than 24 hours.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-410(2): 76-6-106; 76-6-106.1; 76-6-206; 76-6-107; 76-6-107 The actor convicted under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-3-410(3): 77-18-105(6) The court may also require the actor to perform other alternative forms of restitution or repair to the damaged property in accordance with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated - Title 76 - Chapter 4 - Inchoate Offenses
**************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-101 Attempt -- Elements of offense.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-101(1): For purposes of this part, a person is guilty of an attempt to commit a crime if he:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-101(1)(a): engages in conduct constituting a substantial step toward commission of the crime; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-101(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-101(1)(b)(i): intends to commit the crime; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-101(1)(b)(ii): when causing a particular result is an element of the crime, he acts with an awareness that his conduct is reasonably certain to cause that result.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-101(2): (1)(b) For purposes of this part, conduct constitutes a substantial step if it strongly corroborates the actor's mental state as defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-101(3): A defense to the offense of attempt does not arise:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-101(3)(a): because the offense attempted was actually committed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-101(3)(b): due to factual or legal impossibility if the offense could have been committed if the attendant circumstances had been as the actor believed them to be.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102 Attempt -- Classification of offenses.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1): (2); 76-5-202; (1)(c); (d); 76-5-203(2)(a); 76-5-301.1; (1)(d); Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; (3); 76-5-402.1; 76-5-402.3; 76-5-403.1 Criminal attempt to commit:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(a): (2); 76-5-202
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(a)(i): a capital felony, or a felony punishable by imprisonment for life without parole, is a first degree felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(a)(ii): (2); 76-5-202 except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(b): (1)(c); (d) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(c): 76-5-203(2)(a); 76-5-301.1; (1)(d); Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses any of the following offenses is a first degree felony punishable by imprisonment for an indeterminate term of not fewer than three years and which may be for life:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(c)(i): 76-5-203(2)(a) murder, Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(c)(ii): 76-5-301.1 child kidnapping, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(c)(iii): (1)(d); Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(d): (3); 76-5-402.1; 76-5-402.3; 76-5-403.1 except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(d)(i): 76-5-402.1 rape of a child, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(d)(ii): 76-5-402.3 object rape of a child, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(d)(iii): 76-5-403.1 sodomy on a child, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(e): a second degree felony is a third degree felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(f): a third degree felony is a class A misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(g): a class A misdemeanor is a class B misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(h): a class B misdemeanor is a class C misdemeanor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(1)(i): a class C misdemeanor is punishable by a penalty not exceeding one half the penalty for a class C misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(2): (1)(a)(ii); (1)(a)(ii) If, when imposing a sentence under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(2)(a): 10 years and which may be for life; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(2)(b): six years and which may be for life.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(3): (1)(d); (1)(d) If, when imposing a sentence under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(3)(a): 10 years and which may be for life;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(3)(b): six years and which may be for life; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-102(3)(c): three years and which may be for life.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-201 Conspiracy -- Elements of offense.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
For purposes of this part a person is guilty of conspiracy when he, intending that conduct constituting a crime be performed, agrees with one or more persons to engage in or cause the performance of the conduct and any one of them commits an overt act in pursuance of the conspiracy, except where the offense is a capital felony, a felony against the person, arson, burglary, or robbery, the overt act is not required for the commission of conspiracy.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-202 Conspiracy -- Classification of offenses.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Conspiracy to commit:Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-202(1): a capital felony is a first degree felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-202(2): 76-5-301.1; Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses a first degree felony is a second degree felony; except that conspiracy to commit child kidnaping, in violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-202(3): a second degree felony is a third degree felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-202(4): a third degree felony is a class A misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-202(5): a class A misdemeanor is a class B misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-202(6): a class B misdemeanor is a class C misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-202(7): A class C misdemeanor is punishable by a penalty not exceeding one half the penalty for a class C misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-203 Criminal solicitation -- Elements.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-203(1): An actor commits criminal solicitation if, with intent that a felony be committed, he solicits, requests, commands, offers to hire, or importunes another person to engage in specific conduct that under the circumstances as the actor believes them to be would be a felony or would cause the other person to be a party to the commission of a felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-203(2): An actor may be convicted under this section only if the solicitation is made under circumstances strongly corroborative of the actor's intent that the offense be committed.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-203(3): It is not a defense under this section that the person solicited by the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-203(3)(a): does not agree to act upon the solicitation;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-203(3)(b): does not commit an overt act;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-203(3)(c): does not engage in conduct constituting a substantial step toward the commission of any offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-203(3)(d): is not criminally responsible for the felony solicited;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-203(3)(e): was acquitted, was not prosecuted or convicted, or was convicted of a different offense or of a different type or degree of offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-203(3)(f): is immune from prosecution.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-203(4): It is not a defense under this section that the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-203(4)(a): belongs to a class of persons that by definition is legally incapable of committing the offense in an individual capacity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-203(4)(b): fails to communicate with the person he solicits to commit an offense, if the intent of the actor's conduct was to effect the communication.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-203(5): 76-2-202 Nothing in this section prevents an actor who otherwise solicits, requests, commands, encourages, or intentionally aids another person to engage in conduct which constitutes an offense from being prosecuted and convicted as a party to the offense under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204 Criminal solicitation -- Penalties.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(1): (1)(c); (d); 76-5-203(2)(a); 76-5-301.1; (1)(d); Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; (2); 76-5-402.1; 76-5-402.3; 76-5-403.1 Criminal solicitation to commit:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(1)(a): a capital felony, or a felony punishable by imprisonment for life without parole, is a first degree felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(1)(b): (1)(c); (d) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(1)(c): 76-5-203(2)(a); 76-5-301.1; (1)(d); Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses any of the following offenses is a first degree felony punishable by imprisonment for an indeterminate term of not fewer than three years and which may be for life:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(1)(c)(i): 76-5-203(2)(a) murder, Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(1)(c)(ii): 76-5-301.1 child kidnapping, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(1)(c)(iii): (1)(d); Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(1)(d): (2); 76-5-402.1; 76-5-402.3; 76-5-403.1 except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(1)(d)(i): 76-5-402.1 rape of a child, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(1)(d)(ii): 76-5-402.3 object rape of a child, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(1)(d)(iii): 76-5-403.1 sodomy on a child, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(1)(e): a second degree felony is a third degree felony; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(1)(f): a third degree felony is a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(2): (1)(d); (1)(d) If, when imposing a sentence under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(2)(a): 10 years and which may be for life;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(2)(b): six years and which may be for life; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-204(2)(c): three years and which may be for life.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-301 Specific attempt or conspiracy offense prevails.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Whenever any offense specifically designates or defines an attempt or conspiracy and provides a penalty for the attempt or conspiracy other than provided in this chapter, the specific offense shall prevail over the provisions of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-302 Conviction of inchoate and principal offense or attempt and conspiracy to commit offense prohibited.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
No person shall be convicted of both an inchoate and principal offense or of both an attempt to commit an offense and a conspiracy to commit the same offense.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401 Enticing a minor -- Elements -- Penalties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(1): 76-9-201; 76-9-201; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(1)(a): 76-9-201; 76-9-201 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(1)(a)(i): "Minor" means an individual who is under 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(1)(a)(ii): 76-9-201 "Electronic communication" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(1)(a)(iii): 76-9-201 "Electronic communication device" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(2): (2)(a)(ii)(A) An actor commits enticement of a minor if the actor knowingly:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(2)(a): (2)(a)(ii)(A) uses an electronic communication or an electronic communication device to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(2)(a)(i): solicit, seduce, lure, or entice a minor, or to attempt to solicit, seduce, lure, or entice a minor, or another person that the actor believes to be a minor, to engage in sexual activity that is a violation of state criminal law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(2)(a)(ii): (2)(a)(ii)(A)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(2)(a)(ii)(A): initiate contact with a minor or a person the actor believes to be a minor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(2)(a)(ii)(B): (2)(a)(ii)(A) subsequent to the action described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(2)(b): develops a relationship of trust with the minor or the minor's parent or guardian with the intent to solicit, seduce, lure, or entice, or attempt to solicit, seduce, lure, or entice the minor to engage in sexual activity that is a violation of state criminal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(3): (2) It is not a defense to the crime of enticing a minor under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(4): (2); (4)(a); (4)(a) Enticement of a minor under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(4)(a): (4)(a); (4)(a) enticement to engage in sexual activity that would be a first degree felony for the actor is a:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(4)(a)(i): (4)(a) second degree felony upon the first conviction for violation of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(4)(a)(ii): (4)(a) first degree felony punishable by imprisonment for an indeterminate term of not fewer than three years and which may be for life, upon a second or any subsequent conviction for a violation of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(4)(b): enticement to engage in sexual activity that would be a second degree felony for the actor is a third degree felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(4)(c): enticement to engage in sexual activity that would be a third degree felony for the actor is a class A misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(4)(d): enticement to engage in sexual activity that would be a class A misdemeanor for the actor is a class B misdemeanor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(4)(e): enticement to engage in sexual activity that would be a class B misdemeanor for the actor is a class C misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(5): (5)(b); (5)(a); 76-4-401; 76-5-301.1; 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-402.2; 76-5-402.3; 76-5-403; 76-5-403.1; 76-5-404; 76-5-404.1; 76-5-404.3; 76-5-405; 76-5-308.5; (5)(b)(i); (xii); (5)(b)(i); (xiii)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(5)(a): (5)(b) When an actor who commits a felony violation of this section has been previously convicted of an offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(5)(a)(i): grant probation;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(5)(a)(ii): suspend the execution or imposition of the sentence;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(5)(a)(iii): enter a judgment for a lower category of offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(5)(a)(iv): order hospitalization.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(5)(b): (5)(a); 76-4-401; 76-5-301.1; 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-402.2; 76-5-402.3; 76-5-403; 76-5-403.1; 76-5-404; 76-5-404.1; 76-5-404.3; 76-5-405; 76-5-308.5; (5)(b)(i); (xii); (5)(b)(i); (xiii) The sections referred to in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(5)(b)(vii): 76-5-403 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(5)(b)(viii): 76-5-403.1 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(5)(b)(ix): 76-5-404 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(5)(b)(x): 76-5-404.1; 76-5-404.3 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(5)(b)(xi): 76-5-405 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(5)(b)(xii): 76-5-308.5 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(5)(b)(xiii): (5)(b)(i); (xii) any offense in any other state or federal jurisdiction that constitutes or would constitute a crime in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-4-401(5)(b)(xiv): (5)(b)(i); (xiii) the attempt, solicitation, or conspiracy to commit any of the offenses in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated - Title 76 - Chapter 5 - Offenses Against the Individual
****************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-101 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
Unless otherwise provided, as used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-101(1): 77-7-15 "Detained individual" means an individual detained under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-101(2): "Prisoner" means an individual who is in custody of a peace officer pursuant to a lawful arrest or who is confined in a jail or other penal institution or a facility used for confinement of delinquent juveniles operated by the Division of Juvenile Justice Services regardless of whether the confinement is legal.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102 Assault -- Penalties.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102(2): An actor commits assault if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102(2)(a): attempts, with unlawful force or violence, to inflict bodily injury on an individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102(2)(b): commits an act, with unlawful force or violence, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102(2)(b)(i): causes bodily injury to an individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102(2)(b)(ii): creates a substantial risk of bodily injury to an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102(3): (2); (3)(a); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102(3)(b): (3)(a); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102(3)(b)(i): the actor causes substantial bodily injury to an individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102(3)(b)(ii): the individual is pregnant and the actor has knowledge of the pregnancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102(4): The fact that the actor caused serious bodily injury to an individual is not a defense to a violation of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1 Negligently operating a vehicle resulting in injury.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(1): 58-37-2; 76-5-207; 76-5-207; 41-6a-501; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(1)(a): 58-37-2; 76-5-207; 76-5-207; 41-6a-501 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(1)(a)(i): 58-37-2 "Controlled substance" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(1)(a)(ii): 76-5-207 "Drug" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(1)(a)(iii): 76-5-207 "Negligent" or "negligence" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(1)(a)(iv): 41-6a-501 "Vehicle" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(2): An actor commits negligently operating a vehicle resulting in injury if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(2)(a)(i): operates a vehicle in a negligent manner causing bodily injury to another; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(2)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(2)(a)(ii)(A): has sufficient alcohol in the actor's body such that a subsequent chemical test shows that the actor has a blood or breath alcohol concentration of .05 grams or greater at the time of the test;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(2)(a)(ii)(B): is under the influence of alcohol, a drug, or the combined influence of alcohol and a drug to a degree that renders the actor incapable of safely operating a vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(2)(a)(ii)(C): has a blood or breath alcohol concentration of .05 grams or greater at the time of operation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(2)(b)(i): operates a vehicle in a criminally negligent manner causing bodily injury to another; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(2)(b)(ii): has in the actor's body any measurable amount of a controlled substance.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(3): (4); (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(3)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(3)(a)(i): a class A misdemeanor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(3)(a)(ii): a third degree felony if the bodily injury is serious bodily injury; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(3)(b): a separate offense for each victim suffering bodily injury as a result of the actor's violation of this section, regardless of whether the injuries arise from the same episode of driving.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(4): (2)(b); Title 58, Occupations and Professions; 58-37-4.2; 58-37-6 An actor is not guilty of negligently operating a vehicle resulting in injury under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(4)(a): Title 58, Occupations and Professions the controlled substance was obtained under a valid prescription or order, directly from a practitioner while acting in the course of the practitioner's professional practice, or as otherwise authorized by
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(4)(b): the controlled substance is 11-nor-9-carboxy-tetrahydrocannabinol; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(4)(c): 58-37-4.2; 58-37-6 the actor possessed, in the actor's body, a controlled substance listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(4)(c)(i): 58-37-6 the actor is the subject of medical research conducted by a holder of a valid license to possess controlled substances under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(4)(c)(ii): the substance was administered to the actor by the medical researcher.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(5): 63M-7-404; 41-6a-505; 41-6a-515; 41-6a-516; 41-6a-502(3); (4); 77-2a-3(8)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(5)(a): 63M-7-404 A judge imposing a sentence under this section may consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(5)(a)(i): 63M-7-404 the sentencing guidelines developed in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(5)(a)(ii): the defendant's history;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(5)(a)(iii): the facts of the case;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(5)(a)(iv): aggravating and mitigating factors; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(5)(a)(v): any other relevant fact.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(5)(b): 41-6a-505 The judge may not impose a lesser sentence than would be required for a conviction based on the defendant's history under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(5)(c): 41-6a-515; 41-6a-516 The standards for chemical breath analysis under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(5)(d): 41-6a-502(3) A calculation of blood or breath alcohol concentration under this section shall be made in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(5)(e): (4) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(5)(f): Evidence of a defendant's blood or breath alcohol content or drug content is admissible except if prohibited by the Utah Rules of Evidence, the United States Constitution, or the Utah Constitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.1(5)(g): 77-2a-3(8) In accordance with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.3 Assault or threat of violence against a school employee.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.3(1): 76-5-102; 76-5-107; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.3(1)(a): 76-5-102; 76-5-107 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.3(1)(a)(i): 76-5-102 "Assault" means an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.3(1)(a)(ii): "Employee" includes a volunteer.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.3(1)(a)(iii): 76-5-107 "Threat of violence" means an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.3(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.3(2): An actor commits assault or threat of violence against a school employee if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.3(2)(a): the actor commits assault or a threat of violence against an employee of a public or private school;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.3(2)(b): the actor has knowledge that the individual is an employee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.3(2)(c): the employee is acting within the scope of the employee's authority as an employee.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.3(3): (2) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4 Assault against peace officer or a military service member in uniform -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(1): 76-5-102; 39A-3-103; 53-13-103; 53-13-104; 53-13-105; 53-13-106; 76-5-107; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(1)(a): 76-5-102; 39A-3-103; 53-13-103; 53-13-104; 53-13-105; 53-13-106; 76-5-107 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(1)(a)(i): 76-5-102 "Assault" means an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(1)(a)(ii): 39A-3-103 "Military service member in uniform" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(1)(a)(ii)(A): a member of any branch of the United States military who is wearing a uniform as authorized by the member's branch of service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(1)(a)(ii)(B): 39A-3-103 a member of the National Guard serving as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(1)(a)(iii): 53-13-103; 53-13-104; 53-13-105; 53-13-106 "Peace officer" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(1)(a)(iii)(A): 53-13-103 a law enforcement officer certified under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(1)(a)(iii)(B): 53-13-104 a correctional officer under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(1)(a)(iii)(C): 53-13-105 a special function officer under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(1)(a)(iii)(D): 53-13-106 a federal officer under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(1)(a)(iv): 76-5-107 "Threat of violence" means an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(2)(a): An actor commits assault against a peace officer if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(2)(a)(i): the actor commits an assault or threat of violence against a peace officer, with knowledge that the peace officer is a peace officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(2)(a)(ii): at the time of the assault or threat of violence, the peace officer was acting within the scope of authority as a peace officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(2)(b): An actor commits an assault or threat of violence against a military service member in uniform if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(2)(b)(i): the actor commits an assault or threat of violence against a military service member in uniform; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(2)(b)(ii): at the time of the assault or threat of violence, the service member was on orders and acting within the scope of authority granted to the military service member in uniform.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(3): (2); (3)(a); (2); (3)(a); (b); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(3)(b): (3)(a); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(3)(b)(i): has been previously convicted of a class A misdemeanor or a felony violation of this section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(3)(b)(ii): causes substantial bodily injury.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(3)(c): (3)(a); (b); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(3)(c)(i): a dangerous weapon; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(3)(c)(ii): other means or force likely to produce death or serious bodily injury.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(4): This section does not affect or limit any individual's constitutional right to the lawful expression of free speech, the right of assembly, or any other recognized rights secured by the Utah Constitution or laws, or by the United States Constitution or federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(5): An actor who violates this section shall serve, in jail or another correctional facility, a minimum of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(5)(a): 90 consecutive days for a second offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(5)(b): 180 consecutive days for each subsequent offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.4(6): (5) The court may suspend the imposition or execution of the sentence required under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.5 Assault by prisoner.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.5(1): 76-5-102; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.5(1)(a): 76-5-102 As used in this section, "assault" means an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.5(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.5(2): An actor commits assault by prisoner if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.5(2)(a): is a prisoner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.5(2)(b): intending to cause bodily injury, commits an assault.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.5(3): (2) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6 Propelling object or substance at a correctional or peace officer -- Penalties.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(1): 26B-7-201; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(1)(a): 26B-7-201 As used in this section, "infectious agent" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(2): An actor commits the offense of propelling an object or substance at a correctional or peace officer if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(2)(a): is a prisoner or a detained individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(2)(b): throws or otherwise propels an object or substance at a peace officer, a correctional officer, or an employee or volunteer, including a health care provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(3): (2); (3)(a); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(3)(b): (3)(a); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(3)(b)(i): the object or substance causes substantial bodily injury to the peace officer, the correctional officer, or the employee or volunteer, including a health care provider; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(3)(b)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(3)(b)(ii)(A): the object or substance is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(3)(b)(ii)(A)(I): blood, urine, semen, or fecal material;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(3)(b)(ii)(A)(II): an infectious agent or a material that carries an infectious agent;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(3)(b)(ii)(A)(III): vomit or a material that carries vomit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(3)(b)(ii)(A)(IV): the actor's saliva, and the actor knows the actor is infected with HIV, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(3)(b)(ii)(B): the object or substance comes into contact with any portion of the officer's, employee's, volunteer's, or health care provider's face, including the eyes or mouth, or comes into contact with any open wound on the officer's, employee's, volunteer's, or health care provider's body.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.6(4): If an offense committed under this section amounts to an offense subject to a greater penalty under another provision of state law than under this section, this section does not prohibit prosecution and sentencing for the more serious offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7 Assault or threat of violence against health care provider, emergency medical service worker, or health facility employee, owner, or contractor -- Penalty.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(1): 76-5-102; 26B-4-116; 78B-3-403; 26B-2-201; 76-5-107; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(1)(a): 76-5-102; 26B-4-116; 78B-3-403; 26B-2-201; 76-5-107 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(1)(a)(i): 76-5-102 "Assault" means an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(1)(a)(ii): 26B-4-116 "Emergency medical service worker" means an individual licensed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(1)(a)(iii): 78B-3-403 "Health care provider" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(1)(a)(iv): 26B-2-201 "Health facility" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(1)(a)(iv)(A): 26B-2-201 a health care facility as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(1)(a)(iv)(B): the office of a private health care provider, whether for individual or group practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(1)(a)(v): "Health facility employee" means an employee, owner, or contractor of a health facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(1)(a)(vi): 76-5-107 "Threat of violence" means an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(2)(a): An actor commits assault or threat of violence against a health care provider or emergency medical service worker if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(2)(a)(i): the actor is not a prisoner or a detained individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(2)(a)(ii): the actor commits an assault or threat of violence;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(2)(a)(iii): the actor knew that the victim was a health care provider or emergency medical service worker; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(2)(a)(iv): the health care provider or emergency medical service worker was performing emergency or lifesaving duties within the scope of his or her authority at the time of the assault or threat of violence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(2)(b): An actor commits assault or threat of violence against a health facility employee if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(2)(b)(i): the actor is not a prisoner or a detained individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(2)(b)(ii): the actor commits an assault or threat of violence;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(2)(b)(iii): the actor knew that the victim was a health facility employee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(2)(b)(iv): the health facility employee was acting within the scope of the health facility employee's duties for the health facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(3): (2); (3)(a); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(3)(b): (3)(a); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(3)(b)(i): causes substantial bodily injury; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.7(3)(b)(ii): acts intentionally or knowingly.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.8 Disarming a peace officer -- Penalties.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.8(1): 76-10-501; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.8(1)(a): 76-10-501 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.8(1)(a)(i): "Conductive energy device" means a weapon that uses electrical current to disrupt voluntary control of muscles.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.8(1)(a)(ii): 76-10-501 "Firearm" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.8(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.8(2): An actor commits disarming a peace officer if the actor intentionally takes or removes, or attempts to take or remove a firearm or a conductive energy device from an individual or immediate presence of an individual who the actor knows is a peace officer:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.8(2)(a): without the consent of the peace officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.8(2)(b): while the peace officer is acting within the scope of the peace officer's authority as a peace officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.8(3): (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.8(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.8(3)(b): (2) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.9 Propelling a bodily substance or material -- Penalties.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.9(1): 26B-7-201; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.9(1)(a): 26B-7-201 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.9(1)(a)(i): "Bodily substance or material" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.9(1)(a)(i)(A): saliva, blood, urine, semen, or fecal material;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.9(1)(a)(i)(B): an infectious agent or a material that carries an infectious agent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.9(1)(a)(i)(C): vomit or a material that carries vomit.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.9(1)(a)(ii): 26B-7-201 "Infectious agent" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.9(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.9(2): An actor commits propelling a bodily substance or material if the actor knowingly or intentionally throws or otherwise propels a bodily substance or material at another individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.9(3): (2); (3)(a); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.9(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.9(3)(b): (3)(a); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.9(3)(b)(i): the bodily substance or material is the actor's saliva and the actor knows the actor is infected with HIV, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.9(3)(b)(ii): the bodily substance or material comes into contact with any portion of the other individual's face, including the eyes or mouth, or comes into contact with any open wound on the other individual's body.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-102.9(4): If an offense committed under this section amounts to an offense subject to a greater penalty under another provision of state law than under this section, this section does not prohibit prosecution and sentencing for the more serious offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103 Aggravated assault -- Penalties.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(1): 76-5-202; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(1)(a): 76-5-202 As used in this section, "targeting a law enforcement officer" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(2): (2)(a) An actor commits aggravated assault if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(2)(a)(i): attempts, with unlawful force or violence, to do bodily injury to another;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(2)(a)(ii): makes a threat, accompanied by a show of immediate force or violence, to do bodily injury to another; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(2)(a)(iii): commits an act, committed with unlawful force or violence, that causes bodily injury to another or creates a substantial risk of bodily injury to another; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(2)(b): (2)(a) includes in the actor's conduct under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(2)(b)(i): a dangerous weapon;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(2)(b)(ii): any act that impedes the breathing or the circulation of blood of another individual by the actor's use of unlawful force or violence that is likely to produce a loss of consciousness by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(2)(b)(ii)(A): applying pressure to the neck or throat of an individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(2)(b)(ii)(B): obstructing the nose, mouth, or airway of an individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(2)(b)(iii): other means or force likely to produce death or serious bodily injury.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(3): (2); (3)(a); (2); (2); (3)(a); (b); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(3)(b): (3)(a); (2); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(3)(b)(i): the act results in serious bodily injury; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(3)(b)(ii): (2) an act under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103(3)(c): (3)(a); (b); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103.5 Aggravated assault by prisoner.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103.5(1): 76-5-103; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103.5(1)(a): 76-5-103 As used in this section, "aggravated assault" means an offense under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-103.5(2)(b): commits aggravated assault.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-104 Consensual altercation.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-104(1): 76-9-705 As used in this section, "ultimate fighting match" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-104(2): Part 2, Criminal Homicide; 76-5-102 In any prosecution for criminal homicide under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-104(2)(a): any dangerous weapon was used; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-104(2)(b): the defendant was engaged in an ultimate fighting match.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-105 Mayhem.
--------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-105(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-105(2): An actor commits mayhem if the actor unlawfully and intentionally:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-105(2)(a): deprives an individual of a member of the individual's body;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-105(2)(b): disables or renders useless a member of an individual's body;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-105(2)(c): cuts out or disables an individual's tongue;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-105(2)(d): puts out an individual's eye; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-105(2)(e): slits an individual's nose, ear, or lip.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-105(3): (2) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106 Harassment.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106(2): An actor commits harassment if, with intent to frighten or harass another, the actor communicates a written or recorded threat to commit a violent felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106(3): (2) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5 Stalking -- Definitions -- Injunction -- Penalties -- Duties of law enforcement officer.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1): 76-9-408; (2); 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a): 76-9-408; (2) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(i): "Course of conduct" means two or more acts directed at or toward a specific individual, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(i)(A): acts in which the actor follows, monitors, observes, photographs, surveils, threatens, or communicates to or about an individual, or interferes with an individual's property:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(i)(A)(I): directly, indirectly, or through any third party; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(i)(A)(II): by any action, method, device, or means; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(i)(B): when the actor engages in any of the following acts or causes someone else to engage in any of these acts:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(i)(B)(I): approaches or confronts an individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(i)(B)(II): appears at the individual's workplace or contacts the individual's employer or coworker;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(i)(B)(III): appears at an individual's residence or contacts an individual's neighbor, or enters property owned, leased, or occupied by an individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(i)(B)(IV): sends material by any means to the individual or for the purpose of obtaining or disseminating information about or communicating with the individual to a member of the individual's family or household, employer, coworker, friend, or associate of the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(i)(B)(V): places an object on or delivers an object to property owned, leased, or occupied by an individual, or to the individual's place of employment with the intent that the object be delivered to the individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(i)(B)(VI): uses a computer, the Internet, text messaging, or any other electronic means to commit an act that is a part of the course of conduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(ii)(A): "Emotional distress" means significant mental or psychological suffering, whether or not medical or other professional treatment or counseling is required.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(ii)(B): "Emotional distress" includes significant mental or psychological suffering resulting from harm to an animal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(iii): "Immediate family" means a spouse, parent, child, sibling, or any other individual who regularly resides in the household or who regularly resided in the household within the prior six months.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(iv): 76-9-408 "Private investigator" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(v): "Reasonable person" means a reasonable person in the victim's circumstances.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(vi): (2) "Stalking" means an offense as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(a)(vii): "Text messaging" means a communication in the form of electronic text or one or more electronic images sent by the actor from a telephone or computer to another individual's telephone or computer by addressing the communication to the recipient's telephone number.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(2): Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 7, Civil Stalking Injunctions; Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 9, Criminal Stalking Injunctions An actor commits stalking if the actor intentionally or knowingly:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(2)(a): engages in a course of conduct directed at a specific individual and knows or should know that the course of conduct would cause a reasonable person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(2)(a)(i): to fear for the individual's own safety or the safety of a third individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(2)(a)(ii): to suffer other emotional distress; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(2)(b): Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 7, Civil Stalking Injunctions; Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 9, Criminal Stalking Injunctions violates:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(2)(b)(i): Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 7, Civil Stalking Injunctions a stalking injunction issued under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(2)(b)(ii): Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 9, Criminal Stalking Injunctions a permanent criminal stalking injunction issued under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3): (2); (2); Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 7, Civil Stalking Injunctions; (3)(a); (2); Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 9, Criminal Stalking Injunctions; 78B-7-102; (3)(a); (b); (2); (3)(b)(i); (ii); (iii); (3)(b)(iv); (v)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3)(a): (2); (2); Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 7, Civil Stalking Injunctions A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3)(a)(i): (2) upon the actor's first violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3)(a)(ii): Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 7, Civil Stalking Injunctions if the actor violated a stalking injunction issued under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3)(b): (3)(a); (2); Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 9, Criminal Stalking Injunctions; 78B-7-102 Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3)(b)(i): has been previously convicted of an offense of stalking;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3)(b)(ii): has been previously convicted in another jurisdiction of an offense that is substantially similar to the offense of stalking;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3)(b)(iii): has been previously convicted of any felony offense in Utah or of any crime in another jurisdiction which if committed in Utah would be a felony, in which the victim of the stalking offense or a member of the victim's immediate family was also a victim of the previous felony offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3)(b)(iv): Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 9, Criminal Stalking Injunctions violated a permanent criminal stalking injunction issued under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3)(b)(v): 78B-7-102 has been or is at the time of the offense a cohabitant, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3)(c): (3)(a); (b); (2); (3)(b)(i); (ii); (iii); (3)(b)(iv); (v) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3)(c)(i): used a dangerous weapon or used other means or force likely to produce death or serious bodily injury, in the commission of the crime of stalking;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3)(c)(ii): has been previously convicted two or more times of the offense of stalking;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3)(c)(iii): has been convicted two or more times in another jurisdiction or jurisdictions of offenses that are substantially similar to the offense of stalking;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3)(c)(iv): (3)(b)(i); (ii); (iii) has been convicted two or more times, in any combination, of offenses under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3)(c)(v): has been previously convicted two or more times of felony offenses in Utah or of crimes in another jurisdiction or jurisdictions which, if committed in Utah, would be felonies, in which the victim of the stalking was also a victim of the previous felony offenses; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(3)(c)(vi): (3)(b)(iv); (v) has been previously convicted of an offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(4): In a prosecution under this section, it is not a defense that the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(4)(a): was not given actual notice that the course of conduct was unwanted; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(4)(b): did not intend to cause the victim fear or other emotional distress.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(5): An offense of stalking may be prosecuted under this section in any jurisdiction where one or more of the acts that is part of the course of conduct was initiated or caused an effect on the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(6): (6)(b); 53-9-118
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(6)(a): (6)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(6)(a)(i): in the actor's official capacity as a law enforcement officer, governmental investigator, or private investigator; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(6)(a)(ii): for a legitimate official or business purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(6)(b): 53-9-118 A private investigator is not exempt from this section if the private investigator engages in conduct that would constitute a ground for disciplinary action under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(7): 78B-7-902; Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 7, Civil Stalking Injunctions; Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 9, Criminal Stalking Injunctions
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(7)(a): 78B-7-902 A permanent criminal stalking injunction limiting the contact between the actor and victim may be filed in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(7)(b): Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 7, Civil Stalking Injunctions; Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 9, Criminal Stalking Injunctions This section does not preclude the filing of criminal information for stalking based on the same act which is the basis for the violation of the stalking injunction issued under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(8): (8); Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 7, Civil Stalking Injunctions; (8)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(8)(a): (8) A law enforcement officer who responds to an allegation of stalking shall use all reasonable means to protect the victim and prevent further violence, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(8)(a)(i): taking action that, in the officer's discretion, is reasonably necessary to provide for the safety of the victim and any family or household member;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(8)(a)(ii): confiscating the weapon or weapons involved in the alleged stalking;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(8)(a)(iii): making arrangements for the victim and any child to obtain emergency housing or shelter;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(8)(a)(iv): providing protection while the victim removes essential personal effects;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(8)(a)(v): arranging, facilitating, or providing for the victim and any child to obtain medical treatment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(8)(a)(vi): (8) arranging, facilitating, or providing the victim with immediate and adequate notice of the rights of victims and of the remedies and services available to victims of stalking, in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(8)(b): Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 7, Civil Stalking Injunctions
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(8)(b)(i): Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 7, Civil Stalking Injunctions A law enforcement officer shall give written notice to the victim in simple language, describing the rights and remedies available under this section and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(8)(b)(ii): The written notice shall also include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(8)(b)(ii)(A): a statement that the forms needed in order to obtain a stalking injunction are available from the court clerk's office in the judicial district where the victim resides or is temporarily domiciled; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(8)(b)(ii)(B): a list of shelters, services, and resources available in the appropriate community, together with telephone numbers, to assist the victim in accessing any needed assistance.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-106.5(8)(c): (8) If a weapon is confiscated under this Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107 Threat of violence -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107(2)(a): An actor commits a threat of violence if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107(2)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107(2)(a)(i)(A): threatens to commit an offense involving bodily injury, death, or substantial property damage; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107(2)(a)(i)(B): acts with intent to place an individual in fear of imminent serious bodily injury, substantial bodily injury, or death; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107(2)(a)(ii): makes a threat, accompanied by a show of immediate force or violence, to do bodily injury to an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107(2)(b): A threat under this section may be express or implied.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107(3): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107(3)(b): An actor who commits an offense under this section is subject to punishment for that offense, in addition to any other offense committed, including the carrying out of the threatened act.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107(3)(c): In addition to any other penalty authorized by law, a court shall order an actor convicted of a violation of this section to reimburse any federal, state, or local unit of government, or any private business, organization, individual, or entity for all expenses and losses incurred in responding to the violation, unless the court states on the record the reasons why the reimbursement would be inappropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107(4): It is not a defense under this section that the actor did not attempt to or was incapable of carrying out the threat.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1 Threats against schools.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(1): 76-10-401; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(1)(a): 76-10-401 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(1)(a)(i): 76-10-401 "Hoax weapon of mass destruction" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(1)(a)(ii): "School" means a preschool or a public or private elementary or secondary school.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(2): An actor is guilty of making a threat against a school if the actor threatens in person or via electronic means, either with real intent or as an intentional hoax, to commit any offense involving bodily injury, death, or substantial property damage and the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(2)(a): threatens the use of a firearm or weapon or hoax weapon of mass destruction;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(2)(b): acts with intent to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(2)(b)(i): disrupt the regular schedule of the school or influence or affect the conduct of students, employees, or the general public at the school;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(2)(b)(ii): prevent or interrupt the occupancy of the school or a portion of the school, or a facility or vehicle used by the school; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(2)(b)(iii): intimidate or coerce students or employees of the school; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(2)(c): causes an official or volunteer agency organized to deal with emergencies to take action due to the risk to the school or general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(3): (2)(a); (b)(i); (b)(iii); (2)(b)(ii); (2)(c); 80-6-710
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(3)(a): (2)(a); (b)(i); (b)(iii); (2)(b)(ii); (2)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(3)(a)(i): (2)(a); (b)(i); (b)(iii) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(3)(a)(ii): (2)(b)(ii) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(3)(a)(iii): (2)(c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(3)(b): 80-6-710
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(3)(b)(i): In addition to any other penalty authorized by law, a court shall order an actor convicted of a violation of this section to pay restitution to any federal, state, or local unit of government, or any private business, organization, individual, or entity for expenses and losses incurred in responding to the threat, unless the court states on the record the reasons why the reimbursement would be inappropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(3)(b)(ii): 80-6-710 Restitution ordered in the case of a minor adjudicated for a violation of this section shall be determined in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(4): It is not a defense to this section that the actor did not attempt to carry out or was incapable of carrying out the threat.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(5)(a): A violation of this section shall be reported to the local law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(5)(b): If the actor alleged to have violated this section is a minor, the minor may be referred to the juvenile court.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.1(6): Counseling for the minor and the minor's family may be made available through state and local health department programs.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3 Threat of terrorism -- Penalty.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(1): 76-10-401; 76-10-401; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(1)(a): 76-10-401; 76-10-401 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(1)(a)(i): 76-10-401 "Hoax weapon of mass destruction" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(1)(a)(ii): 76-10-401 "Weapon of mass destruction" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(2)(a): An actor commits a threat of terrorism if the actor threatens to commit an offense involving bodily injury, death, or substantial property damage and the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(2)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(2)(a)(i)(A): threatens the use of a weapon of mass destruction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(2)(a)(i)(B): threatens the use of a hoax weapon of mass destruction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(2)(a)(ii): acts with intent to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(2)(a)(ii)(A): intimidate or coerce a civilian population or to influence or affect the conduct of a government or a unit of government;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(2)(a)(ii)(B): prevent or interrupt the occupation of a building or a portion of the building, a place to which the public has access, or a facility or vehicle of public transportation operated by a common carrier; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(2)(a)(ii)(C): cause an official or volunteer agency organized to deal with emergencies to take action due to the actor's conduct posing a serious and substantial risk to the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(2)(b): A threat under this section may be express or implied.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(3): (2)(a)(i); (2)(a)(ii)(A); (2)(a)(ii)(B); (2)(a)(ii)(C)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(3)(a): (2)(a)(i); (2)(a)(ii)(A); (2)(a)(ii)(B); (2)(a)(ii)(C)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(3)(a)(i): (2)(a)(i); (2)(a)(ii)(A) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(3)(a)(ii): (2)(a)(ii)(B) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(3)(a)(iii): (2)(a)(ii)(C) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(3)(b): An actor who commits an offense under this section is subject to punishment for that offense, in addition to any other offense committed, including the carrying out of the threatened act.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(3)(c): In addition to any other penalty authorized by law, a court shall order an actor convicted of a violation of this section to reimburse any federal, state, or local unit of government, or any private business, organization, individual, or entity for all expenses and losses incurred in responding to the violation, unless the court states on the record the reasons why the reimbursement would be inappropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.3(4): It is not a defense under this section that the actor did not attempt to carry out or was incapable of carrying out the threat.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5 Prohibition of "hazing" -- Definitions -- Penalties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(2): An actor commits hazing if the actor intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly commits an act or causes another to commit an act that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(2)(a)(i): endangers the mental or physical health or safety of an individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(2)(a)(ii): involves any brutality of a physical nature such as whipping, beating, branding, calisthenics, bruising, electric shocking, placing of a harmful substance on the body, or exposure to the elements;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(2)(a)(iii): involves consumption of any food, alcoholic product, drug, or other substance or any other physical activity that endangers the mental or physical health and safety of an individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(2)(a)(iv): involves any activity that would subject the individual to extreme mental stress, such as sleep deprivation, extended isolation from social contact, or conduct that subjects another to extreme embarrassment, shame, or humiliation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(2)(b)(i): is for the purpose of initiation, admission into, affiliation with, holding office in, or as a condition for continued membership in any organization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(2)(b)(ii): if the actor knew that the individual is a member of or candidate for membership with a school team or school organization to which the actor belongs or did belong within the preceding two years.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(3): (2); (3)(a); (2); 32B-1-102; 76-5-113; (3)(a); (b); (2); (3)(a); (b); (c); (2); (3)(a); (b); (c); (d); (2); (3)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(3)(b): (3)(a); (2); 32B-1-102; 76-5-113 Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(3)(b)(i): the operation or other use of a motor vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(3)(b)(ii): 32B-1-102 the consumption of an alcoholic product as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(3)(b)(iii): 76-5-113 the consumption of a drug or a substance as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(3)(c): (3)(a); (b); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(3)(d): (3)(a); (b); (c); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(3)(e): (3)(a); (b); (c); (d); (2); (3)(d) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(4)(a): A person who in good faith reports or participates in reporting of an alleged hazing is not subject to any civil or criminal liability regarding the reporting.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(4)(b): It is not a defense to prosecution of hazing that an individual under 21 years old, against whom the hazing was directed, consented to or acquiesced in the hazing activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(5): Title 39A, Chapter 5, Utah Code of Military Justice
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(5)(a): This section does not apply to military training or other official military activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(5)(b): Title 39A, Chapter 5, Utah Code of Military Justice Military conduct is governed by
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(6): (6)(a)(i); (6)(a)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(6)(a): A prosecution under this section does not bar a prosecution of the actor for:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(6)(a)(i): any other offense for which the actor may be liable as a party for conduct committed by the individual hazed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(6)(a)(ii): any offense, caused in the course of the hazing, that the actor commits against the individual hazed.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(6)(b): (6)(a)(i) Under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-107.5(6)(c): (6)(a)(ii) Under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-108 Violation of protective order.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-108(2): (2)(a)(i); Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 3, Uniform Interstate Enforcement of Domestic Violence Protection Orders Act; Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 6, Cohabitant Abuse Protective Orders; Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 8, Criminal Protective Orders; Title 80, Utah Juvenile Code An actor commits violation of protective order if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-108(2)(a): (2)(a)(i); Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 3, Uniform Interstate Enforcement of Domestic Violence Protection Orders Act; Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 6, Cohabitant Abuse Protective Orders; Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 8, Criminal Protective Orders; Title 80, Utah Juvenile Code is the respondent or defendant subject to a protective order, child protective order, ex parte protective order, ex parte child protective order, or foreign protection order issued under, or for the purposes of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109 Child abuse.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1): 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(i): "Child" means an individual who is younger than 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(ii): "Physical injury" means an injury to or condition of a child which impairs the physical condition of the child, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(ii)(A): a bruise or other contusion of the skin;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(ii)(B): a minor laceration or abrasion;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(ii)(C): failure to thrive or malnutrition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(ii)(D): any other condition which imperils the child's health or welfare and that is not a serious physical injury.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(A): "Serious physical injury" means any physical injury or set of injuries that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(A)(I): seriously impairs the child's health;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(A)(II): involves physical torture;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(A)(III): causes serious emotional harm to the child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(A)(IV): involves a substantial risk of death to the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(B): "Serious physical injury" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(B)(I): fracture of any bone or bones;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(B)(II): intracranial bleeding, swelling or contusion of the brain, whether caused by blows, shaking, or causing the child's head to impact with an object or surface;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(B)(III): any burn, including burns inflicted by hot water, or those caused by placing a hot object upon the skin or body of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(B)(IV): any injury caused by use of a dangerous weapon;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(B)(V): any combination of two or more physical injuries inflicted by the same person, either at the same time or on different occasions;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(B)(VI): any damage to internal organs of the body;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(B)(VII): any conduct toward a child that results in severe emotional harm, severe developmental delay or intellectual disability, or severe impairment of the child's ability to function;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(B)(VIII): any injury that creates a permanent disfigurement or protracted loss or impairment of the function of a bodily member, limb, or organ;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(B)(IX): any impediment of the breathing or the circulation of blood by application of pressure to the neck, throat, or chest, or by the obstruction of the nose or mouth, that is likely to produce a loss of consciousness;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(B)(X): any conduct that results in starvation or failure to thrive or malnutrition that jeopardizes the child's life; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(a)(iii)(B)(XI): unconsciousness caused by the unlawful infliction of a brain injury or unlawfully causing any deprivation of oxygen to the brain.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(2): An actor commits child abuse if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(2)(a): inflicts upon a child physical injury; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(2)(b): having the care or custody of such child, causes or permits another to inflict physical injury upon a child.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(3): (2); (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(3)(b): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(3)(c): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(4): 76-2-401; (4)(c)(iii)(A); (C)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(4)(a): A parent or legal guardian who provides a child with treatment by spiritual means alone through prayer, in lieu of medical treatment, in accordance with the tenets and practices of an established church or religious denomination of which the parent or legal guardian is a member or adherent may not, for that reason alone, be considered to have committed an offense under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(4)(b): A parent or guardian of a child does not violate this section by selecting a treatment option for a medical condition of the child, if the treatment option is one that a reasonable parent or guardian would believe to be in the best interest of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(4)(c): 76-2-401; (4)(c)(iii)(A); (C) An actor is not guilty of an offense under this section for conduct that constitutes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(4)(c)(i): reasonable discipline or management of a child, including withholding privileges;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(4)(c)(ii): 76-2-401 conduct described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(4)(c)(iii): (4)(c)(iii)(A); (C) the use of reasonable and necessary physical restraint or force on a child:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(4)(c)(iii)(A): in self-defense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(4)(c)(iii)(B): in defense of others;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(4)(c)(iii)(C): to protect the child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109(4)(c)(iii)(D): (4)(c)(iii)(A); (C) to remove a weapon in the possession of a child for any of the reasons described in Subsections

--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109.2(1): 76-5-109; 76-5-109; 76-1-101.5

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109.2(4)(b): A parent or guardian of a child does not violate this section by selecting a treatment option for the medical condition of the child, if the treatment option is one that a reasonable parent or guardian would believe to be in the best interest of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-109.2(4)(c): 76-2-401; (4)(c)(ii)(A); (C) An actor is not guilty of an offense under this section for conduct that constitutes:
