Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110 Abuse or neglect of a child with a disability.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(1): 76-5-109; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(1)(a): 76-5-109 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(1)(a)(i): "Abuse" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(1)(a)(i)(A): inflicting physical injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(1)(a)(i)(B): having the care or custody of a child with a disability, causing or permitting another to inflict physical injury; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(1)(a)(i)(C): unreasonable confinement.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(1)(a)(ii): "Caretaker" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(1)(a)(ii)(A): any parent, legal guardian, or other person having under that person's care and custody a child with a disability; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(1)(a)(ii)(B): any person, corporation, or public institution that has assumed by contract or court order the responsibility to provide food, shelter, clothing, medical, and other necessities to a child with a disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(1)(a)(iii): "Child with a disability" means an individual under 18 years old who is impaired because of mental illness, mental deficiency, physical illness or disability, or other cause, to the extent that the individual is unable to care for the individual's own personal safety or to provide necessities such as food, shelter, clothing, and medical care.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(1)(a)(iv): "Neglect" means failure by a caretaker to provide care, nutrition, clothing, shelter, supervision, or medical care.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(1)(a)(v): 76-5-109 "Physical injury" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(2): An actor commits abuse or neglect of a child with a disability if the actor is a caretaker and intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly abuses or neglects a child with a disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(4): 80-3-109; (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(4)(a): A parent or legal guardian who provides a child with treatment by spiritual means alone through prayer, in lieu of medical treatment, in accordance with the tenets and practices of an established church or religious denomination of which the parent or legal guardian is a member or adherent may not, for that reason alone, be considered to be in violation under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(4)(b): 80-3-109; (4) Subject to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-110(4)(c): A caretaker of a child with a disability does not violate this section by selecting a treatment option for a medical condition of a child with a disability, if the treatment option is one that a reasonable caretaker would believe to be in the best interest of the child with a disability.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111 Abuse of a vulnerable adult -- Penalties.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1): Title 75, Chapter 2a, Advance Health Care Directive Act; 76-5-111.3; 76-5-111.4; 76-5b-202; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a): Title 75, Chapter 2a, Advance Health Care Directive Act; 76-5-111.3; 76-5-111.4; 76-5b-202 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(i): "Abandonment" means a knowing or intentional action or inaction, including desertion, by a person acting as a caretaker for a vulnerable adult that leaves the vulnerable adult without the means or ability to obtain necessary food, clothing, shelter, or medical or other health care.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(ii): Title 75, Chapter 2a, Advance Health Care Directive Act "Abuse" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(ii)(A): attempting to cause harm, intentionally or knowingly causing harm, or intentionally or knowingly placing another in fear of imminent harm;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(ii)(B): causing physical injury by knowing or intentional acts or omissions;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(ii)(C): unreasonable or inappropriate use of physical restraint, medication, or isolation that causes or is likely to cause harm to a vulnerable adult that is in conflict with a physician's orders or used as an unauthorized substitute for treatment, unless that conduct furthers the health and safety of the vulnerable adult; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(ii)(D): Title 75, Chapter 2a, Advance Health Care Directive Act deprivation of life-sustaining treatment, except:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(ii)(D)(I): Title 75, Chapter 2a, Advance Health Care Directive Act as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(ii)(D)(II): when informed consent, as defined in this section, has been obtained.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(iii): "Caretaker" means a person or public institution that is entrusted with or assumes the responsibility to provide a vulnerable adult with care, food, shelter, clothing, supervision, medical or other health care, or other necessities for pecuniary gain, by contract, or as a result of friendship, or in a position of trust and confidence with a vulnerable adult, including a relative, a household member, an attorney-in-fact, a neighbor, a person who is employed or who provides volunteer work, a court-appointed or voluntary guardian, or a person who contracts or is under court order to provide care.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(iv): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(iv)(A): "Dependent adult" means an individual 18 years old or older, who has a physical or mental impairment that restricts the individual's ability to carry out normal activities or to protect the individual's rights.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(iv)(B): "Dependent adult" includes an individual who has physical or developmental disabilities or whose physical or mental capacity has substantially diminished because of age.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(v): "Elder adult" means an individual 65 years old or older.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(vi): 76-5-111.3; 76-5-111.4; 76-5b-202 "Exploitation" means an offense described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(vii): "Harm" means pain, mental anguish, emotional distress, hurt, physical or psychological damage, physical injury, suffering, or distress inflicted knowingly or intentionally.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(viii): "Informed consent" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(viii)(A): a written expression by the individual or authorized by the individual, stating that the individual fully understands the potential risks and benefits of the withdrawal of food, water, medication, medical services, shelter, cooling, heating, or other services necessary to maintain minimum physical or mental health, and that the individual desires that the services be withdrawn, except that a written expression is valid only if the individual is of sound mind when the consent is given, and the consent is witnessed by at least two individuals who do not benefit from the withdrawal of services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(viii)(B): consent to withdraw food, water, medication, medical services, shelter, cooling, heating, or other services necessary to maintain minimum physical or mental health, as permitted by court order.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(ix): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(ix)(A): "Isolation" means knowingly or intentionally preventing a vulnerable adult from having contact with another person, unless the restriction of personal rights is authorized by court order, by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(ix)(A)(I): preventing the vulnerable adult from communicating, visiting, interacting, or initiating interaction with others, including receiving or inviting visitors, mail, or telephone calls, contrary to the express wishes of the vulnerable adult, or communicating to a visitor that the vulnerable adult is not present or does not want to meet with or talk to the visitor, knowing that communication to be false;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(ix)(A)(II): physically restraining the vulnerable adult in order to prevent the vulnerable adult from meeting with a visitor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(ix)(A)(III): making false or misleading statements to the vulnerable adult in order to induce the vulnerable adult to refuse to receive communication from visitors or other family members.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(ix)(B): "Isolation" does not include an act:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(ix)(B)(I): intended in good faith to protect the physical or mental welfare of the vulnerable adult; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(ix)(B)(II): performed pursuant to the treatment plan or instructions of a physician or other professional advisor of the vulnerable adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(x): "Neglect" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(x)(A): failure of a caretaker to provide nutrition, clothing, shelter, supervision, personal care, or dental or other health care, or failure to provide protection from health and safety hazards or maltreatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(x)(B): failure of a caretaker to provide care to a vulnerable adult in a timely manner and with the degree of care that a reasonable person in a like position would exercise;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(x)(C): a pattern of conduct by a caretaker, without the vulnerable adult's informed consent, resulting in deprivation of food, water, medication, health care, shelter, cooling, heating, or other services necessary to maintain the vulnerable adult's well being;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(x)(D): intentional failure by a caretaker to carry out a prescribed treatment plan that results or could result in physical injury or physical harm; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(x)(E): abandonment by a caretaker.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xi): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xi)(A): "Physical injury" includes damage to any bodily tissue caused by nontherapeutic conduct, to the extent that the tissue must undergo a healing process in order to be restored to a sound and healthy condition, or damage to any bodily tissue to the extent that the tissue cannot be restored to a sound and healthy condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xi)(B): "Physical injury" includes skin bruising, a dislocation, physical pain, illness, impairment of physical function, a pressure sore, bleeding, malnutrition, dehydration, a burn, a bone fracture, a subdural hematoma, soft tissue swelling, injury to any internal organ, or any other physical condition that imperils the health or welfare of the vulnerable adult and is not a serious physical injury as defined in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xii): "Position of trust and confidence" means the position of a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xii)(A): is a parent, spouse, adult child, or other relative of a vulnerable adult;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xii)(B): is a joint tenant or tenant in common with a vulnerable adult;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xii)(C): has a legal or fiduciary relationship with a vulnerable adult, including a court-appointed or voluntary guardian, trustee, attorney, attorney-in-fact, or conservator; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xii)(D): is a caretaker of a vulnerable adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xiii): "Serious physical injury" means any physical injury or set of physical injuries that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xiii)(A): seriously impairs a vulnerable adult's health;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xiii)(B): was caused by use of a dangerous weapon;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xiii)(C): involves physical torture or causes serious emotional harm to a vulnerable adult; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xiii)(D): creates a reasonable risk of death.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xiv): "Vulnerable adult" means an elder adult, or a dependent adult who has a mental or physical impairment which substantially affects that individual's ability to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xiv)(A): provide personal protection;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xiv)(B): provide necessities such as food, shelter, clothing, or medical or other health care;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xiv)(C): obtain services necessary for health, safety, or welfare;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xiv)(D): carry out the activities of daily living;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xiv)(E): manage the adult's own resources; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(a)(xiv)(F): comprehend the nature and consequences of remaining in a situation of abuse, neglect, or exploitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(2): An actor, including a caretaker, commits abuse of a vulnerable adult if the actor, under circumstances other than those likely to produce death or serious physical injury:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(2)(a): causes a vulnerable adult to suffer harm, abuse, or neglect;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(2)(b): having the care or custody of a vulnerable adult, causes or permits that vulnerable adult's person or health to be injured, abused, or neglected; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(2)(c): causes or permits a vulnerable adult to be placed in a situation in which the vulnerable adult's person or health is endangered.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(3): (2); (3)(a); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(3)(a)(i): is a class A misdemeanor if done intentionally or knowingly;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(3)(a)(ii): is a class B misdemeanor if done recklessly; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(3)(a)(iii): is a class C misdemeanor if done with criminal negligence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(3)(b): (3)(a); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(4)(a): It does not constitute a defense to a prosecution for a violation of this section that the actor did not know the age of the vulnerable adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(4)(b): An adult is not considered abused, neglected, or a vulnerable adult for the reason that the adult has chosen to rely solely upon religious, nonmedical forms of healing in lieu of medical care.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(5): (3) If an actor, including a caretaker, violates this section by willfully isolating a vulnerable adult, in addition to the penalties under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(5)(a): undergo appropriate counseling as a condition of the sentence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111(5)(b): pay for the costs of the ordered counseling.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2 Aggravated abuse of a vulnerable adult -- Penalties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(1): 76-5-111; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(1)(a): 76-5-111 As used in this section, "abuse," "caretaker," "isolation," "neglect," "serious physical injury," and "vulnerable adult" all mean the same as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(2): An actor, including a caretaker, commits aggravated abuse of a vulnerable adult if the actor, under a circumstance likely to produce death or serious physical injury:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(2)(a): causes a vulnerable adult to suffer serious physical injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(2)(b): having the care or custody of a vulnerable adult, causes or permits the vulnerable adult's person or health to be injured; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(2)(c): causes or permits a vulnerable adult to be placed in a situation in which the vulnerable adult's person or health is endangered.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(3): (2); (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(3)(b): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(3)(c): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(4)(a): It does not constitute a defense to a prosecution for a violation of this section that the actor did not know the age of the vulnerable adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(4)(b): An adult is not considered abused, neglected, or a vulnerable adult for the reason that the adult has chosen to rely solely upon religious, nonmedical forms of healing in lieu of medical care.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(5): (3) If an actor, including a caretaker, violates this section by willfully isolating a vulnerable adult, in addition to the penalties under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(5)(a): undergo appropriate counseling as a condition of the sentence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.2(5)(b): pay for the costs of the ordered counseling.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3 Personal dignity exploitation of a vulnerable adult -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(1): 76-5-111; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(1)(a): 76-5-111 As used in this section, "abuse," "caretaker," "exploitation," "neglect," and "vulnerable adult" all mean the same as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(2): (4) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(2)(a): creates, transmits, or displays a photographic or electronic image or recording of the vulnerable adult:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(2)(a)(i): to which creation, transmission, or display a reasonable person would not consent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(2)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(2)(a)(ii)(A): that shows the vulnerable adult's unclothed breasts, buttocks, anus, genitals, or pubic area;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(2)(a)(ii)(B): that displays the clothed area of only the vulnerable adult's breasts, buttocks, anus, genitals, or pubic area; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(2)(a)(ii)(C): that shows the vulnerable adult engaged in conduct that is harmful to the mental or physical health or safety of the vulnerable adult; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(2)(b): causes the vulnerable adult to participate in an act that is highly offensive or demeaning to the vulnerable adult:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(2)(b)(i): in which a reasonable person would not participate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(2)(b)(ii): that is harmful to the mental or physical health or safety of the vulnerable adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(3): (2); (2); (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(b); (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(3)(a): (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(3)(a)(i): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(3)(a)(ii): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(3)(b): (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(b); (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(3)(b)(i): (2)(a); (2)(a) It is a separate offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(3)(b)(ii): (2)(b); (2)(b) It is a separate offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(4): (2)(a); (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(4)(a): (2)(a) A caretaker does not violate Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(4)(a)(i): with the consent of the vulnerable adult, if the vulnerable adult:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(4)(a)(i)(A): is mentally and physically able to give voluntary consent to the creation, transmission, or display; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(4)(a)(i)(B): gives voluntary consent for the creation, transmission, or display;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(4)(a)(ii): for a legitimate purpose relating to monitoring or providing care, treatment, or diagnosis; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(4)(a)(iii): for a legitimate purpose relating to investigating abuse, neglect, or exploitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(4)(b): (2)(b) A caretaker does not violate Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(4)(b)(i): the vulnerable adult:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(4)(b)(i)(A): is mentally and physically able to give voluntary consent to participate in the act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(4)(b)(i)(B): gives voluntary consent to participate in the act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(4)(b)(ii): the caretaker causes the vulnerable adult to participate in the act for a legitimate purpose relating to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(4)(b)(ii)(A): monitoring or providing care, treatment, or diagnosis; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(4)(b)(ii)(B): investigating abuse, neglect, or exploitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(5): (2)(a); (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(5)(a): (2)(a); (2)(b) It is not a defense that the vulnerable adult was unaware of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(5)(a)(i): (2)(a) the creation, transmission, or display prohibited under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(5)(a)(ii): (2)(b) participation in the act, or the nature of participation in the act, under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.3(5)(b): It does not constitute a defense to a prosecution for a violation of this section that the actor did not know the age of the vulnerable adult.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4 Financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult -- Penalties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1): 76-5-111; 76-5-111; 76-5-111; 76-5-111; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a): 76-5-111; 76-5-111; 76-5-111; 76-5-111 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(i): 76-5-111 "Abuse" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(ii): "Business relationship" means a relationship between two or more individuals or entities where there exists an oral or written agreement for the exchange of goods or services.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(iii): "Deception" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(iii)(A): a misrepresentation or concealment:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(iii)(A)(I): of a material fact relating to services rendered, disposition of property, or use of property intended to benefit a vulnerable adult;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(iii)(A)(II): of the terms of a contract or agreement entered into with a vulnerable adult; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(iii)(A)(III): relating to the existing or preexisting condition of any property involved in a contract or agreement entered into with a vulnerable adult; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(iii)(B): the use or employment of any misrepresentation, false pretense, or false promise in order to induce, encourage, or solicit a vulnerable adult to enter into a contract or agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(iv): "Endeavor" means to attempt or try.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(v): "Intimidation" means communication conveyed through verbal or nonverbal conduct that threatens deprivation of money, food, clothing, medicine, shelter, social interaction, supervision, health care, or companionship, or that threatens isolation or harm.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(vi): 76-5-111 "Isolation" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(vii): "Lacks capacity to consent" means an impairment by reason of mental illness, developmental disability, organic brain disorder, physical illness or disability, chronic use of drugs, chronic intoxication, short-term memory loss, or other cause to the extent that a vulnerable adult lacks sufficient understanding of the nature or consequences of decisions concerning the vulnerable adult's person or property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(viii): 76-5-111 "Neglect" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(ix): "Undue influence" occurs when a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(ix)(A): uses influence to take advantage of a vulnerable adult's mental or physical impairment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(ix)(B): uses the person's role, relationship, or power:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(ix)(B)(I): to exploit, or knowingly assist or cause another to exploit, the trust, dependency, or fear of a vulnerable adult; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(ix)(B)(II): to gain control deceptively over the decision making of the vulnerable adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(a)(x): 76-5-111 "Vulnerable adult" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(2): An actor commits the offense of financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(2)(a): is in a position of trust and confidence, or has a business relationship, with the vulnerable adult or has undue influence over the vulnerable adult and knowingly, by deception or intimidation, obtains or uses, or endeavors to obtain or use, the vulnerable adult's funds, credit, assets, or other property with the intent to temporarily or permanently deprive the vulnerable adult of the use, benefit, or possession of the vulnerable adult's property, for the benefit of someone other than the vulnerable adult;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(2)(b): knows or should know that the vulnerable adult lacks the capacity to consent, and obtains or uses, or endeavors to obtain or use, or assists another in obtaining or using or endeavoring to obtain or use, the vulnerable adult's funds, assets, or property with the intent to temporarily or permanently deprive the vulnerable adult of the use, benefit, or possession of the vulnerable adult's property for the benefit of someone other than the vulnerable adult;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(2)(c): unjustly or improperly uses or manages the resources of a vulnerable adult for the profit or advantage of someone other than the vulnerable adult;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(2)(d): unjustly or improperly uses a vulnerable adult's power of attorney or guardianship for the profit or advantage of someone other than the vulnerable adult; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(2)(e): involves a vulnerable adult who lacks the capacity to consent in the facilitation or furtherance of any criminal activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(3): (2); (2); (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(3)(b): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(3)(c): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(3)(d): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-111.4(4): It does not constitute a defense to a prosecution for a violation of this section that the actor did not know the age of the vulnerable adult.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112 Reckless endangerment -- Penalty.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112(2): An actor commits reckless endangerment if, under circumstances not amounting to a felony offense, the actor recklessly engages in conduct that creates a substantial risk of death or serious bodily injury to another individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112(3): (2) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5 Endangerment of a child or vulnerable adult.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1): (1)(a)(i); 58-37-2; 58-37a-3; 58-37-2; 76-5-111; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a): (1)(a)(i); 58-37-2; 58-37a-3; 58-37-2; 76-5-111 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(i): (1)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(i)(A): "Chemical substance" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(i)(A)(I): a substance intended to be used as a precursor in the manufacture of a controlled substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(i)(A)(II): a substance intended to be used in the manufacture of a controlled substance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(i)(A)(III): any fumes or by-product resulting from the manufacture of a controlled substance.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(i)(B): (1)(a)(i) Intent under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(i)(B)(I): the use, quantity, or manner of storage of the substance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(i)(B)(II): the proximity of the substance to other precursors or to manufacturing equipment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(ii): "Child" means an individual who is under 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(iii): 58-37-2 "Controlled substance" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(iv): 58-37a-3 "Drug paraphernalia" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(v): "Exposed to" means that the child or vulnerable adult:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(v)(A): is able to access an unlawfully possessed:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(v)(A)(I): controlled substance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(v)(A)(II): chemical substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(v)(B): has the reasonable capacity to access drug paraphernalia; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(v)(C): is able to smell an odor produced during, or as a result of, the manufacture or production of a controlled substance.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(vi): 58-37-2 "Prescription" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(a)(vii): 76-5-111 "Vulnerable adult" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(2): An actor commits endangerment of a child or vulnerable adult if the actor knowingly or intentionally causes or permits a child or a vulnerable adult to be exposed to, inhale, ingest, or have contact with a controlled substance, chemical substance, or drug paraphernalia.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(3): (2); (3)(a); (2); (2); (2); (3)(a); (b); (2); (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(3)(b): (3)(a); (2); (2); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(3)(b)(i): (2) the actor engages in the conduct described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(3)(b)(ii): (2) as a result of the conduct described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(3)(c): (3)(a); (b); (2); (2); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(3)(c)(i): (2) the actor engages in the conduct described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(3)(c)(ii): (2) as a result of the conduct described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(4): (3); (2); Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis; Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(4)(a): (3); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(4)(a)(i): the child is 15 years old or older; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(4)(a)(ii): the other child who is exposed to or inhales, ingests, or has contact with the controlled substance, chemical substance, or drug paraphernalia, is under 12 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(4)(b): Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis; Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis It is an affirmative defense to a violation of this section that the controlled substance:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(4)(b)(i): Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis was obtained by lawful prescription or in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(4)(b)(ii): Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis is used or possessed by the individual to whom the controlled substance was lawfully prescribed or recommended to under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(5): Title 58, Occupations and Professions The penalties described in this section are separate from, and in addition to, the penalties and enhancements described in
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-112.5(6): If an offense committed under this section amounts to an offense subject to a greater penalty under another provision of state law, this section does not prohibit prosecution and sentencing for the more serious offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113 Surreptitious administration of certain substances -- Definitions -- Penalties -- Defenses.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(1): 32B-1-102; 58-37-2; 78B-3-403; 58-17b-102; 19-2-115; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(1)(a): 32B-1-102; 58-37-2; 78B-3-403; 58-17b-102; 19-2-115 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(1)(a)(i): "Administer" means the introduction of a substance into the body by injection, inhalation, ingestion, or by any other means.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(1)(a)(ii): 32B-1-102 "Alcoholic beverage" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(1)(a)(iii): 58-37-2 "Controlled substance" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(1)(a)(iv): "Deleterious substance" means a substance which, if administered, would likely cause bodily injury.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(1)(a)(v): 78B-3-403 "Health care provider" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(1)(a)(vi): "Poisonous" means a substance which, if administered, would likely cause serious bodily injury or death.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(1)(a)(vii): 58-17b-102 "Prescription drug" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(1)(a)(viii): 19-2-115 "Serious bodily injury" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(1)(a)(ix): "Substance" means a controlled substance, poisonous substance, or deleterious substance.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(2): An actor commits surreptitious administration of a certain substance if the actor, surreptitiously or by means of fraud, deception, or misrepresentation, causes an individual to unknowingly consume or receive the administration of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(2)(a): any poisonous, deleterious, or controlled substance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(2)(b): any alcoholic beverage.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(3): (2); (3)(a) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(3)(a): a second degree felony if the substance is a poisonous substance, regardless of whether the substance is a controlled substance or a prescription drug;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(3)(b): (3)(a) a third degree felony if the substance is not within the scope of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(3)(c): a class A misdemeanor if the substance is a deleterious substance or an alcoholic beverage.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(4): (2); (4)(a); (4)(a); (4)(b); (4)(b); (4)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(4)(a): (2) It is an affirmative defense to a prosecution under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(4)(a)(i): provided the appropriate administration of a prescription drug; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(4)(a)(ii): acted on the reasonable belief that the actor's conduct was in the best interest of the well-being of the individual to whom the prescription drug was administered.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(4)(b): (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(4)(b)(i): (4)(a) The defendant shall file and serve on the prosecuting attorney a notice in writing of the defendant's intention to claim a defense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(4)(b)(ii): The notice shall specifically identify the factual basis for the defense and the names and addresses of the witnesses the defendant proposes to examine to establish the defense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(4)(c): (4)(a); (4)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(4)(c)(i): (4)(a) The prosecuting attorney shall file and serve the defendant with a notice containing the names and addresses of the witnesses the prosecutor proposes to examine in order to contradict or rebut the defendant's claim of an affirmative defense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(4)(c)(ii): (4)(b) This notice shall be filed or served not more than 10 days after receipt of the defendant's notice under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(4)(d): (4)(b); (4)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(4)(d)(i): (4)(b); (4)(c) Failure of a party to comply with the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(4)(d)(ii): If the court finds that a party's failure to comply is the result of bad faith, it may impose appropriate sanctions.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(5): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-113(5)(a): This section does not diminish the scope of authorized health care by a health care provider.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114 Commission of domestic violence in the presence of a child.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(1): 78B-7-102; 76-5-201(2); 77-36-1; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(1)(a): 78B-7-102; 76-5-201(2); 77-36-1 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(1)(a)(i): 78B-7-102 "Cohabitant" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(1)(a)(ii): 76-5-201(2) "Criminal homicide offense" means an offense listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(1)(a)(iii): 77-36-1 "Domestic violence" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(1)(a)(iv): "In the presence of a child" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(1)(a)(iv)(A): in the physical presence of a child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(1)(a)(iv)(B): having knowledge that a child is present and may see or hear an act of domestic violence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(2): (2)(a); (b) An actor commits domestic violence in the presence of a child if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(2)(a): commits or attempts to commit a criminal homicide offense against a cohabitant in the presence of a child;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(2)(b): intentionally causes serious bodily injury to a cohabitant or uses a dangerous weapon or other means or force likely to produce death or serious bodily injury against a cohabitant, in the presence of a child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(2)(c): (2)(a); (b) under circumstances not amounting to a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(3): (2)(a); (b); (2)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(3)(a): (2)(a); (b) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(3)(b): (2)(c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(4)(a): A charge under this section is separate and distinct from, and is in addition to, a charge of domestic violence in which the victim is the cohabitant.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(4)(b): Either or both charges may be filed by the prosecutor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-114(5): An actor who commits a violation of this section when more than one child is present is guilty of one offense of domestic violence in the presence of a child regarding each child present when the violation occurred.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-201(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 The terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-201(2): The following are criminal homicide:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-201(2)(a): aggravated murder;

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-201(2)(f): negligent homicide; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-201(2)(g): negligently operating a vehicle resulting in death.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-201(3): (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-201(3)(a): the death of an unborn child is caused by an abortion;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-201(3)(b): the sole reason for the death of an unborn child is that the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-201(3)(b)(i): refused to consent to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-201(3)(b)(i)(A): medical treatment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-201(3)(b)(i)(B): a cesarean section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-201(3)(b)(ii): failed to follow medical advice; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-201(3)(c): a woman causes the death of her own unborn child, and the death:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-201(3)(c)(i): is caused by a criminally negligent act or reckless act of the woman; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-201(3)(c)(ii): is not caused by an intentional or knowing act of the woman.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(3)(a): (2) If a notice of intent to seek the death penalty has been filed, a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(3)(b): 76-3-207.7 If a notice of intent to seek the death penalty has not been filed, aggravated murder is a noncapital first degree felony punishable as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(3)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(3)(c)(i): Within 60 days after arraignment of the defendant, the prosecutor may file notice of intent to seek the death penalty.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(3)(c)(ii): The notice shall be served on the defendant or defense counsel and filed with the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(3)(c)(iii): Notice of intent to seek the death penalty may be served and filed more than 60 days after the arraignment upon written stipulation of the parties or upon a finding by the court of good cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(3)(d): (3)(c)(i) Without the consent of the prosecutor, the court may not accept a plea of guilty to noncapital first degree felony aggravated murder during the period in which the prosecutor may file a notice of intent to seek the death penalty under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(3)(e): 76-3-207.7 If the defendant was younger than 18 years old at the time the offense was committed, aggravated murder is a noncapital first degree felony punishable as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(3)(f): (3)(a); (3)(b); 76-5-205.5 Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(3)(f)(i): if the trier of fact finds the defendant guilty of aggravated murder, the court shall enter a judgment of conviction for murder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(3)(f)(ii): if the trier of fact finds the defendant guilty of attempted aggravated murder, the court shall enter a judgment of conviction for attempted murder.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(4): (4)(a); (3)(a); (3)(b); (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(4)(a): It is an affirmative defense to a charge of aggravated murder or attempted aggravated murder that the actor caused the death of another or attempted to cause the death of another under a reasonable belief that the circumstances provided a legal justification or excuse for the conduct although the conduct was not legally justifiable or excusable under the existing circumstances.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(4)(b): (4)(a) The reasonable belief of the actor under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(4)(c): (3)(a); (3)(b); (4) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(4)(c)(i): if the trier of fact finds the defendant guilty of aggravated murder, the court shall enter a judgment of conviction for murder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(4)(c)(ii): if the trier of fact finds the defendant guilty of attempted aggravated murder, the court shall enter a judgment of conviction for attempted murder.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(5): (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-202(5)(a): (2) Any aggravating circumstance described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-203(2)(d)(iii): the actor acted with the intent required as an element of the predicate offense;

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-203(3)(a)(ii): A defendant who is convicted of murder shall be sentenced to imprisonment for an indeterminate term of not less than 15 years and which may be for life.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-203(4): (4)(a); (3)(a); (4)

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-203(4)(c)(ii): if the trier of fact finds the defendant guilty of attempted murder, the court shall enter a judgment of conviction for attempted manslaughter.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-203(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-203(5)(a): Any predicate offense that constitutes a separate offense does not merge with the crime of murder.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-203(5)(b): An actor who is convicted of murder, based on a predicate offense that constitutes a separate offense, may also be convicted of, and punished for, the separate offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-204 Death of other than intended victim no defense.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In any prosecution for criminal homicide, evidence that the actor caused the death of a person other than the intended victim shall not constitute a defense for any purpose to criminal homicide.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5 Special mitigation for mental condition or provocation -- Burden of proof -- Charge reduction.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(1): 76-2-305; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(1)(a): 76-2-305 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(1)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(1)(a)(i)(A): "Extreme emotional distress" means an overwhelming reaction of anger, shock, or grief that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(1)(a)(i)(A)(I): causes the defendant to be incapable of reflection and restraint; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(1)(a)(i)(A)(II): would cause an objectively reasonable person to be incapable of reflection and restraint.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(1)(a)(i)(B): "Extreme emotional distress" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(1)(a)(i)(B)(I): a condition resulting from a mental condition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(1)(a)(i)(B)(II): distress that is substantially caused by the defendant's own conduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(1)(a)(ii): 76-2-305 "Mental condition" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 The terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(2): (4) Special mitigation exists when a defendant causes the death of another individual or attempts to cause the death of another individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(2)(a)(i): under circumstances that are not legally justified, but the defendant acts under a delusion attributable to a mental condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(2)(a)(ii): the nature of the delusion is such that, if the facts existed as the defendant believed them to be in the delusional state, those facts would provide a legal justification for the defendant's conduct; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(2)(a)(iii): the defendant's actions, in light of the delusion, are reasonable from the objective viewpoint of a reasonable person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(2)(b): (4) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(3): (2)(a) A defendant who is under the influence of voluntarily consumed, injected, or ingested alcohol, controlled substances, or volatile substances at the time of the alleged offense may not claim mitigation of the offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(4): (2)(b); (2)(b) A defendant may not claim special mitigation under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(4)(a): the time period after the victim's highly provoking act and before the defendant's actions was long enough for an objectively reasonable person to have recovered from the extreme emotional distress;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(4)(b): the defendant responded to the victim's highly provoking act by inflicting serious or substantial bodily injury on the victim over a prolonged period, or by inflicting torture on the victim, regardless of whether the victim was conscious during the infliction of serious or substantial bodily injury or torture; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(4)(c): (2)(b) the victim's highly provoking act, described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(5): 76-5-202(3)(f)(i); 76-5-202(3)(f)(ii); 76-5-203(3)(b)(i); 76-5-203(3)(b)(ii) If the trier of fact finds that the elements of aggravated murder, attempted aggravated murder, murder, or attempted murder are proven beyond a reasonable doubt, and also finds that the existence of special mitigation under this section is established by a preponderance of the evidence, the court shall enter a judgment of conviction in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(6): If the issue of special mitigation is submitted to the trier of fact, the trier of fact shall return a special verdict at the same time as the general verdict, indicating whether it finds special mitigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(7): (5); (5)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-205.5(7)(a): If a jury is the trier of fact, a unanimous vote of the jury is required to find special mitigation under this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-208(2): 76-5-202; 76-5-109.2(3)(b); 76-5-109.2(3)(c); (2)(b)(i); 76-5-109(3)(a); (b); (c) Unless a violation amounts to aggravated murder as described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-208(2)(a)(i): the actor causes the death of another individual who is younger than 18 years old; and

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-208(2)(b)(ii): 76-5-109.2(3)(c) the child abuse is done with criminal negligence under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-208(2)(b)(iii): (2)(b)(i); 76-5-109(3)(a); (b); (c) under circumstances not amounting to the type of child abuse homicide described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-208(3): (2); (2)(b)(i); (2); (2)(b)(ii); (iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-208(3)(a): (2); (2)(b)(i) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-208(3)(b): (2); (2)(b)(ii); (iii) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-209 Homicide by assault -- Penalty.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-209(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-209(2): An actor commits homicide by assault if, under circumstances not amounting to aggravated murder, murder, or manslaughter:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-209(2)(a): the actor causes the death of another individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-209(2)(b): the actor causes the other individual's death while intentionally or knowingly attempting, with unlawful force or violence, to do bodily injury to the other individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-209(3): Homicide by assault is a third degree felony.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301 Kidnapping.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301(1): 76-5-111; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301(1)(a): 76-5-111 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301(1)(a)(i): "Against the will of an individual" includes without the consent of the legal guardian, caretaker, or custodian of an individual who is a dependent adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301(1)(a)(ii): 76-5-111 "Dependent adult" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301(1)(a)(iii): "Minor" means an individual who is 14 years old or older but younger than 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301(2): An actor commits kidnapping if the actor intentionally or knowingly, without authority of law, and against the will of an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301(2)(a): detains or restrains the individual for any substantial period of time;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301(2)(b): detains or restrains the individual in circumstances exposing the individual to risk of bodily injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301(2)(c): holds the individual in involuntary servitude;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301(2)(d): detains or restrains a minor without the consent of the minor's parent or legal guardian or the consent of a person acting in loco parentis; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301(2)(e): moves the individual any substantial distance or across a state line.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301(3): (2) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1 Child kidnapping.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(1): 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(1)(a): As used in this section, "child" means an individual under 14 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(2): An actor commits child kidnapping if the actor intentionally or knowingly, without authority of law, and by any means and in any manner, seizes, confines, detains, or transports a child without the consent of the child's parent or guardian, or the consent of a person acting in loco parentis.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(4): (4); (4) An actor convicted of a violation of this section shall be sentenced to imprisonment of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(4)(a): (4) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(4)(b): (4) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(4)(c): life without parole, if the trier of fact finds that at the time of the commission of the child kidnapping the actor was previously convicted of a grievous sexual offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(5): (4); (4); (4); (4) If, when imposing a sentence under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(5)(a): (4) for purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(5)(b): (4) for purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(5)(b)(i): 10 years and which may be for life; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(5)(b)(ii): six years and which may be for life.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(6): (5); (4) The provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(7): (4) Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(8): 76-3-406 Imprisonment under this section is mandatory in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.1(9): 76-5-303 A violation of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2 Parental kidnapping.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(1): 78B-15-201; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(1)(a): 78B-15-201 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(1)(a)(i): "Child" means an individual under 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(1)(a)(ii): "Custody" means court-ordered physical custody of a child entered by a court.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(1)(a)(iii): 78B-15-201 "Parent" means an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(1)(a)(iii)(A): recognized as a biological parent or adoptive parent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(1)(a)(iii)(B): 78B-15-201 that has established a parent-child relationship under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(1)(a)(iv): "Parent-time" means court-ordered parent-time or visitation entered by a court.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(2): (2)(a) A parent commits parental kidnapping of the parent's child if the parent:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(2)(a): takes, entices, conceals, detains, or withholds the child from an individual entitled to custody of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(2)(b): intends to interfere with the custody of the child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(2)(c): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(2)(c)(i): has never had a right to physical custody of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(2)(c)(ii): has never been granted parent-time with the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(2)(c)(iii): has had all rights to physical custody of the child terminated by a court; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(2)(c)(iv): (2)(a) at the time of the parent's action under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(3): (2); (3)(a); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(3)(b): (3)(a); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(4): 76-5-305; (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(a); (4)(b)(i) In addition to the affirmative defenses described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(4)(a): (2)(a) the parent acted under a reasonable belief that the action described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(4)(a)(i): necessary to protect the child from imminent serious bodily injury, or death;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(4)(a)(ii): authorized by law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(4)(a)(iii): taken with the consent of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(4)(a)(iii)(A): the individual entitled to custody of the child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(4)(a)(iii)(B): a custodian, guardian, caretaker, or other individual lawfully acting in place of the individual entitled to custody of the child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-301.2(4)(b): (2)(a); (2)(a); (4)(b)(i)

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302 Aggravated kidnapping.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(1): 76-5-301; 76-5-304; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(1)(a): 76-5-301; 76-5-304 As used in this section, "in the course of committing unlawful detention or kidnapping" means in the course of committing, attempting to commit, or in the immediate flight after the attempt or commission of a violation of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(1)(a)(i): 76-5-301 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(1)(a)(ii): 76-5-304 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(2): Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses An actor commits aggravated kidnapping if the actor, in the course of committing unlawful detention or kidnapping:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(2)(a): uses or threatens to use a dangerous weapon; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(2)(b): Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses acts with the intent to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(2)(b)(i): hold the victim for ransom or reward, as a shield or hostage, or to compel a third person to engage in particular conduct or to forbear from engaging in particular conduct;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(2)(b)(ii): facilitate the commission, attempted commission, or flight after commission or attempted commission of a felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(2)(b)(iii): hinder or delay the discovery of or reporting of a felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(2)(b)(iv): inflict bodily injury on or to terrorize the victim or another individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(2)(b)(v): interfere with the performance of any governmental or political function; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(2)(b)(vi): Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses commit a sexual offense as described in
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(3): (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(3)(b): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(4): (3)(b); (4)(b); (4)(c); (5); (4)(c); (5) An actor convicted of a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(4)(a): (4)(b); (4)(c); (5) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(4)(b): (4)(c); (5) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(4)(c): life without parole, if the trier of fact finds that at the time of the commission of the aggravated kidnapping, the defendant was previously convicted of a grievous sexual offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(5): (4)(a); (b); (4)(a); (b); (4)(b); (4)(a); (b) If, when imposing a sentence under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(5)(a): (4)(b) for purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(5)(b): (4)(a); (b) for purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(5)(b)(i): 10 years and which may be for life; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(5)(b)(ii): six years and which may be for life.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-302(6): (5); (4)(c) The provisions of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303 Custodial interference.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(1): 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(1)(a): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(1)(a)(i): "Child" means an individual under 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(1)(a)(ii): "Custody" means court-ordered physical custody entered by a court of competent jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(1)(a)(iii): "Visitation" means court-ordered parent-time or visitation entered by a court of competent jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(2)(a): An actor who is entitled to custody of a child commits custodial interference if, during a period of time when another individual is entitled to visitation of the child, the actor takes, entices, conceals, detains, or withholds the child from the individual entitled to visitation of the child, with the intent to interfere with the visitation of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(2)(b): An actor who is entitled to visitation of a child commits custodial interference if, during a period of time when the individual is not entitled to visitation of the child, the actor takes, entices, conceals, detains, or withholds the child from an individual who is entitled to custody of the child, with the intent to interfere with the custody of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(3): (2); (3)(a); (2); (3)(b)(i); (3)(a); (b); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(3)(b): (3)(a); (2); (3)(b)(i) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(3)(b)(i): commits custodial interference; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(3)(b)(ii): (3)(b)(i) has been convicted of custodial interference at least twice in the two-year period immediately preceding the day on which the commission of custodial interference described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(3)(c): (3)(a); (b); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(4): 76-5-305; (4) In addition to the affirmative defenses described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(4)(a): the action is consented to by the individual whose custody or visitation of the child was interfered with; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(4)(b): (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(4)(b)(i): the action is based on a reasonable belief that the action is necessary to protect a child from abuse, including sexual abuse; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303(4)(b)(ii): (4) before engaging in the action, the actor reports the actor's intention to engage in the action, and the basis for the belief described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303.5 Notification of conviction of custodial interference.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303.5(1): Title 77, Chapter 2a, Pleas in Abeyance; 76-1-101.5 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303.5(1)(a): Title 77, Chapter 2a, Pleas in Abeyance
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303.5(1)(a)(i): "Convicted" means a conviction by plea or verdict or adjudication in juvenile court of a crime or offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303.5(1)(a)(ii): Title 77, Chapter 2a, Pleas in Abeyance "Convicted" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303.5(1)(a)(ii)(A): a plea of guilty or guilty with a mental condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303.5(1)(a)(ii)(B): a plea of no contest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303.5(1)(a)(ii)(C): Title 77, Chapter 2a, Pleas in Abeyance the acceptance by the court of a plea in abeyance under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303.5(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303.5(2): 76-5-303; 53-3-103; 76-5-303(3)(a); 76-5-303(3)(b); 76-5-303(3) If an individual is convicted of custodial interference under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303.5(2)(a): 76-5-303(3)(a) a class B misdemeanor, under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303.5(2)(b): 76-5-303(3)(b) a class A misdemeanor, under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-303.5(2)(c): 76-5-303(3) a felony, under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-304 Unlawful detention and unlawful detention of a minor.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-304(1): 76-5-111; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-304(1)(a): 76-5-111 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-304(1)(a)(i): Acting "against the will of an individual" includes acting without the consent of the legal guardian, caretaker, or custodian of an individual who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-304(1)(a)(i)(A): a dependent adult; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-304(1)(a)(i)(B): a minor who is 14 or 15 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-304(1)(a)(ii): 76-5-111 "Dependent adult" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-304(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-304(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-304(2)(a): An actor commits unlawful detention if the actor intentionally or knowingly, without authority of law, and against the will of an individual, detains or restrains the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-304(2)(b): An actor commits unlawful detention of a minor if the actor is at least four or more years older than the minor, and intentionally or knowingly, without authority of law, and against the will of the minor, coerces or exerts influence over the minor with the intent to cause the minor to remain with the actor for an unreasonable period of time under the circumstances.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-304(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-304(4): (2)(a); (2)(b); 76-5-301; 76-5-301.1 If the conduct of the actor amounts to a violation under one of the following, the actor shall be charged with the violation and not under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-304(4)(a): 76-5-301 kidnapping, as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-304(4)(b): 76-5-301.1 child kidnapping, as described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-305 Defenses.
----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-305(1): 76-5-111 It is a defense under this part that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-305(1)(a): the actor was acting under a reasonable belief that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-305(1)(a)(i): the conduct was necessary to protect any individual from imminent bodily injury or death; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-305(1)(a)(ii): the detention or restraint was authorized by law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-305(1)(b): 76-5-111 the alleged victim is younger than 18 years old or is a dependent adult, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-305(2): (1)(b); 76-5-308.5 Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-307 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 76-5-307(1): "Child" means an individual younger than 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-307(2): "Commercial purpose" includes direct or indirect participation in or facilitation of the transportation of one or more individuals for the purpose of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-307(2)(a): charging or obtaining a fee for the transportation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-307(2)(b): obtaining, exchanging, or receiving any thing or item of value or an attempt to conduct any of these activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-307(3): (2) "Facilitation" regarding transportation under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-307(3)(a): travel arrangement services;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-307(3)(b): payment for the costs of travel; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-307(3)(c): property that would advance an act of transportation, including a vehicle or other means of transportation, a weapon, false identification, and making lodging available, including by rent, lease, or sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-307(4): "Family member" means an individual's parent, grandparent, sibling, or any other individual related to the individual by consanguinity or affinity to the second degree.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308 Human trafficking for labor.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-5-307 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308(2): An actor commits human trafficking for labor if the actor recruits, harbors, transports, obtains, patronizes, or solicits an individual for labor through the use of force, fraud, or coercion, which may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308(2)(a): threatening serious harm to, or physical restraint against, that individual or another individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308(2)(b): destroying, concealing, removing, confiscating, or possessing any passport, immigration document, or other government-issued identification document;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308(2)(c): abusing or threatening abuse of the law or legal process against the individual or another individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308(2)(d): using a condition of an individual being a debtor due to a pledge of the individual's personal services or the personal services of an individual under the control of the debtor as a security for debt where the reasonable value of the services is not applied toward the liquidation of the debt or the length and nature of those services are not respectively limited and defined;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308(2)(e): using a condition of servitude by means of any scheme, plan, or pattern intended to cause an individual to believe that if the individual did not enter into or continue in a condition of servitude, the individual or another individual would suffer serious harm or physical restraint, or would be threatened with abuse of legal process; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308(2)(f): creating or exploiting a relationship where the individual is dependent upon the actor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308(4): (2) Human trafficking for labor includes any labor obtained through force, fraud, or coercion as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308(5): This offense is a separate offense from any other crime committed in relationship to the commission of this offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1 Human trafficking for sexual exploitation.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-5-307 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1(2): An actor commits human trafficking for sexual exploitation if the actor recruits, harbors, transports, obtains, patronizes, or solicits an individual for sexual exploitation through the use of force, fraud, or coercion, which may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1(2)(a): threatening serious harm to, or physical restraint against, that individual or another individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1(2)(b): destroying, concealing, removing, confiscating, or possessing any passport, immigration document, or other government-issued identification document;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1(2)(c): abusing or threatening abuse of the law or legal process against the individual or another individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1(2)(d): using a condition of an individual being a debtor due to a pledge of the individual's personal services or the personal services of an individual under the control of the debtor as a security for debt where the reasonable value of the services is not applied toward the liquidation of the debt or the length and nature of those services are not respectively limited and defined;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1(2)(e): using a condition of servitude by means of any scheme, plan, or pattern intended to cause an individual to believe that if the individual did not enter into or continue in a condition of servitude, the individual or another individual would suffer serious harm or physical restraint, or would be threatened with abuse of legal process; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1(2)(f): creating or exploiting a relationship where the individual is dependent upon the actor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1(4): (1) Human trafficking for sexual exploitation includes all forms of commercial sexual activity, which may include the following conduct when the person acts under force, fraud, or coercion as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1(4)(a): sexually explicit performance;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1(4)(b): prostitution;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1(4)(c): participation in the production of pornography;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1(4)(d): performance in strip clubs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1(4)(e): exotic dancing or display.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.1(5): This offense is a separate offense from any other crime committed in relationship to the commission of this offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.3 Human smuggling -- Penalty.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.3(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-5-307 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.3(2): An actor commits human smuggling if the actor transports or procures the transportation for one or more individuals for a commercial purpose, knowing or having reason to know that the individual or individuals transported or to be transported are not:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.3(2)(a): citizens of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.3(2)(b): permanent resident aliens; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.3(2)(c): otherwise lawfully in this state or entitled to be in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.3(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.3(4): This offense is a separate offense from any other crime committed in relationship to the commission of this offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.5 Human trafficking of a child -- Penalties.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.5(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-5-307
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.5(1)(a): As used in this section, "commercial sexual activity with a child" means any sexual act with a child, for which anything of value is given to or received by any person.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.5(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-5-307 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.5(2): An actor commits human trafficking of a child if the actor recruits, harbors, transports, obtains, patronizes, or solicits a child for sexual exploitation or forced labor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.5(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.5(4): 76-5-308; 76-5-308.1
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.5(4)(a): 76-5-308 Human trafficking of a child for labor includes any labor obtained through force, fraud, or coercion as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.5(4)(b): 76-5-308.1 Human trafficking of a child for sexual exploitation includes all forms of commercial sexual activity with a child, including sexually explicit performance, prostitution, participation in the production of pornography, performance in a strip club, and exotic dancing or display as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-308.5(5): This offense is a separate offense from any other crime committed in relationship to the commission of this offense.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310 Aggravated human trafficking -- Penalties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-5-307 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(2): 76-5-308; 76-5-308.1; 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-402.2; 76-5-402.3; 76-5-403; 76-5-403.1; 76-5-404.3; 76-5-405 An actor commits aggravated human trafficking for labor or sexual exploitation if, in the course of committing an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(2)(a): results in the death of a trafficked individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(2)(b): results in serious bodily injury of a trafficked individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(2)(c): 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-402.2; 76-5-402.3; 76-5-403; 76-5-403.1; 76-5-404.3; 76-5-405 involves:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(2)(c)(i): 76-5-402 rape under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(2)(c)(ii): 76-5-402.1 rape of a child under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(2)(c)(iii): 76-5-402.2 object rape under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(2)(c)(iv): 76-5-402.3 object rape of a child under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(2)(c)(v): 76-5-403 forcible sodomy under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(2)(c)(vi): 76-5-403.1 sodomy on a child under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(2)(c)(vii): 76-5-404.3 aggravated sexual abuse of a child under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(2)(c)(viii): 76-5-405 aggravated sexual assault under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(2)(d): involves the trafficking of 10 or more individuals; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(2)(e): involves an individual trafficked for longer than 30 consecutive days.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310(4): Aggravated human trafficking is a separate offense from any other crime committed in relationship to the commission of the offense.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310.1(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-5-307 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310.1(2): 76-5-308.3; 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-402.2; 76-5-402.3; 76-5-403; 76-5-403.1; 76-5-404.1; 76-5-405 An actor commits aggravated human smuggling if, in the course of committing an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310.1(2)(a): results in the death of a smuggled individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310.1(2)(b): results in serious bodily injury to a smuggled individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310.1(2)(c): involves the smuggling of a child and the child is not accompanied by a family member who is 18 years old or older;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310.1(2)(d): 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-402.2; 76-5-402.3; 76-5-403; 76-5-403.1; 76-5-404.1; 76-5-405 involves:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310.1(2)(d)(i): 76-5-402 rape under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-5-310.1(2)(d)(vi): 76-5-403.1 sodomy on a child under Section
