Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(2)(a)(iii): the intimate image was created by or provided to the actor under circumstances in which the individual depicted in the image has a reasonable expectation of privacy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(2)(a)(iv): (2)(b) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(2)(b): (2)(a)(iv); (2)(a); (2)(b)(ii) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(2)(b)(i): the individual depicted in the intimate image was the victim of a crime;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(2)(b)(ii): the intimate image was provided to law enforcement as part of an investigation or prosecution of a crime committed against the victim;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(2)(b)(iii): (2)(b)(ii) the intimate image was distributed without a legitimate law enforcement or investigative purpose by an individual who had access to the intimate image due to the individual's association with the investigation or prosecution described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(2)(b)(iv): the victim is incapacitated or deceased.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(3): (2); (3)(a); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(3)(b): (3)(a); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(4): 76-5b-203.5 This section does not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(4)(a): 76-5b-203.5 except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(4)(a)(i): lawful practices of law enforcement agencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(4)(a)(ii): prosecutorial agency functions;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(4)(a)(iii): the reporting of a criminal offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(4)(a)(iv): court proceedings or any other judicial proceeding; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(4)(a)(v): lawful and generally accepted medical practices and procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(4)(b): an intimate image if the individual portrayed in the image voluntarily allows public exposure of the image;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(4)(c): an intimate image that is portrayed in a lawful commercial setting; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(4)(d): an intimate image that is related to a matter of public concern or interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(5): 76-10-1230; 76-10-1230; 76-10-1231
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(5)(a): This section does not apply to an Internet service provider or interactive computer service, as defined in 47 U.S.C. Sec. 230(f)(2), a provider of an electronic communications service as defined in 18 U.S.C. Sec. 2510, a telecommunications service, information service, or mobile service as defined in 47 U.S.C. Sec. 153, including a commercial mobile service as defined in 47 U.S.C. Sec. 332(d), or a cable operator as defined in 47 U.S.C. Sec. 522, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(5)(a)(i): the distribution of an intimate image by the Internet service provider occurs only incidentally through the provider's function of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(5)(a)(i)(A): transmitting or routing data from one person to another person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(5)(a)(i)(B): providing a connection between one person and another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(5)(a)(ii): the provider does not intentionally aid or abet in the distribution of the intimate image; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(5)(a)(iii): the provider does not knowingly receive from or through a person who distributes the intimate image a fee greater than the fee generally charged by the provider, as a specific condition for permitting the person to distribute the intimate image.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(5)(b): 76-10-1230 This section does not apply to a hosting company, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(5)(b)(i): the distribution of an intimate image by the hosting company occurs only incidentally through the hosting company's function of providing data storage space or data caching to a person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(5)(b)(ii): the hosting company does not intentionally engage, aid, or abet in the distribution of the intimate image; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(5)(b)(iii): the hosting company does not knowingly receive from or through a person who distributes the intimate image a fee greater than the fee generally charged by the provider, as a specific condition for permitting the person to distribute, store, or cache the intimate image.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203(5)(c): 76-10-1230; 76-10-1231 A service provider, as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203.5 Misuse of intimate image during a criminal action.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203.5(1): 77-1-3; 76-5b-203; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203.5(1)(a): 77-1-3; 76-5b-203 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203.5(1)(a)(i): 77-1-3 "Criminal action" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203.5(1)(a)(ii): 76-5b-203 "Intimate image" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203.5(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203.5(2): An actor commits misuse of an intimate image during a criminal action if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203.5(2)(a): obtains access to an intimate image in the course of a criminal action; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203.5(2)(b): intentionally displays, duplicates, copies, or shares the intimate image, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203.5(2)(b)(i): displaying, duplicating, copying, or sharing the intimate image is done solely for the purpose of the adjudication, defense, prosecution or investigation of a criminal matter involving the intimate image;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203.5(2)(b)(ii): each individual who is the subject of the intimate image gives written permission to display, duplicate, copy, or share the intimate image; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203.5(2)(b)(iii): the intimate image was not created by or provided to the actor under circumstances in which the depicted individual has a reasonable expectation of privacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203.5(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203.5(3)(a): a class A misdemeanor for a first offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203.5(3)(b): a third degree felony for each subsequent offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-203.5(4): Nothing in this section precludes an agency that employs an individual who is involved in a criminal action from establishing internal policies for an individual's violation of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204 Sexual extortion -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(1): 76-5b-203; 76-5b-203; 76-5-404.1; 76-5b-203; 76-5b-203; 76-5-111; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(1)(a): 76-5b-203; 76-5b-203; 76-5-404.1; 76-5b-203; 76-5b-203; 76-5-111 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(1)(a)(i): "Adult" means an individual 18 years of age or older.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(1)(a)(ii): "Child" means any individual under the age of 18.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(1)(a)(iii): 76-5b-203 "Distribute" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(1)(a)(iv): 76-5b-203 "Intimate image" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(1)(a)(v): 76-5-404.1 "Position of special trust" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(1)(a)(vi): 76-5b-203 "Sexually explicit conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(1)(a)(vii): 76-5b-203 "Simulated sexually explicit conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(1)(a)(viii): 76-5-111 "Vulnerable adult" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(a): An actor commits the offense of sexual extortion if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(a)(i): with an intent to coerce a victim to engage in sexual contact, in sexually explicit conduct, or in simulated sexually explicit conduct, or to produce, provide, or distribute an image, video, or other recording of any individual naked or engaged in sexually explicit conduct, communicates by any means a threat:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(a)(i)(A): to the victim's person, property, or reputation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(a)(i)(B): to distribute an intimate image or video of the victim;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(a)(ii): knowingly causes a victim to engage in sexual contact, in sexually explicit conduct, or in simulated sexually explicit conduct, or to produce, provide, or distribute any image, video, or other recording of any individual naked or engaged in sexually explicit conduct by means of a threat:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(a)(ii)(A): to the victim's person, property, or reputation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(a)(ii)(B): to distribute an intimate image or video of the victim; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(a)(iii): with intent to obtain a thing of value from a victim communicates, by any means, a threat to distribute an intimate image or video of the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(b): (2)(a) An actor commits aggravated sexual extortion when, in conjunction with the offense described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(b)(i): the victim is a child or vulnerable adult;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(b)(ii): the offense was committed by the use of a dangerous weapon or by violence, intimidation, menace, fraud, or threat of physical harm, or was committed during the course of a kidnapping;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(b)(iii): the actor caused bodily injury or severe psychological injury to the victim during or as a result of the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(b)(iv): the actor was a stranger to the victim or became a friend of the victim for the purpose of committing the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(b)(v): the actor, before sentencing for the offense, was previously convicted of any sexual offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(b)(vi): the actor occupied a position of special trust in relation to the victim;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(b)(vii): the actor encouraged, aided, allowed, or benefitted from acts of prostitution or sexual acts by the victim with any other individual, or sexual performance by the victim before any other individual, human trafficking, or human smuggling; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(2)(b)(viii): the actor caused the penetration, however slight, of the genital or anal opening of the victim by any part or parts of the human body, or by any other object.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(3): (2)(a); (2)(b); (2)(b); (2)(a); (2)(b); (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(3)(a): (2)(a); (2)(b); (2)(b) If the actor is an adult:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(3)(a)(i): (2)(a) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(3)(a)(ii): (2)(b) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(3)(a)(iii): (2)(b) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(3)(b): (2)(a); (2)(b) If the actor is a child:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(3)(b)(i): (2)(a) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(3)(b)(ii): (2)(b) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(3)(c): (2); (2) An actor commits a separate offense under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(3)(c)(i): (2) for each victim the actor subjects to the offense outlined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(3)(c)(ii): (2) for each separate time the actor subjects a victim to the offense outlined Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(3)(d): This section does not preclude an actor from being charged and convicted of a separate criminal act if the actor commits the separate criminal act while the individual violates or attempts to violate this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-204(4): An interactive computer service, as defined in 47 U.S.C. Sec. 230, is not subject to liability under this section related to content provided by a user of the interactive computer service.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205 Unlawful distribution of a counterfeit intimate image -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(1): 76-5b-203; 76-5b-203; 76-5b-203; 76-1-401; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(1)(a): 76-5b-203; 76-5b-203; 76-5b-203; 76-1-401 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(1)(a)(i): "Child" means an individual under 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(1)(a)(ii): "Counterfeit intimate image" means any visual depiction, photograph, film, video, recording, picture, or computer or computer-generated image or picture, whether made or produced by electronic, mechanical, or other means, that has been edited, manipulated, or altered to depict the likeness of an identifiable individual and purports to, or is made to appear to, depict that individual's:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(1)(a)(ii)(A): exposed human male or female genitals or pubic area, with less than an opaque covering;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(1)(a)(ii)(B): a female breast with less than an opaque covering, or any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(1)(a)(ii)(C): the individual engaged in any sexually explicit conduct or simulated sexually explicit conduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(1)(a)(iii): 76-5b-203 "Distribute" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(1)(a)(iv): 76-5b-203 "Sexually explicit conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(1)(a)(v): 76-5b-203 "Simulated sexually explicit conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(1)(a)(vi): 76-1-401 "Single criminal episode" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(2): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(2)(a): An actor commits the offense of unlawful distribution of a counterfeit intimate image if the actor knowingly or intentionally distributes a counterfeit intimate image that the actor knows or should reasonably know would cause a reasonable person to suffer emotional or physical distress or harm, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(2)(a)(i): the actor has not received consent from the depicted individual to distribute the counterfeit intimate image; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(2)(a)(ii): the counterfeit intimate image was created or provided by the actor without the knowledge and consent of the depicted individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(2)(b): (2) An actor who is 18 years old or older commits aggravated unlawful distribution of a counterfeit intimate image if, in committing the offense described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(3): (2)(a); (3)(a)(i); (2)(a); (2)(b); (3)(b)(i); (2)(b); 76-5b-201; 76-5b-201.1
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(3)(a): (2)(a); (3)(a)(i); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(3)(a)(i): (2)(a) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(3)(a)(ii): (3)(a)(i); (2)(a) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(3)(b): (2)(b); (3)(b)(i); (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(3)(b)(i): (2)(b) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(3)(b)(ii): (3)(b)(i); (2)(b) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(3)(c): 76-5b-201; 76-5b-201.1 This section does not apply to an actor who engages in conduct that constitutes a violation of this section to the extent that the actor is chargeable, for the same conduct, under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(4): This section does not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(4)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(4)(a)(i): lawful practices of law enforcement agencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(4)(a)(ii): prosecutorial agency functions;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(4)(a)(iii): the reporting of a criminal offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(4)(a)(iv): court proceedings or any other judicial proceeding; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(4)(a)(v): lawful and generally accepted medical practices and procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(4)(b): a counterfeit intimate image if the individual depicted in the image voluntarily allows public exposure of the image;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(4)(c): a counterfeit intimate image that is portrayed in a lawful commercial setting; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(4)(d): a counterfeit intimate image that is related to a matter of public concern or interest or protected by the First Amendment to the United States Constitution or Article I, Sections 1 and 15 of the Utah Constitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(5): 76-10-1230; 76-10-1230; 76-10-1231
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(5)(a): This section does not apply to an Internet service provider or interactive computer service, as defined in 47 U.S.C. Sec. 230(f)(2), a provider of an electronic communications service as defined in 18 U.S.C. Sec. 2510, a telecommunications service, information service, or mobile service as defined in 47 U.S.C. Sec. 153, including a commercial mobile service as defined in 47 U.S.C. Sec. 332(d), or a cable operator as defined in 47 U.S.C. Sec. 522, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(5)(a)(i): the distribution of a counterfeit intimate image by the Internet service provider occurs only incidentally through the provider's function of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(5)(a)(i)(A): transmitting or routing data from one person to another person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(5)(a)(i)(B): providing a connection between one person and another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(5)(a)(ii): the provider does not intentionally aid or abet in the distribution of the counterfeit intimate image; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(5)(a)(iii): the provider does not knowingly receive from or through a person who distributes the counterfeit intimate image a fee greater than the fee generally charged by the provider, as a specific condition for permitting the person to distribute the counterfeit intimate image.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(5)(b): 76-10-1230 This section does not apply to a hosting company, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(5)(b)(i): the distribution of a counterfeit intimate image by the hosting company occurs only incidentally through the hosting company's function of providing data storage space or data caching to a person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(5)(b)(ii): the hosting company does not intentionally engage, aid, or abet in the distribution of the counterfeit intimate image;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(5)(b)(iii): the hosting company does not knowingly receive from or through a person who distributes the counterfeit intimate image a fee greater than the fee generally charged by the provider, as a specific condition for permitting the person to distribute, store, or cache the counterfeit intimate image; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(5)(b)(iv): the hosting company immediately removes the counterfeit intimate image upon notice from a law enforcement agency, prosecutorial agency, or the individual purportedly depicted in the counterfeit intimate image.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-205(5)(c): 76-10-1230; 76-10-1231 A service provider, as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-301 Determination whether material violates chapter.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-301(1): In determining whether material is in violation of this chapter, the material need not be considered as a whole, but may be examined by the trier of fact in part only.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-301(2): It is not an element of the offense of sexual exploitation of a minor that the material appeal to the prurient interest in sex of the average person nor that prohibited conduct need be portrayed in a patently offensive manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-301(3): It is not an element of the offense of sexual exploitation of a vulnerable adult that the material appeal to the prurient interest in sex of the average person nor that prohibited conduct need be portrayed in a patently offensive manner.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-5b-302 Lack of knowledge of age not a defense.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
It is not a defense to an offense described in this chapter that the accused did not know the age of the victim.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 76 - Chapter 6 - Offenses Against Property
**********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-101 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-101(1): As used in this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-101(1)(a): "Etching" means defacing, damaging, or destroying hard surfaces by means of an abrasive object, a knife, or an engraving device, or a chemical action which uses any caustic cream, gel, liquid, or solution.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-101(1)(b): "Fire" means a flame, heat source capable of combustion, or material capable of combustion that is caused, set, or maintained by a person for any purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-101(1)(c): "Graffiti" means any form of unauthorized printing, writing, spraying, scratching, painting, affixing, etching, or inscribing on the property of another regardless of the content or the nature of the material used in the commission of the act.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-101(1)(d): "Habitable structure" means a structure that has the apparent purpose of or is used for lodging or assembling persons or conducting business whether a person is actually present or not.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-101(1)(e): "Property" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-101(1)(e)(i): any form of real property or tangible personal property which is capable of being damaged or destroyed and includes a habitable structure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-101(1)(e)(ii): the property of another, if anyone other than the actor has a possessory or proprietary interest in any portion of the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-101(1)(f): "Value" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-101(1)(f)(i): the market value of the property, if totally destroyed, at the time and place of the offense, or where cost of replacement exceeds the market value; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-101(1)(f)(ii): where the market value cannot be ascertained, the cost of repairing or replacing the property within a reasonable time following the offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-101(2): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-101(3): (1)(f) If the property damaged has a value that cannot be ascertained by the criteria set forth in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102 Arson.
-------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(2): An actor commits arson if, under circumstances not amounting to aggravated arson, the person by means of fire or explosives unlawfully and intentionally damages:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(2)(a): any property with intention of defrauding an insurer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(2)(b): the property of another.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3): (2)(a); (2)(b); 76-1-101.5; 76-6-103; (2)(b); (2)(b); 76-1-101.5; 76-6-103; (2)(b); (2)(b); 76-6-103; (2)(b); (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(a): (2)(a) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(b): (2)(b); 76-1-101.5; 76-6-103; (2)(b) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(b)(i): the damage caused is or exceeds $5,000 in value;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(b)(ii): 76-1-101.5 as a proximate result of the fire or explosion, any person not a participant in the offense suffers serious bodily injury as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(b)(iii): 76-6-103; (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(b)(iii)(A): the damage caused is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000 in value; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(b)(iii)(B): 76-6-103; (2)(b) at the time of the offense the actor has been previously convicted of a violation of this section or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(c): (2)(b); 76-1-101.5; 76-6-103; (2)(b) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(c)(i): the damage caused is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000 in value;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(c)(ii): 76-1-101.5 as a proximate result of the fire or explosion, any person not a participant in the offense suffers substantial bodily injury as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(c)(iii): the fire or explosion endangers human life; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(c)(iv): 76-6-103; (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(c)(iv)(A): the damage caused is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500 in value; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(c)(iv)(B): 76-6-103; (2)(b) at the time of the offense the actor has been previously convicted of a violation of this section or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(d): (2)(b); 76-6-103; (2)(b) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(d)(i): is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500 in value; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(d)(ii): 76-6-103; (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(d)(ii)(A): is less than $500; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(d)(ii)(B): 76-6-103; (2)(b) at the time of the offense the actor has been previously convicted of a violation of this section or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-102(3)(e): (2)(b) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-103 Aggravated arson.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-103(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-103(2): An actor commits aggravated arson if by means of fire or explosives the actor intentionally and unlawfully damages:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-103(2)(a): a habitable structure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-103(2)(b): any structure or vehicle when any person not a participant in the offense is in the structure or vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-103(3): (2) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104 Reckless burning.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104(2): An actor commits reckless burning if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104(2)(a): recklessly starts a fire or causes an explosion which endangers human life;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104(2)(b): having started a fire, whether recklessly or not, and knowing that it is spreading and will endanger the life or property of another, either fails to take reasonable measures to put out or control the fire or fails to give a prompt fire alarm;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104(2)(c): builds or maintains a fire without taking reasonable steps to remove all flammable materials surrounding the site of the fire as necessary to prevent the fire's spread or escape; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104(2)(d): damages the property of another by reckless use of fire or causing an explosion.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104(3): (2)(a); (b); (2)(c); (2)(d); (2)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104(3)(a): (2)(a); (b) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104(3)(b): (2)(c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104(3)(c): (2)(d) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104(3)(c)(i): a class A misdemeanor if damage to property is or exceeds $1,500 in value;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104(3)(c)(ii): a class B misdemeanor if the damage to property is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500 in value; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104(3)(c)(iii): a class C misdemeanor if the damage to property is or exceeds $150 but is less than $500 in value.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104(3)(d): (2)(d) Any other violation under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104.5 Abandonment of a fire -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104.5(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104.5(2): An actor commits abandonment of a fire if, under circumstances not amounting to the offense of arson, aggravated arson, or causing a catastrophe, the actor leaves a fire:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104.5(2)(a): without first completely extinguishing it; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104.5(2)(b): with the intent to not return to the fire.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104.5(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104.5(3)(a): is a class C misdemeanor if there is no property damage;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104.5(3)(b): is a class B misdemeanor if property damage is less than $1,000 in value; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104.5(3)(c): is a class A misdemeanor if property damage is or exceeds $1,000 in value.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104.5(4): (2) An actor does not commit a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104.5(5): (2); 65A-3-4 If a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-104.5(6): (2)(a) A fire spreading or reigniting is prima facie evidence that the actor did not completely extinguish the fire as required by Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-105 Causing a catastrophe -- Penalties.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-105(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-105(2): 76-10-401 An actor commits causing a catastrophe if the actor causes widespread injury or damage to persons or property by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-105(2)(a): 76-10-401 use of a weapon of mass destruction as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-105(2)(b): explosion, fire, flood, avalanche, collapse of a building, or other harmful or destructive force or substance that is not a weapon of mass destruction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-105(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-105(3)(a): a first degree felony if the actor causes the catastrophe knowingly and by the use of a weapon of mass destruction;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-105(3)(b): a second degree felony if the actor causes the catastrophe knowingly and by a means other than a weapon of mass destruction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-105(3)(c): a class A misdemeanor if the actor causes the catastrophe recklessly.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-105(4): In addition to any other penalty authorized by law, a court shall order an actor convicted of any violation of this section to reimburse any federal, state, or local unit of government, or any private business, organization, individual, or entity for all expenses incurred in responding to the violation, unless the court states on the record the reasons why the reimbursement would be inappropriate.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106 Criminal mischief.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(1): 26B-2-201; 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(1)(a): 26B-2-201 As used in this section, "critical infrastructure" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(1)(a)(i): financial and banking systems;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(1)(a)(ii): any railroads, airlines, airports, airways, highways, bridges, waterways, fixed guideways, or other transportation systems intended for the transportation of persons or property;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(1)(a)(iii): 26B-2-201 health care facilities as listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(1)(a)(iv): public health facilities and systems;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(1)(a)(v): food distribution systems; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(1)(a)(vi): other government operations and services.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(2): An actor commits criminal mischief if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(2)(a): intentionally and unlawfully tampers with the property of another and as a result:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(2)(a)(i): recklessly endangers:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(2)(a)(i)(A): human life; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(2)(a)(i)(B): human health or safety; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(2)(a)(ii): recklessly causes or threatens a substantial interruption or impairment of any critical infrastructure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(2)(b): recklessly or willfully shoots or propels a missile or other object at or against a motor vehicle, bus, airplane, boat, locomotive, train, railway car, or caboose, whether moving or standing.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(3): (2)(a)(i)(A); (2)(a)(i)(B); (2)(a)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(3)(a): (2)(a)(i)(A) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(3)(b): (2)(a)(i)(B) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(3)(c): (2)(a)(ii) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(3)(d): Any other violation of this section is a:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(3)(d)(i): second degree felony if the actor's conduct causes or is intended to cause pecuniary loss equal to or in excess of $5,000 in value;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(3)(d)(ii): third degree felony if the actor's conduct causes or is intended to cause pecuniary loss equal to or in excess of $1,500 but is less than $5,000 in value;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(3)(d)(iii): class A misdemeanor if the actor's conduct causes or is intended to cause pecuniary loss equal to or in excess of $500 but is less than $1,500 in value; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(3)(d)(iv): class B misdemeanor if the actor's conduct causes or is intended to cause pecuniary loss less than $500 in value.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(4): 76-6-703 In determining the value of damages under this section, or for computer crimes under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106(5): (2)(a)(ii) In addition to any other penalty authorized by law, a court shall order an actor convicted of any violation of this section to reimburse any federal, state, or local unit of government, or any private business, organization, individual, or entity for all expenses incurred in responding to a violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.1 Property damage or destruction.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.1(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.1(2): An actor commits property damage or destruction if the actor under circumstances not amounting to arson or criminal mischief:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.1(2)(a): damages or destroys property with the intention of defrauding an insurer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.1(2)(b): intentionally damages, defaces, or destroys the property of another.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.1(3): (3)(a)(ii); (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.1(3)(a): (3)(a)(ii); (2)(a); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.1(3)(a)(i): (3)(a)(ii); (2)(a) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.1(3)(a)(ii): (2)(a) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.1(3)(b): (2)(b) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.1(3)(b)(i): second degree felony if the actor's conduct causes or is intended to cause pecuniary loss equal to or in excess of $5,000 in value;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.1(3)(b)(ii): third degree felony if the actor's conduct causes or is intended to cause pecuniary loss equal to or in excess of $1,500 but is less than $5,000 in value;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.1(3)(b)(iii): class A misdemeanor if the actor's conduct causes or is intended to cause pecuniary loss equal to or in excess of $500 but is less than $1,500 in value; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.1(3)(b)(iv): class B misdemeanor if the actor's conduct causes or is intended to cause pecuniary loss less than $500 in value.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.1(4): 76-6-703 In determining the value of damages under this section, or for computer crimes under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3 Destruction or tampering with a critical infrastructure facility -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1): 73-1-14; (1)(a)(i); 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a): 73-1-14; (1)(a)(i) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i): 73-1-14 "Critical infrastructure facility" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(A): a petroleum or alumina refinery;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(B): critical electric infrastructure, as defined in 18 C.F.R. Sec. 388.113, including an electrical power generating facility, substation, switching station, electrical control center, or electric power lines and associated equipment infrastructure;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(C): a chemical, polymer, or rubber manufacturing facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(D): 73-1-14 a water facility as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(E): a natural gas compressor station;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(F): a liquid natural gas terminal or storage facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(G): a telecommunications switching, routing, or regeneration office or facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(H): wireless telecommunications infrastructure, including cell towers;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(I): telecommunications equipment, facilities, or infrastructure used for the transmission or distribution of a communications service;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(J): a port, railroad switching yard, railroad tracks, trucking terminal, or other freight transportation facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(K): a gas processing plant, including a plant used in the processing, treatment, or fractionation of natural gas or natural gas liquids;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(L): a transmission facility used by a federally licensed radio or television station;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(M): a steelmaking facility that uses an electric arc furnace to make steel;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(N): a facility identified and regulated by the Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standards program under 6 U.S.C. Sec. 622;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(O): a natural gas distribution utility facility, including natural gas distribution and transmission mains and services, pipeline interconnections, a city gate or town border station, metering station, meters, aboveground piping and facilities, a regulator station, and a natural gas storage facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(P): a crude oil or refined products production, storage, and distribution facility, including a wellhead and associated production and collection infrastructure, valve sites, pipeline interconnection, pump station, metering station, below or aboveground pipeline or piping, and truck loading or offloading facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(Q): a grain mill or processing facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(R): a generation, transmission, or distribution system of broadband Internet access; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(i)(S): an aboveground portion of an oil, gas, hazardous liquid or chemical production facility including the wellhead and associated production and collection infrastructure, pipeline, tank, railroad facility, or other storage facility that is enclosed by a physical barrier or is marked with signs prohibiting trespassing if the enclosures or signs are designed to exclude intruders.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(ii): (1)(a)(i) "Critical infrastructure facility" includes a facility described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(ii)(A): under construction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(a)(ii)(B): operational.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(2): An actor is guilty of destruction or tampering with a critical infrastructure facility if the actor, by physical, cyber, or other means, causes widespread injury or damage to persons or property by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(2)(a): destroying or substantially damaging:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(2)(a)(i): a critical infrastructure facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(2)(a)(ii): a critical infrastructure facility's equipment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(2)(b): substantially tampering with, inhibiting, or impeding the operation of a critical infrastructure facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(3): (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-106.3(3)(b): (2) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107 Defacement by graffiti defined -- Penalties -- Removal costs -- Reimbursement liability -- Victim liability.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(1)(a): As used in this section, "victim" means the person whose property is defaced or damaged by the use of graffiti and who bears the expense for removal of the graffiti.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(2): An actor commits defacement by graffiti if the actor, without permission, defaces or damages the property of another by graffiti.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(3)(a): second degree felony if the damage caused is in excess of $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(3)(b): third degree felony if the damage caused is equal to or in excess of $1,000 but less than or equal to $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(3)(c): class A misdemeanor if the damage caused is equal to or in excess of $300 but less than $1,000; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(3)(d): class B misdemeanor if the damage caused is less than $300.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(4): (3) Damages under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(5): (3) The court shall order an individual convicted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(6): An additional amount of $1,000 in restitution shall be added to removal costs if the graffiti is positioned on an overpass or an underpass, requires that traffic be interfered with in order to remove it, or the entity responsible for the area in which the clean-up is to take place must provide assistance in order for the removal to take place safely.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(7): An individual who voluntarily, at the individual's own expense, and with the consent of the property owner, removes graffiti for which the individual is responsible may be credited for the removal costs against restitution ordered by a court.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(8): Before an authorized government agency may issue a citation or assess a fine to a victim for the victim's failure to remove graffiti from the victim's property, the agency shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(8)(a): provide written notice to the victim alerting the victim of the graffiti;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(8)(b): allow the victim one week after the day on which the agency provides written notice of the graffiti to remove the graffiti; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(8)(c): provide the victim with a list of resources available to assist the victim with removal of the graffiti.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(9): (8)(a); (8)(a); (9)(b)(ii); (5)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(9)(a): (8)(a); (8)(a) After receiving notification of graffiti under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(9)(b): If an authorized government agency finds a victim has demonstrated that the victim would experience significant hardship in removing the graffiti, the agency:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(9)(b)(i): may not issue a citation or assess a fee to the victim for failure to remove the graffiti; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(9)(b)(ii): shall provide, or hire an outside entity to provide, the assistance necessary to remove the graffiti from the victim's property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107(9)(c): (9)(b)(ii); (5) An authorized government agency that provides, or hires an outside agency to provide, assistance under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107.5 Defacing by graffiti on public lands.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107.5(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107.5(1)(a): As used in this section, "public lands" means state or federally owned property that is held substantially in the property's natural state, including canyons, parks owned or managed by the state, national parks, land managed by the Bureau of Land Management, and other lands owned or maintained by a government entity for outdoor recreational use.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107.5(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107.5(2): An actor commits defacing by graffiti on public lands if the actor creates, or assists in creating, graffiti on any public lands or state-owned object permanently located on public lands.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107.5(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107.5(3)(a): a class B misdemeanor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107.5(3)(b): if the individual was previously convicted of violating this section, a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107.5(4): If an actor is convicted of defacing by graffiti on public lands, the court shall sentence the actor to a term of community service as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107.5(4)(a): for a first conviction, the court shall sentence the actor to 100 hours of community service, to be completed within 90 days after the day on which the court issues the order;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107.5(4)(b): for a second conviction, the court shall sentence the actor to 200 hours of community service, to be completed within 180 days after the day on which the court issues the order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107.5(4)(c): for a third or subsequent conviction, the court shall sentence the actor to 300 hours of community service, to be completed within 270 days after the day on which the court issues the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107.5(5): If an actor is enrolled in school or maintains full or part-time employment, the ordered community service may not be scheduled at a time the actor is scheduled to be in school or performing the individual's employment duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107.5(6): A sentence of community service described in Subjection (4) shall, to the greatest extent possible, be for the benefit of public lands.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107.5(7): If an actor is convicted of defacing by graffiti on public lands, the court may impose a fine up to the full amount of the estimated cost to restore the damaged land, caused by the actor, to the land's original state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-107.5(8): (7) An actor who voluntarily, at the actor's own expense, and with the consent of the property owner, removes graffiti for which the actor is responsible shall be credited for costs ordered by the court under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-108 Damage to or interruption of a communication device -- Penalty.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-108(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-108(1)(a): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-108(1)(a)(i): "Communication device" means any device, including a telephone, cellular telephone, computer, or radio, which may be used in an attempt to summon police, fire, medical, or other emergency aid.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-108(1)(a)(ii): "Emergency aid" means aid or assistance, including law enforcement, fire, or medical services, commonly summoned by persons concerned with imminent or actual:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-108(1)(a)(ii)(A): jeopardy to any person's health or safety; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-108(1)(a)(ii)(B): damage to any person's property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-108(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-108(2): An actor commits damage to or interruption of a communication device if the actor attempts to prohibit or interrupt, or prohibits or interrupts, another person's use of a communication device when the other person is attempting to summon emergency aid or has communicated a desire to summon emergency aid, and in the process the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-108(2)(a): uses force, intimidation, or any other form of violence;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-108(2)(b): destroys, disables, or damages a communication device; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-108(2)(c): commits any other act in an attempt to prohibit or interrupt the person's use of a communication device to summon emergency aid.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-108(3): (2) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111 Wanton destruction of livestock -- Penalties -- Restitution criteria -- Seizure and disposition of property.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(1): 53-13-103; 4-39-102; 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(1)(a): 53-13-103; 4-39-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(1)(a)(i): 53-13-103 "Law enforcement officer" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(1)(a)(ii): 4-39-102 "Livestock" means a domestic animal or fur bearer raised or kept for profit or as an asset, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(1)(a)(ii)(A): cattle;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(1)(a)(ii)(B): sheep;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(1)(a)(ii)(C): goats;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(1)(a)(ii)(D): swine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(1)(a)(ii)(E): horses;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(1)(a)(ii)(F): mules;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(1)(a)(ii)(G): poultry;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(1)(a)(ii)(H): 4-39-102 domesticated elk as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(1)(a)(ii)(I): livestock guardian dogs.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(1)(a)(iii): "Livestock guardian dog" means a dog that is being used to live with and guard livestock, other than itself, from predators.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(2): 4-25-201; 4-25-202; 4-25-401; 4-39-401; 18-1-3 Unless authorized by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(2)(a): injures, physically alters, releases, or causes the death of livestock; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(2)(b): does so:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(2)(b)(i): intentionally or knowingly; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(2)(b)(ii): without the permission of the owner of the livestock.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(3)(a): class B misdemeanor if the aggregate value of the livestock is $250 or less;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(3)(b): class A misdemeanor if the aggregate value of the livestock is more than $250, but does not exceed $750;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(3)(c): third degree felony if the aggregate value of the livestock is more than $750, but does not exceed $5,000; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(3)(d): second degree felony if the aggregate value of the livestock is more than $5,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(4): (2) For purposes of this section, a livestock guardian dog is presumed to belong to an owner of the livestock with which the livestock guardian dog was living at the time of an alleged violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(5): Title 77, Chapter 38b, Crime Victims Restitution Act; (6); 77-38b-205 When a court orders an actor who is convicted of wanton destruction of livestock to pay restitution under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(6): 4-2-102 The minimum restitution value for cattle and sheep is the sum of the following, unless the court states on the record why it finds the sum to be inappropriate:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(6)(a): 4-2-102 the fair market value of the animal, using as a guide the market information obtained from the Department of Agriculture and Food created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(6)(b): 10 years times the average annual value of offspring, for which average annual value is determined using data obtained from the National Agricultural Statistics Service within the United States Department of Agriculture, for the most recent 10-year period available.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(7): (2); Title 77, Chapter 11b, Forfeiture of Seized Property A material, device, or vehicle used in violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(8): (2); (2) A peace officer may seize a material, device, or vehicle used in violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(8)(a): upon notice and service of process issued by a court having jurisdiction over the property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(8)(b): (2) without notice and service of process if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(8)(b)(i): the seizure is incident to an arrest under:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(8)(b)(i)(A): a search warrant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(8)(b)(i)(B): an inspection under an administrative inspection warrant;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(8)(b)(ii): the material, device, or vehicle has been the subject of a prior judgment in favor of the state in a criminal injunction or forfeiture proceeding under this section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(8)(b)(iii): (2) the peace officer has probable cause to believe that the property has been used in violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(9)(a): A material, device, or vehicle seized under this section is not repleviable but is in custody of the law enforcement agency making the seizure, subject only to the orders and decrees of a court or official having jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(9)(b): A peace officer who seizes a material, device, or vehicle under this section may:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(9)(b)(i): place the property under seal;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(9)(b)(ii): remove the property to a place designated by the warrant under which it was seized; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-111(9)(b)(iii): take custody of the property and remove it to an appropriate location for disposition in accordance with law.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-112 Agricultural operation interference -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-112(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-112(1)(a): As used in this section, "agricultural operation" means private property used for the production of livestock, poultry, livestock products, or poultry products.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-112(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-112(2): 76-6-206 An actor commits agricultural operation interference if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-112(2)(a): without consent from the owner of the agricultural operation, or the owner's agent, knowingly or intentionally records an image of, or sound from, the agricultural operation by leaving a recording device on the agricultural operation;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-112(2)(b): obtains access to an agricultural operation under false pretenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-112(2)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-112(2)(c)(i): applies for employment at an agricultural operation with the intent to record an image of, or sound from, the agricultural operation;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-112(2)(c)(ii): knows, at the time that the actor accepts employment at the agricultural operation, that the owner of the agricultural operation prohibits the employee from recording an image of, or sound from, the agricultural operation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-112(2)(c)(iii): while employed at, and while present on, the agricultural operation, records an image of, or sound from, the agricultural operation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-112(2)(d): 76-6-206 without consent from the owner of the operation or the owner's agent, knowingly or intentionally records an image of, or sound from, an agricultural operation while the person is committing criminal trespass, as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-112(3): (2)(a); (2)(b); (c); (d)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-112(3)(a): (2)(a) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-112(3)(b): (2)(b); (c); (d) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-201 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-201(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-201(1)(a): "Building," in addition to its ordinary meaning, means any watercraft, aircraft, trailer, or other structure or vehicle adapted for overnight accommodation of persons or for carrying on business and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-201(1)(a)(i): each separately secured or occupied portion of the structure or vehicle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-201(1)(a)(ii): each structure appurtenant to or connected with the structure or vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-201(1)(b): "Building" does not include a railroad car.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-201(2): "Dwelling" means a building which is usually occupied by a person lodging in the building at night, whether or not a person is actually present.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-201(3): "Enter or remain unlawfully" means a person enters or remains in or on any premises when:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-201(3)(a): at the time of the entry or remaining, the premises or any portion of the premises are not open to the public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-201(3)(b): the actor is not otherwise licensed or privileged to enter or remain on the premises or any portion of the premises.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-201(4): "Enter" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-201(4)(a): intrusion of any part of the body; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-201(4)(b): intrusion of any physical object under control of the actor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-201(5): "Railroad car":
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-201(5)(a): in addition to its ordinary meaning, includes a sleeping car or any container or trailer that is on a railroad car; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-201(5)(b): includes only a railroad car that is operable and part of an ongoing railroad operation.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-202 Burglary.
----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-202(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-101 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-202(2): 76-9-702; 76-9-702.1; 76-9-702.5; 76-9-702.7 An actor commits burglary if the actor enters or remains unlawfully in a building or any portion of a building with intent to commit:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-202(2)(a): a felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-202(2)(b): theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-202(2)(c): an assault on any person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-202(2)(d): 76-9-702 lewdness, in violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-202(2)(e): 76-9-702.1 sexual battery, in violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-202(2)(f): 76-9-702.5 lewdness involving a child, in violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-202(2)(g): 76-9-702.7 voyeurism, in violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-202(3): (3)(b); (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-202(3)(a): (3)(b); (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-202(3)(b): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-202(4): (2)(a); (g) A violation of this section is a separate offense from any of the offenses listed in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-203 Aggravated burglary.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-203(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-201 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-203(2): An actor commits aggravated burglary if in attempting, committing, or fleeing from a burglary the actor or another participant in the crime:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-203(2)(a): causes bodily injury to any person who is not a participant in the crime;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-203(2)(b): uses or threatens the immediate use of a dangerous weapon against any person who is not a participant in the crime; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-203(2)(c): possesses or attempts to use any explosive or dangerous weapon.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-203(3): (2) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-204 Burglary of a vehicle -- Charge of other offense.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-204(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-201 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-204(2): An actor commits burglary of a vehicle if the actor unlawfully enters any vehicle with intent to commit a felony or theft.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-204(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-204(4): (2) A charge against an actor for a violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-204.5 Burglary of a railroad car -- Charge of other offenses.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-204.5(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-201 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-204.5(2): An actor commits burglary of a railroad car if the actor breaks the lock or seal on any railroad car, with the intent to commit a felony or theft.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-204.5(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-204.5(4): (2) Charging a person for a violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-205 Manufacture or possession of instrument for burglary or theft.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-205(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-201 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-205(2): An actor commits manufacture or possession of an instrument for burglary or theft if the actor manufactures or possesses any instrument, tool, device, article, or other thing adapted, designed, or commonly used in advancing or facilitating the commission of any offense under circumstances manifesting an intent to use or knowledge that another person intends to use the same in the commission of a burglary or theft.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-205(3): (2) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206 Criminal trespass.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(1): 76-6-101; 76-1-101.5; 76-6-201
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(1)(a): 76-6-101 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(1)(a)(i): "Enter" means intrusion of the entire body or the entire unmanned aircraft.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(1)(a)(ii): 76-6-101 "Graffiti" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(1)(a)(iii): "Remain unlawfully," as that term relates to an unmanned aircraft, means remaining on or over private property when:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(1)(a)(iii)(A): the private property or any portion of the private property is not open to the public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(1)(a)(iii)(B): the person operating the unmanned aircraft is not otherwise authorized to fly the unmanned aircraft over the private property or any portion of the private property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-201 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(2): 76-6-202; 76-6-203; 76-6-204; 76-10-2402; 57-8-7(8) An actor commits criminal trespass if, under circumstances not amounting to burglary as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(2)(a): the actor enters or remains unlawfully on or causes an unmanned aircraft to enter and remain unlawfully over property and:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(2)(a)(i): intends to cause annoyance or injury to any person or damage to any property, including the use of graffiti;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(2)(a)(ii): intends to commit any crime, other than theft or a felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(2)(a)(iii): is reckless as to whether the actor's or unmanned aircraft's presence will cause fear for the safety of another;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(2)(b): knowing the actor's or unmanned aircraft's entry or presence is unlawful, the actor enters or remains on or causes an unmanned aircraft to enter or remain unlawfully over property to which notice against entering is given by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(2)(b)(i): personal communication to the actor by the owner or someone with apparent authority to act for the owner;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(2)(b)(ii): fencing or other enclosure obviously designed to exclude intruders; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(2)(b)(iii): posting of signs reasonably likely to come to the attention of intruders; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(2)(c): 57-8-7(8) the actor enters a condominium unit in violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(3): (3)(b); (2)(a); (b); (2)(a); (b); (2)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(3)(a): (3)(b); (2)(a); (b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(3)(b): (2)(a); (b) If a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(3)(c): (2)(c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(4): It is a defense to prosecution under this section that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(4)(a): the property was at the time open to the public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(4)(b): the defendant complied with all lawful conditions imposed on access to or remaining on the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(5): 77-38b-205; (2); (2) In addition to an order for restitution under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(5)(a): (2) statutory damages in the amount of three times the value of damages resulting from the violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(5)(b): reasonable attorney fees not to exceed $250, and court costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206(6): (5) Civil damages under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.1 Criminal trespass of abandoned or inactive mines.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.1(1): 76-6-202; 76-6-203; 76-6-204; 76-1-101.5; 76-6-201
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.1(1)(a): 76-6-202; 76-6-203; 76-6-204 For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.1(1)(a)(i): "Abandoned or inactive mine" means an underground mine which is no longer open for access or no longer under excavation and has been clearly marked as closed or protected from entry.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.1(1)(a)(ii): 76-6-202; 76-6-203; 76-6-204 "Burglary" means an offense described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.1(1)(a)(iii): "Enter" means intrusion of the entire body.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.1(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-201 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.1(2): An actor commits criminal trespass of an abandoned or inactive mine if, under circumstances not amounting to burglary, the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.1(2)(a): intentionally enters and remains unlawfully in the underground workings of an abandoned or inactive mine; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.1(2)(b): intentionally and without authority removes, destroys, or tampers with any warning sign, covering, fencing, or other method of protection from entry placed on, around, or over any mine shaft, mine portal, or other abandoned or inactive mining excavation property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.1(3): (2)(a); (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.1(3)(a): (2)(a) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.1(3)(b): (2)(b) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2 Criminal trespass on state park lands.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(1): 76-6-206; 79-4-201; 76-1-101.5; 76-6-201
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(1)(a): 76-6-206; 79-4-201 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(1)(a)(i): "Authorization" means specific written permission by, or contractual agreement with, the Division of State Parks.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(1)(a)(ii): 76-6-206 "Criminal trespass" means the elements of the crime of criminal trespass, as set forth in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(1)(a)(iii): 79-4-201 "Division" means the Division of State Parks created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(1)(a)(iv): "State park lands" means all lands administered by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-201 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(2): (5); 72-3-112 An actor commits criminal trespass on state park lands and is liable for the civil damages prescribed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(2)(a): constructs improvements or structures on state park lands;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(2)(b): uses or occupies state park lands for more than 30 days after the cancellation or expiration of authorization;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(2)(c): knowingly or intentionally uses state park lands for commercial gain;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(2)(d): 72-3-112 intentionally or knowingly grazes livestock on state park lands, except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(2)(e): remains, after being ordered to leave by a person with actual authority to act for the division, or by a law enforcement officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(4): A person does not commit criminal trespass if that person enters onto state park lands:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(4)(a): without first paying the required fee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(4)(b): for the sole purpose of pursuing recreational activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(5): 77-38b-205; (2); (2); (5)(a); 79-4-402
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(5)(a): 77-38b-205; (2); (2) In addition to an order for restitution under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(5)(a)(i): (2) damages resulting from a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(5)(a)(ii): the water, mineral, vegetation, improvement, or structure on state park lands that is removed, destroyed, used, or consumed without authorization;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(5)(a)(iii): the historical, prehistorical, archaeological, or paleontological resource on state park lands that is removed, destroyed, used, or consumed without authorization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(5)(a)(iv): the consideration which would have been charged by the division for unauthorized use of the land and resources during the period of trespass.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(5)(b): (5)(a); 79-4-402 Civil damages awarded under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(5)(b)(i): may be collected in a separate action by the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.2(5)(b)(ii): 79-4-402 shall be deposited into the State Park Fees Restricted Account as established in Section

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
