Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(1)(a)(ii): "Authorization" means specific written permission by, or contractual agreement with, the owner or manager of the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(1)(a)(iii): 76-6-206 "Criminal trespass" means the elements of the crime of criminal trespass under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(1)(a)(iv): 59-2-502 "Land in agricultural use" has the same meaning as in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(1)(a)(v): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(1)(a)(v)(A): "Range land" means privately owned land that is not fenced or divided into lots and that is generally unimproved.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(1)(a)(v)(B): "Range land" includes land used for livestock.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-201 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(2): (5) An actor commits criminal trespass on agricultural or range land and is liable for the civil damages under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(2)(a): personal communication to the actor by the owner of the land, an employee of the owner, or a person with apparent authority to act for the owner;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(2)(b): fencing or other form of enclosure a reasonable person would recognize as intended to exclude intruders; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(2)(c): posted signs or markers that would reasonably be expected to be seen by persons in the area of the borders of the land.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(4): 77-38b-205; (2); (2) In addition to an order for restitution under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(4)(a): (2) statutory damages in the amount of three times the value of damages resulting from the violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(4)(b): reasonable attorney fees not to exceed $250; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(4)(c): court costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.3(5): (4) Civil damages under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.4 Criminal trespass by long-term guest to a residence.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.4(1): 76-6-202; 76-6-203; 76-6-204; 76-1-101.5; 76-6-201
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.4(1)(a): 76-6-202; 76-6-203; 76-6-204 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.4(1)(a)(i): 76-6-202; 76-6-203; 76-6-204 "Burglary" means an offense described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.4(1)(a)(ii): "Long-term guest" means an individual who is not a tenant but who is given express or implied permission by the person who is the primary occupant of the residence or someone with apparent authority to act for the primary occupant to enter a portion of a residence or temporarily occupy a portion of a residence:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.4(1)(a)(ii)(A): for a period of time longer than 48 hours; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.4(1)(a)(ii)(B): without providing the owner or primary occupant of the residence compensation or entering into an agreement that the individual provide labor in lieu of providing the owner or primary occupant compensation for occupying the residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.4(1)(a)(iii): "Residence" means an improvement to real property used or occupied as a primary or secondary dwelling.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.4(1)(a)(iv): "Tenant" means a person who has the right to occupy a residence under a rental agreement or lease, or has a tenancy by operation of law.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.4(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-201 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.4(2): An actor commits criminal trespass of a residence if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.4(2)(a): is a long-term guest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.4(2)(b): in circumstances not amounting to burglary, remains in a residence after the actor receives notice against remaining in the residence by personal communication to the actor by the person who is the primary occupant of the residence or someone with apparent authority to act for the primary occupant.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.4(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.4(4): (2) Before a law enforcement officer escorts an actor from a residence for a violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.5 Cutting, destroying, or rendering ineffective fencing of agricultural or range land.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.5(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-201; 76-6-206.3 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.5(2): An actor commits cutting, destroying, or rendering ineffective the fencing of agricultural or range land if the person willfully cuts, destroys, or renders ineffective any fencing or other form of enclosure a reasonable person would recognize as intended to exclude intruders.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.5(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.5(4): 77-38b-205; (2) In addition to an order for restitution under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.5(4)(a): statutory damages in the amount of $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.5(4)(b): reasonable attorney fees not to exceed $250; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.5(4)(c): court costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.5(5): (4) Civil damages under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6 Criminal trespass on private property for recreational purposes related to use of public waters.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1): 73-29-102; 76-1-101.5; 76-6-201
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a): 73-29-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a)(i): "Bank" means the land within three feet of a public water.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a)(ii): "Private property" means the bed or bank of a non-navigable freshwater stream or river that flows through privately owned land and is privately owned.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a)(iii): 73-29-102 "Private property to which access is restricted" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a)(iv): "Recreational purpose" includes one or more of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a)(iv)(A): hunting;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a)(iv)(B): fishing;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a)(iv)(C): swimming;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a)(iv)(D): skiing;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a)(iv)(E): snowshoeing;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a)(iv)(F): camping;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a)(iv)(G): picnicking;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a)(iv)(H): hiking;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a)(iv)(I): studying nature;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a)(iv)(J): engaging in water sports;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a)(iv)(K): mountain biking; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(a)(iv)(L): viewing or enjoying historical, archaeological, scenic, or scientific sites.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-201 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(2): 73-29-201 An actor is guilty of criminal trespass if for recreational purposes, under circumstances not amounting to a greater offense, and without authorization or a right under state law:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(2)(a): 73-29-201 the actor touches or remains unlawfully on private property to which access is restricted in violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(2)(a)(i): intends to cause annoyance or injury to a person or damage to property;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(2)(a)(ii): intends to commit a crime, other than theft or a felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(2)(a)(iii): is reckless as to whether the actor's presence will cause fear for the safety of another; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(2)(b): knowing the actor's touching or presence is unlawful, the actor touches or remains on private property to which notice against entering is given by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(2)(b)(i): personal communication to the actor by the owner or someone with apparent authority to act for the owner;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(2)(b)(ii): fencing or other enclosure obviously designed to exclude intruders; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(2)(b)(iii): posting of signs reasonably likely to come to the attention of intruders.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(4): 73-29-202 It is a defense to prosecution under this section that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(4)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(4)(a)(i): the private property was at the time open to the public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(4)(a)(ii): the actor complied with all lawful conditions imposed on access to or remaining on the private property;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(4)(b): the actor acted in compliance with an express easement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(4)(c): 73-29-202 the actor touched the private property as allowed by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(5): 77-38b-205; (2); (2) In addition to an order for restitution under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(5)(a): (2) statutory damages in the amount of the greater of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(5)(a)(i): (2) three times the value of damages resulting from the violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(5)(a)(ii): $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(5)(b): reasonable attorney fees not to exceed $250; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(5)(c): court costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-206.6(6): (5) Civil damages under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-301 Robbery.
---------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-301(1): 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-301(1)(a): As used in this section, an act is considered to be "in the course of committing a theft or unauthorized possession of property" if the act occurs:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-301(1)(a)(i): in the course of an attempt to commit theft or unauthorized possession of property;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-301(1)(a)(ii): in the commission of theft or unauthorized possession of property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-301(1)(a)(iii): in the immediate flight after the attempt or commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-301(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-301(2): An actor commits robbery if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-301(2)(a): unlawfully and intentionally takes or attempts to take personal property in the possession of an individual from the individual's person, or immediate presence, against the individual's will, by means of force or fear, and with a purpose or intent to deprive the individual permanently or temporarily of the personal property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-301(2)(b): intentionally or knowingly uses force or fear of immediate force against an individual in the course of committing a theft or unauthorized possession of property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-301(3): (2) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-302 Aggravated robbery.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-302(1): 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-302(1)(a): As used in this section, an act is considered to be "in the course of committing a robbery" if the act occurs in an attempt to commit, during the commission of, or in the immediate flight after the attempt or commission of a robbery.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-302(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-302(2): An actor commits aggravated robbery if in the course of committing a robbery, the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-302(2)(a): uses or threatens to use a dangerous weapon;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-302(2)(b): causes serious bodily injury to another individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-302(2)(c): takes or attempts to take an operable motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-302(3): (2) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-401 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-401(1): "Deception" occurs when a person intentionally:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-401(1)(a): creates or confirms by words or conduct an impression of law or fact that is false and that the actor does not believe to be true and that is likely to affect the judgment of another in the transaction;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-401(1)(b): fails to correct a false impression of law or fact that the actor previously created or confirmed by words or conduct that is likely to affect the judgment of another and that the actor does not now believe to be true;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-401(1)(c): prevents another person from acquiring information likely to affect the person's judgment in the transaction;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-401(1)(d): sells or otherwise transfers or encumbers property without disclosing a lien, security interest, adverse claim, or other legal impediment to the enjoyment of the property, regardless of whether the lien, security interest, claim, or impediment is valid or is a matter of official record; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-401(1)(e): promises performance that is likely to affect the judgment of another in the transaction, which performance the actor does not intend to perform or knows will not be performed, except that failure to perform the promise in issue without other evidence of intent or knowledge is not sufficient proof that the actor did not intend to perform or knew the promise would not be performed.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-401(2): 76-6-111 "Livestock guardian dog" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-401(3): "Obtain" means, in relation to property, to bring about a transfer of possession or of some other legally recognized interest in property, whether to the obtainer or another; in relation to labor or services, to secure performance thereof; and in relation to a trade secret, to make any facsimile, replica, photograph, or other reproduction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-401(4): "Obtain or exercise unauthorized control" means conduct originally defined or known as common-law larceny by trespassory taking, larceny by conversion, larceny by bailee, or embezzlement.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-401(5): "Property" means anything of value, including real estate, tangible and intangible personal property, captured or domestic animals and birds, written instruments or other writings representing or embodying rights concerning real or personal property, labor, services, or otherwise containing anything of value to the owner, commodities of a public utility nature such as telecommunications, gas, electricity, steam, or water, and trade secrets, meaning the whole or any portion of any scientific or technical information, design, process, procedure, formula, or invention which the owner intends to be available only to persons selected by the owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-401(6): "Purpose to deprive" means to have the conscious object:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-401(6)(a): to withhold property permanently or for so extended a period or to use under such circumstances that a substantial portion of its economic value, or of the use and benefit thereof, would be lost;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-401(6)(b): to restore the property only upon payment of a reward or other compensation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-401(6)(c): to dispose of the property under circumstances that make it unlikely that the owner will recover it.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-402 Presumptions and defenses.
---------------------------------------------------------
The following presumption shall be applicable to this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-402(1): Possession of property recently stolen, when no satisfactory explanation of such possession is made, shall be deemed prima facie evidence that the person in possession stole the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-402(2): 76-3-203.16 It is not a defense under this part that the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-402(2)(a): has an interest in the property or service stolen if another person also has an interest that the actor is not entitled to infringe, unless the interest is a security interest for the repayment of a debt or obligation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-402(2)(b): 76-3-203.16 takes livestock, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-402(3): It is a defense under this part that the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-402(3)(a): acted under an honest claim of right to the property or service involved;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-402(3)(b): acted in the honest belief that the actor had the right to obtain or exercise control over the property or service in the manner the actor obtained or exercised control; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-402(3)(c): obtained or exercised control over the property or service honestly believing that the owner, if present, would have consented.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-402(4): A livestock guardian dog is presumed to belong to an owner of the livestock with which the livestock guardian dog is living at the time of an alleged violation of this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-402.5 Defense regarding metal dealers.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
It is a defense against a charge of theft under this part and a defense against a civil claim for conversion if any dealer as defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-403 Theft -- Evidence to support accusation.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Conduct denominated theft in this part constitutes a single offense embracing the separate offenses such as those heretofore known as larceny, larceny by trick, larceny by bailees, embezzlement, false pretense, extortion, blackmail, receiving stolen property. An accusation of theft may be supported by evidence that it was committed in any manner specified in this part, subject to the power of the court to ensure a fair trial by granting a continuance or other appropriate relief where the conduct of the defense would be prejudiced by lack of fair notice or by surprise.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404 Theft -- Elements.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(2): An actor commits theft if the actor obtains or exercises unauthorized control over another person's property with a purpose to deprive the person of the person's property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3): (2); 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402; Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii); (3) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(a): a second degree felony if the:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(a)(i): value of the property is or exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(a)(ii): property stolen is a firearm or an operable motor vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(a)(iii): property is stolen from the person of another;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(b): 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402; Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(b)(i): the value of the property is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(b)(ii): 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402 the property is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(b)(ii)(A): 76-6-1402 a catalytic converter as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(b)(ii)(B): 76-6-1402 25 pounds or more of a suspect metal item as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(b)(iii): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B) the value of the property is or exceeds $500 and the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the following offenses, if each prior offense was committed within 10 years before the date of the current conviction or the date of the offense upon which the current conviction is based and at least one of those convictions is for a class A misdemeanor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(b)(iii)(A): any theft, any robbery, or any burglary with intent to commit theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(b)(iii)(B): Part 5, Fraud any offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(b)(iii)(C): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B) any attempt to commit any offense under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(b)(iv)(A): the value of property is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(b)(iv)(B): the theft occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(b)(iv)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the merchant prohibiting the offender from entering the property pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(b)(v): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) the actor has been previously convicted of a felony violation of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(c): 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) a class A misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404(3)(c)(i): the value of the property stolen is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5 Unauthorized possession of property.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(2): An actor commits unauthorized possession of property if the actor obtains or exercises unauthorized control over another person's property, without the consent of the property's owner or legal custodian, and with the intent to temporarily appropriate, possess, or use the property or to temporarily deprive the property's owner or legal custodian of possession of the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3): (2); 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402; Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii); (3) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(a): a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(a)(i): the value of the property is or exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(a)(ii): the property is a firearm or an operable motor vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(a)(iii): the property is taken from the person of another;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(b): 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402; Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) a class A misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(b)(i): the value of the property is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(b)(ii): 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402 the property is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(b)(ii)(A): 76-6-1402 a catalytic converter as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(b)(ii)(B): 76-6-1402 25 pounds or more of a suspect metal item is defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(b)(iii): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B) the value of the property is or exceeds $500 and the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the following offenses, if each prior offense was committed within 10 years before the date of the current conviction or the date of the offense upon which the current conviction is based and at least one of those convictions is for a class A misdemeanor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(b)(iii)(A): any theft, any robbery, or any burglary with intent to commit theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(b)(iii)(B): Part 5, Fraud any offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(b)(iii)(C): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B) any attempt to commit any offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(b)(iv): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(b)(iv)(A): the value of property is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(b)(iv)(B): the unauthorized possession of property occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(b)(iv)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the merchant prohibiting the offender from entering the property pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(b)(v): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) the actor has been previously convicted of a felony violation of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(c): 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) a class B misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(c)(i): the value of the property is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(c)(ii): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(c)(ii)(A): the value of property is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(c)(ii)(B): the unauthorized possession of property occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(c)(ii)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the merchant prohibiting the offender from entering the property pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(c)(iii): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(3)(d): (3) a class C misdemeanor if the value of the property is less than $500 and the unauthorized possession of property is not an offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(4): 76-6-404 Unauthorized possession of property is a lesser included offense of the offense of theft under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.5(5): The consent of the owner or legal custodian of the property to the property's control by the actor is not presumed or implied because of the owner's or legal custodian's consent on a previous occasion to the control of the property by any person.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7 Theft of motor vehicle fuel.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(1): 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(1)(a): As used in this section, "motor vehicle fuel" means any combustible gas, liquid, matter, or substance that is used in an internal combustion engine for the generation of power.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(2): (2)(a) An actor commits theft of motor vehicle fuel if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(2)(a): causes a motor vehicle to leave any premises where motor vehicle fuel is offered for retail sale when motor fuel has been dispensed into:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(2)(a)(i): the fuel tank of the motor vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(2)(a)(ii): any other container that is then removed from the premises by means of the motor vehicle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(2)(b): (2)(a) commits the act under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3): (2); Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C); (3)(c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(a): a second degree felony if the value of the motor vehicle fuel is or exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(b): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(b)(i): the value of the motor vehicle fuel is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(b)(ii): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B) the value of the motor vehicle fuel is or exceeds $500 and the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the following offenses, if each prior offense was committed within 10 years before the date of the current conviction or the date of the offense upon which the current conviction is based and at least one of those convictions is for a class A misdemeanor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(b)(ii)(A): any theft, any robbery, or any burglary with intent to commit theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(b)(ii)(B): Part 5, Fraud any offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(b)(ii)(C): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B) any attempt to commit any offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(b)(iii): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(b)(iii)(A): the value of the motor vehicle fuel is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(b)(iii)(B): the theft occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(b)(iii)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the merchant prohibiting the offender from entering the property pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(b)(iv): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) the actor has been previously convicted of a felony violation of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(c): 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) a class A misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(c)(i): the value of the motor vehicle fuel is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(c)(ii): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(c)(ii)(A): the value of the motor vehicle fuel is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(c)(ii)(B): the theft occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(c)(ii)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the merchant prohibiting the offender from entering the property pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(c)(iii): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(3)(d): (3)(c) a class B misdemeanor if the value of the motor vehicle fuel is less than $500 and the theft is not an offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(4): (3); (4)(a); 53-3-220
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(4)(a): (3) In addition to the penalties described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-404.7(4)(b): (4)(a); 53-3-220 The suspension described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405 Theft by deception.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(1): 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(1)(a): As used in this section, "puffing" means an exaggerated commendation of wares or worth in a communication addressed to an individual, group, or the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(2): (2)(a)(i); (2)(a)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(2)(a): An actor commits theft by deception if the actor obtains or exercises control over property of another person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(2)(a)(i): by deception; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(2)(a)(ii): with a purpose to deprive the other person of property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(2)(b): (2)(a)(i); (2)(a)(ii) The deception described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3): (2); 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402; Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii); (3)(c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(a): a second degree felony if the:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(a)(i): value of the property is or exceeds $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(a)(ii): property stolen is a firearm or an operable motor vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(b): 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402; Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(b)(i): the value of the property is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(b)(ii): 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402 the property:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(b)(ii)(A): 76-6-1402 is a catalytic converter as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(b)(ii)(B): 76-6-1402 25 pounds or more of a suspect metal item as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(b)(iii): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B) the value of the property is or exceeds $500 and the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the following offenses, if each prior offense was committed within 10 years before the date of the current conviction or the date of the offense upon which the current conviction is based and at least one of those convictions is for a class A misdemeanor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(b)(iii)(A): any theft, any robbery, or any burglary with intent to commit theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(b)(iii)(B): Part 5, Fraud any offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(b)(iii)(C): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B) any attempt to commit any offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(b)(iv): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(b)(iv)(A): the value of property is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(b)(iv)(B): the theft occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(b)(iv)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the merchant prohibiting the offender from entering the property pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(b)(v): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) the actor has been previously convicted of a felony violation of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(c): 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) a class A misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(c)(i): the value of the property stolen is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(c)(ii): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(c)(ii)(A): the value of property is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(c)(ii)(B): the theft occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(c)(ii)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the merchant prohibiting the offender from entering the property pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(c)(iii): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(3)(d): (3)(c) a class B misdemeanor if the value of the property stolen is less than $500 and the theft is not an offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(4): Theft by deception does not occur when there is only:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(4)(a): falsity as to matters having no pecuniary significance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-405(4)(b): puffing by statements unlikely to deceive an ordinary person in the group addressed.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406 Theft by extortion.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(1): 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(1)(a): As used in this section, extortion occurs when an actor threatens to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(1)(a)(i): cause physical harm in the future to the person threatened, to any other person, or to property at any time;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(1)(a)(ii): subject the person threatened or any other person to physical confinement or restraint;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(1)(a)(iii): engage in other conduct constituting a crime;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(1)(a)(iv): accuse any person of a crime or expose any person to hatred, contempt, or ridicule;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(1)(a)(v): reveal any information sought to be concealed by the person threatened;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(1)(a)(vi): testify, provide information, or withhold testimony or information with respect to a person's legal claim or defense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(1)(a)(vii): take action as an official against anyone or anything, or withhold official action, or cause such action or withholding;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(1)(a)(viii): bring about or continue a strike, boycott, or other similar collective action to obtain property that is not demanded or received for the benefit of the group that the actor purports to represent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(1)(a)(ix): do any other act which would not in itself substantially benefit the actor but which would harm substantially any other person with respect to that person's health, safety, business, calling, career, financial condition, reputation, or personal relationships.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(2): An actor commits theft by extortion if the actor obtains or exercises control over the property of another person by extortion and with a purpose to deprive the person of the person's property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3): (2); 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402; Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii)(C); (3)(c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(a): a second degree felony if the:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(a)(i): value of the property is or exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(a)(ii): property stolen is a firearm or an operable motor vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(a)(iii): property is stolen from the person of another;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(b): 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402; Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(b)(i): the value of the property is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(b)(ii): 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402 the property is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(b)(ii)(A): 76-6-1402 a catalytic converter as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(b)(ii)(B): 76-6-1402 25 pounds or more of a suspect metal item as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(b)(iii): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B) the value of the property is or exceeds $500 and the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the following offenses, if each prior offense was committed within 10 years before the date of the current conviction or the date of the offense upon which the current conviction is based and at least one of those convictions is for a class A misdemeanor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(b)(iii)(A): any theft, any robbery, or any burglary with intent to commit theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(b)(iii)(B): Part 5, Fraud any offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(b)(iii)(C): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B) any attempt to commit any offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(b)(iv): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(b)(iv)(A): the value of property is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(b)(iv)(B): the theft occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(b)(iv)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the merchant prohibiting the offender from entering the property pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(b)(v): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) the actor has been previously convicted of a felony violation of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(c): 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii)(C) a class A misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(c)(i): the value of the property stolen is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(c)(ii): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(c)(ii)(A): the value of property is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(c)(ii)(B): the theft occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(c)(ii)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the merchant prohibiting the offender from entering the property pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(c)(iii): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii)(C) the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(3)(d): (3)(c) a class B misdemeanor if the value of the property stolen is less than $500 and the theft is not an offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(4): (2); 78B-2-305; (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(4)(a): (2) A person who is adversely impacted by the conduct prohibited in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-406(4)(b): 78B-2-305; (4)(a) In accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-407 Theft of lost, mislaid, or mistakenly delivered property.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-407(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-407(2): (2)(a) An actor commits theft of lost, mislaid, or mistakenly delivered property if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-407(2)(a): obtains another person's property and knows the property to have been lost or mislaid, or to have been delivered under a mistake as to the identity of the recipient or as to the nature or amount of the property, without taking reasonable measures to return the property to the owner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-407(2)(b): (2)(a) has the purpose to deprive the owner of the property when the actor obtains the property or at any time before taking the measures described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408 Theft by receiving stolen property -- Duties of pawnbrokers, secondhand businesses, coin dealers, and catalytic converter purchasers.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(1): 13-32a-102; 13-32a-102; 13-32a-102; 76-6-1402; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(1)(a): 13-32a-102; 13-32a-102; 13-32a-102; 76-6-1402 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(1)(a)(i): 13-32a-102 "Catalytic converter purchaser" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(1)(a)(ii): 13-32a-102 "Coin dealer" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(1)(a)(iii): 13-32a-102 "Pawnbroker" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(1)(a)(iv): "Receives" means acquiring possession, control, title, or lending on the security of the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(1)(a)(v): 76-6-1402 "Scrap metal processor" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(1)(a)(vi): "Secondhand actor" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(1)(a)(vi)(A): a pawnbroker;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(1)(a)(vi)(B): a person who has or operates a business dealing in or collecting used or secondhand merchandise or personal property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(1)(a)(vi)(C): an agent, employee, or representative of a pawnbroker or person who buys, receives, or obtains property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(2): An actor commits theft by receiving stolen property if the actor receives, retains, or disposes of the property of another knowing that the property is stolen, or believing that the property is probably stolen, or who conceals, sells, withholds, or aids in concealing, selling, or withholding the property from the owner, knowing or believing the property to be stolen, intending to deprive the owner of the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3): (2); 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402; Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii)(C); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii); (3) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(a): a second degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(a)(i): the value of the property is or exceeds $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(a)(ii): the property is a firearm or an operable motor vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(b): 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402; Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii)(C) a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(b)(i): the value of the property is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(b)(ii): 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402 the property is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(b)(ii)(A): 76-6-1402 a catalytic converter as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(b)(ii)(B): 76-6-1402 25 pounds or more of a suspect metal item as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(b)(iii): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B) the value of the property is or exceeds $500 and the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the following offenses, if each prior offense was committed within 10 years before the date of the current conviction or the date of the offense upon which the current conviction is based and at least one of those convictions is for a class A misdemeanor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(b)(iii)(A): any theft, any robbery, or any burglary with intent to commit theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(b)(iii)(B): Part 5, Fraud any offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(b)(iii)(C): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B) any attempt to commit any offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(b)(iv): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii)(C) the actor has been previously convicted of a felony violation of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(c): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) a class A misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(c)(i): the value of the property is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(c)(ii): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-408(3)(d): (3) a class B misdemeanor if the value of the property is less than $500 and the theft is not an offense under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409 Theft of service.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(1): 76-6-409.3; 76-6-409.6; 76-6-409.7; 76-6-409.8; 76-6-409.9; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(1)(a): 76-6-409.3; 76-6-409.6; 76-6-409.7; 76-6-409.8; 76-6-409.9 As used in this section, "service" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(1)(a)(i): labor, professional service, a public utility or transportation service, restaurant, hotel, motel, tourist cabin, rooming house, and like accommodations, the supplying of equipment, a tool, a vehicle, or a trailer for temporary use, telegraph service, steam, admission to entertainment, an exhibition, a sporting event, or other event for which a charge is made;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(1)(a)(ii): 76-6-409.3 gas, electricity, water, sewer, or cable television service, only if the service is obtained by threat, force, or a form of deception not described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(1)(a)(iii): 76-6-409.6; 76-6-409.7; 76-6-409.8; 76-6-409.9 telephone service, only if the service is obtained by threat, force, or a form of deception not described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(2): An actor commits theft of service if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(2)(a): the actor, by deception, threat, force, or another means designed to avoid due payment, obtains a service that the actor knows is available only for compensation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(2)(b): the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(2)(b)(i): has control over the disposition of another person's service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(2)(b)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(2)(b)(ii)(A): diverts the other person's service to the benefit of the actor, knowing that the actor is not entitled to the service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(2)(b)(ii)(B): diverts the other person's service to the benefit of a third person, knowing that the third person is not entitled to the service.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3): (2); Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C); (3)(c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(a): a second degree felony if the value of the service is or exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(b): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(b)(i): the value of the service is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(b)(ii): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B) the value of the service is or exceeds $500 and the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the following offenses, if each prior offense was committed within 10 years before the date of the current conviction or the date of the offense upon which the current conviction is based and at least one of those convictions is for a class A misdemeanor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(b)(ii)(A): any theft, any robbery, or any burglary with intent to commit theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(b)(ii)(B): Part 5, Fraud any offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(b)(ii)(C): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B) any attempt to commit any offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(b)(iii): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(b)(iii)(A): the value of the service is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(b)(iii)(B): the theft occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(b)(iii)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the merchant prohibiting the offender from entering the property pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(b)(iv): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) the actor has been previously convicted of a felony violation of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(c): 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) a class A misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(c)(i): the value of the service stolen is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(c)(ii): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(c)(ii)(A): the value of the service is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(c)(ii)(B): the theft occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(c)(ii)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the merchant prohibiting the offender from entering the property pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(c)(iii): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409(3)(d): (3)(c) a class B misdemeanor if the value of the service is less than $500 and the theft is not an offense under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.1 Unlawful device for theft of service -- Seizure and destruction -- Civil actions for damages.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.1(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.1(2): 76-6-409; 76-6-409.3; 76-6-409; 76-6-409.3 An actor commits unlawful device for theft of service if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.1(2)(a): 76-6-409; 76-6-409.3 makes or possesses an instrument, apparatus, equipment, or device for the use of, or for the purpose of, committing or attempting to commit theft under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.1(2)(b): 76-6-409; 76-6-409.3 sells, offers to sell, advertises, gives, transports, or otherwise transfers to another person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.1(2)(b)(i): an instrument, apparatus, equipment, or device; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.1(2)(b)(ii): 76-6-409; 76-6-409.3 any information, plan, or instruction for obtaining, making, or assembling an instrument, apparatus, equipment, or device, with intent that the instrument, apparatus, equipment, or device be used, or caused to be used, to commit or attempt to commit theft under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.1(3): (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.1(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.1(3)(b): (2) Any instrument, apparatus, equipment, device, information, plan, or instruction referred to in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.1(3)(c): Upon the conviction of an actor for a violation of this section, the sheriff of the county in which the actor was convicted shall destroy as contraband any instrument, apparatus, equipment, device, information, plan, or instruction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.1(4): A criminal prosecution under this section does not affect any person's right of civil action for redress for damages suffered as a result of a violation of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3 Theft of utility or cable television services -- Restitution -- Civil action for damages.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(1): 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(1)(a): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(1)(a)(i): "Cable television service" means an audio, video, or data service provided for payment by a cable television company over the cable company's cable system facilities, but does not include the use of a satellite dish or antenna.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(1)(a)(ii): "Occupant" includes a person, including the owner, who occupies the whole or part of a building, whether alone or with others.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(1)(a)(iii): "Owner" includes a partial owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety of the whole or a part of a building and the property on which the building is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(1)(a)(iv): "Person" means an individual, firm, partnership, corporation, company, association, or other legal entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(1)(a)(v): "Tenant" includes a person, including the owner, who occupies the whole or part of any building, whether alone or with others.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(1)(a)(vi): "Utility" means any public utility, municipally owned utility, or cooperative utility that provides electricity, gas, water, or sewer, or any combination of electricity, gas, water, or sewer, for sale to consumers.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(2): An actor commits theft of a utility or cable television service if, with intent to avoid due payment to the utility or cable television company, the actor makes gas, electricity, water, sewer, or cable television available to a tenant or occupant, including to the actor, by committing any of the following acts:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(2)(a): connecting a tube, pipe, wire, cable, or other instrument with any meter, device, or other instrument used for conducting gas, electricity, water, sewer, or cable television in a manner as permits the use of the gas, electricity, water, sewer, or cable television without the gas, electricity, water, sewer, or cable television passing through a meter or other instrument recording the usage for billing;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(2)(b): altering, injuring, or preventing the normal action of a meter, valve, stopcock, or other instrument used for measuring quantities of gas, electricity, water, or sewer service, or making or maintaining any modification or alteration to any device installed with the authorization of a cable television company for the purpose of intercepting or receiving any program or other service carried by the company that the actor is not authorized by the company to receive;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(2)(c): reconnecting a gas, electricity, water, sewer, or cable television connection or otherwise restoring service when one or more of those utilities or cable service has been lawfully disconnected or turned off by the provider of the utility or cable service;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(2)(d): intentionally breaking, defacing, or causing to be broken or defaced a seal, locking device, or other part of a metering device for recording usage of gas, electricity, water, or sewer service, or a security system for the recording device, or a cable television control device;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(2)(e): removing a metering device designed to measure quantities of gas, electricity, water, or sewer service;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(2)(f): transferring from one location to another location a metering device for measuring quantities of public utility services of gas, electricity, water, or sewer service;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(2)(g): changing the indicated consumption, jamming the measuring device, bypassing the meter or measuring device with a jumper so that it does not indicate use or registers use incorrectly, or otherwise obtaining quantities of gas, electricity, water, or sewer service from the utility without the gas, electricity, water, or sewer service passing through a metering device for measuring quantities of consumption for billing purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(2)(h): using a metering device belonging to the utility that has not been assigned to the location and installed by the utility;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(2)(i): fabricating or using a device to pick or otherwise tamper with the locks used to deter utility service diversion, meter tampering, meter thefts, and unauthorized cable television service;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(2)(j): assisting or instructing a person in obtaining or attempting to obtain any cable television service without payment of all lawful compensation to the company providing the service;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(2)(k): making or maintaining a connection or connections, whether physical, electrical, mechanical, acoustical, or by other means, with a cable, wire, component, or other device used for the distribution of cable television services without authority from the cable television company; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(2)(l): possessing without authority any device or printed circuit board designed in whole or in part to receive any cable television programming or service offered for sale over a cable television system, unless the device or printed circuit board includes the use of a satellite dish or antenna, with the intent that the device or printed circuit be used for the reception of the cable television company's services without payment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3): (2); (2); Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(B)(I); (II); (3)(b)(ii)(B)(I); (3)(b)(ii)(B)(III); (3)(b)(ii)(B)(I); (3)(b)(ii)(B)(III); (3)(b)(iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(a)(i): a second degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(a)(i)(A): the value of the gas, electricity, water, or sewer service is or exceeds $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(a)(i)(B): if the actor previously has been convicted of a violation of this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(a)(ii): a third degree felony if the value of the gas, electricity, water, or sewer service is or exceeds $1,500 but is not more than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(a)(iii): a class A misdemeanor if the value of the gas, electricity, water, or sewer service is or exceeds $500 but is not more than $1,500; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(a)(iv): a class B misdemeanor if the value of the gas, electricity, water, or sewer service is less than $500.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(b): (2); Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(B)(I); (II); (3)(b)(ii)(B)(I); (3)(b)(ii)(B)(III); (3)(b)(ii)(B)(I); (3)(b)(ii)(B)(III); (3)(b)(iii) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(b)(i): a second degree felony if the value of the service is or exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(b)(ii): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(B)(I); (II); (3)(b)(ii)(B)(I); (3)(b)(ii)(B)(III) a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(b)(ii)(A): the value of the service is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(b)(ii)(B): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(B)(I); (II) the value of the service is or exceeds $500 and the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the following offenses, if each prior offense was committed within 10 years before the date of the current conviction or the date of the offense upon which the current conviction is based and at least one of those convictions is for a class A misdemeanor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(b)(ii)(B)(I): any theft, any robbery, or any burglary with intent to commit theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(b)(ii)(B)(II): Part 5, Fraud any offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(b)(ii)(B)(III): (3)(b)(ii)(B)(I); (II) any attempt to commit any offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(b)(ii)(C): (3)(b)(ii)(B)(I); (3)(b)(ii)(B)(III) the actor has been previously convicted of a felony violation of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(b)(iii): (3)(b)(ii)(B)(I); (3)(b)(ii)(B)(III) a class A misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(b)(iii)(A): the value of the service stolen is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(b)(iii)(B): (3)(b)(ii)(B)(I); (3)(b)(ii)(B)(III) the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(b)(iv): (3)(b)(iii) a class B misdemeanor if the value of the service is less than $500 and the theft is not an offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(c)(i): An actor who violates this section shall make restitution to the utility or cable television company for the value of the gas, electricity, water, sewer, or cable television service consumed in violation of this section plus all reasonable expenses and costs incurred on account of the violation of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(3)(c)(ii): Reasonable expenses and costs include expenses and costs for investigation, disconnection, reconnection, service calls, employee time, and equipment use.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(4): 76-2-202
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(4)(a): The presence on property in the possession of an actor of a device or alteration that permits the diversion or use of utility or cable service to avoid the registration of the use by or on a meter installed by the utility or to otherwise avoid the recording of use of the service for payment or otherwise avoid payment gives rise to an inference that the actor in possession of the property installed the device or caused the alteration if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(4)(a)(i): the presence of the device or alteration can be attributed only to a deliberate act in furtherance of an intent to avoid payment for utility or cable television service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(4)(a)(ii): the actor charged has received the direct benefit of the reduction of the cost of the utility or cable television service.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(4)(b): 76-2-202 An actor who aids or abets in a prohibited act is a party to the offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(5)(a): Criminal prosecution under this section does not affect the right of a utility or cable television company to bring a civil action for redress for damages suffered as a result of the commission of any of the acts prohibited by this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.3(5)(b): This section does not abridge or alter any other right, action, or remedy otherwise available to a utility or cable television company.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this section and SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(1): "Access device" means any telecommunication device including the telephone calling card number, electronic serial number, account number, mobile identification number, or personal identification number that can be used to obtain telephone service.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(2): "Clone cellular telephone" or "counterfeit cellular telephone" means a cellular telephone whose electronic serial number has been altered from the electronic serial number that was programmed in the telephone by the manufacturer by someone other than the manufacturer.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(3): "Cloning paraphernalia" means materials that, when possessed in combination, are capable of the creation of a cloned cellular telephone.  These materials include scanners to intercept the electronic serial number and mobile identification number, cellular telephones, cables, EPROM chips, EPROM burners, software for programming the cloned telephone with a false electronic serial number and mobile identification number combination, a computer containing such software, and lists of electronic serial number and mobile identification number combinations.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(4): "Electronic serial number" means the unique number that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(4)(a): was programmed into a cellular telephone by its manufacturer;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(4)(b): is transmitted by the cellular telephone; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(4)(c): is used by cellular telephone providers to validate radio transmissions to the system as having been made by an authorized device.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(5): "EPROM" or "Erasable programmable read-only memory" means an integrated circuit memory that can be programmed from an external source and erased, for reprogramming, by exposure to ultraviolet light.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(6): "Intercept" means to electronically capture, record, reveal, or otherwise access, the signals emitted or received during the operation of a cellular telephone without the consent of the sender or receiver, by means of any instrument, device or equipment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(7): "Manufacture of an unlawful telecommunication device" means to produce or assemble an unlawful telecommunication device, or to modify, alter, program, or reprogram a telecommunication device to be capable of acquiring or facilitating the acquisition of telecommunication service without the consent of the telecommunication service provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(8): "Mobile identification number" means the cellular telephone number assigned to the cellular telephone by the cellular telephone carrier.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(9): "Possess" means to have physical possession or otherwise to exercise control over tangible property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(10): "Sell" means to offer to, agree to offer to, or to sell, exchange, give, or dispose of an unlawful telecommunications device to another.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(11): "Telecommunication device" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(11)(a): any type of instrument, device, machine, or equipment which is capable of transmitting or receiving telephonic, electronic, or radio communications; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(11)(b): any part of an instrument, device, machine, or equipment, or other computer circuit, computer chip, electronic mechanism, or other component, which is capable of facilitating the transmission or reception of telephonic or electronic communications within the radio spectrum allocated to cellular radio telephony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(12): "Telecommunication service" includes any service provided for a charge or compensation to facilitate the origination, transmission, emission, or reception of signs, signals, writings, images, and sounds or intelligence of any nature by telephone, including cellular telephones, wire, radio, television optical or other electromagnetic system.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(13): "Telecommunication service provider" means any person or entity providing telecommunication service including a cellular telephone or paging company or other person or entity which, for a fee, supplies the facility, cell site, mobile telephone switching office, or other equipment or telecommunication service.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.5(14): "Unlawful telecommunication device" means any telecommunication device that is capable of, or has been altered, modified, programmed, or reprogrammed, alone or in conjunction with another access device, so as to be capable of, acquiring or facilitating the acquisition of a telecommunication service without the consent of the telecommunication service provider.  Unlawful devices include tumbler phones, counterfeit phones, tumbler microchips, counterfeit microchips, and other instruments capable of disguising their identity or location or of gaining access to a communications system operated by a telecommunication service provider.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.6 Use of telecommunication device to avoid lawful charge for service.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.6(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-409.5 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.6(2): An actor commits use of a telecommunication device to avoid lawful charge for service if the actor uses a telecommunication device:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.6(2)(a): with the intent to avoid the payment of a lawful charge for telecommunication service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.6(2)(b): with the knowledge that the use of the telecommunication device was to avoid the payment of a lawful charge for telecommunication service.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.6(3): (2); 76-6-409.10
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.6(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.6(3)(a)(i): a class B misdemeanor, if the value of the telecommunication service is less than $300 or cannot be ascertained;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.6(3)(a)(ii): a class A misdemeanor, if the value of the telecommunication service charge is or exceeds $300 but is not more than $1,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.6(3)(a)(iii): a third degree felony, if the value of the telecommunication service is or exceeds $1,000 but is not more than $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.6(3)(a)(iv): a second degree felony, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.6(3)(a)(iv)(A): the value of the telecommunication service is or exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.6(3)(a)(iv)(B): the cloned cellular telephone was used to facilitate the commission of a felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.6(3)(a)(iv)(C): the actor previously has been convicted of a violation of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-409.6(3)(b): 76-6-409.10 An actor who violates this section is subject to the restitution and civil action provisions described in Section
