Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410 Theft by custodian of property pursuant to repair or rental agreement.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(2): An actor commits theft by custodian of property pursuant to repair or rental agreement if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(2)(a)(i): the actor has custody of property pursuant to an agreement between the actor or another person and the property's owner;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(2)(a)(ii): the actor or another person is to perform for compensation a specific service for the property's owner involving the maintenance, repair, or use of the owner's property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(2)(a)(iii): the actor intentionally uses or operates the owner's property, without the consent of the owner, for the actor's own purposes in a manner constituting a gross deviation from the agreed purpose; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(2)(b)(i): the actor has custody of any property pursuant to a rental or lease agreement in which the property is to be returned in a specified manner or at a specified time; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(2)(b)(ii): the actor intentionally fails to comply with the terms of the agreement concerning return so as to render such failure a gross deviation from the agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3): (2); 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402; Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii); (3) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(a): a second degree felony if the:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(a)(i): value of the property is or exceeds $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(a)(ii): property stolen is a firearm or an operable motor vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(b): 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402; Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(b)(i): the value of the property is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(b)(ii): 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402 the property is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(b)(ii)(A): 76-6-1402 a catalytic converter as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(b)(ii)(B): 76-6-1402 25 pounds or more of a suspect metal item as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(b)(iii): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B) the value of the property is or exceeds $500 and the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the following offenses, if each prior offense was committed within 10 years before the date of the current conviction or the date of the offense upon which the current conviction is based and at least one of those convictions is for a class A misdemeanor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(b)(iii)(A): any theft, any robbery, or any burglary with intent to commit theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(b)(iii)(B): Part 5, Fraud any offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(b)(iii)(C): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B) any attempt to commit any offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(b)(iv): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) the actor has been previously convicted of a felony violation of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(c): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) a class A misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(c)(i): the value of the property stolen is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(c)(ii): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii) the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410(3)(d): (3) a class B misdemeanor if the value of the property stolen is less than $500 and the theft is not an offense under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410.5 Theft of a rental vehicle.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410.5(1): 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410.5(1)(a): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410.5(1)(a)(i): "Motor vehicle" means a self-propelled vehicle that is intended primarily for use and operation on the highways.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410.5(1)(a)(ii): "Rental agreement" means a written agreement stating the terms and conditions governing the use of a motor vehicle provided by a rental company.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410.5(1)(a)(iii): "Rental company" means a person or organization in the business of providing motor vehicles to the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410.5(1)(a)(iv): "Renter" means a person or organization obtaining the use of a motor vehicle from a rental company under the terms of a rental agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410.5(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410.5(2): An actor commits theft of a rental vehicle if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410.5(2)(a): is a renter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410.5(2)(b): without notice to and permission of the rental company, knowingly fails without good cause to return the vehicle within 72 hours after the time established for the return in the rental agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410.5(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410.5(4): (4)(a) If a motor vehicle is not rented on a periodic tenancy basis, the rental company shall include the following information, legibly written, as part of the terms of the rental agreement:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410.5(4)(a): the date and time the motor vehicle is required to be returned; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-410.5(4)(b): (4)(a) the maximum penalties under state law if the motor vehicle is not returned within 72 hours from the date and time stated in compliance with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-412.1 Civil remedy for animal theft.
---------------------------------------------------------------
In addition to a criminal penalty under this chapter, an actor who commits theft of a stallion, mare, colt, gelding, cow, heifer, steer, ox, bull, calf, sheep, goat, mule, jack, jenny, swine, poultry, a fur-bearing animal raised for commercial purposes, or a livestock guardian dog, is civilly liable for three times the amount of actual damages, if any sustained by the plaintiff, and for costs of suit and reasonable attorney fees.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-413 Release of a fur-bearing animal -- Finding.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-413(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-413(2): An actor commits release of a fur-bearing animal if the actor intentionally and without permission of the owner releases a fur-bearing animal raised for commercial purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-413(3): (3)(b); (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-413(3)(a): (3)(b); (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-413(3)(b): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-413(4): The Legislature finds that the release of a fur-bearing animal raised for commercial purposes subjects the animal to unnecessary suffering through deprivation of food and shelter and compromises the animal's genetic integrity, thereby permanently depriving the owner of substantial value.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-413(5): (2) An actor who violates Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501 Definitions -- Forgery.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1): 76-6-506; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a): 76-6-506 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(i): "Authentication feature" means any hologram, watermark, certification, symbol, code, image, sequence of numbers or letters, or other feature that either individually or in combination with another feature is used by the issuing authority on an identification document, document-making implement, or means of identification to determine if the document is counterfeit, altered, or otherwise falsified.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(ii): "Document-making implement" means any implement, impression, template, computer file, computer disc, electronic device, computer hardware or software, or scanning, printing, or laminating equipment that is specifically configured or primarily used for making an identification document, a false identification document, or another document-making implement.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(iii): "False authentication feature" means an authentication feature that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(iii)(A): is genuine in origin but that, without the authorization of the issuing authority, has been tampered with or altered for purposes of deceit;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(iii)(B): is genuine, but has been distributed, or is intended for distribution, without the authorization of the issuing authority and not in connection with a lawfully made identification document, document-making implement, or means of identification to which the authentication feature is intended to be affixed or embedded by the issuing authority; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(iii)(C): appears to be genuine, but is not.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(iv): "False identification document" means a document of a type intended or commonly accepted for the purposes of identification of individuals, and that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(iv)(A): is not issued by or under the authority of a governmental entity or was issued under the authority of a governmental entity but was subsequently altered for purposes of deceit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(iv)(B): appears to be issued by or under the authority of a governmental entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(v): "Governmental entity" means the United States government, a state, a political subdivision of a state, a foreign government, a political subdivision of a foreign government, an international governmental organization, or a quasi-governmental organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(vi): "Identification document" means a document made or issued by or under the authority of a governmental entity, which, when completed with information concerning a particular individual, is of a type intended or commonly accepted for the purpose of identification of individuals.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(vii): 76-6-506 "Issuing authority" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(vii)(A): any governmental entity that is authorized to issue identification documents, means of identification, or authentication features; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(vii)(B): 76-6-506 a business organization or financial institution or its agent that issues a financial transaction card as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(viii): "Means of identification" means any name or number that may be used, alone or in conjunction with any other information, to identify a specific individual, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(viii)(A): name, social security number, date of birth, government issued driver license or identification number, alien registration number, government passport number, or employer or taxpayer identification number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(viii)(B): unique biometric data, such as fingerprint, voice print, retina or iris image, or other unique physical representation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(viii)(C): unique electronic identification number, address, or routing code.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(ix): "Personal identification card" means an identification document issued by a governmental entity solely for the purpose of identification of an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(x): "Produce" includes altering, authenticating, or assembling.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(xi): "State" includes any state of the United States, the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, and any other commonwealth, possession, or territory of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(xii): "Traffic" means to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(xii)(A): transport, transfer, or otherwise dispose of an item to another, as consideration for anything of value; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(xii)(B): make or obtain control of with intent to transport, transfer, or otherwise dispose of an item to another.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(xiii): "Writing" includes printing, electronic storage or transmission, or any other method of recording valuable information including forms such as:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(xiii)(A): checks, tokens, stamps, seals, credit cards, badges, trademarks, money, and any other symbols of value, right, privilege, or identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(xiii)(B): a security, revenue stamp, or any other instrument or writing issued by a government or any agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(a)(xiii)(C): a check, an issue of stocks, bonds, or any other instrument or writing representing an interest in or claim against property, or a pecuniary interest in or claim against any person or enterprise.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(2): An actor commits forgery if, with purpose to defraud anyone, or with knowledge that the actor is facilitating a fraud to be perpetrated by anyone, the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(2)(a): alters any writing of another person without the person's authority or utters the altered writing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(2)(b): makes, completes, executes, authenticates, issues, transfers, publishes, or utters any writing so that the writing or the making, completion, execution, authentication, issuance, transference, publication, or utterance:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(2)(b)(i): purports to be the act of another person, whether the person is existent or nonexistent;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(2)(b)(ii): purports to be an act on behalf of another party with the authority of that other party; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(2)(b)(iii): purports to have been executed at a time or place or in a numbered sequence other than was in fact the case, or to be a copy of an original when an original did not exist.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(4): (2)(b)(ii) It is not a defense to a charge of forgery under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(5): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(6): Title 77, Chapter 11b, Forfeiture of Seized Property The forfeiture of property under this section, including any seizure and disposition of the property and any related judicial or administrative proceeding, shall be conducted in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501(7): The court shall order, in addition to the penalty prescribed for any person convicted of a violation of this section, the forfeiture and destruction or other disposition of all illicit authentication features, identification documents, false transaction cards, document-making implements, or means of identification.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501.5 Producing or transferring false identification.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501.5(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-501 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501.5(2): An actor commits producing or transferring a false identification document if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501.5(2)(a): knowingly and without lawful authority produces, attempts, or conspires to produce an identification document, authentication feature, or a false identification document that is or appears to be issued by or under the authority of an issuing authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501.5(2)(b): transfers, or possesses with intent to transfer, an identification document, authentication feature, or a false identification document knowing that the document or feature was stolen or produced without lawful authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501.5(2)(c): produces, transfers, or possesses a document-making implement or authentication feature with the intent that the document-making implement or the authentication feature be used in the production of a false identification document or another document-making implement or authentication feature; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501.5(2)(d): traffics in false or actual authentication features for use in false identification documents, document-making implements, or means of identification.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501.5(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501.5(4): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501.5(5): Title 77, Chapter 11a, Seizure of Property and Contraband; Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence The forfeiture of property under this section, including any seizure and disposition of the property and any related judicial or administrative proceeding, shall be conducted in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-501.5(6): The court shall order, in addition to the penalty prescribed for a person convicted of a violation of this section, the forfeiture and destruction or other disposition of all illicit authentication features, identification documents, false transaction cards, document-making implements, or means of identification.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505 Issuing a bad check or draft -- Presumption.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(2)(a): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(2)(a)(i): An actor commits issuing a bad check or draft if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(2)(a)(i)(A): the actor issues or passes a check or draft for the payment of money, for the purpose of obtaining from any person, firm, partnership, or corporation, any money, property, or other thing of value or paying for any services, wages, salary, labor, or rent;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(2)(a)(i)(B): the actor knows the check or draft will not be paid by the drawee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(2)(a)(i)(C): payment is refused by the drawee.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(2)(a)(ii): (2)(a) For purposes of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(2)(b): An actor commits issuing a bad check or draft if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(2)(b)(i): the actor issues or passes a check or draft for:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(2)(b)(i)(A): the payment of money, for the purpose of obtaining from any person, firm, partnership, or corporation, any money, property, or other thing of value; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(2)(b)(i)(B): paying for any services, wages, salary, labor, or rent;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(2)(b)(ii): payment of the check or draft is legally refused by the drawee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(2)(b)(iii): the actor fails to make good and actual payment to the payee in the amount of the refused check or draft within 14 days of the actor receiving actual notice of the check or draft's nonpayment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(3): (2)(a); (b) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(3)(a): if the check or draft or series of checks or drafts made or drawn in this state within a period not exceeding six months amounts to a sum that is less than $500, the offense is a class B misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(3)(b): if the check or draft or checks or drafts made or drawn in this state within a period not exceeding six months amounts to a sum that is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500, the offense is a class A misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(3)(c): if the check or draft or checks or drafts made or drawn in this state within a period not exceeding six months amounts to a sum that is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000, the offense is a third degree felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(3)(d): if the check or draft or checks or drafts made or drawn in this state within a period not exceeding six months amounts to a sum that is or exceeds $5,000, the offense is a second degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(4): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-505(5): Title 77, Chapter 11a, Seizure of Property and Contraband; Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence The forfeiture of property under this section, including any seizure and disposition of the property and any related judicial or administrative proceeding, shall be conducted in accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506 Financial transaction card offenses -- Definitions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
As used in SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 76-6-506(1): "Authorized credit card merchant" means a person who is authorized by an issuer to furnish money, goods, services, or anything else of value upon presentation of a financial transaction card by a card holder and to present valid credit card sales drafts to the issuer for payment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506(2): "Automated banking device" means any machine which, when properly activated by a financial transaction card or a personal identification code, may be used for any of the purposes for which a financial transaction card may be used.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506(3): "Card holder" means any person or organization named on the face of a financial transaction card to whom or for whose benefit a financial transaction card is issued.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506(4): "Credit card sales draft" means any sales slip, draft, or other written or electronic record of a sale of money, goods, services, or anything else of value made or purported to be made to or at the request of a card holder with a financial transaction card, financial transaction card credit number, or personal identification code, whether the record of the sale or purported sale is evidenced by a sales draft, voucher, or other similar document in writing or electronically recorded and transmitted.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506(5): "Financial transaction card" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506(5)(a): any credit card, credit plate, bank services card, banking card, check guarantee card, debit card, telephone credit card, or any other card, issued by an issuer for the use of the card holder in obtaining money, goods, services, or anything else of value on credit, or in certifying or guaranteeing to a person or business the availability to the card holder of the funds on deposit that are equal to or greater than the amount necessary to honor a draft or check payable to the order of the person or business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506(5)(b): any instrument or device used in providing the card holder access to a demand or time deposit account for the purpose of making deposits of money or checks in the account, or withdrawing funds from the account in the form of money, money orders, travelers' checks, or other form representing value, or transferring funds from any demand or time deposit account to any credit card account in full or partial satisfaction of any outstanding balance existing in the credit card account.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506(6): "Issuer" means a business organization or financial institution or its agent that issues a financial transaction card.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506(7): "Personal identification code" means any numerical or alphabetical code assigned to a card holder by the issuer to permit the authorized electronic use of the holder's financial transaction card.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2 Unlawful use of financial transaction card.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-506 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(2): An actor commits unlawful use of financial transaction card if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(2)(a): knowingly uses a revoked, expired, stolen, or fraudulently obtained financial transaction card to obtain or attempt to obtain credit, goods, property, or services;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(2)(b): knowingly, with the intent to defraud, uses a financial transaction card, credit number, personal identification code, or any other information contained on the card or in the account from which the card is issued, to obtain or attempt to obtain credit, goods, or services;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(2)(c): knowingly, with the intent to defraud, uses a financial transaction card to willfully exceed an authorized credit line by $500 or more, or by 50% or more of the line of credit, whichever is greater; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(2)(d): knowingly, with the intent to defraud, presents or causes to be presented to the issuer or an authorized credit card merchant, for payment or collection, any credit card sales draft, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(2)(d)(i): the draft is counterfeit or fictitious;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(2)(d)(ii): the purported sales evidenced by any credit card sales draft did not take place;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(2)(d)(iii): the purported sale was not authorized by the card holder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(2)(d)(iv): the items or services purported to be sold as evidenced by the credit card sales drafts are not delivered or rendered to the card holder or person intended to receive them.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(3): (2); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(3)(a)(i): a class B misdemeanor if the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(3)(a)(ii): a class A misdemeanor if the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(3)(a)(iii): a third degree felony if the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or attempted to be obtained is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(3)(a)(iv): a second degree felony if the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or attempted to be obtained is or exceeds $5,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(3)(b): (2)(a) Multiple violations of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(4): The court shall make appropriate findings in any prosecution under this section that the card holder did not commit the crime.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(5): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.2(6): Title 77, Chapter 11a, Seizure of Property and Contraband; Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence The forfeiture of property under this section, including any seizure and disposition of the property and any related judicial or administrative proceeding, shall be conducted in accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.3 Unlawful acquisition, possession, or transfer of financial transaction card.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.3(2)(a)(v): 76-6-506.2 possesses, sells, or transfers any information necessary for the use of a financial transaction card, including the credit number of the card, the expiration date of the card, or the personal identification code related to the card:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.3(2)(a)(v)(A):

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.3(2)(a)(v)(B): 76-6-506.2 with intent to use the information in violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.3(2)(b): 76-6-506.2; 76-6-506.2 possesses, sells, or transfers any information necessary for the use of 100 or more financial transaction cards, including the credit number of a card, the expiration date of a card, or the personal identification code related to a card:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.3(2)(b)(i): 76-6-506.2 with intent to use the information in violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.3(2)(b)(ii): 76-6-506.2 with knowledge that the information will be used by another in violation of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.3(3)(a): (2)(a) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.3(3)(b): (2)(b) A violation of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6 Financial transaction card offenses -- Unauthorized factoring of credit card sales drafts.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-506 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(2): An actor commits an unauthorized factoring of credit card sales draft if the actor acts:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(2)(a): knowingly, with intent to defraud;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(2)(b): without the express authorization of the issuer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(2)(c): to employ, solicit, or otherwise cause an authorized credit card merchant, or for the authorized credit card merchant himself or herself, to present any credit card sales draft to the issuer:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(2)(c)(i): for payment pertaining to any sale or purported sale of goods or services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(2)(c)(ii): the sale or purported sale was not made by the authorized credit card merchant in the ordinary course of business.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(3): (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(3)(a)(i): a class B misdemeanor if the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(3)(a)(ii): a class A misdemeanor if the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(3)(a)(iii): a third degree felony if the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or attempted to be obtained is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(3)(a)(iv): a second degree felony if the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or attempted to be obtained is or exceeds $5,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(3)(b): (2) Multiple violations of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(4): The court shall make appropriate findings in any prosecution under this section that the card holder did not commit the crime.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(5): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.6(6): Title 77, Chapter 11a, Seizure of Property and Contraband; Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence The forfeiture of property under this section, including any seizure and disposition of the property and any related judicial or administrative proceeding, shall be conducted in accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7 Obtaining encoded information on a financial transaction card with the intent to defraud the issuer, holder, or merchant.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(1): 76-6-506; (1)(a)(ii)(B); 76-1-101.5; 76-6-506
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(1)(a): 76-6-506; (1)(a)(ii)(B) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(1)(a)(i): 76-6-506 "Card holder" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(1)(a)(ii): "Financial transaction card" or "card" means any credit card, credit plate, bank services card, banking card, check guarantee card, debit card, telephone credit card, or any other card, issued by an issuer for the use of the card holder in:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(1)(a)(ii)(A): obtaining money, goods, services, or anything else of value on credit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(1)(a)(ii)(B): certifying or guaranteeing to a merchant the availability to the card holder of the funds on deposit that are equal to or greater than the amount necessary to honor a draft or check as the instrument for obtaining, purchasing, or receiving goods, services, money, or any other thing of value from the merchant.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(1)(a)(iii): (1)(a)(ii)(B)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(1)(a)(iii)(A): "Merchant" means an owner or operator of any retail mercantile establishment or any agent, employee, lessee, consignee, officer, director, franchisee, or independent contractor of the owner or operator.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(1)(a)(iii)(B): (1)(a)(ii)(B) "Merchant" also means a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(1)(a)(iii)(B)(I): who receives from a card holder, or a third person the merchant believes to be the card holder, a financial transaction card or information from a financial transaction card, or what the merchant believes to be a financial transaction card or information from a card; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(1)(a)(iii)(B)(II): (1)(a)(ii)(B) who accepts the financial transaction card or information from a card under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(1)(a)(iv): "Reencoder" means an electronic device that places encoded information from the magnetic strip or stripe of a financial transaction card onto the magnetic strip or stripe of a different financial transaction card.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(1)(a)(v): "Scanning device" means a scanner, reader, or any other electronic device used to access, read, scan, obtain, memorize, or store, temporarily or permanently, information encoded on the magnetic strip or stripe of a financial transaction card.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-506 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(2): An actor commits obtaining encoded information on a financial transaction card with the intent to defraud the issuer, holder, or merchant if the actor uses:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(2)(a): a scanning device to access, read, obtain, memorize, or store, temporarily or permanently, information encoded on the magnetic strip or stripe of a financial transaction card:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(2)(a)(i): without the permission of the card holder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(2)(a)(ii): with intent to defraud the card holder, the issuer, or a merchant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(2)(b): a reencoder to place information encoded on the magnetic strip or stripe of a financial transaction card onto the magnetic strip or stripe of a different card:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(2)(b)(i): without the permission of the authorized user of the card from which the information is being reencoded; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(2)(b)(ii): with the intent to defraud the card holder, the issuer, or a merchant.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(3): (3)(b); (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(3)(a): (3)(b); (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(3)(b): (2) An actor who has been convicted previously of an offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(4): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.7(5): Title 77, Chapter 11a, Seizure of Property and Contraband; Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence The forfeiture of property under this section, including any seizure and disposition of the property and any related judicial or administrative proceeding, shall be conducted in accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.8 False application for financial transaction card.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.8(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-506 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.8(2): An actor commits false application for a card if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.8(2)(a): knowingly, with the intent to defraud:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.8(2)(a)(i): makes application for a financial transaction card to an issuer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.8(2)(a)(ii): makes or causes to be made a false statement or report of the actor's name, occupation, financial condition, assets, or personal identifying information; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.8(2)(b): willfully and substantially undervalues or understates any indebtedness for the purposes of influencing the issuer to issue the financial transaction card.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.8(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.8(3)(a): a class B misdemeanor if the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.8(3)(b): a class A misdemeanor if the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.8(3)(c): a third degree felony if the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or attempted to be obtained is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.8(3)(d): a second degree felony if the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or attempted to be obtained is or exceeds $5,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.8(4): The court shall make appropriate findings in any prosecution under this section that the card holder did not commit the crime.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.8(5): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.8(6): Title 77, Chapter 11a, Seizure of Property and Contraband; Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence The forfeiture of property under this section, including any seizure and disposition of the property and any related judicial or administrative proceeding, shall be conducted in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.9(3): (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.9(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.9(3)(a)(ii): a class A misdemeanor if the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.9(3)(a)(iii): a third degree felony if the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or attempted to be obtained is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.9(3)(a)(iv): a second degree felony if the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or attempted to be obtained is or exceeds $5,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.9(3)(b): (2) Multiple violations of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-506.9(4): The court shall make appropriate findings in any prosecution under this section that the card holder did not commit the crime.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-507 Deceptive business practices.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-507(1): 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-507(1)(a): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-507(1)(a)(i): "Adulterated" means varying from the standard of composition or quality prescribed, or pursuant to any statute providing criminal penalties for a variance, or set by established commercial usage.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-507(1)(a)(ii): "Mislabeled" means varying from the standard of truth or disclosure in labeling prescribed by or pursuant to any statute providing criminal penalties for a variance, or set by established commercial usage.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-507(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-507(2): An actor commits deceptive business practices if the actor, in the course of business:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-507(2)(a): uses or possesses for use a false weight or measure, or any other device for falsely determining or recording any quality or quantity;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-507(2)(b): takes or attempts to take more than the represented quantity of any commodity or service when as buyer the actor furnishes the weight or measure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-507(2)(c): sells, offers, or exposes for sale adulterated or mislabeled commodities.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-507(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-507(4): It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under this section that the defendant's conduct was not knowing or reckless.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-507(5): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-507(6): Title 77, Chapter 11a, Seizure of Property and Contraband; Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence The forfeiture of property under this section, including any seizure and disposition of the property and any related judicial or administrative proceeding, shall be conducted in accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-508 Bribery of or receiving bribe by person in the business of selection, appraisal, or criticism of goods or services.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-508(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-508(2): An actor commits bribery or receiving a bribe if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-508(2)(a): without the consent of the employer or principal, and contrary to the interests of the employer or principal:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-508(2)(a)(i): confers, offers, or agrees to confer upon the employee, agent, or fiduciary of an employer or principal any benefit with the purpose of influencing the conduct of the employee, agent, or fiduciary in relating to his employer's or principal's affairs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-508(2)(a)(ii): as an employee, agent, or fiduciary of an employer or principal, solicits, accepts, or agrees to accept any benefit from another upon an agreement or understanding that such benefit will influence the actor's conduct in relation to the actor's, employer's, or principal's affairs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-508(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-508(2)(b)(i): holds the actor's self out to the public as being engaged in the business of making disinterested selection, appraisal, or criticism of goods or services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-508(2)(b)(ii): solicits, accepts, or agrees to accept any benefit to influence the actor's selection, appraisal, or criticism.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-508(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-508(4): This section does not apply to inducements made or accepted solely for the purpose of causing a change in employment by an employee, agent, or fiduciary.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-508(5): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-508(6): Title 77, Chapter 11a, Seizure of Property and Contraband; Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence The forfeiture of property under this section, including any seizure and disposition of the property and any related judicial or administrative proceeding, shall be conducted in accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-509 Bribery of a labor official.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-509(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-509(2): An actor commits bribery of a labor official if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-509(2)(a): offers, confers, or agrees to confer upon a labor official any benefit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-509(2)(b): has intent to influence the labor official in respect to any of the labor official's acts, decisions, or duties as a labor official.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-509(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-509(4): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.

---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-510(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-510(2): A labor official commits receiving a bribe by a labor official if the labor official solicits, accepts, or agrees to accept any benefit from another person upon an agreement or understanding that the benefit will influence the labor official in any of the labor official's acts, decisions, or duties as a labor official.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-510(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-510(4): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-511 Defrauding of creditors.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-511(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-511(2): An actor commits defrauding of creditors if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-511(2)(a): destroys, removes, conceals, encumbers, transfers, or otherwise deals with property subject to a security interest with a purpose to hinder enforcement of that interest; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-511(2)(b): knowing that proceedings have been or are about to be instituted for the appointment of a person entitled to administer property for the benefit of creditors:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-511(2)(b)(i): destroys, removes, conceals, encumbers, transfers, or otherwise deals with any property with a purpose to defeat or obstruct the claim of any creditor, or otherwise to obstruct the operation of any law relating to administration of property for the benefit of creditors; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-511(2)(b)(ii): presents to any creditor or to an assignee for the benefit of creditors, orally or in writing, any statement relating to the debtor's estate, knowing that a material part of such statement is false.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-511(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-511(4): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-511(5): Title 77, Chapter 11a, Seizure of Property and Contraband; Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence The forfeiture of property under this section, including any seizure and disposition of the property and any related judicial or administrative proceeding, shall be conducted in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513 Unlawful dealing of property by a fiduciary.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(1): 22-1-1; 7-1-103; 63G-7-102; 76-6-401; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(1)(a): 22-1-1; 7-1-103; 63G-7-102; 76-6-401 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(1)(a)(i): 22-1-1 "Fiduciary" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(1)(a)(ii): 7-1-103 "Financial institution" means "depository institution" and "trust company" as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(1)(a)(iii): 63G-7-102 "Governmental entity" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(1)(a)(iv): "Person" does not include a financial institution whose fiduciary functions are supervised by the Department of Financial Institutions or a federal regulatory agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(1)(a)(v): 76-6-401 "Property" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(2): An actor commits unlawfully dealing with property by a fiduciary if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(2)(a): deals with property:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(2)(a)(i): that has been entrusted to the actor as a fiduciary, or property of a governmental entity, public money, or of a financial institution; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(2)(a)(ii): in a manner which:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(2)(a)(ii)(A): the actor knows is a violation of the actor's duty; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(2)(a)(ii)(B): involves substantial risk of loss or detriment to the property owner or to a person for whose benefit the property was entrusted; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(2)(b): acting as a fiduciary pledges:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(2)(b)(i): as collateral for a personal loan, or as collateral for the benefit of some party, other than the owner or the person for whose benefit the property was entrusted, the property that has been entrusted to the fiduciary; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(2)(b)(ii): without permission of the owner of the property or some other authorized person.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3): (2)(a); Part 5, Fraud; (3)(a)(ii)(B)(I); (II); (3)(a)(ii)(B)(I); (3)(a)(ii)(B)(III); (3)(a)(ii)(B)(I); (3)(a)(ii)(B)(III); (3)(a)(iii)(B); (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(a): (2)(a); Part 5, Fraud; (3)(a)(ii)(B)(I); (II); (3)(a)(ii)(B)(I); (3)(a)(ii)(B)(III); (3)(a)(ii)(B)(I); (3)(a)(ii)(B)(III); (3)(a)(iii)(B) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(a)(i): a second degree felony if the:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(a)(i)(A): value of the property is or exceeds $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(a)(i)(B): property is stolen from the person of another;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(a)(ii): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(a)(ii)(B)(I); (II); (3)(a)(ii)(B)(I); (3)(a)(ii)(B)(III) a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(a)(ii)(A): the value of the property is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(a)(ii)(B): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(a)(ii)(B)(I); (II) the value of the property is or exceeds $500 and the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the following offenses, if each prior offense was committed within 10 years before the date of the current conviction or the date of the offense upon which the current conviction is based and at least one of those convictions is for a class A misdemeanor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(a)(ii)(B)(I): any theft, any robbery, or any burglary with intent to commit theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(a)(ii)(B)(II): Part 5, Fraud any offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(a)(ii)(B)(III): (3)(a)(ii)(B)(I); (II) any attempt to commit any offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(a)(ii)(C): the value of property is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(a)(ii)(D): (3)(a)(ii)(B)(I); (3)(a)(ii)(B)(III) the actor has been previously convicted of a felony violation of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(a)(iii): (3)(a)(ii)(B)(I); (3)(a)(ii)(B)(III) a class A misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(a)(iii)(A): the value of the property stolen is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(a)(iii)(B): (3)(a)(ii)(B)(I); (3)(a)(ii)(B)(III) the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(a)(iv): (3)(a)(iii)(B) a class B misdemeanor if the value of the property stolen is less than $500 and the theft is not an offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(b): (2)(b) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(b)(i): a second degree felony if the value of the property wrongfully pledged is or exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(b)(ii): a third degree felony if the value of the property wrongfully pledged is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(b)(iii): a class A misdemeanor if the value of the property is or exceeds $500, but is less than $1,500 or the actor has been twice before convicted of theft, robbery, burglary with intent to commit theft, or unlawful dealing with property by a fiduciary; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(3)(b)(iv): a class B misdemeanor if the value of the property is less than $500.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-513(4): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-514 Unlawful influence of a contest.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-514(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-514(2): (2)(a); (b) An actor commits unlawful influence of a contest if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-514(2)(a): with a purpose to influence any participant or prospective participant not to give the participant's or prospective participant's best efforts in a publicly exhibited contest, confers or offers or agrees to confer any benefit upon or threatens any injury to a participant or prospective participant;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-514(2)(b): with a purpose to influence an official in a publicly exhibited contest to perform the official's duties improperly, confers or offers or agrees to confer any benefit upon or threatens any injury to such official;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-514(2)(c): with a purpose to influence the outcome of a publicly exhibited contest, tampers with any person, animal, or thing contrary to the rules and usages purporting to govern the contest; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-514(2)(d): (2)(a); (b) knowingly solicits, accepts, or agrees to accept any benefit, the giving of which would be criminal under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-514(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-514(4): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-515 Using or making slugs.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-515(1): 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-515(1)(a): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-515(1)(a)(i): "Coin machine" means any mechanical or electronic device or receptacle designed to receive a coin or bill of a certain denomination, or a token made for the purpose, and, in return for the insertion or deposit thereof, automatically to offer, provide, assist in providing or permit the acquisition of property or a public or private service.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-515(1)(a)(ii): "Slug" means any object which, by virtue of its size, shape, or other quality, is capable of being inserted, deposited, or otherwise used in a coin machine as an improper substitute for a genuine coin, bill, or token.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-515(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-515(2): An actor commits using or making slugs if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-515(2)(a): with a purpose to defraud the supplier of property or a service offered or sold by means of a coin machine, inserts, deposits, or uses a slug in that machine; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-515(2)(b): makes, possesses, or disposes of a slug with the purpose of enabling a person to use it fraudulently in a coin machine.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-515(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-515(4): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-515(5): Title 77, Chapter 11a, Seizure of Property and Contraband; Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence The forfeiture of property under this section, including any seizure and disposition of the property and any related judicial or administrative proceeding, shall be conducted in accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-516 Fraudulent conveyance of marital real estate.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-516(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-516(2): An actor commits fraudulent conveyance of marital real estate if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-516(2)(a): is married;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-516(2)(b): falsely represents the actor as unmarried; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-516(2)(c): knowingly conveys or mortgages real estate situated in this state, without the assent or concurrence of the actor's spouse when such consent or concurrence is necessary to relinquish the spouse's inchoate statutory interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-516(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-516(4): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-518 Criminal simulation.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-518(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-518(2): An actor commits criminal simulation if, with intent to defraud another, the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-518(2)(a): makes or alters an object in whole or in part so that it appears to have value because of age, antiquity, rarity, source, or authorship that it does not have;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-518(2)(b): sells, passes, or otherwise utters an object so made or altered;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-518(2)(c): possesses an object so made or altered with intent to sell, pass, or otherwise utter it; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-518(2)(d): authenticates or certifies an object so made or altered as genuine or as different from what it is.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-518(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-518(3)(a): if the value defrauded or intended to be defrauded is less than $500, the offense is a class B misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-518(3)(b): if the value defrauded or intended to be defrauded is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500, the offense is a class A misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-518(3)(c): if the value defrauded or intended to be defrauded is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000, the offense is a third degree felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-518(3)(d): if the value defrauded or intended to be defrauded is or exceeds $5,000, the offense is a second degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-518(4): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-518(5): Title 77, Chapter 11a, Seizure of Property and Contraband; Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence The forfeiture of property under this section, including any seizure and disposition of the property and any related judicial or administrative proceeding, shall be conducted in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521 Insurance fraud.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(1): 31A-31-102; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(1)(a): 31A-31-102 As used in this section, "runner" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(2): 31A-23a-411.1 An actor commits a fraudulent insurance act if the actor with intent to deceive or defraud:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(2)(a): presents or causes to be presented any oral or written statement or representation knowing that the statement or representation contains false or fraudulent information concerning any fact material to an application for the issuance or renewal of an insurance policy, certificate, or contract, as part of or in support of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(2)(a)(i): obtaining an insurance policy the insurer would otherwise not issue on the basis of underwriting criteria applicable to the person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(2)(a)(ii): a scheme or artifice to avoid paying the premium that an insurer charges on the basis of underwriting criteria applicable to the person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(2)(a)(iii): a scheme or artifice to file an insurance claim for a loss that has already occurred;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(2)(b): presents, or causes to be presented, any oral or written statement or representation:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(2)(b)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(2)(b)(i)(A): as part of or in support of a claim for payment or other benefit pursuant to an insurance policy, certificate, or contract; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(2)(b)(i)(B): in connection with any civil claim asserted for recovery of damages for personal or bodily injuries or property damage; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(2)(b)(ii): knowing that the statement or representation contains false, incomplete, or fraudulent information concerning any fact or thing material to the claim;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(2)(c): knowingly accepts a benefit from proceeds derived from a fraudulent insurance act;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(2)(d): intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly devises a scheme or artifice to obtain fees for professional services, or anything of value by means of false or fraudulent pretenses, representations, promises, or material omissions;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(2)(e): knowingly employs, uses, or acts as a runner for the purpose of committing a fraudulent insurance act;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(2)(f): knowingly assists, abets, solicits, or conspires with another to commit a fraudulent insurance act;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(2)(g): knowingly supplies false or fraudulent material information in any document or statement required by the Department of Insurance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(2)(h): 31A-23a-411.1 knowingly fails to forward a premium to an insurer in violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(3): (2)(a)(i); (2)(a)(ii); (2)(b); (2)(h); (2)(a)(iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(3)(a): (2)(a)(i) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(3)(b): (2)(a)(ii); (2)(b); (2)(h) A violation of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(3)(b)(i): a class B misdemeanor when the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(3)(b)(ii): a class A misdemeanor when the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(3)(b)(iii): a third degree felony when the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(3)(b)(iv): a second degree felony when the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $5,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(3)(c): (2)(a)(iii) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(3)(c)(i): a class A misdemeanor if the value of the loss is less than $1,500 or unable to be determined;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(3)(c)(ii): a third degree felony when the value of the loss is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(3)(c)(iii): a second degree felony when the value of the loss is or exceeds $5,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(4): 76-2-204 A corporation or association is guilty of the offense of insurance fraud under the same conditions as those set forth in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(5): (2)(a)(ii); (2)(b); (2)(h); (2)(a)(ii); (2)(b); (2)(h) The determination of the degree of any offense under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-521(6): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522 Equity skimming of a vehicle.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(1): 41-1a-102; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(1)(a): 41-1a-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(1)(a)(i): "Actor" means a broker, dealer, or a person in collusion with a dealer or broker.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(1)(a)(ii): "Broker" means any person who, for compensation of any kind, arranges for the sale, lease, sublease, or transfer of a vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(1)(a)(iii): "Dealer" means any person engaged in the business of selling, leasing, or exchanging vehicles for compensation of any kind.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(1)(a)(iv): "Lease" means any grant of use or possession of a vehicle for consideration, with or without an option to buy.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(1)(a)(v): "Security interest" means an interest in a vehicle that secures payment or performance of an obligation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(1)(a)(vi): "Transfer" means any delivery or conveyance of a vehicle to another from one person to another.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(1)(a)(vii): 41-1a-102 "Vehicle" means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, or through the air or water, or over land and includes a manufactured home or mobile home as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(2): An actor commits equity skimming of a vehicle if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(2)(a)(i): transfers or arranges the transfer of a vehicle for consideration or profit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(2)(a)(ii): has not first obtained written authorization of the lessor or holder of the security interest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(2)(b): knows or should have known the vehicle is subject to a lease or security interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(4): (2) It is a defense to a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(5): This section may not be construed to impose criminal or civil liability on any law enforcement officer acting within the scope of a criminal investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-522(6): Title 77, Chapter 11a, Seizure of Property and Contraband; Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence The forfeiture of property under this section, including any seizure and disposition of the property and any related judicial or administrative proceeding, shall be conducted in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-601 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-601(1): "Merchandise" means any personal property displayed, held, or offered for sale by a merchant.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-601(2): "Merchant" means an owner or operator of any retail mercantile establishment where merchandise is displayed, held, or offered for sale and includes the merchant's employees, servants, or agents.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-601(3): "Minor" means any unmarried person under 18 years of age.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-601(4): Title 53, Chapter 13, Peace Officer Classifications "Peace officer" has the same meaning as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-601(5): "Premises of a retail mercantile establishment" includes, but is not limited to, the retail mercantile establishment; any common use areas in shopping centers and all parking lots or areas set aside for the benefit of those patrons of the retail mercantile establishment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-601(6): "Retail mercantile establishment" means any place where merchandise is displayed, held, or offered for sale to the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-601(7): "Retail value" means the merchant's stated or advertised price of the merchandise.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-601(8): "Shopping cart" means those push carts of the types which are commonly provided by grocery stores, drug stores, or other mercantile establishments, or markets for the use of the public in transporting commodities in stores and markets from the store to a place outside the store.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-601(9): "Under-ring" means to cause the cash register or other sales recording device to reflect less than the retail value of the merchandise.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602 Retail theft.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-601 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(2): (2)(b)(i) An actor commits retail theft if the actor knowingly:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(2)(a): takes possession of, conceals, carries away, transfers or causes to be carried away or transferred, any merchandise displayed, held, stored, or offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment with the intention of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(2)(a)(i): retaining the merchandise; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(2)(a)(ii): depriving the merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without paying the retail value of the merchandise;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(2)(b): (2)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(2)(b)(i): alters, transfers, or removes any label, price tag, marking, indicia of value, or any other markings which aid in determining value of any merchandise displayed, held, stored, or offered for sale, in a retail mercantile establishment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(2)(b)(ii): (2)(b)(i) attempts to purchase the merchandise described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(2)(c): transfers any merchandise displayed, held, stored, or offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment from the container in or on which the merchandise is displayed to any other container with the intention of depriving the merchant of the retail value of the merchandise;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(2)(d): under-rings with the intention of depriving the merchant of the retail value of the merchandise; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(2)(e): removes a shopping cart from the premises of a retail mercantile establishment with the intent of depriving the merchant of the possession, use, or benefit of the shopping cart.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3): (2); 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402; Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii)(C); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii)(C); (3)(c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(a): a second degree felony if the:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(a)(i): value of the merchandise or shopping cart is or exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(a)(ii): merchandise stolen is a firearm or an operable motor vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(b): 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402; Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii)(C) a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(b)(i): the value of the merchandise is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(b)(ii): 76-6-1402; 76-6-1402 the merchandise is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(b)(ii)(A): 76-6-1402 a catalytic converter as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(b)(ii)(B): 76-6-1402 25 pounds or more of a suspect metal item as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(b)(iii): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B) the value of the merchandise or shopping cart is or exceeds $500 and the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the following offenses, if each prior offense was committed within 10 years before the date of the current conviction or the date of the offense upon which the current conviction is based and at least one of those convictions is for a class A misdemeanor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(b)(iii)(A): any theft, any robbery, or any burglary with intent to commit theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(b)(iii)(B): Part 5, Fraud any offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(b)(iii)(C): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (B) any attempt to commit any offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(b)(iv): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(b)(iv)(A): the value of merchandise or shopping cart is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(b)(iv)(B): the theft occurs in a retail mercantile establishment or on the premises of a retail mercantile establishment where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(b)(iv)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the merchant prohibiting the offender from entering the retail mercantile establishment or premises of a retail mercantile establishment pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(b)(v): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii)(C) the actor has been previously convicted of a felony violation of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(c): 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii)(C) a class A misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(c)(i): the value of the merchandise or shopping cart stolen is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(c)(ii): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(c)(ii)(A): the value of merchandise or shopping cart is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(c)(ii)(B): the theft occurs in a retail mercantile establishment or premises of a retail mercantile establishment where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(c)(ii)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the merchant prohibiting the offender from entering the retail mercantile establishment or premises of a retail mercantile establishment pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(c)(iii): (3)(b)(iii)(A); (3)(b)(iii)(C) the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-602(3)(d): (3)(c) a class B misdemeanor if the value of the merchandise or shopping cart stolen is less than $500 and the theft is not an offense under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-603 Detention of suspected violator by merchant -- Purposes.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-603(1): Any merchant who has probable cause to believe that a person has committed retail theft may detain such person, on or off the premises of a retail mercantile establishment, in a reasonable manner and for a reasonable length of time for all or any of the following purposes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-603(1)(a): to make reasonable inquiry as to whether such person has in his possession unpurchased merchandise and to make reasonable investigation of the ownership of such merchandise;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-603(1)(b): to request identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-603(1)(c): to verify such identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-603(1)(d): to make a reasonable request of such person to place or keep in full view any merchandise such individual may have removed, or which the merchant has reason to believe he may have removed, from its place of display or elsewhere, whether for examination, purchase, or for any other reasonable purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-603(1)(e): to inform a peace officer of the detention of the person and surrender that person to the custody of a peace officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-603(1)(f): in the case of a minor, to inform a peace officer, the parents, guardian, or other private person interested in the welfare of that minor immediately, if possible, of this detention and to surrender custody of such minor to such person.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-603(2): A merchant may make a detention as permitted herein off the premises of a retail mercantile establishment only if such detention is pursuant to an immediate pursuit of such person.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-604 Defense to action by person detained.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
In any action for false arrest, false imprisonment, unlawful detention, defamation of character, assault, trespass, or invasion of civil rights brought by any person detained by the merchant, it shall be a defense to such action that the merchant detaining such person had probable cause to believe that the person had committed retail theft and that the merchant acted reasonably under all circumstances.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-607 Report of arrest to division.
------------------------------------------------------------
Any arrest made for a violation of this part shall be reported by the appropriate jurisdiction to the Criminal Investigations and Technical Services Division of the Department of Public Safety, established in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-608 Theft detection shielding devices prohibited.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-608(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-601 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-608(2): An actor commits the unlawful shielding of a theft detection device if the actor knowingly:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-608(2)(a): makes or possesses any container or device used for, intended for use for, or represented as having the purpose of shielding merchandise from any electronic or magnetic theft alarm sensor, with the intent to commit a theft of merchandise;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-608(2)(b): sells, offers to sell, advertises, gives, transports, or otherwise transfers to another any container or device intended for use for or represented as having the purpose of shielding merchandise from any electronic or magnetic theft alarm sensor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-608(2)(c): possesses any tool or instrument designed to remove any theft detection device from any merchandise, with the intent to use the tool or instrument to remove any theft detection device from any merchandise without the permission of the merchant or the person owning or in possession of the merchandise; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-608(2)(d): intentionally removes a theft detection device from merchandise prior to purchase and without the permission of the merchant.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-608(3): (2)(a); (b); (c); (2)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-608(3)(a): (2)(a); (b); (c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-608(3)(b): (2)(d) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-608(3)(b)(i): class B misdemeanor if the value of the merchandise from which the theft detection device is removed is less than $500; or
