Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-608(3)(b)(ii): class A misdemeanor if the value of the merchandise from which the theft detection device is removed is or exceeds $500.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-608(4): (2); Part 4, Theft; Part 6, Retail Theft A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-608(5): Criminal prosecutions under this section do not affect any person's right of civil action for redress for damages suffered as a result of any violation of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(1): "Access" means to directly or indirectly use, attempt to use, instruct, communicate with, cause input to, cause output from, or otherwise make use of any resources of a computer, computer system, computer network, or any means of communication with any of them.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(2): "Authorization" means having the express or implied consent or permission of the owner, or of the person authorized by the owner to give consent or permission to access a computer, computer system, or computer network in a manner not exceeding the consent or permission.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(3): "Computer" means any electronic device or communication facility that stores, processes, transmits, or facilitates the transmission of data.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(4): "Computer network" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(4)(a): the interconnection of communication or telecommunication lines between:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(4)(a)(i): computers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(4)(a)(ii): computers and remote terminals; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(4)(b): the interconnection by wireless technology between:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(4)(b)(i): computers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(4)(b)(ii): computers and remote terminals.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(5): "Computer property" includes electronic impulses, electronically produced data, information, financial instruments, software, or programs, in either machine or human readable form, any other tangible or intangible item relating to a computer, computer system, computer network, and copies of any of them.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(6): "Computer system" means a set of related, connected or unconnected, devices, software, or other related computer equipment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(7): "Computer technology" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(7)(a): a computer;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(7)(b): a computer network;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(7)(c): computer hardware;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(7)(d): a computer system;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(7)(e): a computer program;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(7)(f): computer services;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(7)(g): computer software; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(7)(h): computer data.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(8): "Confidential" means data, text, or computer property that is protected by a security system that clearly evidences that the owner or custodian intends that it not be available to others without the owner's or custodian's permission.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(9): 26B-2-201 "Critical infrastructure" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(9)(a): a financial or banking system;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(9)(b): any railroad, airline, airport, airway, highway, bridge, waterway, fixed guideway, or other transportation system intended for the transportation of persons or property;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(9)(c): any public utility service, including a power, energy, gas, or water supply system;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(9)(d): a sewage or water treatment system;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(9)(e): 26B-2-201 a health care facility, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(9)(f): an emergency fire, medical, or law enforcement response system;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(9)(g): a public health facility or system;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(9)(h): a food distribution system;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(9)(i): a government computer system or network;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(9)(j): a school; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(9)(k): other government facilities, operations, or services.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(10): "Denial of service attack" means an attack or intrusion that is intended to disrupt legitimate access to, or use of, a network resource, a machine, or computer technology.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(11): "Financial instrument" includes any check, draft, money order, certificate of deposit, letter of credit, bill of exchange, electronic fund transfer, automated clearing house transaction, credit card, or marketable security.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(12)(a): "Identifying information" means a person's:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(12)(a)(i): social security number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(12)(a)(ii): driver license number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(12)(a)(iii): nondriver governmental identification number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(12)(a)(iv): bank account number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(12)(a)(v): student identification number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(12)(a)(vi): credit or debit card number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(12)(a)(vii): personal identification number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(12)(a)(viii): unique biometric data;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(12)(a)(ix): employee or payroll number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(12)(a)(x): automated or electronic signature; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(12)(a)(xi): computer password.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(12)(b): "Identifying information" does not include information that is lawfully available from publicly available information, or from federal, state, or local government records lawfully made available to the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(13): "Information" does not include information obtained:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(13)(a): through use of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(13)(a)(i): an electronic product identification or tracking system; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(13)(a)(ii): other technology used by a retailer to identify, track, or price goods; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(13)(b): by a retailer through the use of equipment designed to read the electronic product identification or tracking system data located within the retailer's location.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(14): "Interactive computer service" means an information service, system, or access software provider that provides or enables computer access by multiple users to a computer server, including a service or system that provides access to the Internet or a system operated, or services offered, by a library or an educational institution.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(15): "License or entitlement" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(15)(a): licenses, certificates, and permits granted by governments;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(15)(b): degrees, diplomas, and grades awarded by educational institutions;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(15)(c): military ranks, grades, decorations, and awards;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(15)(d): membership and standing in organizations and religious institutions;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(15)(e): certification as a peace officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(15)(f): credit reports; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(15)(g): another record or datum upon which a person may be reasonably expected to rely in making decisions that will have a direct benefit or detriment to another.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(16): "Security system" means a computer, computer system, network, or computer property that has some form of access control technology implemented, such as encryption, password protection, other forced authentication, or access control designed to keep out unauthorized persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(17): "Services" include computer time, data manipulation, and storage functions.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(18): "Service provider" means a telecommunications carrier, cable operator, computer hardware or software provider, or a provider of information service or interactive computer service.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-702(19): "Software" or "program" means a series of instructions or statements in a form acceptable to a computer, relating to the operations of the computer, or permitting the functioning of a computer system in a manner designed to provide results including system control programs, application programs, or copies of any of them.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703 Unlawful computer technology access or action or denial of service attack.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-702 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2): An actor commits unlawful computer technology access or action or denial of service attack if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(a): without authorization, or in excess of the actor's authorization, accesses or attempts to access computer technology if the access or attempt to access results in:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(a)(i): the alteration, damage, destruction, copying, transmission, discovery, or disclosure of computer technology;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(a)(ii): interference with or interruption of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(a)(ii)(A): the lawful use of computer technology; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(a)(ii)(B): the transmission of data;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(a)(iii): physical damage to or loss of real, personal, or commercial property;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(a)(iv): audio, video, or other surveillance of another person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(a)(v): economic loss to any person or entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(b): after accessing computer technology that the actor is authorized to access, knowingly takes or attempts to take unauthorized or unlawful action that results in:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(b)(i): the alteration, damage, destruction, copying, transmission, discovery, or disclosure of computer technology;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(b)(ii): interference with or interruption of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(b)(ii)(A): the lawful use of computer technology; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(b)(ii)(B): the transmission of data;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(b)(iii): physical damage to or loss of real, personal, or commercial property;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(b)(iv): audio, video, or other surveillance of another person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(b)(v): economic loss to any person or entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(2)(c): knowingly engages in a denial of service attack.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(3)(a): a class B misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(3)(a)(i): the economic loss or other loss or damage caused or the value of the money, property, or benefit obtained or sought to be obtained is less than $500; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(3)(a)(ii): the information obtained is not confidential;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(3)(b): a class A misdemeanor if the economic loss or other loss or damage caused or the value of the money, property, or benefit obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(3)(c): a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(3)(c)(i): the economic loss or other loss or damage caused or the value of the money, property, or benefit obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(3)(c)(ii): the property or benefit obtained or sought to be obtained is a license or entitlement;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(3)(c)(iii): the damage is to the license or entitlement of another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(3)(c)(iv): the information obtained is confidential or identifying information; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(3)(c)(v): in gaining access the actor breaches or breaks through a security system; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(3)(d): a second degree felony if the economic loss or other loss or damage caused or the value of the money, property, or benefit obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $5,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(4)(a): It is an affirmative defense that the actor obtained access or attempted to obtain access:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(4)(a)(i): in response to, and for the purpose of protecting against or investigating, a prior attempted or successful breach of security of computer technology whose security the actor is authorized or entitled to protect, and the access attempted or obtained was no greater than reasonably necessary for that purpose; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(4)(a)(ii): pursuant to a search warrant or a lawful exception to the requirement to obtain a search warrant.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(4)(b): In accordance with 47 U.S.C. Sec. 230, this section may not apply to, and nothing in this section may be construed to impose liability or culpability on, an interactive computer service for content provided by another person.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(4)(c): This section does not affect, limit, or apply to any activity or conduct that is protected by the constitution or laws of this state, or by the constitution or laws of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(5)(a): An interactive computer service is not guilty of violating this section if a person violates this section using the interactive computer service and the interactive computer service did not knowingly assist the person to commit the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(5)(b): A service provider is not guilty of violating this section for:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(5)(b)(i): action taken in relation to a customer of the service provider, for a legitimate business purpose, to install software on, monitor, or interact with the customer's Internet or other network connection, service, or computer for network or computer security purposes, authentication, diagnostics, technical support, maintenance, repair, network management, updates of computer software or system firmware, or remote system management; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(5)(b)(ii): action taken, including scanning and removing computer software, to detect or prevent the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(5)(b)(ii)(A): unauthorized or fraudulent use of a network, service, or computer software;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(5)(b)(ii)(B): illegal activity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703(5)(b)(ii)(C): infringement of intellectual property rights.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1 Unlawful disclosure of personal information.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(1): 76-9-201; 76-1-101.5; 76-6-702
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(1)(a): 76-9-201 As used in this section, "electronic communication harassment" means an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-702 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(2): An actor commits unlawful disclosure of personal information if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(2)(a): with intent that electronic communication harassment occur, the actor discloses or disseminates another person's identifying information with the expectation that others will further disseminate or use the person's identifying information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(2)(b): the disclosure or dissemination of the other person's identifying information results in electronic communication harassment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(3): (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(3)(a): (2) If the person whose identifying information is disseminated is an adult, a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(3)(a)(i): a class B misdemeanor on the first offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(3)(a)(ii): a class A misdemeanor on the second offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(3)(a)(iii): a third degree felony on a third or subsequent offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(3)(b): (2) If the person whose identifying information is disseminated is a minor, a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(3)(b)(i): a class A misdemeanor on the first offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(3)(b)(ii): a third degree felony on the second or subsequent offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(4): Title 34A, Chapter 6, Utah Occupational Safety and Health Act; Title 67, Chapter 21, Utah Protection of Public Employees Act
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(4)(a): Title 34A, Chapter 6, Utah Occupational Safety and Health Act; Title 67, Chapter 21, Utah Protection of Public Employees Act This section does not apply to an actor who provides information in conjunction with a report under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(4)(b): In accordance with 47 U.S.C. Sec. 230, this section may not apply to, and nothing in this section may be construed to impose liability or culpability on, an interactive computer service for content provided by another person.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(4)(c): This section does not affect, limit, or apply to any activity or conduct that is protected by the constitution or laws of this state, or by the constitution or laws of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(5)(a): An interactive computer service is not guilty of violating this section if an actor violates this section using the interactive computer service and the interactive computer service did not knowingly assist the actor to commit the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(5)(b): A service provider is not guilty of violating this section for:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(5)(b)(i): action taken in relation to a customer of the service provider, for a legitimate business purpose, to install software on, monitor, or interact with the customer's Internet or other network connection, service, or computer for network or computer security purposes, authentication, diagnostics, technical support, maintenance, repair, network management, updates of computer software or system firmware, or remote system management; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(5)(b)(ii): action taken, including scanning and removing computer software, to detect or prevent the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(5)(b)(ii)(A): unauthorized or fraudulent use of a network, service, or computer software;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(5)(b)(ii)(B): illegal activity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.1(5)(b)(ii)(C): infringement of intellectual property rights.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3 Unlawful use of technology to defraud.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(1): 76-10-1801; 76-1-101.5; 76-6-702
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(1)(a): 76-10-1801 As used in this section, "sensitive personal identifying information" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-702 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(2): An actor commits unlawful use of technology to defraud if the actor uses or knowingly allows another person to use a computer, computer network, computer property, or computer system, program, or software to devise or execute any artifice or scheme to defraud or to obtain money, property, a service, or other thing of value by a false pretense, promise, or representation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(3)(a): a class B misdemeanor if the value of the money, property, service, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(3)(b): a class A misdemeanor if the value of the money, property, service, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(3)(c): a third degree felony if the value of the money, property, service, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(3)(d): a second degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(3)(d)(i): the value of the money, property, service, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(3)(d)(ii): the object or purpose of the artifice or scheme to defraud is the obtaining of sensitive personal identifying information, regardless of the value.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(4)(a): In accordance with 47 U.S.C. Sec. 230, this section may not apply to, and nothing in this section may be construed to impose liability or culpability on, an interactive computer service for content provided by another person.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(4)(b): This section does not affect, limit, or apply to any activity or conduct that is protected by the constitution or laws of this state, or by the constitution or laws of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(5)(a): An interactive computer service is not guilty of violating this section if a person violates this section using the interactive computer service and the interactive computer service did not knowingly assist the person to commit the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(5)(b): A service provider is not guilty of violating this section for:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(5)(b)(i): action taken in relation to a customer of the service provider, for a legitimate business purpose, to install software on, monitor, or interact with the customer's Internet or other network connection, service, or computer for network or computer security purposes, authentication, diagnostics, technical support, maintenance, repair, network management, updates of computer software or system firmware, or remote system management; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(5)(b)(ii): action taken, including scanning and removing computer software, to detect or prevent the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(5)(b)(ii)(A): unauthorized or fraudulent use of a network, service, or computer software;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(5)(b)(ii)(B): illegal activity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.3(5)(b)(ii)(C): infringement of intellectual property rights.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.5 Interference or interruption of critical infrastructure.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.5(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-702 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.5(2): An actor commits interference or interruption of critical infrastructure if the actor intentionally or knowingly, and without lawful authorization, interferes with or interrupts critical infrastructure.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.5(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.5(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.5(4)(a): In accordance with 47 U.S.C. Sec. 230, this section may not apply to, and nothing in this section may be construed to impose liability or culpability on, an interactive computer service for content provided by another person.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.5(4)(b): This section does not affect, limit, or apply to any activity or conduct that is protected by the constitution or laws of this state, or by the constitution or laws of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.5(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.5(5)(a): An interactive computer service is not guilty of violating this section if a person violates this section using the interactive computer service and the interactive computer service did not knowingly assist the person to commit the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.5(5)(b): A service provider is not guilty of violating this section for:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.5(5)(b)(i): action taken in relation to a customer of the service provider, for a legitimate business purpose, to install software on, monitor, or interact with the customer's Internet or other network connection, service, or computer for network or computer security purposes, authentication, diagnostics, technical support, maintenance, repair, network management, updates of computer software or system firmware, or remote system management; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.5(5)(b)(ii): action taken, including scanning and removing computer software, to detect or prevent the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.5(5)(b)(ii)(A): unauthorized or fraudulent use of a network, service, or computer software;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.5(5)(b)(ii)(B): illegal activity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.5(5)(b)(ii)(C): infringement of intellectual property rights.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7 Unlawful computer access.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-702 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(2): (2)(a); 76-6-703; 76-6-703.1; 76-6-703.3; 76-6-703.5 An actor commits unlawful computer access if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(2)(a): the actor intentionally or knowingly, and without authorization, gains or attempts to gain access to a computer, computer network, computer property, or computer system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(2)(b): (2)(a); 76-6-703; 76-6-703.1; 76-6-703.3; 76-6-703.5 the circumstances of the violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(4): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(4)(a): (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(4)(b): It is an affirmative defense to a violation under this section that the actor obtained access or attempted to obtain access:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(4)(b)(i): in response to, and for the purpose of protecting against or investigating, a prior attempted or successful breach of security of computer technology whose security the actor is authorized or entitled to protect, and the access attempted or obtained was no greater than reasonably necessary for that purpose; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(4)(b)(ii): pursuant to a search warrant or a lawful exception to the requirement to obtain a search warrant.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(4)(c): In accordance with 47 U.S.C. Sec. 230, this section may not apply to, and nothing in this section may be construed to impose liability or culpability on, an interactive computer service for content provided by another person.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(4)(d): This section does not affect, limit, or apply to any activity or conduct that is protected by the constitution or laws of this state, or by the constitution or laws of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(5)(a): An interactive computer service is not guilty of violating this section if an actor violates this section using the interactive computer service and the interactive computer service did not knowingly assist the actor to commit the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(5)(b): A service provider is not guilty of violating this section for:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(5)(b)(i): action taken in relation to a customer of the service provider, for a legitimate business purpose, to install software on, monitor, or interact with the customer's Internet or other network connection, service, or computer for network or computer security purposes, authentication, diagnostics, technical support, maintenance, repair, network management, updates of computer software or system firmware, or remote system management; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(5)(b)(ii): action taken, including scanning and removing computer software, to detect or prevent the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(5)(b)(ii)(A): unauthorized or fraudulent use of a network, service, or computer software;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(5)(b)(ii)(B): illegal activity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-703.7(5)(b)(ii)(C): infringement of intellectual property rights.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-704 Attorney general, county attorney, or district attorney to prosecute -- Conduct violating other statutes.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-704(1): The attorney general, district attorney, or the county attorney shall prosecute suspected criminal violations of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-704(2): Prosecution under this part does not prevent any prosecutions under any other law.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-705 Reporting violations.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-705(1): 76-6-703; 76-6-703.1; 76-6-703.3; 76-6-703.5; 76-6-703.7 Each person who has reason to believe that a provision of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-705(1)(a): the attorney general, or county attorney, or, if within a prosecution district, the district attorney of the county or prosecution district in which part or all of the violation occurred; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-705(1)(b): a state or local law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-705(2): (1) Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801 Library theft.
---------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(1): 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(1)(a): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(1)(a)(i): "Library" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(1)(a)(i)(A): a public library;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(1)(a)(i)(B): a library of an educational or historical society;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(1)(a)(i)(C): a museum; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(1)(a)(i)(D): a repository of public records.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(1)(a)(ii): "Library materials" means a book, plate, picture, photograph, engraving, painting, drawing, map, newspaper, magazine, pamphlet, broadside, manuscript, document, letter, public record, microfilm, sound recording, audiovisual materials in any format, electronic data processing records, artifacts, or other documentary, written or printed materials regardless of physical form or characteristics, belonging to, on loan to, or otherwise in the custody of a library.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(2): An actor commits library theft if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(2)(a): willfully, for the purpose of converting to personal use, and depriving the owner, conceals on the actor's person or among the actor's belongings library materials while on the premises of the library; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(2)(b): willfully and without authority removes library materials from the library building with the intention of converting them to the actor's own use.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3): (2); Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C); (3)(c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(a): a second degree felony if the value of the library materials is or exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(b): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(b)(i): the value of the library materials is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(b)(ii): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B) the value of the library materials is or exceeds $500 and the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the following offenses, if each prior offense was committed within 10 years before the date of the current conviction or the date of the offense upon which the current conviction is based and at least one of those convictions is for a class A misdemeanor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(b)(ii)(A): any theft, any robbery, or any burglary with intent to commit theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(b)(ii)(B): Part 5, Fraud any offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(b)(ii)(C): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B) any attempt to commit any offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(b)(iii): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(b)(iii)(A): the value of the library materials is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(b)(iii)(B): the theft occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(b)(iii)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the library prohibiting the offender from entering the property if the library has complied with the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(b)(iv): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) the actor has been previously convicted of a felony violation of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(c): 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) a class A misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(c)(i): the value of the library materials stolen is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(c)(ii): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(c)(ii)(A): the value of the library materials is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(c)(ii)(B): the theft occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(c)(ii)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the library if the library has complied with the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(c)(iii): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(3)(d): (3)(c) a class B misdemeanor if the value of the library materials stolen is less than $500 and the theft is not an offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(4)(a): An actor who willfully conceals library materials on the actor's person or among the actor's belongings while on the premises of the library or in the library's immediate vicinity is prima facie presumed to have concealed library materials with the intention of converting the library materials to the actor's own use.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-801(4)(b): If library materials are found concealed upon the actor's person or among the actor's belongings, or electronic security devices are activated by the actor's presence, it is prima facie evidence of willful concealment.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803 Mutilation or damaging of library material.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(1): 76-6-801; 76-6-801; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(1)(a): 76-6-801; 76-6-801 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(1)(a)(i): 76-6-801 "Library" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(1)(a)(ii): 76-6-801 "Library materials" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(2): An actor is guilty of mutilation or damage of library materials if the actor intentionally or recklessly writes upon, injures, defaces, tears, cuts, mutilates, destroys, or otherwise damages library materials.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3): (2); Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C); (3)(c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(a): a second degree felony if the value of the library materials is or exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(b): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(b)(i): the value of the library materials is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(b)(ii): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B) the value of the library materials is or exceeds $500 and the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the following offenses, if each prior offense was committed within 10 years before the date of the current conviction or the date of the offense upon which the current conviction is based and at least one of those convictions is for a class A misdemeanor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(b)(ii)(A): any theft, any robbery, or any burglary with intent to commit theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(b)(ii)(B): Part 5, Fraud any offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(b)(ii)(C): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B) any attempt to commit any offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(b)(iii): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(b)(iii)(A): the value of the library materials is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(b)(iii)(B): the theft occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(b)(iii)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the library if the library has complied with the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(b)(iv): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) the actor has been previously convicted of a felony violation of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(c): 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) a class A misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(c)(i): the value of the library materials stolen is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(c)(ii): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(c)(ii)(A): the value of the library materials is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(c)(ii)(B): the theft occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(c)(ii)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the library if the library has complied with the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(c)(iii): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803(3)(d): (3)(c) a class B misdemeanor if the value of the library materials stolen is less than $500 and the theft is not an offense under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30 Failure to return library material -- Written notice.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(1): 76-6-801; 76-6-801; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(1)(a): 76-6-801; 76-6-801 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(1)(a)(i): 76-6-801 "Library" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(1)(a)(ii): 76-6-801 "Library materials" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(2)(a): An actor is guilty of failure to return library materials if the actor, having possession or having been in possession of library materials:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(2)(a)(i): fails to return the materials within 30 days after receiving written notice demanding return of the materials; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(2)(a)(ii): if the materials are lost or destroyed, fails to pay the replacement value of the materials within 30 days after being notified.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(2)(b): Written notice is considered received upon the sworn affidavit of the person delivering the notice with a statement as to the date, place, and manner of delivery, or upon proof that the notice was mailed postage prepaid, via the United States Postal Service, to the current address listed for the person in the library records.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3): (2); Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C); (3)(c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(a): a second degree felony if the value of the library materials is or exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(b): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B); 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(b)(i): the value of the library materials is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(b)(ii): Part 5, Fraud; (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B) the value of the library materials is or exceeds $500 and the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the following offenses, if each prior offense was committed within 10 years before the date of the current conviction or the date of the offense upon which the current conviction is based and at least one of those convictions is for a class A misdemeanor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(b)(ii)(A): any theft, any robbery, or any burglary with intent to commit theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(b)(ii)(B): Part 5, Fraud any offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(b)(ii)(C): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (B) any attempt to commit any offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(b)(iii): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(b)(iii)(A): the value of the library materials is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(b)(iii)(B): the theft occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(b)(iii)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the library if the library has complied with the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(b)(iv): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) the actor has been previously convicted of a felony violation of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(c): 78B-3-108(4); (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) a class A misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(c)(i): the value of the library materials stolen is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(c)(ii): 78B-3-108(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(c)(ii)(A): the value of the library materials is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(c)(ii)(B): the theft occurs on a property where the offender has committed any theft within the past five years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(c)(ii)(C): 78B-3-108(4) the offender has received written notice from the library if the library has complied with the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(c)(iii): (3)(b)(ii)(A); (3)(b)(ii)(C) the actor has been twice before convicted of any of the offenses listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.30(3)(d): (3)(c) a class B misdemeanor if the value of the library material stolen is less than $500 and the theft is not an offense under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.60 Detention of theft suspect by library employee -- Purposes.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.60(1): 76-6-801; 76-6-801; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.60(1)(a): 76-6-801; 76-6-801 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.60(1)(a)(i): 76-6-801 "Library" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.60(1)(a)(ii): 76-6-801 "Library materials" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.60(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.60(2): Any employee of the library who has probable cause to believe that a person has committed library theft may detain the person, on or off the premises of a library, in a reasonable manner and for a reasonable length of time for all or any of the following purposes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.60(2)(a): to make reasonable inquiry as to whether the person has in his possession concealed library materials;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.60(2)(b): to request identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.60(2)(c): to verify identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.60(2)(d): to make a reasonable request of the person to place or keep in full view any library materials the individual may have removed, or which the employee has reason to believe he may have removed, from its place of display or elsewhere, whether for examination, or for any other reasonable purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.60(2)(e): to inform a peace officer of the detention of the person and surrender that person to the custody of a peace officer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.60(2)(f): in the case of a minor, to inform a peace officer, the parents, guardian, or other private person interested in the welfare of the minor as soon as possible of this detention and to surrender custody of the minor to this person.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.60(3): An employee may make a detention under this section off the library premises only if the detention is pursuant to an immediate pursuit of the person.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.90 Liability -- Defense -- Probable cause -- Reasonableness.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.90(1): 76-6-801; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.90(1)(a): 76-6-801 As used in this section, "library" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.90(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-803.90(2): In any action for false arrest, false imprisonment, unlawful detention, defamation of character, assault, trespass, or invasion of civil rights brought by any person detained by an employee of the library, it is a defense to the action that the employee of the library detaining the person had probable cause to believe that the person had committed library theft and that the employee acted reasonably under all circumstances.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-901 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-901(1): "Antiquities" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-901(1)(a): all material remains and their associations, recoverable through excavation or surface collection, that provide information pertaining to the historic or prehistoric peoples in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-901(1)(b): vertebrate fossils and other exceptional fossils and fossil sites designated as state landmarks.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-901(2): "Landowner" includes the School and Institutional Trust Lands Administration with respect to lands sold by the School and Institutional Trust Lands Administration and upon which a restrictive deed covenant has been imposed by the School and Institutional Trust Lands Administration.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-901(3): "Persons" means an individual, corporation, partnership, trust, institution, association, or any other private entity or any officer, employee, agent, department, or instrumentality of the United States, of any Native American tribe, or of any state or political subdivision of any state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-901(4): "State lands" means all lands owned by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-901(4)(a): Utah, including school and institutional trust lands and lands sold by the School and Institutional Trust Lands Administration subject to a restrictive deed covenant for the protection of antiquities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-901(4)(b): political subdivisions.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902 Antiquities alteration, removal, injury, or destruction.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-901 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902(2): (2)(a) An actor commits antiquities alteration, removal, injury, or destruction if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902(2)(a): intentionally alters, removes, injures, or destroys antiquities from state lands or private lands without the landowner's consent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902(2)(b): (2)(a) counsels, procures, solicits, or employs another person to violate Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902(3): (3)(b); (2); (2); 76-6-902.1; 76-6-902.2; (3)(c); (3)(b)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902(3)(a): (3)(b); (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902(3)(b): (2); 76-6-902.1; 76-6-902.2; (3)(c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902(3)(b)(i): 76-6-902.1; 76-6-902.2 the violation is the actor's second or subsequent violation of this section, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902(3)(b)(ii): (3)(c) the amount at issue, as calculated under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902(3)(c): (3)(b)(ii) The amount described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902(3)(c)(i): the commercial or archaeological value of the antiquities involved in the violation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902(3)(c)(ii): the cost of the restoration and repair of the antiquities involved in the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902(3)(d): An actor shall surrender to the landowner all articles and material discovered, collected, excavated, or offered for sale or exchange in violation of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1 Unlawful creation, labeling, or sale of reproduction of antiquities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-901 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(2): (2)(a) An actor commits unlawful reproduction, labeling, or sale of reproduction of antiquities if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(2)(a): with the intent to represent one or more objects as original and genuine antiquities, intentionally:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(2)(a)(i): reproduces, reworks, or forges antiquities; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(2)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(2)(a)(ii)(A): makes an object, whether as a copy or not; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(2)(a)(ii)(B): falsely labels, describes, identifies, or offers for sale or exchange an object; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(2)(b): (2)(a) counsels, procures, solicits, or employs another person to violate Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(3): (3)(b); (2); (2); 76-6-902; 76-6-902.2; (3)(c); (3)(b)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(3)(a): (3)(b); (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(3)(b): (2); 76-6-902; 76-6-902.2; (3)(c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(3)(b)(i): 76-6-902; 76-6-902.2 the violation is the actor's second or subsequent violation of this section, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(3)(b)(ii): (3)(c) the amount at issue, as calculated under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(3)(c): (3)(b)(ii) The amount described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(3)(c)(i): the commercial or archaeological value of the antiquities involved in the violation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(3)(c)(ii): the cost of the restoration and repair of the antiquities involved in the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.1(3)(d): An actor shall surrender to the landowner all articles and material discovered, collected, excavated, or offered for sale or exchange in violation of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.2 Unlawful sale or exchange of antiquities.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.2(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-901 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.2(2): 76-6-902; (2)(a) An actor commits unlawful sale or exchange of antiquities if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.2(2)(a): 76-6-902 offers for sale or exchange an object that was collected or excavated in violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.2(2)(b): (2)(a) counsels, procures, solicits, or employs another person to violate Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.2(3): (3)(b); (2); (2); 76-6-902; 76-6-902.1; (3)(c); (3)(b)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.2(3)(a): (3)(b); (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.2(3)(b): (2); 76-6-902; 76-6-902.1; (3)(c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.2(3)(b)(i): 76-6-902; 76-6-902.1 the violation is the actor's second or subsequent violation of this section, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.2(3)(b)(ii): (3)(c) the amount at issue, as calculated under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.2(3)(c): (3)(b)(ii) The amount described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.2(3)(c)(i): the commercial or archaeological value of the antiquities involved in the violation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.2(3)(c)(ii): the cost of the restoration and repair of the antiquities involved in the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-902.2(3)(d): An actor shall surrender to the landowner all articles and material discovered, collected, excavated, or offered for sale or exchange in violation of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1001 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1001(1): "Common mail carrier" means a person engaged in or transacting the business of collecting, transporting, or delivering mail, other than the United States Postal Service.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1001(2): "Key" means any instrument used by the postal service and postal customer, and which is designed to operate the lock on a mail receptacle.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1001(3): "Mail" means any letter, card, parcel, or other material, along with its contents, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1001(3)(a): has postage affixed by the postal customer or postal service;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1001(3)(b): has been accepted for delivery by the postal service;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1001(3)(c): the postal customer leaves for collection by the postal service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1001(3)(d): the postal service delivers to the postal customer.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1001(4): "Mail receptacle" means a mail box, post office box, rural box, or any place or area intended or used by postal customers or a postal service for the collection or delivery of mail.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1001(5): 76-6-1101 "Personal identifying information" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1001(6): "Postage" means a postal service stamp, permit imprint, meter strip, or other indication of either prepayment for postal service provided or authorization by the postal service for collection and delivery of mail.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1001(7): "Postal service" means the United States Postal Service or a private common mail carrier.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002 Damage to mail receptacle.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-1001 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(2): An actor commits damage to a mail receptacle if the actor knowingly damages the condition of a mail receptacle, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(2)(a): taking, concealing, damaging, or destroying a key; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(2)(b): breaking open, tearing down, taking, damaging, or destroying a mail receptacle.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(3): (2); (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(3)(a)(i): second degree felony if the actor's conduct causes or is intended to cause pecuniary loss equal to or in excess of $5,000 in value;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(3)(a)(ii): third degree felony if the actor's conduct causes or is intended to cause pecuniary loss equal to or in excess of $1,500 but is less than $5,000 in value;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(3)(a)(iii): class A misdemeanor if the actor's conduct causes or is intended to cause pecuniary loss equal to or in excess of $500 but is less than $1,500 in value; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(3)(a)(iv): class B misdemeanor if the actor's conduct causes or is intended to cause pecuniary loss less than $500 in value.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(3)(b): (3)(a) If the act committed amounts to an offense subject to a greater penalty, Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(4): (4)(b) The following presumptions and defenses shall be applicable to this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(4)(a): possession of property recently stolen, when no satisfactory explanation of such possession is made, is prima facie evidence that the actor in possession stole the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(4)(b): (4)(b) it is no defense under this part that the actor has an interest in the property or service stolen if another person also has an interest that the actor is not entitled to infringe, provided an interest in property for purposes of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(4)(c): it is a defense under this section that the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(4)(c)(i): acted under an honest claim of right to the property or service involved;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(4)(c)(ii): acted in the honest belief that the actor had the right to obtain or exercise control over the property or service as the actor did; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1002(4)(c)(iii): obtained or exercised control over the property or service honestly believing that the owner, if present, would have consented.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003 Mail theft.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-1001 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(2): An actor commits mail theft if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(2)(a): knowingly, and with the intent to deprive another:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(2)(a)(i): takes, destroys, hides, or embezzles mail; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(2)(a)(ii): obtains any mail by fraud or deception; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(2)(b): buys, receives, conceals, or possesses mail and knows or reasonably should have known that the mail was unlawfully taken or obtained.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(3)(a): a third degree felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(3)(b): a class A misdemeanor, if the mail has no monetary value and does not include the name of an individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(3)(c): a second degree felony, if the mail contains the personal identifying information of 10 or more individuals.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(4): (4)(b) The following presumptions and defenses shall be applicable to this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(4)(a): possession of property recently stolen, when no satisfactory explanation of such possession is made, is prima facie evidence that the actor in possession stole the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(4)(b): (4)(b) it is no defense under this section that the actor has an interest in the property or service stolen if another person also has an interest that the actor is not entitled to infringe, provided an interest in property for purposes of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(4)(c): it is a defense under this section that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(4)(c)(i): the actor acted under an honest claim of right to the property or service involved;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(4)(c)(ii): the actor acted in the honest belief that the actor had the right to obtain or exercise control over the property or service as the actor did;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(4)(c)(iii): the actor obtained or exercised control over the property or service honestly believing that the owner, if present, would have consented;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(4)(c)(iv): the actor was unaware that the mail belonged to another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(4)(c)(v): the actor reasonably believed the actor was entitled to the mail or had a right to acquire or dispose of the mail as the actor did; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1003(4)(c)(vi): the mail belonged to the actor's spouse, unless the parties were either legally separated or living in separate residences at the time of the alleged mail theft.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101(1): Title 46, Chapter 4, Uniform Electronic Transactions Act; 76-6-506; 76-6-506.2; 76-6-506.3; 76-6-506.6; 77-38b-102 As used in this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101(1)(a): Title 46, Chapter 4, Uniform Electronic Transactions Act; 76-6-506; 76-6-506.2; 76-6-506.3; 76-6-506.6 "Personal identifying information" may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101(1)(a)(i): name;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101(1)(a)(ii): birth date;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101(1)(a)(iii): address;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101(1)(a)(iv): telephone number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101(1)(a)(v): driver license number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101(1)(a)(vi): social security number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101(1)(a)(vii): place of employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101(1)(a)(viii): employee identification numbers or other personal identification numbers;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101(1)(a)(ix): mother's maiden name;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101(1)(a)(x): electronic identification numbers;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101(1)(a)(xi): Title 46, Chapter 4, Uniform Electronic Transactions Act electronic signatures under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101(1)(a)(xii): 76-6-506; 76-6-506.2; 76-6-506.3; 76-6-506.6 any other numbers or information that can be used to access a person's financial resources or medical information, except for numbers or information that can be prosecuted as financial transaction card offenses under Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101(1)(a)(xiii): a photograph or any other realistic likeness.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1101(1)(b): 77-38b-102 "Restitution" means the same as that term is defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102 Identity fraud.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-1101 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(2): An actor commits identity fraud if the actor knowingly or intentionally uses, or attempts to use, the personal identifying information of another person, whether that person is alive or deceased, with fraudulent intent, including to obtain, or attempt to obtain, credit, goods, services, employment, any other thing of value, or medical information.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(3): (2); (3)(b)(ii); (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(3)(a): (3)(b)(ii) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(3)(b): (2) a second degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(3)(b)(i): the value of the credit, goods, services, employment, or any other thing of value is or exceeds $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(3)(b)(ii): (2) the use described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(4): (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(4)(a): (2) It is not a defense to a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(4)(b): (2) Multiple violations of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(5): Title 77, Chapter 38b, Crime Victims Restitution Act; (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(5)(a): Title 77, Chapter 38b, Crime Victims Restitution Act If a defendant is convicted of a violation of this section, the court shall order the defendant to pay restitution in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(5)(b): (5)(a) Restitution under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(5)(b)(i): payment for any costs incurred, including attorney fees, lost wages, and replacement of checks; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(5)(b)(ii): the value of the victim's time incurred due to the offense:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(5)(b)(ii)(A): in clearing the victim's credit history or credit rating;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(5)(b)(ii)(B): in any civil or administrative proceedings necessary to satisfy or resolve any debt, lien, or other obligation of the victim or imputed to the victim and arising from the offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1102(5)(b)(ii)(C): in attempting to remedy any other intended or actual harm to the victim incurred as a result of the offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1103 Investigation of violation.
-----------------------------------------------------------
In addition to investigations conducted by law enforcement agencies, the Office of the Attorney General also has responsibility for investigating violations of this part where identity fraud is the primary violation that is alleged to have been committed.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1104 Court records.
----------------------------------------------
In any case in which a person commits identify fraud and uses the personal identifying information obtained to commit a crime in addition to the identity fraud, the court shall make appropriate findings in any prosecution of such a crime that the person whose identity was falsely used to commit the crime did not commit the crime.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105 Unlawful possession of another's identification documents.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(1): 76-6-1101(1)(a); 76-1-101.5; 76-6-1101
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(1)(a): 76-6-1101(1)(a) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(1)(a)(i): 76-6-1101(1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(1)(a)(i)(A): 76-6-1101(1)(a) "Identifying document" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(1)(a)(i)(A)(I): a government issued document commonly used for identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(1)(a)(i)(A)(II): a vehicle registration certificate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(1)(a)(i)(A)(III): 76-6-1101(1)(a) any other document, image, data file, or medium containing personal identifying information as defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(1)(a)(i)(B): "Identifying document" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(1)(a)(i)(B)(I): a counterfeit identifying document; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(1)(a)(i)(B)(II): a document containing personal identifying information of a deceased individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(1)(a)(ii): "Possess" means to have physical control or electronic access.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-1101 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2): 76-6-502; 76-6-1102; 76-6-502; 76-6-1102; 76-6-502; 76-6-1102
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(a): 76-6-502; 76-6-1102 Under circumstances that do not constitute a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(a)(i): obtains or possesses an identifying document:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(a)(i)(A): with knowledge that the actor is not entitled to obtain or possess the identifying document; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(a)(i)(B): with intent to deceive or defraud; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(a)(ii): assists another person in obtaining or possessing an identifying document:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(a)(ii)(A): with knowledge that the person is not entitled to obtain or possess the identifying document; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(a)(ii)(B): with knowledge that the person intends to use the identifying document to deceive or defraud.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(b): 76-6-502; 76-6-1102 Under circumstances that do not constitute a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(b)(i): obtains or possesses identifying documents of more than two, but fewer than 100, individuals:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(b)(i)(A): with knowledge that the individual is not entitled to obtain or possess the identifying documents; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(b)(i)(B): with intent to deceive or defraud; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(b)(ii): assists another person in obtaining or possessing identifying documents of more than two, but fewer than 100, individuals:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(b)(ii)(A): with knowledge that the person is not entitled to obtain or possess the multiple identifying documents; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(b)(ii)(B): with knowledge that the person intends to use the identifying documents to deceive or defraud.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(c): 76-6-502; 76-6-1102 Under circumstances that do not constitute a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(c)(i): obtains or possesses identifying documents of 100 or more individuals:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(c)(i)(A): with knowledge that the individual is not entitled to obtain or possess the identifying documents; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(c)(i)(B): with intent to deceive or defraud; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(c)(ii): assists another person in obtaining or possessing identifying documents of 100 or more individuals:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(c)(ii)(A): with knowledge that the person is not entitled to obtain or possess the identifying documents; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(2)(c)(ii)(B): with knowledge that the person intends to use the identifying documents to deceive or defraud.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(3): (2)(a); (2)(b); (2)(c) A violation of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(3)(a): (2)(a) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1105(3)(b): (2)(b) Subsection
