Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1202 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1202(1): "Mortgage lending process" means the process through which a person seeks or obtains a mortgage loan, including solicitation, application, or origination, negotiation of terms, third-party provider services, underwriting, signing and closing, and funding of the loan.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1202(2): "Mortgage loan":
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1202(2)(a): means a loan or agreement made to extend credit to a person when the loan is secured by a deed, security deed, mortgage, security interest, deed of trust, or other document representing a security interest or lien upon any interest in one-to-four family residential property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1202(2)(b): includes the renewal or refinancing of any loan.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1202(3): 76-10-1602 "Pattern of unlawful activity" has the same definition as in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1202(4): "Sensitive personal identifying information" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1202(4)(a): the following information regarding an individual's:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1202(4)(a)(i): Social Security number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1202(4)(a)(ii): driver license number or other government issued identification number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1202(4)(a)(iii): financial account number or credit or debit card number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1202(4)(a)(iv): password or personal identification number or other identification required to gain access to a financial account or a secure website;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1202(4)(a)(v): automated or electronic signature; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1202(4)(a)(vi): unique biometric data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1202(4)(b): any other information that can be used to gain access to an individual's financial accounts or to obtain goods or services.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1202(5): "Value" means the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1203 Mortgage fraud.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1203(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-1202 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1203(2): An actor commits mortgage fraud if the actor does any of the following with the intent to defraud:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1203(2)(a): knowingly makes any material misstatement, misrepresentation, or omission during the mortgage lending process, intending that it be relied upon by a mortgage lender, borrower, or any other party to the mortgage lending process;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1203(2)(b): knowingly uses or facilitates the use of any material misstatement, misrepresentation, or omission, during the mortgage lending process, intending that it be relied upon by a mortgage lender, borrower, or any other party to the mortgage lending process;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1203(2)(c): files or causes to be filed with any county recorder in Utah any document that the actor knows contains a material misstatement, misrepresentation, or omission; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1203(2)(d): receives any proceeds or any compensation in connection with a mortgage loan that the actor knows resulted from a violation of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1203(3): (2); (3)(a); (2); (3)(a)(iv)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1203(3)(a): (2) Notwithstanding any other administrative, civil, or criminal penalties, a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1203(3)(a)(i): class A misdemeanor if the value is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1203(3)(a)(ii): third degree felony if the value is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1203(3)(a)(iii): second degree felony if the value is or exceeds $5,000; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1203(3)(a)(iv): second degree felony if the object or purpose of the commission of an act of mortgage fraud is the obtaining of sensitive personal identifying information, regardless of the value.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1203(3)(b): (3)(a); (2); (3)(a)(iv) The determination of the degree of any offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1203(4): Each residential or commercial property transaction offense under this section constitutes a separate violation.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1302 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1302(1): "Automated sales suppression device" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1302(1)(a): a software program that falsifies the electronic records of electronic cash registers or any other point-of-sale systems, including transaction data and transaction reports; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1302(1)(b): a general reference to a device that allows for, creates, or supports an automated sales suppression system or any kind of phantomware.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1302(2): "Electronic cash register" means any device, wherever located, that maintains a transaction register or supporting documents by means of an electronic device or computer system designed to record transaction data for the purpose of computing, compiling, or processing retail, wholesale, or any other sales transaction data.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1302(3): "Person" means an individual, business, or entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1302(4): "Phantomware" means a programming option that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1302(4)(a): is pre-installed, installed at a later time, or otherwise embedded in the operating system of an electronic cash register or hardwired into the electronic cash register; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1302(4)(b): can be used to create a virtual alternate register or to eliminate or manipulate transaction records that may or may not be preserved in digital formats in order to represent a manipulated record or records of transactions in the electronic cash register.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1302(5): "Transaction data" includes items purchased by a customer, the price for each item, a taxability determination for each item, a segregated tax amount for each of the taxed items, the amount of cash or credit tendered, the net amount returned to the customer in change or in a refund, the date and time of the purchase, the name, address, and identification number of the vendor, and the receipt or invoice number of the transaction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1302(6): "Transaction report" means a report that includes the sales, taxes collected, media totals, and discount voids at an electronic cash register and that is generated at the end of a day or shift.  The report is printed on cash register tape or is stored electronically.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1303 Possession, sale, or use of automated sales suppression device unlawful.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1303(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-1302 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1303(2): An actor commits possession, sale, or use of an automated sales suppression device if the actor willfully or knowingly sells, purchases, installs, transfers, uses, or possesses in this state any automated sales suppression device or phantomware with the intent to defraud.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1303(3): (3)(b); (2); (2); 76-3-301; (2); (2); 59-1-401; 59-1-402
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1303(3)(a): (3)(b); (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1303(3)(b): (2) A second or subsequent violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1303(3)(c): 76-3-301; (2) Notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1303(3)(d): (2); 59-1-401; 59-1-402 Any person convicted of a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1303(3)(d)(i): 59-1-401; 59-1-402 is liable for all applicable taxes, penalties under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1303(3)(d)(ii): shall disgorge all profits associated with the sale or use of an automated sales suppression device or phantomware.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1303(4): Title 77, Chapter 11b, Forfeiture of Seized Property An automated sales suppression device and any device containing an automated sales suppression device is contraband and subject to forfeiture under


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(1): "Catalytic converter" means a motor vehicle exhaust system component that reduces vehicle emissions by breaking down harmful exhaust emissions.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(2): 76-6-1402; 19-6-502; 19-6-603; 19-6-604; 19-6-605 "Dealer" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(2)(a): 76-6-1402; 19-6-502; 19-6-603; 19-6-604; 19-6-605 a scrap metal processor or secondary metals dealer or recycler, but does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(2)(a)(i): 76-6-1402 junk dealers as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(2)(a)(ii): 19-6-502 solid waste management facilities as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(2)(a)(iii): 19-6-603; 19-6-604; 19-6-605 the following businesses that are authorized to accept delivery of used lead batteries for recycling under Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(2)(a)(iii)(A): retailers;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(2)(a)(iii)(B): wholesalers;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(2)(a)(iii)(C): battery manufacturers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(2)(a)(iii)(D): secondary lead smelters.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(2)(b): a metals refiner.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(3): "Ferrous metal" means a metal that contains significant quantities of iron or steel.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(4): "Identification" means a form of positive identification issued by a state of the United States or the United States federal government that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(4)(a): contains a numerical identifier and a photograph of the person identified;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(4)(b): provides the date of birth of the person identified; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(4)(c): includes a state identification card, a state driver license, a United States military identification card, or a United States passport.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(5): "Junk dealer" means all persons, firms, or corporations engaged in the business of purchasing or selling secondhand or castoff material, including ropes, cordage, bottles, bagging, rags, rubber, paper, and other like materials, but not including regulated metal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(6): "Local law enforcement agency" means the law enforcement agency that has jurisdiction over the area where the dealer's business is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(7): "Metals refiner" means an individual or business that refines or melts any regulated metal, but does not include an individual or business that primarily uses ore, concentrate, or other primary materials in refining, melting, or producing any regulated metal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(8): "Nonferrous metal":
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(8)(a): means a metal that does not contain significant quantities of iron or steel; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(8)(b): includes copper, brass, aluminum, bronze, lead, zinc, nickel, and their alloys.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9): (9)(c); (9)(c); (9)(b)(ii); (iv)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(a): (9)(c) "Regulated metal" means any item composed primarily of nonferrous metal, except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(b): (9)(c) "Regulated metal" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(b)(i): (9)(c) aluminum, brass, copper, lead, chromium, tin, nickel, or alloys of these metals, except under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(b)(ii): property that is a regulated metal and that is owned by, and also identified by marking or other means as the property of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(b)(ii)(A): a telephone, cable, electric, water, or other utility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(b)(ii)(B): a railroad company;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(b)(iii): unused and undamaged building construction materials made of metal or alloy, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(b)(iii)(A): copper pipe, tubing, or wiring; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(b)(iii)(B): aluminum wire, siding, downspouts, or gutters;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(b)(iv): oil well rigs, including any part of the rig;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(b)(v): nonferrous materials, stainless steel, and nickel; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(b)(vi): irrigation pipe.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(c): (9)(b)(ii); (iv) "Regulated metal" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(c)(i): (9)(b)(ii); (iv) ferrous metal, except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(c)(ii): household-generated recyclable materials;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(c)(iii): items composed wholly of light iron or sheet steel;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(c)(iv): aluminum beverage containers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(9)(c)(v): containers used solely for containing food.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(10): "Scrap metal processor" means any person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(10)(a): who, from a fixed location, utilizes machinery and equipment for processing and manufacturing iron, steel, or nonferrous scrap into prepared grades; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(10)(b): whose principal product is scrap iron, scrap steel, or nonferrous metallic scrap, not including precious metals, for sale for remelting purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(11): "Secondary metals dealer or recycler" means any person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(11)(a): is engaged in the business of purchasing, collecting, or soliciting regulated metal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(11)(b): operates or maintains a facility where regulated metal is purchased or kept for shipment, sale, transfer, or salvage.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12): "Suspect metal items" are the following items made of regulated metal:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12)(a): manhole covers and sewer grates;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12)(b): gas meters and water meters;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12)(c): traffic signs, street signs, aluminum street light poles, communications transmission towers, and guard rails;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12)(d): grave site monument vases and monument plaques;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12)(e): any monument plaque;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12)(f): brass or bronze bar stock and bar ends;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12)(g): ingots;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12)(h): nickel and nickel alloys containing greater than 50% nickel;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12)(i): #1 and #2 copper as defined by the most recent institute of Scrap Recycling Industries, Inc., Scrap Specifications Circular;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12)(j): unused and undamaged building materials, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12)(j)(i): greenline copper;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12)(j)(ii): copper pipe, tubing, or wiring; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12)(j)(iii): aluminum wire, siding, downspouts, or gutters;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12)(k): catalytic converters;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12)(l): automotive and industrial lead batteries;  and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1402(12)(m): wire that has been burned or that has the appearance of having been burned.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403 Requirements for records of sale or purchases.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(1): (2); 76-6-1406(4) Every dealer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(1)(a): (2); 76-6-1406(4) require the information under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(1)(b): maintain for each purchase of regulated metal the information required by this part in a written or electronic log, in the English language.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(2): (1); (2)(g) The dealer shall require the following information of the seller and shall record the information as required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(2)(a): a complete description of the regulated metal, including weight and metallic description, in accordance with scrap metal recycling industry standards;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(2)(b): the full name and residence of each person selling the regulated metal;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(2)(c): the vehicle type and license plate number, if applicable, of the vehicle transporting the regulated metal to the dealer;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(2)(d): the price per pound and the amount paid for each type of regulated metal purchased by the dealer;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(2)(e): the date, time, and place of the purchase;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(2)(f): (2)(g) the type and the identifying number of the identification provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(2)(g): a form of identification that is a valid United States federal or state-issued photo ID, which includes a driver license, a United States passport, a United States passport card, or a United States military identification card;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(2)(h): the seller's signature on a certificate stating that the seller has the legal right to sell the scrap metal or junk; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(2)(i): a digital photograph or still video of the seller, taken at the time of the sale, or a clearly legible photocopy of the seller's identification.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(3): No entry in the log may be erased, deleted, mutilated, or changed.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(4): The log and entries shall be open to inspection by the following officials having jurisdiction over the area in which the dealer does business during regular business hours:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(4)(a): the county sheriff or deputies;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(4)(b): any law enforcement agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(4)(c): any constable or other state, municipal, or county official in the county in which the dealer does business.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(5): A dealer shall make these records available for inspection by any law enforcement agency, upon request, at the dealer's place of business during the dealer's regular business hours.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(6): Log entries made under this section shall be maintained for not less than three years from date of entry.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(7): (2); (7)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(7)(a): (2); (7)(b) The dealer may maintain the information required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(7)(b): The dealer shall obtain regarding each transaction with repeat sellers:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(7)(b)(i): a photograph of the seller; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(7)(b)(ii): a signature from the seller.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403(8): 76-6-1403.1 A dealer who violates this section is subject to the penalties described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403.1(3)(a)(ii): A dealer who is convicted of a class C misdemeanor under this section is subject to a mandatory fine of no less than $750.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403.1(4)(b): 76-6-1403 This section does not impair the authority of a county or municipality to revoke or deny a business license or permit required by that county or municipality regulating the authority to sell, purchase, or possess metal, including the revocation or denial of a business license or permit based on a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1403.1(4)(c): This section does not prohibit the charging of a seller or dealer with any other criminal offense related to the obtaining, possession, or selling of stolen regulated metals.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1404 Required notice to sellers of identification requirements.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1404(1): A dealer shall at all times maintain in a prominent place at the dealer's place of business, in open view to a seller of regulated metal, a clearly legible notice in not less than two-inch high lettering that contains the following language: "A PERSON ATTEMPTING TO SELL ANY REGULATED METAL MUST PROVIDE IDENTIFICATION AS REQUIRED BY STATE LAW."
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1404(2): 76-6-1404.1 A dealer who violates this section is subject to the penalties described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406 Restrictions on the purchase of regulated metal -- Exemption.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(1): A dealer may conduct purchase transactions involving regulated metal only between the hours of 6 a.m. and 7 p.m.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(2): Except when the dealer pays a government entity by check for regulated metal, the dealer may not purchase any of the following regulated metal without obtaining and keeping on file reasonable documentation that the seller is an employee, agent, or contractor of a governmental entity who is authorized to sell the item of regulated metal property on behalf of the governmental entity:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(2)(a): a manhole cover or sewer grate;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(2)(b): an electric light pole; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(2)(c): a guard rail.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(3): (3)(b); (3)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(3)(a): (3)(b) A dealer may not purchase suspect metal without obtaining the information under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(3)(b): The owner of the suspect metal shall provide in writing:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(3)(b)(i): the owner's telephone number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(3)(b)(ii): the owner's business or residential address, which may not be a post box;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(3)(b)(iii): a copy of the owner's driver license; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(3)(b)(iv): a signed statement that the person is the lawful owner of the suspect metal and authorizes the seller, identified by name, to sell the suspect metal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(3)(c): (3)(b) The dealer shall keep the identifying information provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(4): (2); (3) Transactions with businesses that have an established account with the dealer are exempt from the requirements of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(4)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(4)(a)(i): the dealer has on file a statement from the business identifying those employees authorized to sell all metals to the dealer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(4)(a)(ii): the dealer conducts regulated metal transactions only with those identified employees of the business and records the name of the employee when recording the transaction;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(4)(b): the dealer has on file reasonable documentation from the business that any person verified as representing the business as an employee, and whom the dealer has verified is an employee, may sell regulated metal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(4)(c): the dealer makes payment for regulated metal purchased from a person by issuing a check to the business employing the seller.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(5): 13-32a-102; Title 13, Chapter 32a, Pawnshop, Secondhand Merchandise, and Catalytic Converter Transaction Information Act If a dealer is a catalytic converter purchaser as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406(6): 76-6-1406.1 A dealer who violates this section is subject to the penalties described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1406.1(3)(a)(ii): A dealer who is convicted of a class C misdemeanor under this section is subject to a mandatory fine of no less than $750.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1408(2)(b): 76-6-1403; 76-6-1405; 76-6-1406 in providing information required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1408(3): (3)(b); (2); (2)

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1408(3)(b)(i): (2) A violation of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409 Hold on stolen regulated metal property -- Hold notice.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409(1): (1)(a); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409(1)(a): If a law enforcement agency has reasonable cause to believe that items of regulated metal in the possession of a dealer are stolen, the law enforcement agency may issue a written hold notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409(1)(b): (1)(a); (2) The hold notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409(1)(b)(i): identify those items of regulated metal alleged to be stolen and subject to hold; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409(1)(b)(ii): (2) inform the dealer of the restrictions imposed on the regulated metal property under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409(2): For 60 days after the date of receiving a hold notice, a dealer may not process or remove from the dealer's place of business any regulated metal identified in the hold notice, unless the property is released earlier by the law enforcement agency or by order of a court of competent jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409(3): On the expiration of the hold notice period, the hold is automatically released, and the dealer may dispose of the regulated metal, unless otherwise directed by a court of competent jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409(4): 76-6-1409.1 A dealer who violates this section is subject to the penalties described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409.1 Unlawful violation of regulated metal hold requirement.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409.1(1): 76-1-101.5; 76-6-1402 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409.1(2): 76-6-1409 A dealer commits unlawful violation of regulated metal hold requirement if the dealer violates a requirement under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409.1(3): (3)(b); (2); (2); 76-6-1403.1; 76-6-1404.1; 76-6-1405.1; 76-6-1406.1
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409.1(3)(a): (3)(b); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409.1(3)(a)(i): (3)(b); (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409.1(3)(a)(ii): A dealer who is convicted of a class C misdemeanor under this section is subject to a mandatory fine of no less than $750.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409.1(3)(b): (2); 76-6-1403.1; 76-6-1404.1; 76-6-1405.1; 76-6-1406.1
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409.1(3)(b)(i): (2); 76-6-1403.1; 76-6-1404.1; 76-6-1405.1; 76-6-1406.1 A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409.1(3)(b)(ii): A dealer who is convicted of a class A misdemeanor under this section is subject to a mandatory fine of no less than $2,500.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409.1(4): 76-6-1409; 76-6-1409
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409.1(4)(a): 76-6-1409 This section does not impair the authority of a county or municipality in this state to license, tax, and regulate any junk dealer or metal dealer, except that local regulations may not be any less stringent than the provisions in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409.1(4)(b): 76-6-1409 This section does not impair the authority of a county or municipality to revoke or deny a business license or permit required by that county or municipality regulating the authority to sell, purchase, or possess metal, including the revocation or denial of a business license or permit based on a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6-1409.1(4)(c): This section does not prohibit the charging of a seller or dealer with any other criminal offense related to the obtaining, possession, or selling of stolen regulated metals.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 76 - Chapter 6a - Pyramid Scheme Act
****************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-101(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-101(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-101(1)(a)(i): "Compensation" means money, money bonuses, overrides, prizes, or other real or personal property, tangible or intangible.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-101(1)(a)(ii): "Compensation" does not include payment based on the sale of goods or services to anyone purchasing the goods or services for actual personal use or consumption.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-101(1)(b): "Consideration" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-101(1)(b)(i): payment for sales demonstration equipment or materials furnished at cost for use in making sales and not for resale; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-101(1)(b)(ii): time or effort spent in selling or recruiting activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-101(1)(c): "Person" includes a business trust, estate, trust, joint venture, or any other legal or commercial entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-101(1)(d): "Pyramid scheme" means any sales device or plan under which a person gives consideration to another person in exchange for compensation or the right to receive compensation that is derived primarily from the introduction of other persons into the sales device or plan rather than from the sale of goods, services, or other property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-101(2): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-102 Conducting pyramid scheme -- Violation as deceptive consumer sales practice -- Prosecution of civil violation.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-102(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-102(2): An actor commits the offense of conducting a pyramid scheme if the actor knowingly organizes, establishes, promotes, or administers a pyramid scheme.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-102(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-102(4): It is not a defense to an action brought under this section that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-102(4)(a): the sales device or plan limits the number of persons who may be introduced into the sales device or plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-102(4)(b): the sales device or plan includes additional conditions affecting eligibility for introduction into the sales device or plan or when compensation may be received from the sales device or plan; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-102(4)(c): a person receives property or services in addition to the compensation or right to receive compensation in connection with a pyramid scheme.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-102(5): The appropriate county attorney or district attorney has primary responsibility for investigating and prosecuting a criminal violation of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-102(6): 13-11-4; 13-11-4; Title 13, Chapter 11, Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-102(6)(a): 13-11-4 A violation under this section constitutes a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-102(6)(b): 13-11-4 A criminal conviction under this section is prima facie evidence of a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-102(6)(c): Title 13, Chapter 11, Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act In addition to prosecution under this section, a violation of this section shall be civilly investigated and prosecuted as prescribed by


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-103 Participating in pyramid scheme -- Violation as deceptive consumer sales practice -- Prosecution of civil violation.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-103(1): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-103(2): An actor commits the offense of participating in a pyramid scheme if the actor participates in a pyramid scheme only by receiving compensation for the introduction of another person into the pyramid scheme rather than from the sale of goods, services, or other property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-103(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-103(4): It is not a defense to an action brought under this section that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-103(4)(a): the sales device or plan limits the number of persons who may be introduced into the sales device or plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-103(4)(b): the sales device or plan includes additional conditions affecting eligibility for introduction into the sales device or plan or when compensation may be received from the sales device or plan; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-103(4)(c): a person receives property or services in addition to the compensation or right to receive compensation in connection with a pyramid scheme.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-103(5): The appropriate county attorney or district attorney has primary responsibility for investigating and prosecuting a criminal violation of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-103(6): 13-11-4; 13-11-4; Title 13, Chapter 11, Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-103(6)(a): 13-11-4 A violation under this section constitutes a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-103(6)(b): 13-11-4 A criminal conviction under this section is prima facie evidence of a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-103(6)(c): Title 13, Chapter 11, Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act In addition to prosecution under this section, a violation of this section shall be civilly investigated and prosecuted as prescribed by


Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-104 Rights of person giving consideration in pyramid scheme.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-104(1): (1)(a); 15-1-4
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-104(1)(a): Any person giving consideration in connection with a pyramid scheme may, notwithstanding any agreement to the contrary, declare the person's giving of consideration and the related sale or contract for sale void, and may bring a court action to recover the consideration.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-104(1)(b): (1)(a); 15-1-4 In an action brought under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-104(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-104(2)(a): The rights, remedies, and penalties provided in this chapter are independent of and supplemental to each other and to any other right, remedy or penalty available in law or equity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-6a-104(2)(b): Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed to diminish or abrogate any other right, remedy or penalty.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-101 Bigamy -- Penalty -- Defense.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-101(1): (1)(a) An individual is guilty of bigamy if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-101(1)(a): the individual purports to marry another individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-101(1)(b): (1)(a) knows or reasonably should know that one or both of the individuals described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-101(2): (1) An individual who violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-101(3): An individual is guilty of a third degree felony if the individual induces bigamy:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-101(3)(a): under fraudulent or false pretenses; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-101(3)(b): by threat or coercion.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-101(4): (1); (4)(a); (4)(b); 76-5-109; 76-5-109.2; 76-5-109.3; 76-5-111; 76-5-111.2; 76-5-111.3; 76-5-111.4; Chapter 5, Part 2, Criminal Homicide; 76-5-208; Chapter 5, Part 3, Kidnapping, Trafficking, and Smuggling; Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; 76-7-201; 76-9-702.1; Title 77, Chapter 36, Cohabitant Abuse Procedures Act; Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 8, Criminal Protective Orders An individual is guilty of a second degree felony if the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-101(4)(a): (1) cohabitates with another individual with whom the individual is engaged in bigamy as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-101(4)(b): (4)(a); (4)(b); 76-5-109; 76-5-109.2; 76-5-109.3; 76-5-111; 76-5-111.2; 76-5-111.3; 76-5-111.4; Chapter 5, Part 2, Criminal Homicide; 76-5-208; Chapter 5, Part 3, Kidnapping, Trafficking, and Smuggling; Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; 76-7-201; 76-9-702.1; Title 77, Chapter 36, Cohabitant Abuse Procedures Act; Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 8, Criminal Protective Orders in furtherance of the conduct described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-101.5 Child bigamy -- Penalty.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-101.5(1): An actor 18 years of age or older is guilty of child bigamy when, knowing he or she has a wife or husband, or knowing that a person under 18 years of age has a wife or husband, the actor carries out the following with the person who is under 18 years of age:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-101.5(1)(a): purports to marry the person who is under 18 years of age; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-101.5(1)(b): cohabitates with the person who is under 18 years of age.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-101.5(2): (1) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102 Incest -- Definitions -- Penalty.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(1)(a): "Provider" means a person who provides or makes available his seminal fluid or her human egg.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(1)(b): "Related person" means a person related to the provider or actor as an ancestor, descendant, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, nephew, niece, or first cousin, and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(1)(b)(i): blood relationships of the whole or half blood, regardless of whether the relationship is legally recognized;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(1)(b)(ii): the relationship of parent and child by adoption; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(1)(b)(iii): the relationship of stepparent and stepchild while the marriage creating the relationship of a stepparent and stepchild exists.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(2): (2)(b)(i); (ii); (iii); (iv); (2)(b)(v); (2)(a); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(2)(a): (2)(b)(i); (ii); (iii); (iv); (2)(b)(v) An actor is guilty of incest when, under circumstances not amounting to rape, rape of a child, or aggravated sexual assault, the actor knowingly and intentionally:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(2)(a)(i): (2)(b)(i); (ii); (iii); (iv) engages in conduct under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(2)(a)(ii): (2)(b)(v) provides a human egg or seminal fluid under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(2)(b): (2)(a) Conduct referred to under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(2)(b)(i): sexual intercourse between the actor and a person the actor knows has kinship to the actor as a related person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(2)(b)(ii): the insertion or placement of the provider's seminal fluid into the vagina, cervix, or uterus of a related person by means other than sexual intercourse;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(2)(b)(iii): providing or making available his seminal fluid for the purpose of insertion or placement of the fluid into the vagina, cervix, or uterus of a related person by means other than sexual intercourse;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(2)(b)(iv): a woman 18 years of age or older who:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(2)(b)(iv)(A): knowingly allows the insertion of the seminal fluid of a provider into her vagina, cervix, or uterus by means other than sexual intercourse; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(2)(b)(iv)(B): knows that the seminal fluid is that of a person with whom she has kinship as a related person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(2)(b)(v): providing the actor's sperm or human egg that is used to conduct in vitro fertilization, or any other means of fertilization, with the human egg or sperm of a person who is a related person.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(2)(c): (2) This Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(3): Incest is a third degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-102(4): 78B-15-702 A provider under this section is not a donor under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-201 Criminal nonsupport.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-201(1): A person commits criminal nonsupport if, having a spouse, a child, or children under the age of 18 years, the person knowingly fails to provide for the support of a spouse, child, or children when any one of them:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-201(1)(a): is in needy circumstances; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-201(1)(b): would be in needy circumstances but for support received from a source other than the defendant or paid on the defendant's behalf.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-201(2): (3) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-201(3): Criminal nonsupport is a felony of the third degree if the defendant:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-201(3)(a): has been convicted one or more times of nonsupport, whether in this state, any other state, or any court of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-201(3)(b): committed the offense while residing outside of Utah; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-201(3)(c): commits the crime of nonsupport in each of 18 individual months within any 24-month period, or the total arrearage is in excess of $10,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-201(4): For purposes of this section "child" includes a child born out of wedlock whose paternity has been admitted by the defendant or has been established in a civil suit.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-201(5): (5)(b); (5)(b); (5)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-201(5)(a): In a prosecution for criminal nonsupport under this section, it is an affirmative defense that the defendant is unable to provide support.  Voluntary unemployment or underemployment by the defendant does not give rise to that defense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-201(5)(b): Not less than 20 days before trial the defendant shall file and serve on the prosecuting attorney a notice, in writing, of the defendant's intention to claim the affirmative defense of inability to provide support.  The notice shall specifically identify the factual basis for the defense and the names and addresses of the witnesses who the defendant proposes to examine in order to establish the defense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-201(5)(c): (5)(b) Not more than 10 days after receipt of the notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-201(5)(d): (5)(b); (5)(c) Failure to comply with the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-201(6): Criminal nonsupport is a continuing offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-202 Orders for support in criminal nonsupport proceedings.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-202(1): 76-7-201; 76-7-201 In any proceeding under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-202(2): (3) The order to periodically pay a sum for the support of the dependents:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-202(2)(a): may be issued with the consent of the defendant prior to trial, or after conviction, having regard to the circumstances, financial ability, and earning capacity of the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-202(2)(b): shall be subject to change from time to time as circumstances may require;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-202(2)(c): may not require payments for a period exceeding the term of probation provided for the offense with which the defendant is charged, or of which he is found guilty; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-202(2)(d): (3) shall be conditioned upon the defendant either entering a recognizance in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-202(3): The condition of recognizance shall require the defendant to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-202(3)(a): make personal appearance in court whenever ordered to do so within the period of probation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-202(3)(b): comply with the terms of the order and any subsequent modifications of the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-202(4): 76-7-201 If the court is satisfied by information and due proof under oath that at any time during the period of probation the defendant has violated the terms of the order, it may proceed with the trial of defendant under the original charge or sentence him under the original conviction or enforce the original sentence as the case may be.  In the case of forfeiture of bail or bond in any proceeding under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203 Sale of child -- Felony -- Payment of adoption related expenses.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1): (1)(a)(iii)(A); (B); (1)(b)(i) For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a): (1)(a)(iii)(A); (B) "Adoption related expenses" means expenses that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(i): are reasonably related to the adoption of a child;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(ii): are incurred for a reasonable amount; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(iii): (1)(a)(iii)(A); (B) may include expenses:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(iii)(A): of the mother or father of the child being adopted, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(iii)(A)(I): legal expenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(iii)(A)(II): maternity expenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(iii)(A)(III): medical expenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(iii)(A)(IV): hospital expenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(iii)(A)(V): counseling expenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(iii)(A)(VI): temporary living expenses and lost wages during the pregnancy of the mother for up to eight weeks after the day on which the mother delivers the child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(iii)(A)(VII): expenses for travel between the mother's or father's home and the location where the child will be born or placed for adoption;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(iii)(B): of a directly affected person for:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(iii)(B)(I): travel between the directly affected person's home and the location where the child will be born or placed for adoption; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(iii)(B)(II): temporary living expenses during the pregnancy or confinement of the mother; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(iii)(C): (1)(a)(iii)(A); (B) other than those included in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(iii)(C)(I): place the child for adoption;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(iii)(C)(II): consent to an adoption; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(a)(iii)(C)(III): cooperate in the completion of an adoption.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(b): (1)(b)(i) "Directly affected person" means a person who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(b)(i): a parent or guardian of a minor when the minor is the mother or father of the child being adopted;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(b)(ii): (1)(b)(i) a dependent of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(b)(ii)(A): the mother or father of the child being adopted; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(b)(ii)(B): (1)(b)(i) the parent or guardian described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(1)(b)(iii): the spouse or partner of the mother or father of the child being adopted.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(2): (3); (2)(a) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(2)(a): while having custody, care, control, or possession of a child, sells, or disposes of the child, or attempts or offers to sell or dispose of the child, for and in consideration of the payment of money or another thing of value; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(2)(b): (2)(a) offers, gives, or attempts to give money or another thing of value to a person, with the intent to induce or encourage a person to violate Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(3): A person does not violate this section by paying or receiving payment for adoption related expenses, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(3)(a): the expenses are paid as an act of charity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(3)(b): the payment is not made for the purpose of inducing the mother, parent, or legal guardian of a child to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(3)(b)(i): place the child for adoption;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(3)(b)(ii): consent to an adoption; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-203(3)(b)(iii): cooperate in the completion of an adoption.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(1)(a): "Abortion" means the act, by a physician, of using an instrument, or prescribing a drug, with the intent to cause the death of an unborn child of a woman known to be pregnant, except as permitted under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(1)(b): "Abortion" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(1)(b)(i): removal of a dead unborn child;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(1)(b)(ii): removal of an ectopic pregnancy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(1)(b)(iii): the killing or attempted killing of an unborn child without the consent of the pregnant woman, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(1)(b)(iii)(A): the killing or attempted killing is done through a medical procedure carried out by a physician or through a substance used under the direction of a physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(1)(b)(iii)(B): the physician is unable to obtain the consent due to a medical emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(2): 80-1-102 "Abuse" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(3): "Department" means the Department of Health and Human Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(4): "Down syndrome" means a genetic condition associated with an extra chromosome 21, in whole or in part, or an effective trisomy for chromosome 21.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(5): "Gestational age" means the age of an unborn child as calculated from the first day of the last menstrual period of the pregnant woman.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(6): Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection "Hospital" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(6)(a): Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection a general hospital licensed by the department according to
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(6)(b): a clinic or other medical facility that meets the following criteria:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(6)(b)(i): a clinician who performs procedures at the clinic is required to be credentialed to perform the same procedures at a general hospital licensed by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(6)(b)(ii): any procedures performed at the clinic are done with the same level of safety for the pregnant woman and unborn child as would be available in a general hospital licensed by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(7): "Information module" means the pregnancy termination information module prepared by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(8): "Medical emergency" means a life threatening physical condition aggravated by, caused by, or arising from a pregnancy that places the pregnant woman at risk of death, or poses a serious risk of substantial impairment of a major bodily function, unless the abortion is performed or induced.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(9): "Minor" means an individual who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(9)(a): under 18 years old;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(9)(b): unmarried; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(9)(c): not emancipated.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(10)(a): "Partial birth abortion" means an abortion in which the person performing the abortion:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(10)(a)(i): deliberately and intentionally vaginally delivers a living fetus until, in the case of a head first presentation, the entire fetal head is outside the body of the mother, or, in the case of breech presentation, any part of the fetal trunk past the navel is outside the body of the mother, for the purpose of performing an overt act that the person knows will kill the partially delivered living fetus; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(10)(a)(ii): performs the overt act, other than completion of delivery, that kills the partially living fetus.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(10)(b): "Partial birth abortion" does not include the dilation and evacuation procedure involving dismemberment prior to removal, the suction curettage procedure, or the suction aspiration procedure for abortion.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(11): "Perinatal hospice" means comprehensive support to the mother and her family from the time of the diagnosis of a lethal fetal anomaly, through the time of the child's birth, and through the postpartum period, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(11)(a): focuses on alleviating fear and ensuring that the woman and her family experience the life and death of a child in a comfortable and supportive environment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(11)(b): may include counseling or medical care by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(11)(b)(i): maternal-fetal medical specialists;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(11)(b)(ii): obstetricians;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(11)(b)(iii): neonatologists;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(11)(b)(iv): anesthesia specialists;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(11)(b)(v): psychiatrists, psychologists, or other mental health providers;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(11)(b)(vi): clergy;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(11)(b)(vii): social workers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(11)(b)(viii): specialty nurses.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(12): Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; (12)(a); (b) "Physician" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(12)(a): Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act a medical doctor licensed to practice medicine and surgery under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(12)(b): Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act an osteopathic physician licensed to practice osteopathic medicine under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(12)(c): (12)(a); (b) a physician employed by the federal government who has qualifications similar to an individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(13): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(13)(a): "Severe brain abnormality" means a malformation or defect that causes an individual to live in a mentally vegetative state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(13)(b): "Severe brain abnormality" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(13)(b)(i): Down syndrome;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(13)(b)(ii): spina bifida;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(13)(b)(iii): cerebral palsy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301(13)(b)(iv): any other malformation, defect, or condition that does not cause an individual to live in a mentally vegetative state.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301.1 Preamble -- Findings and policies of Legislature.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301.1(1): It is the finding and policy of the Legislature, reflecting and reasserting the provisions of Article I, Sections 1 and 7, Utah Constitution, which recognize that life founded on inherent and inalienable rights is entitled to protection of law and due process; and that unborn children have inherent and inalienable rights that are entitled to protection by the state of Utah pursuant to the provisions of the Utah Constitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301.1(2): The state of Utah has a compelling interest in the protection of the lives of unborn children.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301.1(3): It is the intent of the Legislature to protect and guarantee to unborn children their inherent and inalienable right to life  as required by Article I, Sections 1 and 7, Utah Constitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301.1(4): It is also the policy of the Legislature and of the state that, in connection with abortion, a woman's liberty interest, in limited circumstances, may outweigh the unborn child's right to protection.   These limited circumstances arise when the abortion is necessary to save the pregnant woman's life or prevent grave damage to her medical health, and when pregnancy occurs as a result of rape or incest.   It is further the finding and policy of the Legislature and of the state that a woman may terminate the pregnancy if the unborn child would be born with grave  defects.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301.5 Relationship to criminal homicide.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301.5(1): This part does not apply to the killing or attempted killing of a live unborn child in any manner that is not an abortion.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-301.5(2): Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 2, Criminal Homicide The killing or attempted killing of a live unborn child in a manner that is not an abortion shall be punished as provided in


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-302 Circumstances under which abortion authorized.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-302(1): An abortion may be performed in this state only by a physician.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-302(2): (4); 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-406(2)(j); 76-7-102; (2)(c)(i)(A); (2)(c)(i)(A); 80-2-602 An abortion may be performed in this state only under the following circumstances:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-302(2)(a): the unborn child has not reached 18 weeks gestational age;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-302(2)(b): (4) the unborn child has reached 18 weeks gestational age, and:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-302(2)(b)(i): the abortion is necessary to avert:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-302(2)(b)(i)(A): the death of the woman on whom the abortion is performed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-302(2)(b)(i)(B): a serious physical risk of substantial impairment of a major bodily function of the woman on whom the abortion is performed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-302(2)(b)(ii): (4) subject to Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-302(2)(c)(i): 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-406(2)(j); 76-7-102
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-302(2)(c)(i)(A): 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-406(2)(j); 76-7-102 the woman is pregnant as a result of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-302(2)(c)(i)(A)(I): 76-5-402 rape, as described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-302(3): An abortion may be performed only in a hospital, unless it is necessary to perform the abortion in another location due to a medical emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-302(4): If the unborn child has been diagnosed with a fetal abnormality that is incompatible with life, at the time of the diagnosis, the physician shall inform the woman, both verbally and in writing, that perinatal hospice and perinatal palliative care services are available and are an alternative to abortion.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-302.4 Abortion restriction of an unborn child with Down syndrome.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Notwithstanding any other provision of this part, an abortion may not be performed if the pregnant mother's sole reason for the abortion is that the unborn child has or may have Down syndrome, unless the abortion is permissible for a reason described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-303 Concurrence of attending physician based on medical judgment.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
No abortion may be performed in this state without the concurrence of the attending physician, based on his best medical judgment.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-304 Considerations by physician -- Notice to a parent or guardian -- Exceptions.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-304(1): To enable the physician to exercise the physician's best medical judgment, the physician shall consider all factors relevant to the well-being of a pregnant woman upon whom an abortion is to be performed, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-304(1)(a): her physical, emotional, and psychological health and safety;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-304(1)(b): her age; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-304(1)(c): her familial situation.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-305.5 Requirements for information module and website.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-305.5(1): In order to ensure that a woman's consent to an abortion is truly an informed consent, the department shall, in accordance with the requirements of this section, develop an information module and maintain a public website.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-305.5(2): (1); 35A-3-308; (2)(g); 76-7-203; (2)(h); (4); (4); (2)(j); (2)(m); (5); 76-7-308.5; 26B-2-232(3)(a)(i) The information module and public website described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306 Refusal to participate, admit, or treat for abortion based on religious or moral grounds -- Cause of action.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(1): 26B-2-201 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(1)(a): 26B-2-201 "Health care facility" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(1)(b): "Health care provider" means an individual who is an employee of, has practice privileges at, or is otherwise associated with a health care facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(2): A health care provider may, on religious or moral grounds, refuse to perform or participate in any way, in:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(2)(a): an abortion; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(2)(b): a procedure that is intended to, or likely to, result in the termination of a pregnancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(3): Except as otherwise required by law, a health care facility may refuse, on religious or moral grounds, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(3)(a): admit a patient for an abortion procedure or another procedure that is intended to, or likely to, result in the termination of a pregnancy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(3)(b): perform for a patient an abortion procedure or another procedure that is intended to, or likely to, result in the termination of a pregnancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(4): (2); (3) A health care provider's refusal under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(5): (2); (6) A health care facility, employer, or other person may not take an adverse action against a health care provider for exercising the health care provider's right of refusal described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(5)(a): dismissal;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(5)(b): demotion;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(5)(c): suspension;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(5)(d): discipline;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(5)(e): discrimination;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(5)(f): harassment;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(5)(g): retaliation;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(5)(h): adverse change in status;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(5)(i): termination of, adverse alteration of, or refusal to renew an association or agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(5)(j): refusal to provide a benefit, privilege, raise, promotion, tenure, or increased status that the health care provider would have otherwise received.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-306(6): (5) A person who is adversely impacted by conduct prohibited in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-307 Medical procedure required to save life of unborn child.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If an abortion is performed when the unborn child is sufficiently developed to have any reasonable possibility of survival outside its mother's womb, the medical procedure used must be that which, in the best medical judgment of the physician will give the unborn child the best chance of survival.  No medical procedure designed to kill or injure that unborn child may be used unless necessary, in the opinion of the woman's physician, to prevent grave damage to her medical health.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-308 Medical skills required to preserve life of unborn child.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Consistent with the purpose of saving the life of the woman or preventing grave damage to the woman's medical health, the physician performing the abortion must use all of his medical skills to attempt to promote, preserve and maintain the life of any unborn child sufficiently developed to have any reasonable possibility of survival outside of the mother's womb.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-308.5 Administration of anesthetic or analgesic to an unborn child.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A physician who performs an abortion of an unborn child who is at least 20 weeks gestational age shall administer an anesthetic or analgesic to eliminate or alleviate organic pain to the unborn child caused by the particular method of abortion to be employed, unless:Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-308.5(1): the abortion is necessary to avert:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-308.5(1)(a): the death of the woman on whom the abortion is performed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-308.5(1)(b): a serious risk of substantial and irreversible impairment of a major bodily function of the woman on whom the abortion is performed;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-308.5(2): the abortion is performed because the fetus has a defect that is uniformly diagnosable and uniformly lethal, based on the written concurrence of two physicians who practice maternal fetal medicine; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-308.5(3): the treating physician and one other physician concur, in writing, that the administration of an anesthetic or analgesic would:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-308.5(3)(a): cause the death of the woman on whom the abortion is performed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-308.5(3)(b): create a serious risk of substantial or irreversible impairment of a major bodily function of the woman on whom the abortion is performed.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-309 Pathologist's report.
----------------------------------------------------
Any human tissue removed during an abortion shall be submitted to a pathologist who shall make a report, including whether:Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-309(1): the pregnancy was aborted by evacuating the uterus; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-309(2): a medical record indicates that, through a prenatal screening or other diagnostic test, the aborted fetus had or may have had Down syndrome.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-310 Experimentation with unborn children prohibited -- Testing for genetic defects.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Live unborn children may not be used for experimentation, but when advisable, in the best medical judgment of the physician, may be tested for genetic defects.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-310.5 Prohibition of specified abortion procedures -- Viability defined.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-310.5(1): As used in this section, "saline abortion procedure" means performance of amniocentesis and injection of saline into the amniotic sac within the uterine cavity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-310.5(2): (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-310.5(2)(a): (2)(b) After viability has been determined in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-310.5(2)(b): For purposes of this section determination of viability shall be made by the physician, based upon his own best clinical judgment.  The physician shall determine whether, based on the particular facts of a woman's pregnancy that are known to him, and in light of medical technology and information reasonably available to him, there is a realistic possibility of maintaining and nourishing a life outside of the womb, with or without temporary, artificial life-sustaining support.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-310.5(3): Intentional, knowing, and willful violation of this section is a third degree felony.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-311 Selling and buying unborn children prohibited.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Selling, buying, offering to sell and offering to buy unborn children is prohibited.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-312 Intimidation or coercion to obtain abortion prohibited.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
No person shall intimidate or coerce in any way any person to obtain an abortion.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-313 Department's enforcement responsibility -- Physician's report to department -- Reporting.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-314 Violations of abortion laws -- Classifications.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
