Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-314.5 Killing an unborn child.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-314.5(1): 76-7-302(2) A person is guilty of killing an unborn child if the person intentionally causes the death of an unborn child by performing an abortion of the unborn child in violation of the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-314.5(2): 76-7-302(2)(b)(ii); 76-7-305 A woman is not criminally liable for:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-314.5(2)(a): seeking to obtain, or obtaining, an abortion that is permitted by this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-314.5(2)(b): 76-7-302(2)(b)(ii); 76-7-305 a physician's failure to comply with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-315 Exceptions to certain requirements in serious medical emergencies.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When due to a serious medical emergency, time does not permit compliance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-316 Actions not precluded.
-----------------------------------------------------
Nothing in this part shall preclude any person believing himself aggrieved by another under this part, from bringing any other action at common law or other statutory provision.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-317 Severability clause.
---------------------------------------------------
If any one or more provision, section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or word of this part or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is found to be unconstitutional, the same is hereby declared to be severable and the balance of this part shall remain effective notwithstanding such unconstitutionality. The legislature hereby declares that it would have passed this part, and each provision, section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or word thereof, irrespective of the fact that any one or more provision, section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or word be declared unconstitutional. This section applies to any provision, section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or word of this part, regardless of the time of enactment, amendment, or repeal.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-321 Contraceptive and abortion services -- Funds -- Minor -- Definitions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
As used in SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 76-7-321(1): "Abortion services" means any material, program, plan, or undertaking which seeks to promote abortion, encourages individuals to obtain an abortion, or provides abortions.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-321(2): "Contraceptive services" means any material, program, plan, or undertaking that is used for instruction on the use of birth control devices and substances, encourages individuals to use birth control methods, or provides birth control devices.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-321(3): "Funds" means any money, supply, material, building, or project provided by this state or its political subdivisions.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-321(4): "Minor" means any person under the age of 18 who is not otherwise emancipated, married, or a member of the armed forces of the United States.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-322 Public funds for provision of contraceptive or abortion services restricted.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
No funds of the state or its political subdivisions shall be used to provide contraceptive or abortion services to an unmarried minor without the prior written consent of the minor's parent or guardian.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-323 Public funds for support entities providing contraceptive or abortion services restricted.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
No agency of the state or its political subdivisions shall approve any application for funds of the state or its political subdivisions to support, directly or indirectly, any organization or health care provider that provides contraceptive or abortion services to an unmarried minor without the prior written consent of the minor's parent or guardian.  No institution shall be denied state or federal funds under relevant provisions of law on the ground that a person on its staff provides contraceptive or abortion services in that person's private practice outside of such institution.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-324 Violation of restrictions on public funds for contraceptive or abortion services as misdemeanor.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any agent of a state agency or political subdivision, acting alone or in concert with others, who violates Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-325 Notice to parent or guardian of minor requesting contraceptive -- Definition of contraceptives -- Penalty for violation.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-325(1): Any person before providing contraceptives to a minor shall notify, whenever possible, the minor's parents or guardian of the service requested to be provided to such minor.  Contraceptives shall be defined as appliances (including but not limited to intrauterine devices), drugs, or medicinal preparations intended or having special utility for prevention of conception.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-325(2): Any person in violation of this section shall be guilty of a class C misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-326 Partial birth abortions prohibited.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Any physician who knowingly performs a partial birth abortion and thereby kills a human fetus shall be fined or imprisoned, or both, as provided under this part.  This section does not apply to a partial birth abortion that is necessary to save the life of a mother whose life is endangered by a physical disorder, physical illness, or physical injury, including a life endangering physical condition caused by or arising from the pregnancy itself.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-327 Remedies for father or maternal grandparents.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-327(1): The father, if married to the mother at the time she receives a partial birth abortion, and if the mother has not attained the age of 18 years at the time of the abortion, the maternal grandparents of the fetus, may in a civil action obtain appropriate relief, unless the pregnancy resulted from the plaintiff's criminal conduct or the plaintiff consented to the abortion.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-327(2): 76-7-326 Such relief shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-327(2)(a): 76-7-326 money damages for all injuries, psychological and physical, occasioned by the violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-327(2)(b): statutory damages equal to three times the cost of the partial birth abortion.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-328 Hearing to determine necessity of physician's conduct.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-328(1): 76-7-326; 58-67-201; 58-68-201 A physician accused of an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-328(2): The findings on that issue are admissible on that issue at the trial of the physician.  Upon a motion from the physician, the court shall delay the beginning of the trial for not more than 30 days to permit such a hearing to take place.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-330 Contingent continuance of prior law.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-330(1): 76-7-326; 76-7-326; (2); 76-7-326 If the implementation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-330(1)(a): be given effect as if this bill did not amend those statutes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-330(1)(b): 76-7-326 remain in effect as if not amended by this bill until the day on which a court orders that Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-330(2): (1); 76-7-301; 76-7-310.5; 76-7-314 Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-330(2)(a): 76-7-301 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-330(2)(b): 76-7-310.5 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-330(2)(c): 76-7-314 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-330(3): (2) Nothing in this section prevents the Legislature from amending, repealing, or taking any other action regarding the sections listed in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-331 Public funding of abortion forbidden.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-331(1): As used in this section, "damage to a major bodily function" refers only to injury or impairment of a physical nature and may not be interpreted to mean mental, psychological, or emotional harm, illness, or distress.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-331(2): Public funds of the state, its institutions, or its political subdivisions may not be used to pay or otherwise reimburse, either directly or indirectly, any person, agency, or facility for the performance of any induced abortion services unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-331(2)(a): in the professional judgment of the pregnant woman's attending physician, the abortion is necessary to save the pregnant woman's life;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-331(2)(b): the pregnancy is the result of rape or incest reported to law enforcement agencies, unless the woman was unable to report the crime for physical reasons or fear of retaliation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-331(2)(c): in the professional judgment of the pregnant woman's attending physician, the abortion is necessary to prevent permanent, irreparable, and grave damage to a major bodily function of the pregnant woman provided that a caesarian procedure or other medical procedure that could also save the life of the child is not a viable option.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-331(3): Any officer or employee of the state who knowingly authorizes the use of funds prohibited by this section shall be dismissed from that person's office or position and the person's employment shall be immediately terminated.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-332 Drugs known to be used for abortion -- Prescriber limitation -- Criminal penalties -- Pharmacy presumption for other use.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-332(1): As used in the section, "abortion-related drug" means a drug or medication that is known to be used for the purpose of performing an abortion, and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-332(1)(a): methotrexate, or methotrexate with misoprostol;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-332(1)(b): mifepristone, also known as mifeprex;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-332(1)(c): misoprostol, also known as cytotec; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-332(1)(d): RU-486.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-332(2): Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act An individual may not prescribe an abortion-related drug for the purpose of causing an abortion, unless the individual is licensed as a physician in this state under:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-332(2)(a): Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-332(2)(b): Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-332(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-332(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-332(4)(a): Any prescription or medical order for a drug that is known to possibly cause an abortion shall be presumed by a pharmacy to be for an indication other than for the termination of a pregnancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-332(4)(b): A pharmacy dispensing a prescription or medical order for a drug that is known to possibly cause an abortion shall not be required to verify whether the prescription or medical order violates any provision of this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-401 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-401(1): "Assisted reproductive treatment" means a method of causing pregnancy by any means other than through sexual intercourse, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-401(1)(a): intrauterine or intracervical insemination;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-401(1)(b): donation of eggs or sperm;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-401(1)(c): donation of embryos;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-401(1)(d): in vitro fertilization and embryo transfer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-401(1)(e): intracytoplasmic sperm injection.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-401(2): "Gamete" means a cell containing a haploid complement of DNA that has the potential to form an embryo when combined with another gamete, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-401(2)(a): a sperm;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-401(2)(b): an egg; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-401(2)(c): nuclear DNA from one individual combined with the:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-401(2)(c)(i): cytoplasm of another individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-401(2)(c)(ii): cytoplasmic DNA of another individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-401(3): 78B-3-403(12) "Health care provider" means an individual listed in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-402 Genetic material misuse.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-402(1): A health care provider may not knowingly use the health care provider's own gamete, when providing assisted reproductive treatment to a patient, without the patient's written consent.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7-402(2): (1) A health care provider who violates Subsection


Utah Code Annotated - Title 76 - Chapter 7a - Abortion Prohibition
******************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(1)(a): "Abortion" means the act, by a physician, of using an instrument, or prescribing a drug, with the intent to cause the death of an unborn child of a woman known to be pregnant, except as permitted under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(1)(b): "Abortion" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(1)(b)(i): removal of a dead unborn child;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(1)(b)(ii): removal of an ectopic pregnancy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(1)(b)(iii): the killing or attempted killing of an unborn child without the consent of the pregnant woman, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(1)(b)(iii)(A): the killing or attempted killing is done through a medical procedure carried out by a physician or through a substance used under the direction of a physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(1)(b)(iii)(B): the physician is unable to obtain the consent due to a medical emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(2): "Department" means the Department of Health and Human Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(3): "Down syndrome" means a genetic condition associated with an extra chromosome 21, in whole or in part, or an effective trisomy for chromosome 21.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(4): "Hospital" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(4)(a): a general hospital licensed by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(4)(b): a clinic or other medical facility that meets the following criteria:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(4)(b)(i): a clinician who performs procedures at the clinic is required to be credentialed to perform the same procedures at a general hospital licensed by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(4)(b)(ii): any procedures performed at the clinic are done with the same level of safety for the pregnant woman and unborn child as would be available in a general hospital licensed by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(5): "Medical emergency" means a life threatening physical condition aggravated by, caused by, or arising from a pregnancy that places the pregnant woman at risk of death, or poses a serious risk of substantial impairment of a major bodily function, unless the abortion is performed or induced.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(6): "Perinatal hospice" means comprehensive support to the mother and her family from the time of the diagnosis of a lethal fetal anomaly, through the time of the child's birth, and through the postpartum period, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(6)(a): focuses on alleviating fear and ensuring that the woman and her family experience the life and death of a child in a comfortable and supportive environment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(6)(b): may include counseling or medical care by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(6)(b)(i): maternal-fetal medical specialists;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(6)(b)(ii): obstetricians;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(6)(b)(iii): neonatologists;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(6)(b)(iv): anesthesia specialists;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(6)(b)(v): psychiatrists, psychologists, or other mental health providers;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(6)(b)(vi): clergy;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(6)(b)(vii): social workers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(6)(b)(viii): specialty nurses.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(7): (7)(a); (b) "Physician" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(7)(a): a medical doctor licensed to practice medicine and surgery in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(7)(b): an osteopathic physician licensed to practice osteopathic medicine in the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(7)(c): (7)(a); (b) a physician employed by the federal government who has qualifications similar to an individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(8)(a): "Severe brain abnormality" means a malformation or defect that causes an individual to live in a mentally vegetative state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(8)(b): "Severe brain abnormality" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(8)(b)(i): Down syndrome;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(8)(b)(ii): spina bifida;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(8)(b)(iii): cerebral palsy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-101(8)(b)(iv): any other malformation, defect, or condition that does not cause an individual to live in a mentally vegetative state.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201 Abortion prohibition -- Exceptions -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(1): (3); 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-406(2)(j); 76-7-102; (1)(c)(i)(A); (1)(c)(i)(A) An abortion may be performed in this state only under the following circumstances:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(1)(a): the abortion is necessary to avert:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(1)(a)(i): the death of the woman on whom the abortion is performed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(1)(a)(ii): a serious physical risk of substantial impairment of a major bodily function of the woman on whom the abortion is performed;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(1)(b): (3) subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(1)(c): 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-406(2)(j); 76-7-102; (1)(c)(i)(A); (1)(c)(i)(A) the unborn child has not reached 18 weeks gestational age and:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(1)(c)(i): 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-406(2)(j); 76-7-102
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(1)(c)(i)(A): 76-5-402; 76-5-402.1; 76-5-406(2)(j); 76-7-102 the woman is pregnant as a result of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(1)(c)(i)(A)(I): 76-5-402 rape, as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(1)(c)(i)(A)(II): 76-5-402.1 rape of a child, as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(1)(c)(i)(A)(III): 76-5-406(2)(j); 76-7-102 incest, as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(1)(c)(i)(B): the pregnant child is under the age of 14; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(1)(c)(ii): (1)(c)(i)(A); (1)(c)(i)(A) before the abortion is performed, the physician who performs the abortion:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(1)(c)(ii)(A): (1)(c)(i)(A); (1)(c)(i)(A) for an abortion authorized under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(1)(c)(ii)(B): if applicable, complies with requirements related to reporting suspicions of or known child abuse.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(2): An abortion may be performed only:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(2)(a): by a physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(2)(b): in a hospital, unless it is necessary to perform the abortion in another location due to a medical emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(3): If the unborn child has been diagnosed with a fetal abnormality that is incompatible with life, at the time of the diagnosis, the physician shall inform the woman, both verbally and in writing, that perinatal hospice services and perinatal palliative care are available and are an alternative to abortion.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(4): A person who performs an abortion in violation of this section is guilty of a second degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(5): (4) In addition to the penalty described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(6): The department shall report a physician's violation of any provision of this section to the state entity that regulates the licensing of a physician.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(7): (1)(c); (1)(c)(ii)(A); (7)(a); 76-7-313 A physician who performs an abortion under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(7)(a): (1)(c)(ii)(A) maintain an accurate record as to the manner in which the physician conducted the verification under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-201(7)(b): (7)(a); 76-7-313 report the information described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-7a-301 Superseding clause.
---------------------------------------------------
If, at the time this chapter takes effect, any provision in the Utah Code conflicts with a provision of this chapter, the provision of this chapter supersedes the conflicting provision.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 76 - Chapter 8 - Offenses Against the Administration of Government
**********************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-101 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-101(1): "Candidate for electoral office" means a person who files as a candidate for office under the laws of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-101(2): "Party official" means a person holding any post in a political party whether by election, appointment, or otherwise.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-101(3): "Peace officer" means an employee of a police or law enforcement agency that is part of or administered by the state or any of its political subdivisions, and whose duties consist primarily of the prevention and detection of crime and the enforcement of criminal statutes or ordinances of this state or any of its political subdivisions.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-101(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-101(4)(a): "Pecuniary benefit" means any advantage in the form of money, property, commercial interest, or anything else, the primary significance of which is economic gain.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-101(4)(b): "Pecuniary benefit" does not include economic advantage applicable to the public generally, such as tax reduction or increased prosperity generally.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-101(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-101(5)(a): "Public property" means real or personal property that is owned, held, or managed by a public entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-101(5)(b): "Public property" includes real or personal property that is owned, held, or managed by a public entity after the real or personal property is transferred by the public entity to an independent contractor of the public entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-101(5)(c): "Public property" remains public property while in the possession of an independent contractor of a public entity for the purpose of providing a program or service for, or on behalf of, the public entity.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-102 Campaign contributions not prohibited.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prohibit the giving or receiving of campaign contributions made for the purpose of defraying the costs of a political campaign. No person shall be convicted of an offense solely on the evidence that a campaign contribution was made and that an appointment or nomination was subsequently made by the person to whose campaign or political party the contribution was made.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-103 Bribery or offering a bribe.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-103(1): A person is guilty of bribery or offering a bribe if that person promises, offers, or agrees to give or gives, directly or indirectly, any benefit to another with the purpose or intent to influence an action, decision, opinion, recommendation, judgment, vote, nomination, or exercise of discretion of a public servant, party official, or voter.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-103(2): It is not a defense to a prosecution under this statute that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-103(2)(a): the person sought to be influenced was not qualified to act in the desired way, whether because the person had not assumed office, lacked jurisdiction, or for any other reason;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-103(2)(b): the person sought to be influenced did not act in the desired way; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-103(2)(c): the benefit is not conferred, solicited, or accepted until after:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-103(2)(c)(i): the action, decision, opinion, recommendation, judgment, vote, nomination, or exercise of discretion, has occurred; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-103(2)(c)(ii): the public servant ceases to be a public servant.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-103(3): Bribery or offering a bribe is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-103(3)(a): a third degree felony when the value of the benefit asked for, solicited, accepted, or conferred is less than $1,000; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-103(3)(b): a second degree felony when the value of the benefit asked for, solicited, accepted, or conferred is $1,000 or more.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-104 Threats to influence official or political action.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-104(1): A person is guilty of a class A misdemeanor if he threatens any harm to a public servant, party official, or voter with a purpose of influencing his action, decision, opinion, recommendation, nomination, vote, or other exercise of discretion.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-104(2): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-104(2)(a): "Harm" means any disadvantage or injury, pecuniary or otherwise, including disadvantage or injury to any other person or entity in whose welfare the public servant, party official, or voter is interested.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-104(2)(b): "Public servant" does not include jurors.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-105 Receiving or soliciting bribe or bribery by public servant.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-105(1): A person is guilty of receiving or soliciting a bribe if that person asks for, solicits, accepts, or receives, directly or indirectly, any benefit with the understanding or agreement that the purpose or intent is to influence an action, decision, opinion, recommendation, judgment, vote, nomination, or exercise of discretion, of a public servant, party official, or voter.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-105(2): It is not a defense to a prosecution under this statute that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-105(2)(a): the person sought to be influenced was not qualified to act in the desired way, whether because the person had not assumed office, lacked jurisdiction, or for any other reason;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-105(2)(b): the person sought to be influenced did not act in the desired way; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-105(2)(c): the benefit is not asked for, conferred, solicited, or accepted until after:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-105(2)(c)(i): the action, decision, opinion, recommendation, judgment, vote, nomination, or exercise of discretion, has occurred; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-105(2)(c)(ii): the public servant ceases to be a public servant.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-105(3): Receiving or soliciting a bribe is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-105(3)(a): a third degree felony when the value of the benefit asked for, solicited, accepted, or conferred is $1,000 or less; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-105(3)(b): a second degree felony when the value of the benefit asked for, solicited, accepted, or conferred exceeds $1,000.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-106 Receiving bribe or bribery for endorsement of person as public servant.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor if:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-106(1): He solicits, accepts, agrees to accept for himself, another person, or a political party, money or any other pecuniary benefit as compensation for his endorsement, nomination, appointment, approval, or disapproval of any person for a position as a public servant or for the advancement of any public servant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-106(2): He knowingly gives, offers, or promises any pecuniary benefit prohibited by paragraph (1).


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-107 Alteration of proposed legislative bill or resolution.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who fraudulently alters the draft of any bill or resolution which has been presented to either of the houses composing the Legislature to be passed or adopted, with intent to procure its being passed or adopted by either house, or certified by the presiding officer of either house in language different from that intended by such house, is guilty of a felony of the third degree.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-108 Alteration of enrolled legislative bill or resolution.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who fraudulently alters the enrolled copy of any bill or resolution which has been passed or adopted by the Legislature with intent to procure it to be approved by the governor or certified by the Division of Archives, or printed or published by the printer of statutes in language different from that in which it was passed or adopted by the Legislature, is guilty of a felony of the third degree.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-110 Peace officer prohibited from acting as compensated collection agent for collection agencies or creditors.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-110(1): A peace officer may not have any interest in any collection agency or act as a compensated collection agent for any creditor or collection agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-110(2): A person that violates this section is guilty of a class C misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-201 Official misconduct -- Unauthorized acts or failure of duty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A public servant is guilty of a class B misdemeanor if, with an intent to benefit himself or another or to harm another, he knowingly commits an unauthorized act which purports to be an act of his office, or knowingly refrains from performing a duty imposed on him by law or clearly inherent in the nature of his office.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-202 Official misconduct -- Unlawful acts based on "inside" information.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A public servant is guilty of a class A misdemeanor if, knowing that official action is contemplated or in reliance on information which he has acquired by virtue of his office or from another public servant, which information has not been made public, he:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-202(1): acquires or divests himself of a pecuniary interest in any property, transaction, or enterprise which may be affected by such action or information;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-202(2): speculates or wagers on the basis of such action or information; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-202(3): knowingly aids another to do any of the foregoing.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-203 Unofficial misconduct.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-203(1): A person is guilty of unofficial misconduct if the person exercises or attempts to exercise any of the functions of a public office when the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-203(1)(a): has not taken and filed the required oath of office;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-203(1)(b): has failed to execute and file a required bond;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-203(1)(c): has not been elected or appointed to office;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-203(1)(d): exercises any of the functions of his office after his term has expired and the successor has been elected or appointed and has qualified, or after his office has been legally removed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-203(1)(e): knowingly withholds or retains from his successor in office or other person entitled to the official seal or any records, papers, documents, or other writings appertaining or belonging to his office or mutilates or destroys or takes away the same.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-203(2): Unofficial misconduct is a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301 Interference with public servant.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301(1): An individual is guilty of interference with a public servant if the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301(1)(a): uses force, violence, intimidation, or engages in any other unlawful act with a purpose to interfere with a public servant performing or purporting to perform an official function;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301(1)(b): obstructs, hinders, conceals, or prevents the lawful service of any legal process, civil or criminal, by any sheriff, constable, deputy sheriff, deputy constable, peace officer, private investigator, or any other person authorized to serve legal process; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301(1)(c): on property that is owned, operated, or controlled by the state or a political subdivision of the state, willfully denies to a public servant lawful:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301(1)(c)(i): freedom of movement;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301(1)(c)(ii): use of the property or facilities; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301(1)(c)(iii): entry into or exit from the facilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301(2): (1)(a); (b); (1)(c) Interference with a public servant:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301(2)(a): (1)(a); (b) under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301(2)(b): (1)(c) under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301(3): For purposes of this section, "public servant" does not include jurors.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301.5 Failure to disclose identity.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301.5(1): 77-7-15; (1)(a) A person is guilty of failure to disclose identity if during the period of time that the person is lawfully subjected to a stop as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301.5(1)(a): a peace officer demands that the person disclose the person's name or date of birth;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301.5(1)(b): (1)(a) the demand described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301.5(1)(c): the disclosure of the person's name or date of birth by the person does not present a reasonable danger of self-incrimination in the commission of a crime; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301.5(1)(d): the person fails to disclose the person's name or date of birth.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-301.5(2): Failure to disclose identity is a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-302 Picketing or parading in or near court.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
A person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor if he pickets or parades in or near a building which houses a court of this state with intent to obstruct access to that court or to affect the outcome of a case pending before that court.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-303 Prevention of Legislature or public servants from meeting or organizing.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person is guilty of a felony of the third degree if he intentionally and by force or fraud:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-303(1): Prevents the Legislature, or either of the houses composing it, or any of the members thereof, from meeting or organizing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-303(2): Prevents any other public servant from meeting or organizing to perform a lawful governmental function.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-305 Interference with peace officer.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-305(1): A person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor if the person knows, or by the exercise of reasonable care should have known, that a peace officer is seeking to effect a lawful arrest or detention of that person or another person and interferes with the arrest or detention by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-305(1)(a): use of force or any weapon;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-305(1)(b): refusing to perform any act required by lawful order:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-305(1)(b)(i): necessary to effect the arrest or detention; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-305(1)(b)(ii): made by a peace officer involved in the arrest or detention; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-305(1)(c): refusing to refrain from performing any act that would impede the arrest or detention.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-305(2): Recording the actions of a law enforcement officer with a camera, mobile phone, or other photographic device, while the officer is performing official duties in plain view, does not by itself constitute:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-305(2)(a): interference with the officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-305(2)(b): willful resistance;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-305(2)(c): disorderly conduct; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-305(2)(d): obstruction of justice.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-305.5 Failure to stop at the command of a peace officer.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person is guilty of a class A misdemeanor who flees from or otherwise attempts to elude a peace officer:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-305.5(1): after the officer has issued a verbal or visual command to stop;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-305.5(2): for the purpose of avoiding arrest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-305.5(3): 41-6a-210 by any means other than a violation of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306 Obstruction of justice in criminal investigations or proceedings -- Elements -- Penalties -- Exceptions.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(1): An actor commits obstruction of justice if the actor, with intent to hinder, delay, or prevent the investigation, apprehension, prosecution, conviction, or punishment of any person regarding conduct that constitutes a criminal offense:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(1)(a): provides any person with a weapon;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(1)(b): prevents by force, intimidation, or deception, any person from performing any act that might aid in the discovery, apprehension, prosecution, conviction, or punishment of any person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(1)(c): alters, destroys, conceals, or removes any item or other thing;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(1)(d): makes, presents, or uses any item or thing known by the actor to be false;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(1)(e): harbors or conceals a person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(1)(f): provides a person with transportation, disguise, or other means of avoiding discovery or apprehension;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(1)(g): warns any person of impending discovery or apprehension;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(1)(h): warns any person of an order authorizing the interception of wire communications or of a pending application for an order authorizing the interception of wire communications;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(1)(i): conceals information that is not privileged and that concerns the offense, after a judge or magistrate has ordered the actor to provide the information; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(1)(j): provides false information regarding a suspect, a witness, the conduct constituting an offense, or any other material aspect of the investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(2)(a): As used in this section, "conduct that constitutes a criminal offense" means conduct that would be punishable as a crime and is separate from a violation of this section, and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(2)(a)(i): any violation of a criminal statute or ordinance of this state, its political subdivisions, any other state, or any district, possession, or territory of the United States; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(2)(a)(ii): conduct committed by a juvenile which would be a crime if committed by an adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(2)(b): A violation of a criminal statute that is committed in another state, or any district, possession, or territory of the United States, is a:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(2)(b)(i): capital felony if the penalty provided includes death or life imprisonment without parole;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(2)(b)(ii): a first degree felony if the penalty provided includes life imprisonment with parole or a maximum term of imprisonment exceeding 15 years;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(2)(b)(iii): a second degree felony if the penalty provided exceeds five years;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(2)(b)(iv): a third degree felony if the penalty provided includes imprisonment for any period exceeding one year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(2)(b)(v): a misdemeanor if the penalty provided includes imprisonment for any period of one year or less.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(3): (1)(b); (c); (d); (e); (f); (1)(a); (1)(h); (3)(a); (b) Obstruction of justice is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(3)(a): a second degree felony if the conduct which constitutes an offense would be a capital felony or first degree felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(3)(b): (1)(b); (c); (d); (e); (f); (1)(a); (1)(h) a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(3)(b)(i): (1)(b); (c); (d); (e); (f) the conduct that constitutes an offense would be a second or third degree felony and the actor violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(3)(b)(ii): (1)(a) the conduct that constitutes an offense would be any offense other than a capital or first degree felony and the actor violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(3)(b)(iii): the obstruction of justice is presented or committed before a court of law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(3)(b)(iv): (1)(h) a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(3)(c): (3)(a); (b) a class A misdemeanor for any violation of this section that is not enumerated under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(4): It is not a defense that the actor was unaware of the level of penalty for the conduct constituting an offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(5): (1)(e); 80-1-102; 76-8-311.5 Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(6): (1)(b); 76-8-508.5; 76-8-316; 76-8-508; 76-8-508.3; 76-8-509 Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(6)(a): 76-8-508.5 tampering with a juror, which is governed by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(6)(b): 76-8-316 influencing, impeding, or retaliating against a judge or member of the Board of Pardons and Parole, which is governed by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(6)(c): 76-8-508 tampering with a witness or soliciting or receiving a bribe, which is governed by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(6)(d): 76-8-508.3 retaliation against a witness, victim, or informant, which is governed by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(6)(e): 76-8-509 extortion or bribery to dismiss a criminal proceeding, which is governed by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306(7): (1); (2); (3); 76-8-309 Notwithstanding Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306.5 Obstructing service of a Board of Pardons' warrant or a probationer order to show cause.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person is guilty of a third degree felony who:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306.5(1): knows that the Board of Pardons and Parole has issued a warrant for a parolee or that a court has issued an order to show cause regarding a defendant's violation of the terms of probation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306.5(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306.5(2)(a): harbors or conceals the parolee or probationer;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306.5(2)(b): provides the parolee or probationer with transportation, disguise, or other means or assistance to avoid discovery; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-306.5(2)(c): warns the parolee or probationer of his impending discovery.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-307 Failure to aid peace officer.
------------------------------------------------------------
A person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor if, upon command by a peace officer identifiable or identified by him as such, he unreasonably fails or refuses to aid the peace officer in effecting an arrest or in preventing the commission of any offense by another person.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-308 Acceptance of bribe or bribery to prevent criminal prosecution -- Defense.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-308(1): A person is guilty of a class A misdemeanor if he:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-308(1)(a): solicits, accepts, or agrees to accept any benefit as consideration for his refraining from initiating or aiding in a criminal prosecution; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-308(1)(b): confers, offers, or agrees to confer any benefit upon another as consideration for the person refraining from initiating or aiding in a criminal prosecution.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-308(2): It is an affirmative defense that the value of the benefit did not exceed an amount which the actor believed to be due as restitution or indemnification for the loss caused or to be caused by the offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309 Escape and aggravated escape -- Consecutive sentences -- Definitions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(1): (1); (1)(c); (1); 76-2-202
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(1)(a)(i): A prisoner is guilty of escape if the prisoner leaves official custody without lawful authorization.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(1)(a)(ii): If a prisoner obtains authorization to leave official custody by means of deceit, fraud, or other artifice, the prisoner has not received lawful authorization.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(1)(b): (1); (1)(c) Escape under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(1)(c): (1); 76-2-202 Escape under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(1)(c)(i): the actor escapes from a state prison; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(1)(c)(ii): 76-2-202
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(1)(c)(ii)(A): 76-2-202 the actor is convicted as a party to the offense, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(1)(c)(ii)(B): the actor is an employee at or a volunteer of a law enforcement agency, the Department of Corrections, a county or district attorney's office, the office of the state attorney general, the Board of Pardons and Parole, or the courts, the Judicial Council, the Administrative Office of the Courts, or similar administrative units in the judicial branch of government.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(2): 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(2)(a): 76-1-101.5 A prisoner is guilty of aggravated escape if in the commission of an escape the prisoner uses a dangerous weapon, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(2)(b): Aggravated escape is a first degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(3): Any prison term imposed upon a prisoner for escape under this section shall run consecutively with any other sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(4): For the purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(4)(a): "Confinement" means the prisoner is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(4)(a)(i): housed in a state prison or any other facility pursuant to a contract with the Utah Department of Corrections after being sentenced and committed and the sentence has not been terminated or voided or the prisoner is not on parole;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(4)(a)(ii): lawfully detained in a county jail prior to trial or sentencing or housed in a county jail after sentencing and commitment and the sentence has not been terminated or voided or the prisoner is not on parole; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(4)(a)(iii): lawfully detained following arrest.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(4)(b): "Escape" is considered to be a continuing activity commencing with the conception of the design to escape and continuing until the escaping prisoner is returned to official custody or the prisoner's attempt to escape is thwarted or abandoned.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(4)(c): "Official custody" means arrest, whether with or without warrant, or confinement in a state prison, jail, institution for secure confinement of juvenile offenders, or any confinement pursuant to an order of the court or sentenced and committed and the sentence has not been terminated or voided or the prisoner is not on parole.  A person is considered confined in the state prison if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(4)(c)(i): without authority fails to return to the person's place of confinement from work release or home visit by the time designated for return;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(4)(c)(ii): is in prehearing custody after arrest for parole violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(4)(c)(iii): is being housed in a county jail, after felony commitment, pursuant to a contract with the Department of Corrections; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(4)(c)(iv): is being transported as a prisoner in the state prison by correctional officers.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(4)(d): "Prisoner" means any person who is in official custody and includes persons under trusty status.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-309(4)(e): "Volunteer" means any person who donates service without pay or other compensation except expenses actually and reasonably incurred as approved by the supervising agency.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(1): 76-10-501; 76-8-311.3; 76-10-306; 26B-5-301 In addition to the definitions in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(1)(c): "Law enforcement facility" means a facility which is owned, leased, or operated by a law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(1)(d): 26B-5-301 "Mental health facility" has the same meaning as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(1)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(1)(e)(i): "Secure area" means any area into which certain persons are restricted from transporting any firearm, ammunition, dangerous weapon, or explosive.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(1)(e)(ii): A "secure area" may not include any area normally accessible to the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(2): (2)(a); (3); (4); (5); (6); 53B-3-103(2)(a)(ii); (b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(2)(a): A person in charge of the State Tax Commission or a correctional, law enforcement, or mental health facility may establish secure areas within the facility and may prohibit or control by rule any firearm, ammunition, dangerous weapon, or explosive.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(2)(b): (2)(a); (3); (4); (5); (6); 53B-3-103(2)(a)(ii); (b) Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(3): At least one notice shall be prominently displayed at each entrance to an area in which a firearm, ammunition, dangerous weapon, or explosive is restricted.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(4)(a): Provisions shall be made to provide a secure weapons storage area so that persons entering the secure area may store their weapons prior to entering the secure area.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(4)(b): The entity operating the facility shall be responsible for weapons while they are stored in the storage area.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(5): It is a defense to any prosecution under this section that the accused, in committing the act made criminal by this section, acted in conformity with the facility's rule or policy established pursuant to this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(6): 76-10-306
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(6)(a): Any person who knowingly or intentionally transports into a secure area of a facility any firearm, ammunition, or dangerous weapon is guilty of a third degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.1(6)(b): 76-10-306 Any person violates Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(2)(d): knowingly or intentionally possessed at a correctional or mental health facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(3): It is a defense to any prosecution under this section if the accused in committing the act made criminal by this section with respect to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(3)(a): a correctional facility operated by the Department of Corrections, acted in conformity with departmental rule or policy;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(3)(b): a correctional facility operated by a municipality, acted in conformity with the policy of the municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(3)(c): a correctional facility operated by a county, acted in conformity with the policy of the county; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(3)(d): a mental health facility, acted in conformity with the policy of the mental health facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(4): 76-10-306
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(4)(a): An individual who transports to or upon a correctional facility, or into a secure area of a mental health facility, any firearm, ammunition, dangerous weapon, or implement of escape with intent to provide or sell it to any offender, is guilty of a second degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(4)(b): An individual who provides or sells to any offender at a correctional facility, or any detainee at a secure area of a mental health facility, any firearm, ammunition, dangerous weapon, or implement of escape is guilty of a second degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(4)(c): An offender who possesses at a correctional facility, or a detainee who possesses at a secure area of a mental health facility, any firearm, ammunition, dangerous weapon, or implement of escape is guilty of a second degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(4)(d): An individual who, without the permission of the authority operating the correctional facility or the secure area of a mental health facility, knowingly possesses at a correctional facility or a secure area of a mental health facility any firearm, ammunition, dangerous weapon, or implement of escape is guilty of a third degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(4)(e): 76-10-306 An individual violates Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5): (5)(f)(ii); (5)(d); (5)(f); 64-13-40
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(a): An individual is guilty of a third degree felony who, without the permission of the authority operating the correctional facility or secure area of a mental health facility, knowingly transports to or upon a correctional facility or into a secure area of a mental health facility any:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(a)(i): spirituous or fermented liquor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(a)(ii): medicine, whether or not lawfully prescribed for the offender; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(a)(iii): poison in any quantity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(b): An individual is guilty of a third degree felony who knowingly violates correctional or mental health facility policy or rule by providing or selling to any offender at a correctional facility or detainee within a secure area of a mental health facility any:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(b)(i): spirituous or fermented liquor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(b)(ii): medicine, whether or not lawfully prescribed for the offender; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(b)(iii): poison in any quantity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(c): An inmate is guilty of a third degree felony who, in violation of correctional or mental health facility policy or rule, possesses at a correctional facility or in a secure area of a mental health facility any:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(c)(i): spirituous or fermented liquor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(c)(ii): medicine, other than medicine provided by the facility's health care providers in compliance with facility policy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(c)(iii): poison in any quantity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(d): An individual is guilty of a class A misdemeanor who, with the intent to directly or indirectly provide or sell any tobacco product, electronic cigarette product, or nicotine product to an offender, directly or indirectly:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(d)(i): transports, delivers, or distributes any tobacco product, electronic cigarette product, or nicotine product to an offender or on the grounds of any correctional facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(d)(ii): solicits, requests, commands, coerces, encourages, or intentionally aids another person to transport any tobacco product, electronic cigarette product, or nicotine product to an offender or on any correctional facility, if the person is acting with the mental state required for the commission of an offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(d)(iii): facilitates, arranges, or causes the transport of any tobacco product, electronic cigarette product, or nicotine product in violation of this section to an offender or on the grounds of any correctional facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(e): An individual is guilty of a class A misdemeanor who, without the permission of the authority operating the correctional or mental health facility, fails to declare or knowingly possesses at a correctional facility or in a secure area of a mental health facility any:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(e)(i): spirituous or fermented liquor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(e)(ii): medicine; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(e)(iii): poison in any quantity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.3(5)(f): (5)(f)(ii); (5)(d); (5)(f)
