Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5 Aiding or concealing a juvenile offender -- Trespass of a secure care facility -- Criminal penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(1): 80-5-103; 80-1-102; 80-1-102; 80-1-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(1)(a): 80-5-103 "Division" means the Division of Juvenile Justice Services created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(1)(b): 80-1-102 "Juvenile offender" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(1)(c): 80-1-102 "Secure care" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(1)(d): 80-1-102 "Secure care facility" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(2): An individual who commits any of the following offenses is guilty of a class A misdemeanor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(2)(a): entering, or attempting to enter, a building or enclosure appropriated to the use of juvenile offenders, without permission;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(2)(b): entering any premises belonging to a secure care facility and committing or attempting to commit a trespass or damage on the premises of a secure care facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(2)(c): willfully annoying or disturbing the peace and quiet of a secure care facility or of a juvenile offender in a secure care facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(3): (4) An individual is guilty of a third degree felony who:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(3)(a): (4) knowingly harbors or conceals a juvenile offender who has:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(3)(a)(i): escaped from secure care; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(3)(a)(ii): (4) as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(3)(a)(ii)(A): a facility or supervision; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(3)(a)(ii)(B): supervision of the division; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(3)(b): willfully aided or assisted a juvenile offender who has been lawfully committed to a secure care facility in escaping or attempting to escape from the secure care facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(4): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(4)(a): a juvenile offender absconds from a facility under this section when the juvenile offender:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(4)(a)(i): leaves the facility without permission; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(4)(a)(ii): fails to return at a prescribed time.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(4)(b): A juvenile offender absconds from supervision when the juvenile offender:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(4)(b)(i): changes the juvenile offender's residence from the residence that the juvenile offender reported to the division as the juvenile offender's correct address to another residence, without notifying the division or obtaining permission; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(4)(b)(ii): for the purpose of avoiding supervision:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(4)(b)(ii)(A): hides at a different location from the juvenile offender's reported residence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-311.5(4)(b)(ii)(B): leaves the juvenile offender's reported residence.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-312 Bail-jumping.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-312(1): A person is guilty of an offense when having been released on bail or on his own recognizance by court order or by other lawful authority upon condition that he subsequently appear personally upon a charge of an offense, he fails without just cause to appear at the time and place which have been lawfully designated for his appearance.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-312(2): An offense under this section is a felony of the third degree when the offense charged is a felony, a class B misdemeanor when the offense charged is a misdemeanor, and an infraction when the offense charged is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-313 Threatening elected officials -- Assault.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person commits assault on an elected official when he attempts or threatens, irrespective of a showing of immediate force or violence, to inflict bodily injury to the elected official with the intent to impede, intimidate, or interfere with the elected official in the performance of his official duties or with the intent to retaliate against the elected official because of the performance of his official duties.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-314 Threatening elected officials -- "Elected official" defined.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
As used in this section, "elected official" means:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-314(1): any elected official of the state, county, or city and includes the members of the official's immediate family;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-314(2): any temporary judge appointed to fill a vacant judicial position;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-314(3): any judge not yet retained by a retention election;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-314(4): any member of a school board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-314(5): (1) any person appointed to fill a vacant position of an elected official as defined in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-315 Threatening elected officials -- Penalties for assault.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Assault on an elected official is a felony of the third degree if bodily injury is attempted or occurs, otherwise the assault is a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-316 Influencing, impeding, or retaliating against a judge or member of the Board of Pardons and Parole or acting against a family member of a judge or a member of the Board of Pardons and Parole.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-316(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-316(1)(a): "Board member" means an appointed member of the Board of Pardons and Parole.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-316(1)(b): "Family member" means parents, spouse, surviving spouse, children, and siblings of a judge or board member.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-316(1)(c): "Judge" means judges of all courts of record and courts not of record and court commissioners.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-316(2): A person is guilty of a third degree felony if the person threatens to assault, kidnap, or murder a judge, a family member of a judge, a board member, or a family member of a board member with the intent to impede, intimidate, or interfere with the judge or board member while engaged in the performance of the judge's or board member's official duties or with the intent to retaliate against the judge or board member on account of the performance of those official duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-316(3): A person is guilty of a second degree felony if the person commits an assault on a judge, a family member of a judge, a board member, or a family member of a board member with the intent to impede, intimidate, or interfere with the judge or board member while engaged in the performance of the judge's or board member's official duties, or with the intent to retaliate against the judge or board member on account of the performance of those official duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-316(4): A person is guilty of a first degree felony if the person commits aggravated assault on a judge, a family member of a judge, a board member, or a family member of a board member with the intent to impede, intimidate, or interfere with the judge or board member while engaged in the performance of the judge's or board member's official duties or with the intent to retaliate against the judge or board member on account of the performance of those official duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-316(5): A person is guilty of a first degree felony if the person commits attempted murder on a family member of a judge or a family member of a board member with the intent to impede, intimidate, or interfere with the judge or board member while engaged in the performance of the judge's or board member's official duties or with the intent to retaliate against the judge or board member on account of the performance of those official duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-316(6): 76-5-202(2)(a)(xiii) A member of the Board of Pardons and Parole is an executive officer for purposes of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-317 Refusal to comply with order to evacuate or other orders issued in a local or state emergency -- Penalties.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-317(1): 53-2a-204; 53-2a-205 A person may not refuse to comply with an order to evacuate issued under this chapter or refuse to comply with any other order issued by the governor in a state of an emergency under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-317(2): A person who violates this section is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-318 Assault or threat of violence against child welfare worker -- Penalty.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-318(1): 76-5-102; 80-2-201; 76-5-107 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-318(1)(a): 76-5-102 "Assault" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-318(1)(b): 80-2-201 "Child welfare worker" means an employee of the Division of Child and Family Services created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-318(1)(c): 76-5-107 "Threat of violence" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-318(2): 77-7-15 An individual who commits an assault or threat of violence against a child welfare worker is guilty of a class A misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-318(2)(a): 77-7-15 the individual is not:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-318(2)(a)(i): 77-7-15 a prisoner or an individual detained under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-318(2)(a)(ii): a minor in the custody of or receiving services from a division within the Department of Human Services;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-318(2)(b): the individual knew that the victim was a child welfare worker; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-318(2)(c): the child welfare worker was acting within the scope of the child welfare worker's authority at the time of the assault or threat of violence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-318(3): 76-1-101.5 An individual who violates this section is guilty of a third degree felony if the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-318(3)(a): 76-1-101.5 causes substantial bodily injury, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-318(3)(b): acts intentionally or knowingly.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402 Misusing public money or public property.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(1): (1)(a)(iii) As used in this section, "authorized personal use" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(1)(a): (1)(a)(iii) the use of public property, for a personal matter, by a public servant if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(1)(a)(i): the public servant is authorized to use or possess the public property to fulfill the public servant's duties as a public servant;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(1)(a)(ii): the primary purpose of the public servant using or possessing the public property is to fulfill the public servant's duties as a public servant;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(1)(a)(iii): at the time the public servant uses the public property for a personal matter, a written policy of the public servant's public entity is in effect that authorizes the public servant to use or possess the public property for personal use in addition to the primary purpose of fulfilling the public servant's duties as a public servant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(1)(a)(iv): (1)(a)(iii) the public servant uses and possesses the public property in a lawful manner and in accordance with the policy described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(1)(b): incidental or de minimus use of public property for a personal matter by a public servant, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(1)(b)(i): the value provided to the public servant's public entity by the public servant's use or possession of the public property for a public purpose substantially outweighs the personal benefit received by the employee from the incidental use of the public property for a personal matter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(1)(b)(ii): the incidental or de minimus use of the public property for a personal matter is not prohibited by law or by the public servant's public entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(2): (2)(e) It is unlawful for a public servant to knowingly:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(2)(a): appropriate public money to the public servant's own use or benefit or to the use or benefit of another without authority of law;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(2)(b): loan or transfer public money without authority of law;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(2)(c): fail to keep public money in the public servant's possession until disbursed by authority of law;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(2)(d): deposit public money in a bank or with another person in violation of the written policy of the public servant's public entity or the requirements of law;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(2)(e): keep a false account or make a false entry or erasure in an account of, or relating to, public money;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(2)(f): (2)(e) fraudulently alter, falsify, conceal, or destroy an account described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(2)(g): refuse or omit to pay over, on demand, any public money in the public servant's custody or control, upon the presentation of a draft, order, or warrant drawn upon the public money by competent authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(2)(h): omit to transfer public money when the transfer is required by law;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(2)(i): omit or refuse to pay over, to any officer or person authorized by law to receive public money, public money received by the public servant under any duty imposed on the public servant by law;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(2)(j): damage or dispose of public property in violation of the written policy of the public servant's public entity or the requirements of law;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(2)(k): obtain or exercise unauthorized control of public property with the intent to deprive the owner of possession of the public property;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(2)(l): obtain or exercise unauthorized control of public property with the intent to temporarily appropriate, possess, use, or deprive the owner of possession of the public property;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(2)(m): appropriate public property to the public servant's own use or benefit or to the use or benefit of another without authority of law;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(2)(n): loan or transfer public property without authority of law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(2)(o): fail to keep public property in the public servant's possession until returned to the property owner, or disposed of or relinquished, in accordance with the written policy of the public servant's public entity and the requirements of law.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(3): (4); (2)(a); (i) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(4): (2)(a); (i) A violation of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(4)(a): the value of the public money exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(4)(b): the amount of the false account exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(4)(c): the amount falsely entered exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(4)(d): the amount that is the difference between the original amount and the fraudulently altered amount exceeds $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(4)(e): the amount falsely erased, fraudulently concealed, destroyed, or falsified in the account exceeds $5,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(5): (2)(j) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(5)(a): a class B misdemeanor, if the cost to repair or replace the public property is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(5)(b): a class A misdemeanor, if the cost to repair or replace the public property is $500 or more, but less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(5)(c): a felony of the third degree, if the cost to repair or replace the public property is $1,500 or more, but less than $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(5)(d): a felony of the second degree, if the cost to repair or replace the public property is $5,000 or more.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(6): (2)(k); (m); (n); (o) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(6)(a): a class B misdemeanor, if the value of the public property is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(6)(b): a class A misdemeanor, if the value of the public property is $500 or more, but less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(6)(c): a felony of the third degree, if the value of the public property is $1,500 or more, but less than $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(6)(d): a felony of the second degree, if the value of the public property is $5,000 or more.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(7): (2)(l) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(7)(a): a class C misdemeanor, if the value of the public property is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(7)(b): a class B misdemeanor, if the value of the public property is $500 or more, but less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(7)(c): a class A misdemeanor, if the value of the public property is $1,500 or more, but less than $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(7)(d): a felony of the third degree, if the value of the public property is $5,000 or more.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(8): (3); (7); (2); 76-8-404 In addition to the penalty described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(8)(a): 76-8-404 is subject to the penalties described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(8)(b): may not disburse public funds or access public accounts.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(9): (2)(j); (o)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(9)(a): (2)(j); (o) A public servant is not guilty of a violation of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(10): (2) It is not a defense to a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(10)(a): subsequent to the violation, a public entity modifies or adopts a policy or law, or takes other action, to retroactively authorize, approve, or ratify the conduct that constitutes a violation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-402(10)(b): a written policy of the public servant's public entity permits private use of the public property if it is proven, beyond a reasonable doubt, that the public servant did not comply with the written policy.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-403 Failure to keep and pay over public money.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Except as otherwise provided in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-404 Making profit from or misusing public money or public property -- Disqualification from office -- Criminal penalty.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A public officer, regardless of whether the public officer receives, safekeeps, transfers, disburses, or has a fiduciary relationship with public money, who makes a profit from or out of public money or public property, or who uses public money or public property in a manner or for a purpose not authorized by law and is convicted of a felony under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-405 Failure to pay over fine, forfeiture, or fee.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every public officer who receives any fine, forfeiture, or fee and refuses or neglects to pay it over within the time prescribed by law is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-406 Obstructing collection of revenue.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who willfully obstructs or hinders any public officer from collecting any revenue, taxes, or other sums of money in which the people of this state are interested, and which such officer is by law empowered to collect, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-407 Refusing to give tax assessment information, or giving false information.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who unlawfully refuses, upon demand, to give to any county assessor or deputy county assessor a list of his property subject to taxation, or to swear to such list, or who gives a false name, or fraudulently refuses to give his true name when demanded by the assessor in the discharge of his official duties, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-408 Giving false tax receipt or failing to give receipt.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who uses or gives any receipt, except that prescribed by law, as evidence of the payment for any tax or license of any kind, or who receives payment for the tax or license without delivering the receipt prescribed by law, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-409 Refusing to give tax assessor or tax or license collector list of, or denying access to, employees.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who, when requested by the assessor or collector of taxes or license fees, refuses to give to the assessor or collector the name and residence of each person in his employ, or to give the assessor or collector access to the building or place of employment, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-410 Doing business without license.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who commences or carries on any business, trade, profession, or calling, for the transaction or carrying on of which a license is required by any law, or by any county, city, or town ordinance, without taking out the license required by law or ordinance is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-411 Trafficking in warrants.
-------------------------------------------------------
No state, county, city, town, or district officer shall, either directly or indirectly, contract for or purchase any warrant or order issued by the state, county, city, town, or district of which he is an officer, at any discount whatever upon the sum due on the warrant or order, and, if any state, county, city, town, or district officer shall so contract for or purchase any such order or warrant on a discount, he is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-412 Stealing, destroying or mutilating public records by custodian.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every officer having the custody of any record, map, or book, or of any paper or proceedings of any court, filed or deposited in any public office, or placed in his hands for any purpose, who is guilty of stealing, willfully destroying, mutilating, defacing, altering, falsifying, removing, or secreting the whole or any part thereof, or who permits any other person so to do, is guilty of a felony of the third degree.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-413 Stealing, destroying or mutilating public records by one not custodian.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person, not an officer such as is referred to in the preceding section, who is guilty of any of the acts specified in that section is guilty of a class A misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-414 Recording false or forged instruments.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who knowingly procures or offers any false or forged instrument to be filed, registered, or recorded in any public office, which instrument, if genuine, might be filed or registered or recorded under any law of this state or of the United States, is guilty of a felony of the third degree.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-415 Damaging or removing monuments of official surveys.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who willfully injures, defaces, or removes any signal, monument, building, or appurtenance thereto, placed, erected, or used by persons engaged in the United States or state survey is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-416 Taking toll or maintaining road, bridge, or ferry without authority -- Refusal to pay lawful toll.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person who demands or receives compensation for the use of any bridge or ferry, or who sets up or keeps any road, bridge, or ferry, or constructed ford, for the purpose of receiving remuneration for its use without authority of law; and any person who refuses to pay on demand the compensation or fee authorized to be collected for use of a licensed toll road, bridge, ferry, or constructed ford after having used it is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-417 Tampering with official notice or proclamation.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who intentionally defaces, obliterates, tears down, or destroys any copy or transcript or extract from or of any law of the United States or of this state, or any proclamation, advertisement, or notice, set up at any place in this state by authority of any law of the United States or of this state, or by order of any court or of any public officer, before the expiration of the time for which the same was to remain set up, is guilty of an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-418 Damaging jails or other places of confinement.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-418(1): 80-1-102; 80-1-102; 80-1-102; 80-1-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-418(1)(a): 80-1-102 "Child" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-418(1)(b): 80-1-102 "Detention facility" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-418(1)(c): 80-1-102 "Secure care facility" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-418(1)(d): 80-1-102 "Shelter facility" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-418(2): A person who willfully and intentionally breaks down, pulls down, destroys, floods, or otherwise damages any public jail or other place of confinement, including a detention facility, a shelter facility, or a secure care facility, is guilty of a felony of the third degree.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-418(3): This section is applicable to a child who willfully and intentionally commits an offense against a public jail, a detention facility, a shelter facility, or a secure care facility.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-419 Damaging highways or bridges.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-419(1): Every person who intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly digs up, removes, displaces, breaks, or otherwise damages or destroys any public highway, or any private way laid out by authority of law, or any bridge upon the highway or private way is guilty of a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-419(2): Title 76, Utah Criminal Code If the violation of this section constitutes an offense subject to a greater penalty under another provision of


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-420 Removing or damaging road signs.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who intentionally or knowingly removes or injures any milepost or milestone or guidepost or any inscription on them, erected upon any highway, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-501 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-501(1): 78B-18a-102 "False statement" includes a false unsworn declaration, with "unsworn declaration" being defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-501(2): "Material" means capable of affecting the course or outcome of an official proceeding, unless the person who made the statement or provided the information retracts the statement or information before the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-501(2)(a): the end of the official proceeding in which the statement was made or the information was provided;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-501(2)(b): when it becomes manifest that the false or misleading nature of the statement or information has been or will be exposed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-501(2)(c): when the statement or information substantially affects the proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-501(3): (3)(a)(i); (3)(c)(i); (3)(c)(i) "Official proceeding" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-501(3)(a): (3)(a)(i) any proceeding before:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-501(3)(a)(i): a legislative, judicial, administrative, or other governmental body or official authorized by law to take evidence under oath or affirmation;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-501(3)(a)(ii): a notary; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-501(3)(a)(iii): (3)(a)(i) a person that takes evidence in connection with a proceeding described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-501(3)(b): any civil or administrative action, trial, examination under oath, administrative proceeding, or other civil or administrative adjudicative process; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-501(3)(c): (3)(c)(i); (3)(c)(i) an investigation or audit conducted by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-501(3)(c)(i): the Legislature, or a house, committee, subcommittee, or task force of the Legislature; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-501(3)(c)(ii): (3)(c)(i); (3)(c)(i) an employee or independent contractor of an entity described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-502 False or inconsistent material statements.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person is guilty of a felony of the second degree if in any official proceeding:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-502(1): He makes a false material statement under oath or affirmation or swears or affirms the truth of a material statement previously made and he does not believe the statement to be true; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-502(2): He makes inconsistent material statements under oath or affirmation, both within the period of limitations, one of which is false and not believed by him to be true.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-503 False or inconsistent statements.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-503(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-503(1)(a): the person makes a false statement under oath or affirmation or swears or affirms the truth of the statement previously made and the person does not believe the statement to be true if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-503(1)(a)(i): the falsification occurs in an official proceeding, or is made with a purpose to mislead a public servant in performing the public servant's official functions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-503(1)(a)(ii): the statement is one that is authorized by law to be sworn or affirmed before a notary or other person authorized to administer oaths; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-503(1)(b): the person makes inconsistent statements under oath or affirmation, both within the period of limitations, one of which is false and not believed by the person to be true.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-503(2): (1); 36-12-9.5 Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-503(3): A person is not guilty under this section if the person retracts the falsification before it becomes manifest that the falsification has been or will be exposed.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504 Written false statement.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504(1): An actor commits the offense of written false statement if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504(1)(a): the actor makes a statement that the actor does not believe to be true on or under a form bearing a notification authorized by law to the effect that false statements made therein are punishable; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504(1)(b): with intent to deceive a public servant in the performance of the public servant's official function, the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504(1)(b)(i): makes a written false statement that the actor does not believe to be true;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504(1)(b)(ii): knowingly creates a false impression in a written application for a pecuniary or other benefit by omitting information necessary to prevent a statement in the application from being misleading;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504(1)(b)(iii): submits or invites reliance on a writing that the actor knows to be lacking in authenticity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504(1)(b)(iv): submits or invites reliance on a sample, specimen, map, boundary mark, or other object that the actor knows to be false.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504(2): (2)(b); (1); (1); 77-38b-204
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504(2)(a): (2)(b); (1) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504(2)(b): (1); 77-38b-204 A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504(3): It is not an offense under this section if the actor retracts the falsification before it becomes manifest that the falsification was or would be exposed.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.5 False statements -- Preliminary hearing.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.5(1): A person is guilty of a class A misdemeanor if the person makes a false statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.5(1)(a): which the person does not believe to be true;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.5(1)(b): that the person has reason to believe will be used in a preliminary hearing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.5(1)(c): after having been notified either verbally or in writing that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.5(1)(c)(i): the statement may be used in a preliminary hearing before a magistrate or a judge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.5(1)(c)(ii): if the person makes a false statement after having received this notification, he is subject to a criminal penalty.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.5(2): (1) Notification under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.6 False or misleading information.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.6(1): Title 77, Chapter 42, Utah White Collar Crime Offender Registry A person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor if the person, not under oath or affirmation, intentionally or knowingly provides false or misleading material information to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.6(1)(a): an officer of the court for the purpose of influencing a criminal proceeding; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.6(1)(b): Title 77, Chapter 42, Utah White Collar Crime Offender Registry the Bureau of Criminal Identification for the purpose of obtaining a certificate of eligibility for:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.6(1)(b)(i): expungement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.6(1)(b)(ii): Title 77, Chapter 42, Utah White Collar Crime Offender Registry removal of the person's name from the White Collar Crime Registry created in
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.6(2): For the purposes of this section "officer of the court" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.6(2)(a): prosecutor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.6(2)(b): judge;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.6(2)(c): court clerk;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.6(2)(d): interpreter;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.6(2)(e): presentence investigator;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.6(2)(f): probation officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.6(2)(g): parole officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.6(2)(h): any other person reasonably believed to be gathering information for a criminal proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-504.6(3): 76-8-306 This section does not apply under circumstances amounting to Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-505 False or inconsistent statements -- Proof of falsity of statements -- Irregularities no defense.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-505(1): 76-8-502(1); 76-8-503(1)(a) On any prosecution for a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-505(2): 76-8-502(2); 76-8-503(1)(b) In prosecutions for violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-505(3): It is not a defense to a charge under this part that the oath or affirmation was administered or taken in an irregular manner.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-506 Providing false information to law enforcement officers, government agencies, or specified professionals.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor if he:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-506(1): knowingly gives or causes to be given false information to any peace officer or any state or local government agency or personnel with a purpose of inducing the recipient of the information to believe that another has committed an offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-506(2): knowingly gives or causes to be given to any peace officer, any state or local government agency or personnel, or to any person licensed in this state to practice social work, psychology, or marriage and family therapy, information concerning the commission of an offense, knowing that the offense did not occur or knowing that he has no information relating to the offense or danger; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-506(3): knowingly gives or causes to be given false information to any state or local government agency or personnel with a purpose of inducing a change in the person's licensing or certification status or the licensing or certification status of another.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-507 False personal information to peace officer.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-507(1): A person commits a class C misdemeanor if, with intent of misleading a peace officer as to the person's identity, birth date, or place of residence, the person knowingly gives a false name, birth date, or address to a peace officer in the lawful discharge of the peace officer's official duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-507(2): A person commits a class A misdemeanor if, with the intent of leading a peace officer to believe that the person is another actual person, he gives the name, birth date, or address of another person to a peace officer acting in the lawful discharge of the peace officer's official duties.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508 Tampering with witness -- Receiving or soliciting a bribe.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508(1): A person is guilty of the third degree felony of tampering with a witness if, believing that an official proceeding or investigation is pending or about to be instituted, or with the intent to prevent an official proceeding or investigation, he attempts to induce or otherwise cause another person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508(1)(a): testify or inform falsely;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508(1)(b): withhold any testimony, information, document, or item;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508(1)(c): elude legal process summoning him to provide evidence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508(1)(d): absent himself from any proceeding or investigation to which he has been summoned.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508(2): (1) A person is guilty of the third degree felony of soliciting or receiving a bribe as a witness if he solicits, accepts, or agrees to accept any benefit in consideration of his doing any of the acts specified under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508(3): The offense of tampering with a witness or soliciting or receiving a bribe under this section does not merge with any other substantive offense committed in the course of committing any offense under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.3 Retaliation against a witness, victim, or informant.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.3(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.3(1)(a): A person is "closely associated" with a witness, victim, or informant if the person is a member of the witness', victim's, or informant's family, has a close personal or business relationship with the witness or victim, or resides in the same household with the witness, victim, or informant.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.3(1)(b): "Harm" means physical, emotional, or economic injury or damage to a person or to his property, reputation, or business interests.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.3(2): A person is guilty of the third degree felony of retaliation against a witness, victim, or informant if, believing that an official proceeding or investigation is pending, is about to be instituted, or has been concluded, he:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.3(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.3(2)(a)(i): makes a threat of harm; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.3(2)(a)(ii): causes harm; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.3(2)(b): directs the threat or action:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.3(2)(b)(i): against a witness or an informant regarding any official proceeding, a victim of any crime, or any person closely associated with a witness, victim, or informant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.3(2)(b)(ii): as retaliation or retribution against the witness, victim, or informant.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.3(3): This section does not prohibit any person from seeking any legal redress to which the person is otherwise entitled.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.3(4): The offense of retaliation against a witness, victim, or informant under this section does not merge with any other substantive offense committed in the course of committing any offense under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.5 Tampering with juror -- Retaliation against juror -- Penalty.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.5(1): As used in this section "juror" means a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.5(1)(a): summoned for jury duty; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.5(1)(b): serving as or having served as a juror or alternate juror in any court or as a juror on any grand jury of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.5(2): A person is guilty of tampering with a juror if he attempts to or actually influences a juror in the discharge of the juror's service by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.5(2)(a): communicating with the juror by any means, directly or indirectly, except for attorneys in lawful discharge of their duties in open court;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.5(2)(b): offering, conferring, or agreeing to confer any benefit upon the juror; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.5(2)(c): communicating to the juror a threat that a reasonable person would believe to be a threat to injure:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.5(2)(c)(i): the juror's person or property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.5(2)(c)(ii): the person or property of any other person in whose welfare the juror is interested.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.5(3): A person is guilty of tampering with a juror if he commits any unlawful act in retaliation for anything done by the juror in the discharge of the juror's service:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.5(3)(a): to the juror's person or property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.5(3)(b): to the person or property of any other person in whose welfare the juror is interested.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-508.5(4): Tampering with a juror is a third degree felony.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-509 Extortion or bribery to dismiss criminal proceeding.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-509(1): A person is guilty of a felony of the second degree if by the use of force or by any threat which would constitute a means of committing the crime of theft by extortion under this code, if the threat were employed to obtain property, or by promise of any reward or pecuniary benefits, he attempts to induce an alleged victim of a crime to secure the dismissal of or to prevent the filing of a criminal complaint, indictment, or information.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-509(2): "Victim," as used in this section, includes a child or other person under the care or custody of a parent or guardian.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-510.5 Tampering with evidence -- Definitions -- Elements -- Penalties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-510.5(1): As used in this section, "thing or item" includes any document, record book, paper, file, electronic compilation, or other evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-510.5(2): A person is guilty of tampering with evidence if, believing that an official proceeding or investigation is pending or about to be instituted, or with the intent to prevent an official proceeding or investigation or to prevent the production of any thing or item which reasonably would be anticipated to be evidence in the official proceeding or investigation, the person knowingly or intentionally:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-510.5(2)(a): alters, destroys, conceals, or removes any thing or item with the purpose of impairing the veracity or availability of the thing or item in the proceeding or investigation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-510.5(2)(b): makes, presents, or uses any thing or item which the person knows to be false with the purpose of deceiving a public servant or any other party who is or may be engaged in the proceeding or investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-510.5(3): (2); 76-8-306 Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-510.5(4): (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-510.5(4)(a): Tampering with evidence is a third degree felony if the offense is committed in conjunction with an official proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-510.5(4)(b): (4)(a) Any violation of this section except under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-511 Falsification or alteration of government record -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor if under circumstances not amounting to an offense subject to a greater penalty underUtah Code Annotated § 76-8-511(1): knowingly makes a false entry in or false alteration of anything belonging to, received, or kept by the government for information or record, or required by law to be kept for information of the government;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-511(2): (1) presents or uses anything knowing it to be false and with a purpose that it be taken as a genuine part of information or records referred to in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-511(3): intentionally destroys, conceals, or otherwise impairs the verity or availability of the information or records, knowing that the destruction, concealment, or impairment is unlawful.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-512 Impersonation of officer.
--------------------------------------------------------
A person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor who:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-512(1): impersonates a public servant or a peace officer with intent to deceive another or with intent to induce another to submit to his pretended official authority or to rely upon his pretended official act;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-512(2): falsely states he is a public servant or a peace officer with intent to deceive another or to induce another to submit to his pretended official authority or to rely upon his pretended official act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-512(3): displays or possesses without authority any badge, identification card, other form of identification, any restraint device, or the uniform of any state or local governmental entity, or a reasonable facsimile of any of these items, with the intent to deceive another or with the intent to induce another to submit to his pretended official authority or to rely upon his pretended official act.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-513 False judicial or official notice.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
A person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor who, with a purpose to procure the compliance of another with a request made by the person, knowingly sends, mails, or delivers to the person a notice or other writing which has no judicial or other sanction but which in its format or appearance simulates a summons, complaint, court order, or process, or an insignia, seal, or printed form of a federal, state, or local government or an instrumentality thereof, or is otherwise calculated to induce a belief that it does have a judicial or other official sanction.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-515 Impersonation of a utility officer or employee.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-515(1): 76-6-106.3; 76-8-901; 53-2a-102; 76-1-101.5
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-515(1)(a): 76-6-106.3; 76-8-901; 53-2a-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-515(1)(a)(i): 76-6-106.3 "Critical infrastructure facility" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-515(1)(a)(ii): 76-8-901 "Sabotage" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-515(1)(a)(iii): 53-2a-102 "Terrorism" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-515(1)(a)(iv): "Utility" means a private or governmental entity operating a critical infrastructure facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-515(1)(b): 76-1-101.5 Terms defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-515(2): An actor commits impersonation of a utility officer or employee if the actor, without authority from a utility:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-515(2)(a): intends to lead an individual to believe that the actor is acting on behalf of the utility in an official capacity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-515(2)(b): attempts to act on behalf of the utility.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-515(3): (2); (3)(a); (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-515(3)(a): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-515(3)(b): (3)(a); (2); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-601 Wrongful commencement of action in justice court.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any party to any suit or proceeding, and any attorney or agent for the party, who knowingly commences, prosecutes, or maintains any action, suit, or proceeding in any justice court other than as provided in Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-602 Assuming liability for conferring jurisdiction upon justice court judge.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person who binds himself, or voluntarily becomes liable jointly or jointly and severally with any other person, for the purpose of conferring jurisdiction of any cause upon any justice court judge in any precinct or city that would be without jurisdiction except for the liability of the joint obligor, and any person who induces a person to assume the liability for the purpose of conferring jurisdiction upon the justice court judge, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-603 Wrongful attachment by justice court judge -- Liability.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is unlawful for any justice court judge to issue any writ of attachment, and for any party, agent, or attorney of the party, to advise, induce, or procure the issuance thereof, in any action, suit, or proceeding before the affidavit  is filed, or where the affidavit filed does not conform substantially with the requirements of Rule 64C of the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section is guilty of a class B misdemeanor and shall be liable to the person whose property, credits, money, or earnings are attached for double the value of the attached property, together with all costs paid by him, and all damages incurred in the attachment proceedings.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-701 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
For the purposes of this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-701(1): "Chief administrative officer" means the president of an institution of higher education or a person designated by the president.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-701(2): "Enter" means intrusion of the entire body.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-701(3): 53B-3-102 "Institution" or "institution of higher education" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-701(3)(a): 53B-3-102 a state institution of higher education as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-701(3)(b): a private institution of higher education in the state accredited by a regional or national accrediting agency recognized by the United States Department of Education.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-702 Purpose.
---------------------------------------
It is the purpose of this part to:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-702(1): supplement and clarify the power vested in the governing board of each institution of higher education; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-702(2): regulate, conduct, and enforce law and order on property owned, operated, or controlled by each institution of higher education.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703 Criminal trespass upon an institution of higher education.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(1): (1)(a); 53B-3-102; (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(1)(a): A chief administrative officer may order a person to leave property that is owned, operated, or controlled by an institution of higher education if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(1)(a)(i): acts or if the chief administrative officer has reasonable cause to believe that the person intends to act to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(1)(a)(i)(A): cause injury to a person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(1)(a)(i)(B): cause damage to property;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(1)(a)(i)(C): commit a crime;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(1)(a)(i)(D): interfere with the peaceful conduct of the activities of the institution;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(1)(a)(i)(E): violate any rule or regulation of the institution if that rule or regulation is not in conflict with state law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(1)(a)(i)(F): disrupt the institution, its pupils, or the institution's activities; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(1)(a)(ii): is reckless as to whether the person's actions will cause fear for the safety of another.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(1)(b): (1)(a) A person is guilty of criminal trespass upon an institution of higher education if the person enters or remains on property that is owned, operated, or controlled by an institution of higher education after being ordered to leave under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(1)(c): 53B-3-102; (1)(a) The mere carrying or possession of a firearm on the campus of a state institution of higher education, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(2): A person is guilty of criminal trespass upon an institution of higher education if the person enters or remains without authorization upon property that is owned, operated, or controlled by an institution of higher education if notice against entry or remaining has been given by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(2)(a): personal communication to the person by the chief administrative officer or a person with apparent authority to act for the institution;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(2)(b): the posting of signs reasonably likely to come to the attention of trespassers;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(2)(c): fencing or other enclosure obviously designed to exclude trespassers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(2)(d): a current order of suspension or expulsion.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(3): (1); (2) If an employee or student of an institution of higher education is ordered to leave under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-703(4): 76-8-717 A person who violates this section shall be punished as provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-705 Willful interference with lawful activities of students or faculty.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person is guilty of a class C misdemeanor if, on property that is owned, operated, or controlled by an institution of higher education, the person willfully:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-705(1): denies to a student, school official, employee, or invitee lawful:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-705(1)(a): freedom of movement;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-705(1)(b): use of the property or facilities; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-705(1)(c): ingress or egress to the institution's physical facilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-705(2): impedes a faculty or staff member of the institution in the lawful performance of the member's duties; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-705(3): impedes a student of the institution in the lawful pursuit of the student's educational activities.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-707 Assistance by local authorities.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-707(1): If, in the judgment of the chief administrative officer of any institution of higher education, or in the judgment of any officer or employee designated by him to maintain order on a campus or related facility, the law enforcement agency or security department of that institution lacks sufficient manpower to deal effectively with any condition of unrest existing or developing on a campus or related facility of the institution, he may call for assistance from the county sheriff of the county or any city law enforcement agency or from the Department of Public Safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-707(2): Upon receipt of the request, the county sheriff, city law enforcement agency, or Department of Public Safety must render all necessary assistance without expense to the institution of higher education.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-707(3): All personnel while rendering assistance shall serve under the general direction of the chief administrative officer of the institution or the officer or employee designated by him to maintain order on the campus or related facility.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-709 Enforcement of laws by local agencies not limited.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Nothing in this part shall limit:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-709(1): the right or duty of any local law enforcement agency to enforce the law which it had prior to this enactment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-709(2): the right of any state or local law enforcement agency to enforce the laws of this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-716 Request for assistance from state and local law enforcement authorities.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If, in the judgment of the chief administrative officer of any school or institution of higher education, his agent, or representative, the police or security department of that institution lacks sufficient manpower to deal effectively with any condition of unrest existing or developing on a campus or facility of the institution, he may request assistance from state and local law enforcement authorities. All state and local law enforcement officers while rendering assistance shall serve in co-operation with the chief administrative officer of the institution or his agent or representative and without expense to the institution.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-717 Violations -- Classifications of offenses.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Except as otherwise provided, a person found guilty of a violation of this part shall be punished as follows:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-717(1): upon the first and second conviction, the person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-717(2): if the person has previously been convicted two or more times of a violation of this part, the person is guilty of a class A misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-801 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
For the purpose of this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-801(1): "Highway" includes any private or public street, way, or other place used for travel to or from property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-801(2): "Highway commissioners" means any individual, board, or other body having authority under then existing law to discontinue the use of the highway which it is desired to restrict or close to public use and travel.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-801(3): "Public utility" includes any pipeline, gas, electric, heat, water, oil, sewer, telephone, telegraph, radio, railway, railroad, airplane, transportation communication or other system by whomsoever owned or operated for public use.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-802 Destruction of property to interfere with preparation for defense or war.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Whoever intentionally destroys, impairs, injures, interferes, or tampers with real or personal property with reasonable grounds to believe that the act will hinder, delay, or interfere with the preparation of the United States or of any of the states for defense or for war, or with the prosecution of war by the United States, shall be guilty of a felony of the second degree.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-803 Causing or omitting to note defects in articles used in preparation for defense or war.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Whoever intentionally makes or causes to be made or omits to note on inspection any defect in any article or thing with reasonable grounds to believe that the article or thing is intended to be used in connection with the preparation of the United States or any of the states for defense or for war, or for the prosecution of war by the United States, or that the article or thing is one of a number of similar articles or things, some of which are intended so to be used, shall be guilty of a felony of the third degree.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-804 Attempts to commit crimes of sabotage.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Whoever attempts to commit any of the crimes defined by this part shall be punishable for the attempt as prescribed in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-805 Conspiracy to commit crimes of sabotage.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
If two or more persons conspire to commit any crime defined by this part each of the persons is guilty of conspiracy and subject to the same punishment as if he had committed the crime which he conspired to commit, whether or not any act be done in furtherance of the conspiracy. It shall not constitute any defense or ground of suspension of judgment, sentence, or punishment on behalf of any person prosecuted under this section that any of his fellow conspirators has been acquitted, has not been arrested or convicted, or is amenable to justice or has been pardoned or otherwise discharged before or after conviction.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-806 Facts kept secret until complaint filed.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
A person may not make public any evidence of fact or the name of the person accused of violating the provisions of Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-807 Posting of signs at war or defense facilities -- Entering posted premises without permission.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-807(1): Any individual, partnership, association, corporation, municipal corporation, or state or any political subdivision thereof engaged in, or preparing to engage in, the manufacture, transportation or storage of any product to be used in the preparation of the United States or of any of the states for defense or for war or in the prosecution of war by the United States, or the manufacture, transportation, distribution or storage of gas, oil, coal, electricity or water, or any natural or artificial persons operating any public utility, whose property, except where it fronts on water or where there are entrances for railway cars, vehicles, persons, or things, is surrounded by a fence or wall, or a fence or wall and buildings, may post around his or its property at each gate, entrance, dock, or railway entrance and every one hundred feet of water front a sign reading "No Entry Without Permission."  The sign shall also designate a point of entrance or place where application may be made for permission to enter, and permission shall not be denied to any loyal citizen who has a valid right to enter.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-807(2): (1) Any person willfully entering property enumerated in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-808 Detention and arrest without warrant of unauthorized persons on posted premises.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any peace officer or any person employed as watchman, guard, or in a supervisory capacity on premises posted as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-809 Closing or restricting use of highways abutting defense or war facilities -- Posting of notices.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any individual, partnership, association, corporation, municipal corporation or state or any political subdivision thereof engaged in or preparing to engage in the manufacture, transportation or storage of any product to be used in the preparation of the United States or any of the states for defense or for war or in the prosecution of war by the United States, or in the manufacture, transportation, distribution or storage of gas, oil, coal, electricity or water, or any of said natural or artificial persons operating any public utility who has property so used which he or it believes will be endangered if public use and travel is not restricted or prohibited on one or more highways or parts thereof upon which the property abuts, may petition the highway commissioners of any city, town, or county to close one or more of the highways or parts thereof to public use and travel or to restrict by order the use and travel upon one or more of the highways or parts thereof.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-810 Violation of order relating to use of highways -- Classification of offense.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Whoever violates any order made under the immediate preceding section shall be guilty of a class C misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-811 Bargaining rights of employees not impaired by sabotage prevention laws.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Nothing in this part shall be construed to impair, curtail, or destroy the rights of employees and their representatives to self organize, to form, join, or assist labor organizations, to bargain collectively through representatives of their own choosing, and to engage in concerted activities, for the purpose of collective bargaining or other mutual aid or protection as provided by state or federal laws.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-901 "Criminal syndicalism" and "sabotage" defined.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
For the purpose of this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-901(1): "Criminal syndicalism" is the doctrine which advocates crime, violence, force, arson, destruction of property, sabotage, or other unlawful acts or methods, as a means of accomplishing or effecting industrial or political ends, or as a means of effecting industrial or political revolution.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-901(2): "Sabotage" means the unlawful and intentional damage or injury to, or destruction of, real or personal property, in any form whatsoever, of any employer or owner by his employees, or by any employer, or by any person at the instance of any employer, or at the instance, request, or instigation of employees, or any other person.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-902 Advocating criminal syndicalism or sabotage.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person who by word of mouth or writing advocates, suggests, or teaches the duty, necessity, propriety, or expediency of crime, criminal syndicalism or sabotage, or who advocates, suggests or teaches the duty, necessity, propriety, or expediency or doing any act of violence, the destruction of or damage to any property, the bodily injury to any person, or the commission of any crime or unlawful act as a means of accomplishing or effecting any industrial or political ends, change or revolution, or who prints, publishes, edits, or issues, or knowingly circulates, sells, or distributes, or publicly displays, any books, pamphlets, paper, handbill, poster, document, or written or printed matter in any form whatsoever, containing, advocating, advising, suggesting, or teaching crime, criminal syndicalism, sabotage, the doing of any act of violence, the destruction of or damage to any property, the injury to any person, or the commission of any crime or unlawful act, as a means of accomplishing, effecting, or bringing about any industrial or political ends or change, or as a means of accomplishing, effecting, or bringing about any industrial or political revolution, or who openly or at all attempts to justify by word of mouth or writing the commission or the attempt to commit sabotage, any act of violence, the destruction of or damage to any property, the injury of any person, or the commission of any crime or unlawful act, with the intent to exemplify, spread, or teach or suggest criminal syndicalism, or organizes, or helps to organize, or becomes a member of, or voluntarily assembles with, any society or assemblage of persons formed to teach or advocate, or which teaches, advocates, or suggests the doctrine of criminal syndicalism or sabotage, or the necessity, propriety, or expediency of doing any act of violence or the commission of any crime or unlawful act as a means of accomplishing or effecting any industrial or political ends, change or revolution, is guilty of a felony of the third degree.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-903 Assembly for advocating criminal syndicalism or sabotage.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The assembly or consorting of two or more persons for the purpose of advocating, teaching, or suggesting the doctrine of criminal syndicalism, or to advocate, teach, suggest or encourage sabotage, or the duty, necessity, propriety or expediency of doing any act of violence, the destruction of or damage to any property, the bodily injury to any person, or the commission of any crime or unlawful act as a means of accomplishing or effecting any industrial or political ends, change or revolution, is hereby declared unlawful, and every person voluntarily participating therein, or by his presence aiding and instigating the same is guilty of a felony of the third degree.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-904 Permitting use of property for assembly advocating criminal syndicalism or sabotage.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The owner, lessee, agent, superintendent, or person in charge or occupation of any place, building, room, or structure, who knowingly permits therein any assembly or consorting of persons prohibited by the provisions of Section
