Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1201 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1201(1): "Client" means a person who receives or has received public assistance.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1201(2): 35A-3-102 "Overpayment" has the same meaning as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1201(3): 26B-9-101 "Provider" has the same meaning as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1201(4): 35A-1-102 "Public assistance" has the same meaning as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1202 Application of part.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1202(1): Title 26B, Chapter 3, Part 11, Utah False Claims Act This part does not apply to offenses by providers under the state's Medicaid program that are actionable under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1202(2): 35A-1-503
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1202(2)(a): 35A-1-503 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1202(2)(b): The repayment of funds or other benefits obtained in violation of the provisions of this chapter shall not constitute a defense or grounds for dismissal of a criminal action.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1203 Disclosure required -- Penalty.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1203(1): Each person who applies for public assistance shall disclose to the state agency administering the public assistance each fact that may materially affect the determination of the person's eligibility to receive public assistance, including the person's current:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1203(1)(a): marital status;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1203(1)(b): household composition;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1203(1)(c): employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1203(1)(d): earned and unearned income, as defined by rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1203(1)(e): receipt of monetary and in-kind gifts that may affect the person's eligibility;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1203(1)(f): assets that may affect the person's eligibility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1203(1)(g): any other material fact or change in circumstance that may affect the determination of that person's eligibility to receive public assistance benefits, or may affect the amount of benefits for which the person is eligible.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1203(2): (1); 76-8-1206 A person applying for public assistance who intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly fails to disclose a material fact required to be disclosed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1203(3): (1); 76-8-1206 With the exception of a client receiving public assistance from the Department of Workforce Services or the Department of Health, a client who intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly fails to disclose to the state agency administering the public assistance a change in a material fact required to be disclosed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1203(4): (1); 76-8-1206 A client who intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly fails to disclose to the Department of Workforce Services or the Department of Health at the time of a review or recertification, whichever comes first, a change in a material fact required to be disclosed under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1204 Disclosure by provider required -- Penalty.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1204(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1204(1)(a): Any provider who solicits, requests, or receives, actually or constructively, any payment or contribution through a payment, assessment, gift, devise, bequest, or other means, directly or indirectly, from a client or client's family shall notify the state agency administering the public assistance the client is receiving of the amount of payment or contribution in writing within 10 days after receiving that payment or contribution.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1204(1)(b): If the payment or contribution is to be made under an agreement, written or oral, the provider shall notify the state agency administering the public assistance the client is receiving of the payment or contribution within 10 days after entering into the agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1204(2): 76-8-1206 Any person who intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly fails to notify the state agency administering the public assistance the client is receiving as required by this section is guilty of public assistance fraud as provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1205 Public assistance fraud defined.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Each of the following persons, who intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly commits any of the following acts, is guilty of public assistance fraud:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1205(1): 35A-1-102 a person who uses, transfers, acquires, traffics in, falsifies, or possesses SNAP benefits as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1205(2): 35A-1-102 a person who fraudulently misappropriates funds exchanged for SNAP benefits as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1205(3): a person who receives an unauthorized payment as a result of acts described in this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1205(4): 76-8-1203; 76-8-1204 a provider who receives payment or a client who receives benefits after failing to comply with any applicable requirement in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1205(5): a provider who files a claim for payment under a state or federally funded public assistance program for goods or services not provided to or for a client of that program;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1205(6): a provider who files or falsifies a claim, report, or document required by state or federal law, rule, or provider agreement for goods or services not authorized under the state or federally funded public assistance program for which the goods or services were provided;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1205(7): a provider who fails to credit the state for payments received from other sources;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1205(8): a provider who bills a client or a client's family for goods or services not provided, or bills in an amount greater than allowed by law or rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1205(9): a client who, while receiving public assistance, acquires income or resources in excess of the amount the client previously reported to the state agency administering the public assistance, and fails to notify the state agency to which the client previously reported within 10 days after acquiring the excess income or resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1205(10): 76-8-1203; 76-8-1204; 35A-3-102 a person who fails to act as required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1205(11): 76-8-1203; 76-8-1204 a person who obtains an overpayment by violation of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1206 Penalties for public assistance fraud.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1206(1): The severity of the offense of public assistance fraud is classified in accordance with the value of payments, assistance, or other benefits received, misappropriated, claimed, or applied for as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1206(1)(a): second degree felony if the value is or exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1206(1)(b): third degree felony if the value is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1206(1)(c): class A misdemeanor if the value is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1206(1)(d): class B misdemeanor if the value is less than $500.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1206(2): (1) For purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1206(3): 35A-1-102 Incidents of trafficking in SNAP benefits as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1207 Legal actions -- Evidence -- Value of benefits -- Repayment no defense to criminal action.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In any criminal action pursuant to this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1207(1): a paid state warrant made to the order of a party or a payment made through an electronic benefit card issued to a party constitutes prima facie evidence that the party received financial assistance from the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1207(2): all of the records in the custody of the department relating to the application for, verification of, issuance of, receipt of, and use of public assistance constitute records of regularly conducted activity within the meaning of the exceptions to the hearsay rule of evidence;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1207(3): the value of the benefits received shall be based on the ordinary or usual charge for similar benefits in the private sector; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1207(4): the repayment of funds or other benefits obtained in violation of the provisions of this part constitutes no defense to, or ground for dismissal of, that action.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1301 False statements regarding unemployment compensation -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1301(1)(b)(ii): a class A misdemeanor when the value of the money obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1301(1)(b)(iii): a third degree felony when the value of the money obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1301(1)(b)(iv): a second degree felony when the value of the money obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $5,000.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1301(2)(b)(i): a class B misdemeanor when the value of the money obtained or sought to be obtained is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1301(2)(b)(ii): a class A misdemeanor when the value of the money obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1301(2)(b)(iii): a third degree felony when the value of the money obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1301(2)(b)(iv): a second degree felony when the value of the money obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $5,000.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1301(4)(a): 35A-4-312; Title 35A, Chapter 4, Employment Security Act as an employee of the Department of Workforce Services, in willful violation of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1401 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1401(1): "Chief administrator" means the principal of a school or the chief administrator of a school that does not have a principal, and includes the administrator's designee or representative.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1401(2): "School" means an elementary school or a secondary school that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1401(2)(a): is a public or private school; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1401(2)(b): provides instruction for one or more of the grades kindergarten through 12.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1402 Disruption of activities in or near school building -- Failure to leave -- Reentry -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1402(1): (1); (2); (1)(a) In the absence of a local ordinance or other controlling law governing the conduct described in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1402(1)(a): by his or her presence or acts, materially disrupts the peaceful conduct of school activities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1402(1)(b): (1)(a) remains upon the place under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1402(2): (1); (2)(b); (1); (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1402(2)(a): (1); (2)(b) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1402(2)(b): (1); (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1402(2)(b)(i): (1) The first and second violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1402(2)(b)(ii): (1) A third and any subsequent violations of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1403 Evading law enforcement by going onto school property -- Penalty -- Restitution.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1403(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1403(1)(a): "School" means any public or private kindergarten, elementary, or secondary school through grade 12, including all buildings and property of the school.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1403(1)(b): "School property" means real property:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1403(1)(b)(i): that is owned or occupied by a public or private school; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1403(1)(b)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1403(1)(b)(ii)(A): that is temporarily occupied by students for a school-related activity or program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1403(1)(b)(ii)(B): regarding which, during the time the activity or program is being conducted, the main use of the real property is allocated to participants in the activity or program.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1403(2): A person is guilty of the class A misdemeanor of evading law enforcement while on school property, if the person enters onto school property when:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1403(2)(a): students are attending the school or students are participating in any school-related activity or program on school property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1403(2)(b): the person is in the act of fleeing or evading, or attempting to flee or evade, pursuit or apprehension by any peace officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1403(3): It is not a defense that the person did not know that the person had entered onto school property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1403(4): As a part of the sentence for violation of this section, the court shall order the defendant to reimburse the school for costs incurred by the school in responding to the defendant's presence on the school property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1403(5): 41-6a-210; 76-8-305.5 The offense under this section of evading law enforcement while on school property is a separate offense from a violation of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1403(5)(a): 41-6a-210 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-8-1403(5)(b): 76-8-305.5 Section


Utah Code Annotated - Title 76 - Chapter 9 - Offenses Against Public Order and Decency
**************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-101 Riot -- Penalties.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-101(1): An individual is guilty of riot if the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-101(1)(a): simultaneously with two or more other individuals engages in violent conduct, knowingly or recklessly creating a substantial risk of causing public alarm;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-101(1)(b): assembles with two or more other individuals with the purpose of engaging, soon thereafter, in violent conduct, knowing, that two or more other individuals in the assembly have the same purpose; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-101(1)(c): assembles with two or more other individuals with the purpose of committing an offense against a person, or the property of another person who the individual supposes to be guilty of a violation of law, believing that two or more other individuals in the assembly have the same purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-101(2): (1); (2) Any individual who refuses to comply with a lawful order to withdraw prior to, during, or immediately following a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-101(3): (4) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-101(4): 76-1-101.5 Riot is a third degree felony if, in the course of the conduct:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-101(4)(a): the individual causes substantial or serious bodily injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-101(4)(b): the individual causes substantial property damage or commits arson; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-101(4)(c): 76-1-101.5 the individual was in possession of a dangerous weapon as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-101(5): (4) An individual arrested for a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-101(6): (4); 77-38b-205 The court shall order a defendant convicted under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102 Disorderly conduct.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(1): 52-4-103 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(1)(a): 52-4-103 "Official meeting" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(1)(a)(i): 52-4-103 a meeting, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(1)(a)(ii): a meeting of the Legislature, the Utah Senate, the Utah House of Representatives, a legislative caucus, or any committee, task force, working group, or other organization in the state legislative branch; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(1)(a)(iii): a meeting of an entity created by the Utah Constitution, Utah Code, Utah administrative rule, legislative rule, or a written rule or policy of the Legislative Management Committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(1)(b): "Public place" means a place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(1)(b)(i): streets or highways; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(1)(b)(ii): the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, public buildings, public facilities, transport facilities, and shops.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(2): An individual is guilty of disorderly conduct if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(2)(a): the individual refuses to comply with the lawful order of a law enforcement officer to move from a public place or an official meeting, or knowingly creates a hazardous or physically offensive condition, by any act that serves no legitimate purpose; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(2)(b): intending to cause public inconvenience, annoyance, or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk of public inconvenience, annoyance, or alarm, the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(2)(b)(i): engages in fighting or in violent, tumultuous, or threatening behavior;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(2)(b)(ii): makes unreasonable noises in a public place or an official meeting;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(2)(b)(iii): makes unreasonable noises in a private place which can be heard in a public place or an official meeting; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(2)(b)(iv): obstructs vehicular or pedestrian traffic in a public place or an official meeting.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(3): (3) The mere carrying or possession of a holstered or encased firearm, whether visible or concealed, without additional behavior or circumstances that would cause a reasonable person to believe the holstered or encased firearm was carried or possessed with criminal intent, does not constitute a violation of this section. Nothing in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(4): (4)(b); (c); (d); (4)(c); (d); (4)(d) An individual who violates this section is guilty of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(4)(a): (4)(b); (c); (d) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(4)(b): (4)(c); (d) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(4)(c): (4)(d) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(4)(c)(i): the violation occurs after the individual has been asked to cease conduct prohibited under this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(4)(c)(ii): within five years before the day on which the individual violates this section, the individual was previously convicted of a violation of this section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(4)(d): a class A misdemeanor, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(4)(d)(i): the violation occurs after the individual has been asked to cease conduct prohibited under this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-102(4)(d)(ii): within five years before the day on which the individual violates this section, the individual was previously convicted of two or more violations of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-103 Disrupting a meeting or procession.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-103(1): A person is guilty of disrupting a meeting or procession if, intending to prevent or disrupt a lawful meeting, procession, or gathering, he obstructs or interferes with the meeting, procession, or gathering by physical action, verbal utterance, or any other means.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-103(2): Disrupting a meeting or procession is a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-104 Failure to disperse.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-104(1): A person is guilty of failure to disperse when he remains at the scene of a riot, disorderly conduct, or an unlawful assembly after having been ordered to disperse by a peace officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-104(2): This section shall not apply to a person who attempted to but was unable to leave the scene of the riot or unlawful assembly.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-104(3): Failure to disperse is a class C misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-105 Making a false alarm -- Penalties.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-105(1): A person is guilty of making a false alarm if he initiates or circulates a report or warning of any fire, impending bombing, or other crime or catastrophe, knowing that the report or warning is false or baseless and is likely to cause evacuation of any building, place of assembly, or facility of public transport, to cause public inconvenience or alarm or action of any sort by any official or volunteer agency organized to deal with emergencies.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-105(2): 76-10-401; (2)(a); (b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-105(2)(a): 76-10-401 A person is guilty of a second degree felony if the person makes a false alarm relating to a weapon of mass destruction as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-105(2)(b): A person is guilty of a third degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-105(2)(b)(i): the person makes a false alarm alleging on ongoing act or event, or an imminent threat; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-105(2)(b)(ii): the false alarm causes or threatens to cause bodily harm, serious bodily injury, or death to another person.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-105(2)(c): (2)(a); (b) Making a false alarm other than under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-105(3): In addition to any other penalty authorized by law, a court shall order any person convicted of a felony violation of this section to reimburse any federal, state, or local unit of government, or any private business, organization, individual, or entity for all expenses and losses incurred in responding to the violation, unless the court states on the record the reasons why the court finds the reimbursement would be inappropriate.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-106 Disrupting the operation of a school.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-106(1): A person is guilty of disrupting the operation of a school if the person, after being asked to leave by a school official, remains on school property for the purpose of encouraging or creating an unreasonable and substantial disruption or risk of disruption of a class, activity, program, or other function of a public or private school.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-106(2): For purposes of this section, "school property" includes property being used by a public or private school for a school function.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-106(3): Disrupting the operation of a school is a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-107 Unauthorized entry of school bus -- Posting of warning on school buses.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-107(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-107(1)(a): "Driver" means the driver of the school bus.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-107(1)(b): "School bus" means every publicly or privately owned motor vehicle designed for transporting 10 or more passengers and operated for the transportation of children to or from school or school activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-107(2): A person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-107(2)(a): enters a school bus with the intent to commit a criminal offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-107(2)(b): enters a school bus and disrupts or interferes with the driver; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-107(2)(c): enters a school bus and refuses to leave the bus after being ordered to leave by the driver and the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-107(2)(c)(i): is not a peace officer acting within the scope of his or her authority as a peace officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-107(2)(c)(ii): is not authorized by the school district to board the bus as a student or as an individual employed by the school district or volunteering as a participant in a school activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-107(2)(c)(iii): causes or attempts to cause a disruption or an annoyance to any passenger on the bus; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-107(2)(c)(iv): is reckless as to whether the person's presence or behavior will cause fear on the part of any passenger on the bus.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-107(3): Each school district shall ensure that clearly legible signs be placed on each school bus,  next to each entrance to the bus, warning that unauthorized entry of a school bus is a violation of state law.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108 Disrupting a funeral or memorial service.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108(1)(a): "Funeral procession" means a procession of two or more motor vehicles where:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108(1)(a)(i): the operators of the vehicles identify themselves as being part of the procession by having the lamps or lights of the vehicle on and by keeping in close formation with the other vehicles in the procession;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108(1)(a)(ii): at least one vehicle contains the body or remains of a deceased person being memorialized; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108(1)(a)(iii): the vehicles are going to or from a memorial service.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108(1)(b): "Memorial service" means a wake, funeral, graveside service, burial, or other ceremony or rite held in connection with the burial or cremation of an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108(1)(c): "Memorial site" means a church, synagogue, mosque, funeral home, mortuary, cemetery, grave site, mausoleum, or other place at which a memorial service is conducted.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108(1)(d): "Disruptive activity" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108(1)(d)(i): a loud or disruptive oration or speech that is not part of the memorial service;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108(1)(d)(ii): the display of a placard, banner, poster, flag, or other item that is not part of the memorial service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108(1)(d)(iii): the distribution of any handbill, pamphlet, leaflet, or other written material or other item that is not part of the memorial service.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108(2): A person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor if the person, with intent to disrupt the memorial service, does any of the following during the period beginning 60 minutes immediately before the scheduled commencement of a memorial service and ending 60 minutes after the conclusion of a memorial service:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108(2)(a): obstructs, hinders, impedes, or blocks another person's entry to or exit from the memorial site;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108(2)(b): obstructs, hinders, impedes, or blocks a funeral procession;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108(2)(c): makes unreasonable noise; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-108(2)(d): engages in a disruptive activity within 200 feet of the memorial service.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-109 Targeted residential picketing.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-109(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-109(1)(a): "Picketing" means the stationing or posting of one or more individuals to apprise the public, vocally or by standing or marching with signs, banners, sound amplification devices, or other means, of an opinion or a message.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-109(1)(b): "Residence" means any single-family, duplex, or multi-family dwelling unit that is not being used as a targeted occupant's sole place of business or as a place of public meeting.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-109(1)(c): "Targeted residential picketing" means picketing, with or without signs, that is specifically directed or focused toward a residence, or one or more occupants of the residence, and that takes place:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-109(1)(c)(i): on that portion of a sidewalk or street in front of the residence, in front of an adjoining residence, or on either side of the targeted residence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-109(1)(c)(ii): within 100 feet of the property line of the targeted residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-109(2): It is unlawful to engage in targeted residential picketing.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-109(3): This section does not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-109(3)(a): an individual picketing at the individual's own residence;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-109(3)(b): the picketing of a meeting place or assembly area commonly used to discuss subjects of general public interest; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-109(3)(c): general picketing that proceeds through residential neighborhoods or that proceeds past residences.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-109(4): It is unlawful to publish, post, disseminate, or disclose an individual's residential address, or other information identifying the specific location of an individual's residence, with the intent to cause another individual to engage in targeted residential picketing.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-109(5): Targeted residential picketing is a class B misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-109(6): (4) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201 Electronic communication harassment -- Definitions -- Penalties.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(1): 76-6-1101 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(1)(a): "Adult" means an individual 18 years old or older.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(1)(b): "Electronic communication" means a communication by electronic, electro-mechanical, or electro-optical communication device for the transmission and reception of audio, image, or text but does not include broadcast transmissions or similar communications that are not targeted at a specific individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(1)(c): "Electronic communication device" includes a telephone, a facsimile machine, electronic mail, a pager, a computer, or another device or medium that can be used to communicate electronically.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(1)(d): "Minor" means an individual who is younger than 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(1)(e): 76-6-1101 "Personal identifying information" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(2): 76-9-203 Except to the extent the person's conduct constitutes an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(2)(a)(i): makes repeated contact by means of electronic communications, regardless of whether a conversation ensues; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(2)(a)(ii): after the recipient has requested or informed the person not to contact the recipient, and the person repeatedly or continuously:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(2)(a)(ii)(A): contacts the electronic communication device of the recipient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(2)(a)(ii)(B): causes an electronic communication device of the recipient to ring or to receive other notification of attempted contact by means of electronic communication;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(2)(b): makes contact by means of electronic communication and insults, taunts, or challenges the recipient of the communication or any person at the receiving location in a manner likely to provoke a violent or disorderly response;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(2)(c): makes contact by means of electronic communication and threatens to inflict injury, physical harm, or damage to any person or the property of any person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(2)(d): causes disruption, jamming, or overload of an electronic communication system through excessive message traffic or other means utilizing an electronic communication device.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(3): A person is guilty of electronic communication harassment if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(3)(a): electronically publishes, posts, or otherwise discloses personal identifying information of another individual in a public online site or forum with the intent to abuse, threaten, or disrupt the other individual's electronic communication and without the other individual's permission; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(3)(b): sends a communication by electronic mail, instant message, or other similar means, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(3)(b)(i): the communication references personal identifying information of another individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(3)(b)(ii): the person sends the communication:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(3)(b)(ii)(A): without the individual's consent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(3)(b)(ii)(B): with the intent to cause a recipient of the communication to reasonably believe that the individual authorized or sent the communication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(3)(b)(iii): with the intent to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(3)(b)(iii)(A): cause an individual physical, emotional, or economic injury or damage; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(3)(b)(iii)(B): defraud an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(4)(a): Electronic communication harassment is a class B misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(4)(b): A second or subsequent offense of electronic communication harassment is a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(5): (5)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(5)(a): (5)(b) Except as provided under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-201(5)(b): This section does not create a civil cause of action based on electronic communications made for legitimate business purposes.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202 Emergency reporting -- Interference -- False report.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(1)(a): "Emergency" means a situation in which property or human life is in jeopardy and the prompt summoning of aid is essential to the preservation of human life or property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(1)(b): "Party line" means a subscriber's line or telephone circuit:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(1)(b)(i): that consists of two or more connected main telephone stations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(1)(b)(ii): where each telephone station has a distinctive ring or telephone number.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(2): (2)(d)(i); (2)(d)(i) An actor is guilty of emergency reporting abuse if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(2)(a): intentionally refuses to yield or surrender the use of a party line or a public pay telephone to another individual upon being informed that the telephone is needed to report a fire or summon police, medical, or other aid in case of emergency, unless the telephone is likewise being used for an emergency call;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(2)(b): asks for or requests the use of a party line or a public pay telephone on the pretext that an emergency exists, knowing that no emergency exists;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(2)(c): reports an emergency or causes an emergency to be reported to any public, private, or volunteer entity whose purpose is to respond to fire, police, or medical emergencies, when the actor knows the reported emergency does not exist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(2)(d): (2)(d)(i); (2)(d)(i) makes a false report, or intentionally aids, abets, or causes a third party to make a false report, to an emergency response service, including a law enforcement dispatcher or a 911 emergency response service, if the false report claims that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(2)(d)(i): an ongoing emergency exists;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(2)(d)(ii): (2)(d)(i) the emergency described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(2)(d)(iii): (2)(d)(i) the emergency described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(3): (2)(a); (b); (2)(c); (3)(c); (2)(c); 76-10-401; (2)(d); (3)(d)(ii); (2)(d)(iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(3)(a): (2)(a); (b) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(3)(b): (2)(c); (3)(c) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(3)(c): (2)(c); 76-10-401 A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(3)(d): (2)(d); (3)(d)(ii); (2)(d)(iii) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(3)(d)(i): (3)(d)(ii) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(3)(d)(ii): (2)(d)(iii) is a second degree felony if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(3)(d)(ii)(A): (2)(d)(iii) while acting in response to the report, the emergency responder causes physical injury to an individual at the location described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(3)(d)(ii)(B): the actor makes the false report or aids, abets, or causes a third party to make the false report with intent to ambush, attack, or otherwise harm a responding law enforcement officer or emergency responder.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(4): (3)(d)(ii); (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(4)(a): (3)(d)(ii) In addition to any other penalty authorized by law, a court shall order an actor convicted of a violation of this section to reimburse:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(4)(a)(i): any federal, state, or local unit of government, or any private business, organization, individual, or entity for all expenses and losses incurred in responding to the violation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(4)(a)(ii): (3)(d)(ii) an individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-202(4)(b): (4)(a) The court may order that the defendant pay less than the full amount of the costs described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203 Penalty for online impersonation.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(1)(a): "Commercial social networking website" means a person who operates a website that allows a person to register as a user for the purpose of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(1)(a)(i): establishing a personal relationship with one or more other users through direct or real time communication with the other user; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(1)(a)(ii): the creation of web pages or profiles available to the public or to other users.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(1)(b): "Commercial social networking website" does not include an electronic mail program or a message board program.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(2): (2)(b) It is a criminal offense for a person to use the name or persona of an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(2)(a): without the individual's consent;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(2)(b)(i): to create a web page on a commercial social networking website or other website; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(2)(b)(ii): to post or send a message on or through a commercial social networking website or other website, other than on or through an electronic mail program or message board program;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(2)(c): (2)(b) with the intent to cause an individual to reasonably believe that the individual whose name or persona is used authorized or performed the applicable action described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(2)(d): with the intent to harm, defraud, intimidate, or threaten any individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(3)(a): An offense under this section is a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(3)(b): A second or subsequent offense under this section is a third degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(4): 10-1-402; 10-18-102 It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the person is one of the following entities or that the person's conduct consisted solely of action taken as an employee of one of the following entities:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(4)(a): a commercial social networking website;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(4)(b): an Internet service provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(4)(c): an interactive computer service, as defined in 47 U.S.C. Sec. 230;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(4)(d): 10-1-402 a telecommunications provider, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(4)(e): a cable television service;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(4)(f): 10-18-102 an entity that provides cable television service, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-203(4)(g): a law enforcement agency engaged in lawful practices.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301 Cruelty to animals.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1): (1)(b)(ii); 23A-1-101; Title 23A, Wildlife Resources Act; 4-39-102; 76-6-111 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(a)(i): "Abandon" means to intentionally deposit, leave, or drop off any live animal:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(a)(i)(A): without providing for the care of that animal, in accordance with accepted animal husbandry practices or customary farming practices; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(a)(i)(B): in a situation where conditions present an immediate, direct, and serious threat to the life, safety, or health of the animal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(a)(ii): "Abandon" does not include returning wildlife to its natural habitat.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(b): (1)(b)(ii); 23A-1-101
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(b)(i): (1)(b)(ii) "Animal" means, except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(b)(ii): 23A-1-101 "Animal" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(b)(ii)(A): a live, nonhuman vertebrate creature, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(b)(ii)(A)(I): the conduct toward the creature, and the care provided to the creature, is in accordance with accepted animal husbandry practices; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(b)(ii)(A)(II): the creature is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(b)(ii)(A)(II)(Aa): owned or kept by a zoological park that is accredited by, or a member of, the American Zoo and Aquarium Association;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(b)(ii)(A)(II)(Bb): kept, owned, or used for the purpose of training hunting dogs or raptors; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(b)(ii)(A)(II)(Cc): temporarily in the state as part of a circus or traveling exhibitor licensed by the United States Department of Agriculture under 7 U.S.C. Sec. 2133;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(b)(ii)(B): a live, nonhuman vertebrate creature that is owned, kept, or used for rodeo purposes, if the conduct toward the creature, and the care provided to the creature, is in accordance with accepted rodeo practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(b)(ii)(C): livestock, if the conduct toward the creature, and the care provided to the creature, is in accordance with accepted animal husbandry practices or customary farming practices; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(b)(ii)(D): 23A-1-101 wildlife, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(c): "Companion animal" means an animal that is a domestic dog or a domestic cat.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(d): "Custody" means ownership, possession, or control over an animal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(e): Title 23A, Wildlife Resources Act "Legal privilege" means an act that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(e)(i): Title 23A, Wildlife Resources Act is authorized by state law, including rules under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(e)(ii): is not in violation of a local ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(f): 4-39-102; 76-6-111 "Livestock" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(f)(i): domesticated:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(f)(i)(A): cattle;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(f)(i)(B): sheep;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(f)(i)(C): goats;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(f)(i)(D): turkeys;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(f)(i)(E): swine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(f)(i)(F): equines;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(f)(i)(G): camelidae;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(f)(i)(H): ratites; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(f)(i)(I): bison;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(f)(ii): 4-39-102 domesticated elk, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(f)(iii): 76-6-111 a livestock guardian dog, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(f)(iv): any domesticated nonhuman vertebrate creature, domestic furbearer, or domestic poultry, raised, kept, or used for agricultural purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(g): "Necessary food, water, care, or shelter" means the following, taking into account the species, age, and physical condition of the animal:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(g)(i): appropriate and essential food and water;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(g)(ii): adequate protection, including appropriate shelter, against extreme weather conditions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(g)(iii): other essential care.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(1)(h): "Torture" means intentionally or knowingly causing or inflicting extreme physical pain to an animal in an especially heinous, atrocious, cruel, or exceptionally depraved manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(2): (4); (6) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(2)(a): fails to provide necessary food, water, care, or shelter for an animal in the person's custody;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(2)(b): abandons an animal in the person's custody;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(2)(c): injures an animal;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(2)(d): causes any animal, not including a dog or game fowl, to fight with another animal of like kind for amusement or gain; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(2)(e): causes any animal, including a dog or game fowl, to fight with a different kind of animal or creature for amusement or gain.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(3): 76-9-301.7; (2) Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(3)(a): a class B misdemeanor if committed intentionally or knowingly; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(3)(b): a class C misdemeanor if committed recklessly or with criminal negligence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(4): A person is guilty of aggravated cruelty to an animal if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(4)(a): tortures an animal;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(4)(b): administers, or causes to be administered, poison or a poisonous substance to an animal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(4)(c): kills an animal or causes an animal to be killed without having a legal privilege to do so.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(5): (6); 76-9-301.7; (4) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(5)(a): a class A misdemeanor if committed intentionally or knowingly;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(5)(b): a class B misdemeanor if committed recklessly; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(5)(c): a class C misdemeanor if committed with criminal negligence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(6): A person is guilty of a third degree felony if the person intentionally or knowingly tortures a companion animal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(7): 18-1-3 It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the conduct of the actor towards the animal was:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(7)(a): by a licensed veterinarian using accepted veterinary practice;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(7)(b): directly related to bona fide experimentation for scientific research, provided that if the animal is to be destroyed, the manner employed will not be unnecessarily cruel unless directly necessary to the veterinary purpose or scientific research involved;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(7)(c): 18-1-3 permitted under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(7)(d): by a person who humanely destroys any animal found suffering past recovery for any useful purpose; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(7)(e): by a person who humanely destroys any apparently abandoned animal found on the person's property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(8): (7)(d) For purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(8)(a): the judgment of a veterinarian of the animal's nonrecoverable condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(8)(b): the judgment of two other persons called by the person to view the unrecoverable condition of the animal in the person's presence;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(8)(c): the consent from the owner of the animal to the destruction of the animal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(8)(d): a reasonable conclusion that the animal's suffering is beyond recovery, through the person's own observation, if the person is in a location or circumstance where the person is unable to contact another person.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(9): This section does not affect or prohibit:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(9)(a): the training, instruction, and grooming of animals, if the methods used are in accordance with accepted animal husbandry practices or customary farming practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(9)(b): the use of an electronic locating or training collar by the owner of an animal for the purpose of lawful animal training, lawful hunting practices, or protecting against loss of that animal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(9)(c): the lawful hunting of, fishing for, or trapping of, wildlife.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(10): County and municipal governments may not prohibit the use of an electronic locating or training collar.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(11): Upon conviction under this section, the court may in its discretion, in addition to other penalties:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(11)(a): order the defendant to be evaluated to determine the need for psychiatric or psychological counseling, to receive counseling as the court determines to be appropriate, and to pay the costs of the evaluation and counseling;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(11)(b): require the defendant to forfeit any rights the defendant has to the animal subjected to a violation of this section and to repay the reasonable costs incurred by any person or agency in caring for each animal subjected to violation of this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(11)(c): order the defendant to no longer possess or retain custody of any animal, as specified by the court, during the period of the defendant's probation or parole or other period as designated by the court; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(11)(d): order the animal to be placed for the purpose of adoption or care in the custody of a county or municipal animal control agency or an animal welfare agency registered with the state to be sold at public auction or humanely destroyed.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(12): This section does not prohibit the use of animals in lawful training.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301(13): A veterinarian who, acting in good faith, reports a violation of this section to law enforcement may not be held civilly liable for making the report.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.1 Dog fighting -- Training dogs for fighting -- Dog fighting exhibitions.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.1(1): (1)(a); (b); (c) It is unlawful for any person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.1(1)(a): own, possess, keep, or train a dog with the intent to engage it in an exhibition of fighting with another dog;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.1(1)(b): cause a dog to fight with another dog or cause a dog to injure another dog for amusement or gain;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.1(1)(c): tie, attach, or fasten any live animal to a machine or device propelled by any power, for the purpose of causing the animal to be pursued by a dog; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.1(1)(d): (1)(a); (b); (c) permit or allow any act which violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.1(2): (1)(b); (c) Possession of any breaking stick, treadmill, wheel, hot walker, cat mill, cat walker, jenni, or other paraphernalia together with evidence that the paraphernalia is being used or is intended for use in the unlawful training of a dog to fight with another dog, together with the possession of any such dog, is prima facie evidence of violation of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.1(3): (1) A person who violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.1(4): It is unlawful for a person to knowingly and intentionally be present as a spectator at any place, building, or tenement where preparations are being made for an exhibition of dog fighting, or to knowingly and intentionally be present at a dog fighting exhibition or any other occurrence of fighting or injury described in this section.  A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.1(5): Nothing in this section prohibits any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.1(5)(a): the use of dogs for management of livestock by the owner, his employees or agents, or any other person in the lawful custody of livestock;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.1(5)(b): the use of dogs for hunting; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.1(5)(c): the training of dogs or the possession or use of equipment in the training of dogs for any purpose not prohibited by law.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.3 Game fowl fighting.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.3(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.3(1)(a): "Game fowl" means a fowl reared or used for fighting other fowl.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.3(1)(b): "Promote" means to engage in promoting, producing, or staging events or activities that involve game fowl fighting.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.3(2): (2)(a) It is unlawful for a person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.3(2)(a): intentionally cause a game fowl to fight with or attack another game fowl for the purpose of entertainment, sport, or contest; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.3(2)(b): (2)(a) promote any activity that involves game fowl fighting, including promoting an activity that is a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.3(3): (2) A person who violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.3(3)(a): a class B misdemeanor for the first violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.3(3)(b): a class A misdemeanor for the second violation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.3(3)(c): a third degree felony for a third or subsequent violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.3(4): This section does not prohibit the lawful use of livestock by the livestock owner, an employee or agent of the livestock owner, or a person in the lawful custody of livestock.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.5 Spectator at organized animal fighting exhibitions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is unlawful for a person to knowingly be present as a spectator at any place, building, or tenement where preparations are being made for an exhibition of the fighting of animals, as prohibited by Subsections

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.6 Dog fighting exhibition -- Authority to arrest and take possession of dogs and property.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.6(2)(b): (2)(a) The officer, at the time of the taking of property pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.6(3): (2); 76-9-301; 76-9-301.1

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.6(3)(b): 76-9-301; 76-9-301.1 The affidavit shall include:

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.6(4)(d): If the person charged is acquitted or discharged without conviction, the court shall, on demand, order the property to be returned to its owner.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.7 Cruelty to animals -- Enhanced penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.7(1): Title 77, Chapter 2a, Pleas in Abeyance As used in this section, "conviction" means a conviction by plea or by verdict, including a plea of guilty or no contest that is held in abeyance under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.7(2): (4); 76-9-301; 76-9-301.5; 76-9-301.1(4); 76-9-301; 76-9-301.5; 76-9-301.1(4); (3) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.7(3): The enhanced degree of offense for offenses committed under this section are:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.7(3)(a): if the offense is a class C misdemeanor, it is a class B misdemeanor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.7(3)(b): if the offense is a class B misdemeanor, it is a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.7(4): 76-9-301(6) The penalty enhancements described in this section do not apply to a conviction for the offense described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.8 Bestiality -- Definitions -- Penalty.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.8(1): A person commits the crime of bestiality if the actor engages in any sexual activity with an animal with the intent of sexual gratification of the actor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.8(2): For purposes of this section only:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.8(2)(a): "Animal" means any live, nonhuman vertebrate creature, including fowl.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.8(2)(b): "Sexual activity" means physical sexual contact:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.8(2)(b)(i): between the actor and the animal involving the genitals of the actor and the genitals of the animal;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.8(2)(b)(ii): the genitals of the actor or the animal and the mouth or anus of the actor or the animal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.8(2)(b)(iii): through the actor's use of an object in contact with the genitals or anus of the animal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-301.8(3): A crime of bestiality is a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-304 Allowing vicious animal to go at large.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Any owner of a vicious animal, knowing its propensities, who willfully allows it to go at large or who keeps it without ordinary care, and any animal, while at large, or while not kept with ordinary care, causes injury to another animal or to any human being who has taken reasonable precaution which the circumstances permitted, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor unless the animal causes the death of a human being, whereupon the owner is guilty of a felony of the third degree.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-305 Officer's authority to take possession of animals -- Lien for care.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-305(1): Any law enforcement officer may take possession of any animals being treated cruelly and, after reasonable efforts to notify the owner, may provide shelter and care for them or upon permission from the owner may destroy them.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-305(2): Officers caring for animals pursuant to this section have a lien for the reasonable value of the care and/or destruction. Any court upon proof that the owner has been notified of the lien and amount due, at least five days prior, shall order the animal sold at public auction or destroyed.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-305(3): Any law enforcement officer may humanely destroy any animal found suffering past recovery for any useful purpose. Before destroying the animal the officer shall obtain the judgment to the effect of a veterinarian, or of two reputable citizens called by him to view the animal in his presence, or shall obtain consent to the destruction from the owner of the animal.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306 Police service canine -- Causing injury or interfering with handler -- Penalties.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306(1)(a): "Handler" means a law enforcement officer who is specially trained, and uses a police service canine during the course of the performance of his law enforcement duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306(1)(b): "Police service canine" means any dog used by a law enforcement agency, which is specially trained for law enforcement work, or any animal contracted to assist a law enforcement agency in the performance of law enforcement duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306(2): It is a second degree felony for a person to intentionally or knowingly cause death to a police service canine.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306(3): It is a third degree felony for a person to intentionally or knowingly:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306(3)(a): cause bodily injury to a police service canine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306(3)(b): engage in conduct likely to cause bodily injury or death to a police service canine; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306(3)(c): lay out, place, or administer any poison, trap, substance, or object which is likely to produce bodily injury or death to a police service canine.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306(4): It is a class A misdemeanor for a person to intentionally or knowingly:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306(4)(a): taunt, torment, strike, or otherwise assault a police service canine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306(4)(b): throw any object or substance at, or in the path of, a police service canine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306(4)(c): interfere with or obstruct a police service canine, or attempt to, or interfere with the handler of the canine in a manner that inhibits, restricts, or deprives the handler of control of the canine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306(4)(d): release a police service canine from its area of control, such as a vehicle, kennel, or pen, or trespass in that area; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306(4)(e): place any food, object, or substance into a police service canine's area of control without the permission of the handler.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306(5): A police service canine is exempt from quarantine or other animal control ordinances if it bites any person while under proper police supervision or routine veterinary care.  The law enforcement agency and the canine's handler shall make the canine available for examination at any reasonable time and shall notify the local health officer if the canine exhibits any abnormal behavior.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-306(6): In addition to any other penalty, a person convicted of a violation of this section is liable for restitution to the owning or employing law enforcement agency or individual owner of the police service canine for the replacement, training, and veterinary costs incurred as a result of the violation of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307 Injury to service animals -- Penalties.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(1): 26B-6-801; 26B-6-801 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(1)(a): 26B-6-801 "Disability" has the same meaning as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(1)(b): "Search and rescue dog" means a dog:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(1)(b)(i): with documented training to locate persons who are:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(1)(b)(i)(A): lost, missing, or injured; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(1)(b)(i)(B): trapped under debris as the result of a natural or man-made event; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(1)(b)(ii): affiliated with an established search and rescue dog organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(1)(c): 26B-6-801 "Service animal" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(1)(c)(i): 26B-6-801 a service animal as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(1)(c)(ii): a search and rescue dog.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(2): It is a class A misdemeanor for a person to knowingly, intentionally, or recklessly cause substantial bodily injury or death to a service animal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(3): It is a class A misdemeanor for a person who owns, keeps, harbors, or exercises control over an animal to knowingly, intentionally, or recklessly fail to exercise sufficient control over the animal to prevent it from causing:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(3)(a): any substantial bodily injury or the death of a service animal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(3)(b): the service animal's subsequent inability to function as a service animal as a result of the animal's attacking, chasing, or harassing the service animal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(4): It is a class B misdemeanor for a person to chase or harass a service animal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(5): It is a class B misdemeanor for a person who owns, keeps, harbors, or exercises control over an animal to knowingly, intentionally, or recklessly fail to exercise sufficient control over the animal to prevent it from chasing or harassing a service animal while it is carrying out its functions as a service animal, to the extent that the animal temporarily interferes with the service animal's ability to carry out its functions.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(6): (2); (3); (4); (5)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(6)(a): (2); (3); (4); (5) A service animal is exempt from quarantine or other animal control ordinances if it bites any person while it is subject to an offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(6)(b): The owner of the service animal or the person with a disability whom the service animal serves shall make the animal available for examination at any reasonable time and shall notify the local health officer if the animal exhibits any abnormal behavior.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(7): In addition to any other penalty, a person convicted of any violation of this section is liable for restitution to the owner of the service animal or the person with a disability whom the service animal serves for the replacement, training, and veterinary costs incurred as a result of the violation of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-307(8): Title 76, Utah Criminal Code If the act committed under this section amounts to an offense subject to a greater penalty under another provision of


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308 Harassment of livestock.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(1): 76-9-301(1); 72-10-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(1)(a): 76-9-301(1) "Livestock" has the same meaning as that term is defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(1)(b): 72-10-102 "Unmanned aircraft system" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(2): (3) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(2)(a): a motorized vehicle or all-terrain vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(2)(b): a dog; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(2)(c): an unmanned aircraft system.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(3): A person is not guilty of harassment of livestock if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(3)(a): the person is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(3)(a)(i): the owner of the livestock;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(3)(a)(ii): an employee or agent of the owner, or otherwise acting under the owner's general direction or with the owner's permission;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(3)(a)(iii): acting in an emergency situation to prevent damage to the livestock or property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(3)(a)(iv): an employee or agent of the state or a political subdivision and acting in the employee or agent's official capacity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(3)(b): the action is in line with generally accepted animal husbandry practices.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(4): A person who violates this section is guilty of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(4)(a): a class B misdemeanor if the violation is a first offense and:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(4)(a)(i): no livestock is seriously injured or killed as a result of the person's actions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(4)(a)(ii): the person's actions cause the livestock to be displaced onto property where the livestock is not legally entitled to be; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(4)(b): a class A misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(4)(b)(i): the person has previously been convicted of harassment of livestock under this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(4)(b)(ii): livestock is seriously injured or killed as a result of the person's actions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-308(4)(b)(iii): livestock or property suffered damage in excess of $1,000, including money spent in recovering the livestock, as a result of the person's actions.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-401 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
For purposes of this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-401(1): "Private place" means a place where one may reasonably expect to be safe from casual or hostile intrusion or surveillance.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-401(2): "Eavesdrop" means to overhear, record, amplify, or transmit any part of a wire or oral communication of others without the consent of at least one party thereto by means of any electronic, mechanical, or other device.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-401(3): "Public" includes any professional or social group of which the victim of a defamation is a member.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402 Privacy violation.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(1)(a): A property owner has an expectation of privacy regarding characteristics, data, or information pertaining to the owner's property that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(1)(a)(i): is not immediately apparent through routine visual observation of the property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(1)(a)(ii): requires ground-penetrating technology to detect, observe, measure, map, or otherwise capture information or data about the property or characteristics of the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(2): (1) A person is guilty of privacy violation if, except as authorized by law, the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(2)(a): trespasses on property with intent to subject anyone to eavesdropping or other surveillance in a private place;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(2)(b): installs, or uses after unauthorized installation in a private place, without the consent of the person or persons entitled to privacy in the private place, any device for observing, photographing, hearing, recording, amplifying, or broadcasting sounds or events in the private place;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(2)(c): installs or uses outside of a private place a device for observing, photographing, hearing, recording, amplifying, or broadcasting sounds or events originating in the private place which would not ordinarily be audible, visible, or comprehensible outside the private place, without the consent of the person or persons entitled to privacy in the private place; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(2)(d): (1) uses ground-penetrating technology, without the consent of the property owner, to detect, observe, measure, map, or otherwise capture information or data about the property or characteristics of the property of another for which the property owner has an expectation of privacy as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(3): (2) A person is not guilty of a violation of this section if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(3)(a): the device used is an unmanned aircraft;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(3)(b): the person is operating the unmanned aircraft for legitimate commercial or educational purposes in a manner consistent with applicable Federal Aviation Administration rules, exemptions, or other authorizations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(3)(c): (2) any conduct described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(4): (2); (2) For a person who commits a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(5): Privacy violation is a class B misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(6): (2)(d); (6)(b)(i); (6)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(6)(a): This section does not apply to lawful practices of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(6)(a)(i): a law enforcement agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(6)(a)(ii): another government entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(6)(b): (2)(d); (6)(b)(i); (6)(b)(i) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-402(6)(b)(i): the land surveyor is performing a survey service in good faith pursuant to a bona fide contract; and
