Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-403 Communication Abuse.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-403(1): A person commits communication abuse if, except as authorized by law, he:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-403(1)(a): Intercepts, without the consent of the sender or receiver, a message by telephone, telegraph, letter, or other means of communicating privately; this paragraph does not extend to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-403(1)(a)(i): Overhearing of messages through a regularly installed instrument on a telephone party line or on an extension; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-403(1)(a)(ii): Interception by the telephone company or subscriber incident to enforcement of regulations limiting use of the facilities or to other normal operation and use; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-403(1)(b): Divulges without consent of the sender or receiver the existence or contents of any such message if the actor knows that the message was illegally intercepted or if he learned of the message in the course of employment with an agency engaged in transmitting it.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-403(2): Communication abuse is a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-404 Criminal defamation.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-404(1): A person is guilty of criminal defamation if he knowingly communicates to any person orally or in writing any information which he knows to be false and knows will tend to expose any other living person to public hatred, contempt, or ridicule.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-404(2): Criminal defamation is a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-406 Injunctive relief against privacy offenses -- Damages.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person, or the heirs of any deceased person, who has been injured by a violation of this part may bring an action against the person who committed the violation. If in the action the court finds the defendant is violating or has violated any of the provisions of this part, it shall enjoin the defendant from a continuance thereof. It shall not be necessary that actual damages to the plaintiffs be alleged or proved, but if damages are alleged and proved, the plaintiff in the action shall be entitled to recover from the defendant the actual damages, if any, sustained in addition to injunctive relief. A finding that the defendant is in violation of this part shall entitle the plaintiff to reasonable attorney's fees. Exemplary damages may be awarded where the violation is found to be malicious.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-407 Crime of abuse of personal identity -- Penalty -- Defense -- Permitting civil action.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-407(1): 45-3-2 The definitions in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-407(2): Any person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor who knowingly or intentionally causes the publication of an advertisement in which the personal identity of an individual is used in a manner which expresses or implies that the individual approves, endorses, has endorsed, or will endorse the specific subject matter of the advertisement without the consent for such use by the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-407(3): It is an affirmative defense that the person causing the publication of the advertisement reasonably believed that the person whose personal identity was to be used had consented to its use.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-407(4): Upon conviction of an offense under this section, unless waived by the victim, the court shall order that, within 30 days of the conviction, the person convicted shall issue a public apology or retraction to whomever received the advertisement.  The apology or retraction shall be of similar size and placement as the original advertisement.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-407(5): Title 45, Chapter 3, Abuse of Personal Identity Act Nothing in this section prohibits a civil action under


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408 Unlawful installation of a tracking device.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(1): 41-12a-103(4); Title 53, Chapter 9, Private Investigator Regulation Act As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(1)(a): 41-12a-103(4) "Motor vehicle" means the same as that term is defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(1)(b): Title 53, Chapter 9, Private Investigator Regulation Act "Private investigator" means an individual who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(1)(b)(i): Title 53, Chapter 9, Private Investigator Regulation Act licensed as a private investigator under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(1)(b)(ii): acting in the capacity of a private investigator.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(1)(c): "Protective order" means a protective order, stalking injunction, or restraining order issued by a court of any jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(1)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(1)(d)(i): "Tracking device" means a device used for the primary purpose of revealing the device's location or movement by the transmission or recording of an electronic signal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(1)(d)(ii): "Tracking device" does not include location technology installed on a vehicle by the vehicle manufacturer or a commercial vehicle dealer that transmits electronic signals for the purpose of data collection, if the data collection is anonymized.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(2): (3) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(3): A person is not guilty of unlawful installation of a tracking device if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(3)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(3)(a)(i): is a licensed private investigator installing the tracking device for a legitimate business purpose; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(3)(a)(ii): installs the tracking device on a motor vehicle that is not:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(3)(a)(ii)(A): owned or leased by an individual under the protection of a protective order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(3)(a)(ii)(B): operated by an individual under the protection of a protective order who resides with, or is an immediate family member of, the owner or lessee of the motor vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(3)(b): installs the tracking device pursuant to a court order.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(4): Unlawful installation of a tracking device is a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(5): This section does not apply to a peace officer, acting in the peace officer's official capacity, who installs a tracking device on a motor vehicle in the course of a criminal investigation or pursuant to a court order.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(6): (3) Before installing a tracking device on a motor vehicle under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(6)(a): the owner or lessee of the vehicle is not under the protection of a protective order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(6)(b): an individual who resides with, or is an immediate family member of, the owner or lessee of the motor vehicle is not under the protection of a protective order.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(7): On request from a licensed private investigator, a state entity, including a law enforcement agency, with access to protective order records shall confirm or deny the existence of a protective order, disclosing only whether an individual named by the private investigator is under the protection of a protective order issued in any jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(8): (7) A private investigator may not disclose the information obtained under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-408(9): On request from the Bureau of Criminal Identification, a private investigator who installs a tracking device on a motor vehicle shall disclose the purpose of the tracking device to the Bureau of Criminal Identification.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-504 Fair reporting privilege of newspaper or broadcasting station personnel as to public official proceedings -- Privilege as to defamatory matter not subject to censorship.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
No reporter, editor, or proprietor of any newspaper, and no owner, licensee, or operator of a visual or sound radio broadcasting station, or network of stations, nor the agents or employees of a newspaper or broadcasting station, is liable to any prosecution for a fair and true report or broadcast of any judicial, legislative, or other public official proceedings, or of any statement, speech, argument, or debate in course of the same, except upon proof of malice in making the report, which shall not be implied from the mere fact of publication. In no event shall any owner, licensee, or operator of a visual or sound radio broadcasting station or network of stations, or the agents or employees thereof, be liable for prosecution for any defamatory matter or statement published or uttered in such radio or television broadcast where the publication cannot be censored by reason of the provisions of federal statute or the regulations of the federal communications commission.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-505 Libelous matter not privileged.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Libelous remarks or comments connected with matter privileged by the next preceding section receive no privilege by reason of their being so connected.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-506 Privilege as to communications between interested persons.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A communication made to a person interested in the communication by one who is also interested, or who stands in a relation to the former as to afford a reasonable ground for supposing his motive innocent, is not presumed to be malicious, and is a privileged communication.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-509 Conveying false or libelous material to newspaper or broadcasting stations.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person who willfully states, conveys, delivers, or transmits, by any means whatsoever, to the manager, editor, publisher, reporter, or agent of any radio station, television station, newspaper, magazine, periodical, or serial for publication therein, any false or libelous statement concerning any person, and thereby secures actual publication of the same, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-601 Abuse of a flag.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-601(1): A person is guilty of abuse of a flag if he:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-601(1)(a): Intentionally places any unauthorized inscription or other thing upon any flag of the United States or of any state of the United States; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-601(1)(b): Knowingly exhibits any such flag, knowing the inscription or other thing to be unauthorized; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-601(1)(c): For purposes of advertising a product or service for sale or for distribution, affixes a representation of the flag of the United States or of a state of the United States to the product or on any display whereon the product or service is advertised; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-601(1)(d): Knowingly casts contempt upon the flag of the United States or of any state of the United States by publicly mutilating, defacing, defiling, burning, or trampling upon it.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-601(2): Abuse of a flag is a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-701 Intoxication -- Release of arrested person or placement in detoxification center.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-701(1): A person is guilty of intoxication if the person is under the influence of alcohol, a controlled substance, or any substance having the property of releasing toxic vapors, to a degree that the person may endanger the person or another, in a public place or in a private place where the person unreasonably disturbs other persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-701(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-701(2)(a): A peace officer or a magistrate may release from custody a person arrested under this section if the peace officer or magistrate believes imprisonment is unnecessary for the protection of the person or another.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-701(2)(b): A peace officer may take the arrested person to a detoxification center or other special facility as an alternative to incarceration or release from custody.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.3 Public urination.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.3(1): A person is guilty of public urination if the person urinates or defecates:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.3(1)(a): in a public place, other than a public rest room; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.3(1)(b): under circumstances which the person should know will likely cause affront or alarm to another.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.3(2): Public urination is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.5 Lewdness involving a child.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.5(2)(a): does any of the following in the presence of a child who is under 14 years of age:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.5(2)(a)(i): performs an act of sexual intercourse or sodomy;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.5(2)(a)(ii): exposes his or her genitals, the female breast below the top of the areola, the buttocks, the anus, or the pubic area:

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.5(2)(a)(ii)(B): in a private place under circumstances the person should know will likely cause affront or alarm or with the intent to arouse or gratify the sexual desire of the actor or the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.5(2)(a)(iii): masturbates; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.5(2)(a)(iv): performs any other act of lewdness; or

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.7 Voyeurism offenses -- Penalties.
-----------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.7(1)(a): for the purpose of viewing any portion of the individual's body regarding which the individual has a reasonable expectation of privacy, whether or not that portion of the body is covered with clothing;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.7(1)(b): without the knowledge or consent of the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.7(1)(c): under circumstances in which the individual has a reasonable expectation of privacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.7(2): (1); (1) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.7(3): (1); (3) Distribution or sale of any images, including in print, electronic, magnetic, or digital format, obtained under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.7(4): (1) A person is guilty of voyeurism who, under circumstances not amounting to a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.7(4)(a): with the intent of viewing any portion of the individual's body regarding which the individual has a reasonable expectation of privacy, whether or not that portion of the body is covered with clothing;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.7(4)(b): without the knowledge or consent of the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-702.7(4)(c): under circumstances in which the individual has a reasonable expectation of privacy.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704 Abuse or desecration of a dead human body -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(1): 9-8a-302 For purposes of this section, "dead human body" includes any part of a human body in any stage of decomposition, including ancient human remains as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(2): (2)(e)(i) A person is guilty of abuse or desecration of a dead human body if the person intentionally and unlawfully:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(2)(a): fails to report the finding of a dead human body to a local law enforcement agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(2)(b): disturbs, moves, removes, conceals, or destroys a dead human body or any part of it;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(2)(c): disinters a buried or otherwise interred dead human body, without authority of a court order;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(2)(d): dismembers a dead human body to any extent, or damages or detaches any part or portion of a dead human body; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(2)(e): (2)(e)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(2)(e)(i): commits or attempts to commit upon any dead human body any act of sexual penetration, regardless of the sex of the actor and of the dead human body; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(2)(e)(ii): (2)(e)(i) as used in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(3): Title 9, Chapter 8a, Part 3, Antiquities; Title 26B, Chapter 8, Part 2, Utah Medical Examiner; Title 26B, Chapter 8, Part 3, Revised Uniform Anatomical Gift Act; Title 53B, Chapter 17, Part 3, Use of Dead Bodies for Medical Purposes; Title 58, Chapter 9, Funeral Services Licensing Act; Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act A person does not violate this section if when that person directs or carries out procedures regarding a dead human body, that person complies with:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(3)(a): Title 9, Chapter 8a, Part 3, Antiquities
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(3)(b): Title 26B, Chapter 8, Part 2, Utah Medical Examiner
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(3)(c): Title 26B, Chapter 8, Part 3, Revised Uniform Anatomical Gift Act
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(3)(d): Title 53B, Chapter 17, Part 3, Use of Dead Bodies for Medical Purposes
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(3)(e): Title 58, Chapter 9, Funeral Services Licensing Act
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(3)(f): Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(4): (2)(a); (2)(b); (e)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(4)(a): (2)(a) Failure to report the finding of a dead human body as required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-704(4)(b): (2)(b); (e) Abuse or desecration of a dead human body as described in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-705 Participation in an ultimate fighting match.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-705(1): For purposes of this section, "ultimate fighting match" means a live match in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-705(1)(a): an admission fee is charged;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-705(1)(b): match rules permit professional contestants to use a combination of boxing, kicking, wrestling, hitting, punching, or other combative, contact techniques; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-705(1)(c): match rules do not:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-705(1)(c)(i): incorporate a formalized system of combative techniques against which a contestant's performance is judged to determine the prevailing contestant;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-705(1)(c)(ii): divide a match into two or more equal and specified time periods for a match total of no more than 50 minutes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-705(1)(c)(iii): prohibit contestants from:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-705(1)(c)(iii)(A): using anything that is not part of the human body, except for boxing gloves, to intentionally inflict serious bodily injury upon an opponent through direct contact or the expulsion of a projectile;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-705(1)(c)(iii)(B): striking a person who demonstrates an inability to protect himself from the advances of an opponent;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-705(1)(c)(iii)(C): biting; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-705(1)(c)(iii)(D): direct, intentional, and forceful strikes to the eyes, groin area, adam's apple area of the neck, and temple area of the head.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-705(2): Any person who publicizes, promotes, conducts, or engages in an ultimate fighting match is guilty of a class A misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706 False representation of military award -- False wearing or use of medal, name, title, insignia, ritual, or ceremony of a military related organization.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1): (1)(a)(i); (1)(a)(i); (1)(a)(i); (1)(b)(i); (x); (1)(b)(i); (xi) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(a): (1)(a)(i); (1)(a)(i); (1)(a)(i) "Military related organization" means a public or private society, order, or organization that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(a)(i): only accepts as a member, a person, or the relative of a person, who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(a)(i)(A): a member of the military; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(a)(i)(B): an honorably discharged member of the military; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(a)(ii): (1)(a)(i); (1)(a)(i); (1)(a)(i) is organized for the purpose of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(a)(ii)(A): recognizing or honoring a person for military service;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(a)(ii)(B): (1)(a)(i); (1)(a)(i) assisting a person described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(a)(ii)(C): (1)(a)(i) provide support for, or assistance to, a person described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b): (1)(b)(i); (x); (1)(b)(i); (xi) "Service medal" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(i): a congressional medal of honor, as defined in 18 U.S.C. 704(c)(2);
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(ii): a distinguished service cross, as defined in 10 U.S.C 3742;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(iii): a Navy cross, as defined in 10 U.S.C. 6242;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(iv): an Air Force cross, as defined in 10 U.S.C. 8742;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(v): a silver star, as defined in 10 U.S.C. 3746, 6244, or 8746;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(vi): a bronze star, as defined in 10 U.S.C. 1133;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(vii): a purple heart, as defined in 10 U.S.C. 1129;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(viii): any decoration or medal authorized by the Congress of the United States for the armed forces of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(ix): any service medal or badge awarded to members of the armed forces of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(x): any of the following Utah National Guard medals or ribbons:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(x)(A): medal of valor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(x)(B): Utah cross;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(x)(C): joint medal of merit;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(x)(D): Utah medal of merit;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(x)(E): joint commendation medal;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(x)(F): commendation medal;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(x)(G): achievement ribbon;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(x)(H): joint staff service ribbon;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(x)(I): state partnership service ribbon;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(x)(J): service ribbon;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(x)(K): military funeral honors service ribbon;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(x)(L): emergency service ribbon; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(x)(M): recruiting ribbon;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(xi): (1)(b)(i); (x) any ribbon, button, or rosette for a decoration, medal, or badge described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(1)(b)(xii): (1)(b)(i); (xi) an imitation of a decoration, medal, badge, ribbon, button, or rosette described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(2): Any person who intentionally makes a false representation, verbally or in writing, that the person has been awarded a service medal is guilty of an infraction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(3): Any person who wears, purchases, attempts to purchase, solicits for purchase, mails, ships, imports, exports, produces blank certificates of receipt for, manufactures, sells, attempts to sell, advertises for sale, trades, barters, or exchanges for anything of value a service medal, or any colorable imitation thereof, except when authorized by federal law, or under regulations made pursuant to federal law, with the intent to defraud, or with the intent to falsely represent that the person or another person has been awarded a service medal, is guilty of an infraction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(4): A person is guilty of an infraction if the person wears or uses a medal of a military related organization:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(4)(a): that the person is not entitled to wear or use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(4)(b): with the intent to defraud or with the intent to falsely represent that the person or another person has been awarded the medal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(5): A person is guilty of an infraction if the person uses the name, an officer title, an insignia, a ritual, or a ceremony of a military related organization:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(5)(a): that the person is not entitled to use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-706(5)(b): with the intent to defraud, or with the intent to falsely represent that the person or another person was or is a member, representative, or officer of the military related organization.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-801 Title.
-------------------------------------
This part is known as "Criminal Street Gang Penalties."

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(1): "Criminal street gang" means an organization, association in fact, or group of three or more persons, whether operated formally or informally:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(1)(a): that is currently in operation;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(1)(b): that has as one of its primary activities the commission of one or more predicate gang crimes;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(1)(c): that has, as a group, an identifying name or identifying sign or symbol, or both; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(1)(d): whose members, acting individually or in concert with other members, engage in or have engaged in a pattern of criminal gang activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(2): "Intimidate" means the use of force, duress, violence, coercion, menace, or threat of harm for the purpose of causing an individual to act or refrain from acting.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(3): "Minor" means a person younger than 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(4): "Pattern of criminal gang activity" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(4)(a): committing, attempting to commit, conspiring to commit, or soliciting the commission of two or more predicate gang crimes within five years;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(4)(b): the predicate gang crimes are:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(4)(b)(i): committed by two or more persons; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(4)(b)(ii): committed by an individual at the direction of, or in association with a criminal street gang; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(4)(c): the criminal activity was committed with the specific intent to promote, further, or assist in any criminal conduct by members of the criminal street gang.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(5): Title 41, Chapter 1a, Motor Vehicle Act; 41-1a-1313; 41-1a-1315; 41-1a-1316; 41-1a-1317; 41-1a-1318; Title 58, Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act; Title 58, Chapter 37a, Utah Drug Paraphernalia Act; Title 58, Chapter 37b, Imitation Controlled Substances Act; Title 58, Chapter 37c, Utah Controlled Substance Precursor Act; 76-5-102; 76-5-103.5; Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 2, Criminal Homicide; 76-5-301; 76-5-304; Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 1, Property Destruction; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 2, Burglary and Criminal Trespass; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 3, Robbery; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 4, Theft; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 6, Retail Theft; 76-6-404.5; 76-6-405; 76-6-407; 76-6-408; 76-6-409; 76-6-409.1; 76-6-409.3; 76-6-409.6; 76-6-409.7; 76-6-409.8; 76-6-409.9; 76-6-410; 76-6-410.5; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 5, Fraud; 76-6-504; 76-6-505; 76-6-507; 76-6-508; 76-6-509; 76-6-510; 76-6-511; 76-6-512; 76-6-513; 76-6-514; 76-6-516; 76-6-517; 76-6-518; 76-6-520; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 11, Identity Fraud Act; Title 76, Chapter 8, Part 3, Obstructing Governmental Operations; 76-8-302; 76-8-303; 76-8-307; 76-8-308; 76-8-312; 76-8-508; 76-8-508.3; 76-8-509; 76-9-102; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 3, Explosives; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 5, Weapons; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 15, Bus Passenger Safety Act; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 16, Pattern of Unlawful Activity Act; 76-10-1801; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 19, Money Laundering and Currency Transaction Reporting Act; 76-10-2002; (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(5)(a): Title 41, Chapter 1a, Motor Vehicle Act; 41-1a-1313; 41-1a-1315; 41-1a-1316; 41-1a-1317; 41-1a-1318; Title 58, Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act; Title 58, Chapter 37a, Utah Drug Paraphernalia Act; Title 58, Chapter 37b, Imitation Controlled Substances Act; Title 58, Chapter 37c, Utah Controlled Substance Precursor Act; 76-5-102; 76-5-103.5; Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 2, Criminal Homicide; 76-5-301; 76-5-304; Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 1, Property Destruction; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 2, Burglary and Criminal Trespass; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 3, Robbery; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 4, Theft; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 6, Retail Theft; 76-6-404.5; 76-6-405; 76-6-407; 76-6-408; 76-6-409; 76-6-409.1; 76-6-409.3; 76-6-409.6; 76-6-409.7; 76-6-409.8; 76-6-409.9; 76-6-410; 76-6-410.5; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 5, Fraud; 76-6-504; 76-6-505; 76-6-507; 76-6-508; 76-6-509; 76-6-510; 76-6-511; 76-6-512; 76-6-513; 76-6-514; 76-6-516; 76-6-517; 76-6-518; 76-6-520; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 11, Identity Fraud Act; Title 76, Chapter 8, Part 3, Obstructing Governmental Operations; 76-8-302; 76-8-303; 76-8-307; 76-8-308; 76-8-312; 76-8-508; 76-8-508.3; 76-8-509; 76-9-102; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 3, Explosives; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 5, Weapons; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 15, Bus Passenger Safety Act; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 16, Pattern of Unlawful Activity Act; 76-10-1801; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 19, Money Laundering and Currency Transaction Reporting Act; 76-10-2002 "Predicate gang crime" means any of the following offenses:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(5)(a)(i): Title 41, Chapter 1a, Motor Vehicle Act; 41-1a-1313; 41-1a-1315; 41-1a-1316; 41-1a-1317; 41-1a-1318

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-802(5)(b)(ii): (4)(a) any felony violation of a criminal statute of any other state, the United States, or any district, possession, or territory of the United States which would constitute a violation of any offense in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-803 Penalties regarding criminal street gang activities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-803(1): (1)(a) It is a class B misdemeanor to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-803(1)(a): solicit, recruit, entice, or intimidate a minor to join a criminal street gang, whether or not the minor actually joins the criminal street gang;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-803(1)(b): (1)(a) conspire to commit any act under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-803(1)(c): use intimidation to prevent or attempt to prevent a minor from leaving a criminal street gang or ending the minor's affiliation with a criminal street gang.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-803(2): (1)(a) It is a class A misdemeanor for any person who is a member of or actively involved with a criminal street gang to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-803(2)(a): intimidate or otherwise cause a minor to commit or attempt to commit any misdemeanor criminal offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-803(2)(b): (1)(a) commit a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-803(2)(b)(i): more than once;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-803(2)(b)(ii): regarding the same minor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-803(2)(b)(iii): within a period of 180 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-803(3): Prosecution for any offense under this section does not prohibit prosecution for any other criminal offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-804 Convicted criminal gang offender -- Prohibition.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-804(1): 76-3-203.1; 76-1-101.5; 76-10-501 A person who has been convicted of a crime for which the penalty was enhanced under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-804(2): (1) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-901 Title.
-------------------------------------
This part is known as "Prohibition of Gang Activity."

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-902 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-902(1): "Criminal street gang" means an organization, association in fact, or group of three or more persons, whether operated formally or informally:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-902(1)(a): that is currently in operation;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-902(1)(b): that has as one of its substantial activities the commission of one or more predicate gang crimes;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-902(1)(c): that has, as a group, an identifying name or an identifying sign or symbol, or both; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-902(1)(d): whose members, acting individually or in concert with other members, engage in or have engaged in a pattern of criminal gang activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-902(2): "Gang loitering" means a person remains in one place under circumstances that would cause a reasonable person to believe that the purpose or effect of that behavior is to enable or facilitate a criminal street gang to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-902(2)(a): establish control over one or more identifiable areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-902(2)(b): intimidate others from entering those areas; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-902(2)(c): conceal illegal activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-902(3): "Pattern of criminal gang activity" means committing, attempting to commit, conspiring to commit, or soliciting the commission of two or more predicate gang crimes within five years, if the predicate gang crimes are committed:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-902(3)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-902(3)(a)(i): by two or more persons; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-902(3)(a)(ii): by an individual at the direction of or in association with a criminal street gang; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-902(3)(b): with the specific intent to promote, further, or assist in any criminal conduct by members of a criminal street gang.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-902(4): Title 58, Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act; Title 58, Chapter 37a, Utah Drug Paraphernalia Act; Title 58, Chapter 37b, Imitation Controlled Substances Act; Title 58, Chapter 37c, Utah Controlled Substance Precursor Act; 76-5-102; 76-5-103.5; Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 2, Criminal Homicide; 76-5-301; 76-5-304; Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 1, Property Destruction; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 2, Burglary and Criminal Trespass; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 3, Robbery; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 4, Theft; 76-6-404.5; 76-6-405; 76-6-407; 76-6-408; 76-6-409; 76-6-409.1; 76-6-409.3; 76-6-409.6; 76-6-409.7; 76-6-409.8; 76-6-409.9; 76-6-410; 76-6-410.5; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 5, Fraud; 76-6-504; 76-6-505; 76-6-507; 76-6-508; 76-6-509; 76-6-510; 76-6-511; 76-6-512; 76-6-513; 76-6-514; 76-6-516; 76-6-517; 76-6-518; 76-6-520; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 11, Identity Fraud Act; Title 76, Chapter 8, Part 3, Obstructing Governmental Operations; 76-8-302; 76-8-303; 76-8-307; 76-8-308; 76-8-312; 76-8-508; 76-8-508.3; 76-8-509; 76-9-102; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 3, Explosives; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 5, Weapons; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 15, Bus Passenger Safety Act; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 16, Pattern of Unlawful Activity Act; 76-10-1801; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 19, Money Laundering and Currency Transaction Reporting Act; 76-10-2002; Title 41, Chapter 1a, Motor Vehicle Act; 41-1a-1313; 41-1a-1315; 41-1a-1316; 41-1a-1317; 41-1a-1318; (4)(a)

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-903 Gang loitering -- Failure to disperse -- Penalties.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-903(1): 76-9-905 When a law enforcement officer observes a person whom the officer reasonably believes to be a member of a criminal street gang engaging in gang loitering in the presence of one or more other persons in any public place where gang loitering is prohibited under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-903(1)(a): inform all the persons that they are within an area in which loitering by a group containing one or more criminal street gang members is prohibited;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-903(1)(b): order all the persons in the group to disperse and remove themselves from within sight and hearing of the location where the officer issues the order to disperse; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-903(1)(c): inform the persons that any person in the group will be subject to being charged with a criminal offense and will also be subject to arrest if the person fails to promptly obey the order to disperse.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-903(2): (1) The officer under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-903(2)(a): present in a public place with a group that includes one or more persons a peace officer reasonably believes to be a member of a criminal street gang; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-903(2)(b): within sight or hearing of the location where the law enforcement officer is currently issuing the order to disperse.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-904 Failure to disperse -- Penalties.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-904(1): 76-9-903(1)(b); (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-904(1)(a): 76-9-903(1)(b) Failure to comply with an order issued under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-904(1)(b): (1)(a) Any second and subsequent violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-904(2): 76-9-903; (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-904(2)(a): 76-9-903 A person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor of subsequent failure to disperse who:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-904(2)(a)(i): is present in a public place with or as part of a group of two or more persons, and that group includes one or more persons a peace officer reasonably believes to be a member of a criminal street gang; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-904(2)(a)(ii): 76-9-903 is within sight or hearing of a location where a law enforcement officer issued an order to the person to disperse under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-904(2)(b): (2)(a) A violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-905 Designation of areas where orders to disperse are authorized and gang loitering is prohibited.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-905(1): 76-9-903 Municipal and county legislative bodies shall, within their respective jurisdictions, designate the areas within their jurisdictions that they have determined are subject to the enforcement of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-905(1)(a): establish control over these identifiable areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-905(1)(b): intimidate others from entering those areas; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-905(1)(c): conceal illegal activities conducted in those areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-905(2): 76-9-903; 76-9-903; (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-905(2)(a): 76-9-903; 76-9-903 Prior to designating areas subject to enforcement under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-905(2)(b): (2)(a) Persons consulted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-905(2)(b)(i): members of local law enforcement agencies who have training or experience related to criminal street gangs;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-905(2)(b)(ii): other agency personnel with particular knowledge of gang activities in the proposed designated area;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-905(2)(b)(iii): elected and appointed officials of the area where the proposed designated area is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-905(2)(b)(iv): representatives of community-based organizations.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-905(3): (1) The municipal or county legislative body shall develop and implement procedures for periodic review and update of area designations it makes under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-906 Protection of constitutional rights.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-906(1): This section does not affect or limit any individual's constitutional right to engage in collective advocacy activities that are protected by the constitution or laws of this state or by the constitution or laws of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-906(2): 76-9-903 The sheriff or chief of police shall issue a written directive to all agency employees that provides information on preventing the enforcement of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-907 Training for participating law enforcement officers.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The sheriff or chief of police implementing this part shall ensure that:Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-907(1): all officers charged with enforcing this part successfully complete appropriate training on identification of gang members and criminal street gangs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-907(2): Title 63G, Chapter 22, State Training and Certification Requirements any training described in this section complies with


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1001 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as "The Illegal Immigration Enforcement Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1002 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1002(1): "Alien" means a person who is not a citizen or national of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1002(2): "ICE" means the federal Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency of the United States Department of Homeland Security.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1002(3): 53-13-103 "Law enforcement officer" has the same meaning as in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1002(4): "SAVE program" means the federal Systematic Alien Verification for Entitlements program operated by the federal Department of Homeland Security.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1002(5): "State or local governmental agency" includes any private contractor or vendor that contracts with the agency to provide the agency's functions or services.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1002(6): "Verify immigration status" or "verification of immigration status" means the determination of a person's immigration status by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1002(6)(a): a law enforcement officer who is authorized by a federal agency to determine an alien's immigration status; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1002(6)(b): the United States Department of Homeland Security, ICE, or other federal agency authorized to provide immigration status as provided by 8 U.S.C. Sec. 1373(c).


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1003 Detention or arrest -- Determination of immigration status.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1003(1): (1)(b); (c); (d); (1)(a)(i); (ii); 76-9-1004(1); (1)(b); (c); (d); (1)(b); (c); (d); (1)(a); (1)(a); (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1003(1)(a): (1)(b); (c); (d); (1)(a)(i); (ii); 76-9-1004(1); (1)(b); (c); (d); (1)(b); (c); (d) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1003(1)(a)(i): (1)(b); (c); (d) shall request verification of the citizenship or the immigration status of the person under 8 U.S.C. Sec. 1373(c), except as allowed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1003(1)(a)(ii): (1)(b); (c); (d) may attempt to verify the immigration status of the person, except as exempted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1003(1)(b): (1)(a) In individual cases, the law enforcement officer may forego the verification of immigration status under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1003(1)(c): (1)(a) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1003(1)(d): (1)(a) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1003(2): (1); 76-5-308; 76-5-308.1; 76-5-308.3; 76-5-308.5; 76-5-310; 76-5-310.1; 76-10-2901 When a law enforcement officer makes a lawful stop, detention, or arrest under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1003(2)(a): detain the occupants of the vehicle to investigate the suspected violations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1003(2)(b): inquire regarding the immigration status of the occupants of the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1003(3): (1) When a person under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1003(4): The law enforcement agency that has custody of a person verified to be an illegal alien shall request that the United States Department of Homeland Security issue a detainer requesting transfer of the illegal alien into federal custody.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1003(5): A law enforcement officer may not consider race, color, or national origin in implementing this section, except to the extent permitted by the constitutions of the United States and this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1004 Grounds for presumption of lawful presence in United States -- Statement to officer.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1004(1): 53-3-804; 63G-14-204 A person is presumed to be lawfully present in the United States for the purposes of this part if the person provides one of the following documents to the law enforcement officer, unless the law enforcement officer has a reasonable suspicion that the document is false or identifies a person other than the person providing the document:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1004(1)(a): a valid Utah driver license issued on or after January 1, 2010;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1004(1)(b): 53-3-804 a valid Utah identification card issued under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1004(1)(c): a valid tribal enrollment card or other valid form of tribal membership identification that includes photo identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1004(1)(d): a valid identification document that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1004(1)(d)(i): includes a photo or biometric identifier of the holder of the document; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1004(1)(d)(ii): is issued by a federal, state, or local governmental agency that requires proof or verification of legal presence in the United States as a condition of issuance of the document; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1004(1)(e): 63G-14-204 a valid resident immigrant permit issued under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1004(2): A person is presumed to be a citizen or national of the United States for purposes of this part if the person makes a statement or affirmation to the law enforcement officer that the person is a United States citizen or national, unless the officer has a reasonable suspicion that the statement or affirmation is false.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1005 Illegal alien -- Notification of federal government -- Transportation to federal facility.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A state or local law enforcement agency may securely transport an alien who is in the agency's custody and whom the agency has verified is unlawfully present in the United States to a federal detention facility in this state or, with the concurrence of the receiving federal agency, to a federal facility or other point of transfer to federal custody that is outside this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1006 Enforcement of federal immigration laws.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
A state or local governmental agency of this state, or any representative of the agency, may not:Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1006(1): limit or restrict by ordinance, regulation, or policy the authority of any law enforcement agency or other governmental agency to assist the federal government in the enforcement of any federal law or regulation governing immigration; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1006(2): limit or restrict by ordinance, regulation, or policy the authority of any law enforcement agency to investigate or enforce any violation of the federal misdemeanor offenses of willful failure to register as an alien or willful failure to personally possess an alien registration document as required by 8 U.S.C. Sec. 1304(e) or 1306(a).


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1007 Determining an alien's immigration status -- Transfer or maintenance of information.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Except as limited by federal law, any state or local governmental agency is not restricted or prohibited in any way from sending, receiving, or maintaining information related to the lawful or unlawful immigration status of any person by communicating with any federal, state, or local governmental entity for any lawful purpose, including:Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1007(1): determining a person's eligibility for any public benefit, service, or license provided by any federal agency, by this state, or by any political subdivision of this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1007(2): confirming a person's claim of residence or domicile if determination is required by state law or a judicial order issued pursuant to a civil or criminal proceeding in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1007(3): if the person is an alien, determining if the person is in compliance with the federal registration laws of Title II, Part 7, Immigration and Nationality Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1007(4): a valid request for verification of the citizenship or immigration status of any person pursuant to 8 U.S.C. Sec. 1373.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1008 Proof of immigration status required to receive public benefits.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1008(1): 63G-12-402; 63G-12-402(3)(g); (k); (1)(b); (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1008(1)(a): 63G-12-402; 63G-12-402(3)(g); (k) An agency that provides state or local public benefits as defined in 8 U.S.C. Sec. 1621 shall comply with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1008(1)(a)(i): 63G-12-402(3)(g); (k) as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1008(1)(a)(ii): when compliance is exempted by federal law or when compliance could reasonably be expected to be grounds for the federal government to withhold federal Medicaid funding.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1008(1)(b): The agency shall verify a person's lawful presence in the United States by requiring that the applicant under this section sign a certificate under penalty of perjury, stating that the applicant:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1008(1)(b)(i): is a United States citizen; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1008(1)(b)(ii): is a qualified alien as defined by 8 U.S.C. Sec. 1641.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1008(1)(c): (1)(b) The certificate under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1008(1)(d): (1) The signature under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1008(1)(e): When an applicant who is a qualified alien has executed the certificate under this section, the applicant's eligibility for benefits shall be verified by the agency through the federal SAVE program or an equivalent program designated by the United States Department of Homeland Security.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1008(2): 76-8-1205 Any person who knowingly and willfully makes a false, fictitious, or fraudulent statement of representation in a certificate executed under this section is guilty of public assistance fraud under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1008(3): If the certificate constitutes a false claim of United States citizenship under 18 U.S.C. Sec. 911, the agency requiring the certificate shall file a complaint with the United States Attorney for the applicable federal judicial district based upon the venue in which the certificate was executed.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1008(4): Agencies may, with the concurrence of the Utah Attorney General, adopt variations to the requirements of the provisions of this section that provide for adjudication of unique individual circumstances where the verification procedures in this section would impose unusual hardship on a legal resident of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1008(5): (1); 76-8-1205 If an agency under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-9-1009 Implementation to be consistent with federal law and civil rights.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
All state and local agencies shall implement this part in a manner that is consistent with federal laws that regulate immigration, protect the civil rights of all persons, and establish the privileges and immunities of United States citizens.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 76 - Chapter 10 - Offenses Against Public Health, Safety, Welfare, and Morals
*********************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(1)(a): "Alternative nicotine product" means a product, other than a cigarette, a counterfeit cigarette, an electronic cigarette product, a nontherapeutic nicotine product, or a tobacco product, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(1)(a)(i): contains nicotine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(1)(a)(ii): is intended for human consumption;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(1)(a)(iii): is not purchased with a prescription from a licensed physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(1)(a)(iv): is not approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration as nicotine replacement therapy.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(1)(b): "Alternative nicotine product" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(1)(b)(i): pure nicotine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(1)(b)(ii): snortable nicotine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(1)(b)(iii): dissolvable salts, orbs, pellets, sticks, or strips; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(1)(b)(iv): nicotine-laced food and beverage.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(1)(c): "Alternative nicotine product" does not include a fruit, a vegetable, or a tea that contains naturally occurring nicotine.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(2): "Cigar" means a product that contains nicotine, is intended to be burned under ordinary conditions of use, and consists of any roll of tobacco wrapped in leaf tobacco, or in any substance containing tobacco, other than any roll of tobacco that is a cigarette.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(3): (3)(a) "Cigarette" means a product that contains nicotine, is intended to be heated or burned under ordinary conditions of use, and consists of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(3)(a): any roll of tobacco wrapped in paper or in any substance not containing tobacco; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(3)(b): (3)(a) any roll of tobacco wrapped in any substance containing tobacco which, because of its appearance, the type of tobacco used in the filler, or its packaging and labeling, is likely to be offered to, or purchased by, consumers as a cigarette described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(4): (4)(a)(i); (4)(a)(i); (4)(a); 26B-4-201
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(4)(a): (4)(a)(i); (4)(a)(i) "Electronic cigarette" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(4)(a)(i): any electronic oral device:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(4)(a)(i)(A): that provides an aerosol or a vapor of nicotine or other substance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(4)(a)(i)(B): which simulates smoking through the use or inhalation of the device;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(4)(a)(ii): (4)(a)(i) a component of the device described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(4)(a)(iii): (4)(a)(i) an accessory sold in the same package as the device described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(4)(b): (4)(a) "Electronic cigarette" includes an oral device that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(4)(b)(i): composed of a heating element, battery, or electronic circuit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(4)(b)(ii): (4)(a) marketed, manufactured, distributed, or sold as:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(4)(b)(ii)(A): an e-cigarette;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(4)(b)(ii)(B): an e-cigar;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(4)(b)(ii)(C): an e-pipe; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(4)(b)(ii)(D): (4)(a) any other product name or descriptor, if the function of the product meets the definition of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(4)(c): 26B-4-201 "Electronic cigarette" does not mean a medical cannabis device, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(5): "Electronic cigarette product" means an electronic cigarette, an electronic cigarette substance, or a prefilled electronic cigarette.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(6): "Electronic cigarette substance" means any substance, including liquid containing nicotine, used or intended for use in an electronic cigarette.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(7)(a): "Flavored electronic cigarette product" means an electronic cigarette product that has a taste or smell that is distinguishable by an ordinary consumer either before or during use or consumption of the electronic cigarette product.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(7)(b): "Flavored electronic cigarette product" includes an electronic cigarette product that has a taste or smell of any fruit, chocolate, vanilla, honey, candy, cocoa, dessert, alcoholic beverage, herb, or spice.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(7)(c): "Flavored electronic cigarette product" does not include an electronic cigarette product that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(7)(c)(i): has a taste or smell of only tobacco, mint, or menthol; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(7)(c)(ii): has been approved by an order granting a premarket tobacco product application of the electronic cigarette product by the United States Food and Drug Administration under 21 U.S.C. Sec. 387j(c)(1)(A)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(8): "Nicotine" means a poisonous, nitrogen containing chemical that is made synthetically or derived from tobacco or other plants.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(9): "Nicotine product" means an alternative nicotine product or a nontherapeutic nicotine product.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(10)(a): "Nontherapeutic nicotine device" means a device that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(10)(a)(i): has a pressurized canister that is used to administer nicotine to the user through inhalation or intranasally;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(10)(a)(ii): is not purchased with a prescription from a licensed physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(10)(a)(iii): is not approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration as nicotine replacement therapy.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(10)(b): "Nontherapeutic nicotine device" includes a nontherapeutic nicotine inhaler or a nontherapeutic nicotine nasal spray.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(11): "Nontherapeutic nicotine device substance" means a substance that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(11)(a): contains nicotine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(11)(b): is sold in a cartridge for use in a nontherapeutic nicotine device;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(11)(c): is not purchased with a prescription from a licensed physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(11)(d): is not approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration as nicotine replacement therapy.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(12): "Nontherapeutic nicotine product" means a nontherapeutic nicotine device, a nontherapeutic nicotine device substance, or a prefilled nontherapeutic nicotine device.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13): "Place of business" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(a): a shop;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(b): a store;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(c): a factory;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(d): a public garage;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(e): an office;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(f): a theater;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(g): a recreation hall;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(h): a dance hall;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(i): a poolroom;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(j): a cafe;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(k): a cafeteria;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(l): a cabaret;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(m): a restaurant;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(n): a hotel;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(o): a lodging house;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(p): a streetcar;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(q): a bus;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(r): an interurban or railway passenger coach;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(s): a waiting room; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(13)(t): any other place of business.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(14): "Prefilled electronic cigarette" means an electronic cigarette that is sold prefilled with an electronic cigarette substance.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(15): "Prefilled nontherapeutic nicotine device" means a nontherapeutic nicotine device that is sold prefilled with a nontherapeutic nicotine device substance.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(16): 26B-7-501 "Retail tobacco specialty business" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(17): "Smoking" means the possession of any lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe, or other lighted smoking equipment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(18): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(18)(a): "Tobacco paraphernalia" means equipment, product, or material of any kind that is used, intended for use, or designed for use to package, repackage, store, contain, conceal, ingest, inhale, or otherwise introduce a tobacco product, an electronic cigarette substance, or a nontherapeutic nicotine device substance into the human body.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(18)(b): "Tobacco paraphernalia" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(18)(b)(i): metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic, or ceramic pipes with or without screens, permanent screens, hashish heads, or punctured metal bowls;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(18)(b)(ii): water pipes;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(18)(b)(iii): carburetion tubes and devices;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(18)(b)(iv): smoking and carburetion masks;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(18)(b)(v): roach clips, meaning objects used to hold burning material, such as a cigarette, that has become too small or too short to be held in the hand;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(18)(b)(vi): chamber pipes;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(18)(b)(vii): carburetor pipes;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(18)(b)(viii): electric pipes;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(18)(b)(ix): air-driven pipes;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(18)(b)(x): chillums;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(18)(b)(xi): bongs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(18)(b)(xii): ice pipes or chillers.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(18)(c): "Tobacco paraphernalia" does not include matches or lighters.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(19): "Tobacco product" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(19)(a): a cigar;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(19)(b): a cigarette; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(19)(c): tobacco in any form, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(19)(c)(i): chewing tobacco; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(19)(c)(ii): any substitute for tobacco, including flavoring or additives to tobacco.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(20): 26B-7-501 "Tobacco retailer" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(20)(a): 26B-7-501 a general tobacco retailer, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-101(20)(b): a retail tobacco specialty business.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-102 Cigarettes and tobacco -- Advertising restrictions -- Warnings in smokeless tobacco advertisements.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-102(1): It is a class B misdemeanor for any person to display on any billboard, streetcar sign, streetcar, bus, placard, or on any other object or place of display, any advertisement of cigarettes, cigarette papers, cigars, chewing tobacco, or smoking tobacco or any disguise or substitute of either, except that a dealer in cigarettes, cigarette papers, tobacco or cigars, or their substitutes, may have a sign on the front of his place of business stating that he is a dealer in the articles; provided that nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the advertising of cigarettes, cigarette papers, chewing tobacco or smoking tobacco, or any substitute of either, in any newspaper, magazine or periodical printed or circulating in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-102(2): Any advertisement for smokeless tobacco placed in a newspaper, magazine, or periodical published in this state must bear a warning which states: "Use of smokeless tobacco may cause oral cancer and other mouth disorders and is addictive." This warning must be in a conspicuous location and in conspicuous and legible type, in contrast with the typography, layout, and color of all other printed material in the advertisement.  For purposes of this subsection, "smokeless tobacco" means any finely cut, ground, powdered, or leaf tobacco that is intended to be placed in the oral cavity or nasal passage.  In the event the United States Congress passes legislation which requires warnings in advertisements of smokeless tobacco, the specific language required to be placed in advertisements by that legislation shall take precedence over this subsection.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-103 Permitting minors to use tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, or nicotine products in place of business.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is a class C misdemeanor for the proprietor of any place of business to knowingly permit an individual under 21 years old to frequent a place of business while the individual is using a tobacco product, an electronic cigarette product, or a nicotine product.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104 Providing a cigar, a cigarette, an electronic cigarette product, a nicotine product, or tobacco to a minor -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104(1): As used in this section "provides":
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104(1)(a): includes selling, giving, furnishing, sending, or causing to be sent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104(1)(b): does not include the acts of the United States Postal Service or other common carrier when engaged in the business of transporting and delivering packages for others or the acts of a person, whether compensated or not, who transports or delivers a package for another person without any reason to know of the package's content.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104(2): An individual who knowingly, intentionally, recklessly, or with criminal negligence provides a tobacco product, an electronic cigarette product, or a nicotine product to an individual who is under 21 years old, is guilty of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104(2)(a): a class C misdemeanor on the first offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104(2)(b): a class B misdemeanor on the second offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104(2)(c): a class A misdemeanor on any subsequent offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104(3): 76-10-114 This section does not apply to conduct of an employee of a tobacco retailer that is a violation of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104.1 Providing tobacco paraphernalia to a minor -- Penalties.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104.1(1): As used in this section, "provides":
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104.1(1)(a): includes selling, giving, furnishing, sending, or causing to be sent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104.1(1)(b): does not include the acts of the United States Postal Service or other common carrier when engaged in the business of transporting and delivering packages for others or the acts of a person, whether compensated or not, who transports or delivers a package for another person without any reason to know of the package's content.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104.1(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104.1(2)(a): It is unlawful for an individual to knowingly, intentionally, recklessly, or with criminal negligence provide tobacco paraphernalia to an individual under 21 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104.1(2)(b): An individual who violates this section is guilty of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104.1(2)(b)(i): a class C misdemeanor on the first offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-104.1(2)(b)(ii): a class B misdemeanor on any subsequent offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-105 Buying or possessing a tobacco product or an electronic cigarette product by a minor -- Penalty -- Compliance officer authority -- Juvenile court jurisdiction.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-105(1): An individual who is 18 years old or older, but younger than 21 years old, and who buys or attempts to buy, accepts, or has in the individual's possession a tobacco product, an electronic cigarette product, or a nicotine product is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-105(1)(a): guilty of an infraction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-105(1)(b): subject to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-105(1)(b)(i): a minimum fine or penalty of $60; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-105(1)(b)(ii): participation in a court-approved tobacco education or cessation program, which may include a participation fee.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-105.1(1)(a)(ii)(B): self-service display.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-105.1(1)(b)(ii): operates a facility with a vending machine that sells a tobacco product, an electronic cigarette product, or a nicotine product.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-105.3 Prohibition of sale or gift of clove cigarettes.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is unlawful for any person to knowingly sell, offer for sale, give or furnish any clove cigarette in this state.  For purposes of this section "clove cigarette" means any cigarette which contains more than 10%, by weight, of raw eugenia caryophyllata or caryophyllus, commonly known as clove.  Any person who violates this section is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107 Abuse of psychotoxic chemical solvents.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107(1): (1)(a) A person is guilty of abuse of psychotoxic chemical solvents if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107(1)(a): for the purpose of causing a condition of intoxication, inebriation, excitement, stupefaction, or the dulling of his brain or nervous system, he intentionally:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107(1)(a)(i): smells or inhales the fumes of any psychotoxic chemical solvent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107(1)(a)(ii): possesses, purchases, or attempts to possess or purchase any psychotoxic chemical solvent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107(1)(b): (1)(a) the person offers, sells, or provides a psychotoxic chemical solvent to another person, knowing that other person or a third party intends to possess or use that psychotoxic chemical solvent in violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107(2): This section does not apply to the prescribed use, distribution, or sale of those substances for medical or dental purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107(3): Abuse of psychotoxic chemical solvents is a class B misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107(4): Title 58, Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act As used in this section, psychotoxic chemical solvent includes any glue, cement, or other substance containing one or more of the following chemical compounds: acetone and acetate, amyl nitrite or amyl nitrate or their isomers, benzene, butyl alcohol, butyl nitrite, butyl nitrate, or their isomers, ethyl alcohol, ethyl nitrite or ethyl nitrate, ethylene dichloride, isobutyl alcohol, methyl alcohol, methyl ethyl ketone, n-propyl alcohol, pentachlorophenol, petroleum ether, propyl nitrite or propyl nitrate or their isomers, toluene or xylene, or other chemical substance capable of causing a condition of intoxication, inebriation, excitement, stupefaction, or the dulling of the brain or nervous system as a result of the inhalation of the fumes or vapors of such chemical substance.  Nothing in this section shall be construed to include any controlled substance regulated by the provisions of


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107.5 Abuse of nitrous oxide -- Penalty.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107.5(1): As used in this section, "nitrous oxide" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107.5(1)(a): N2O, a colorless gas or liquid that is also referred to as dinitrogen monoxide, nitrogen oxide, or laughing gas; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107.5(1)(b): any substance containing nitrous oxide.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107.5(2): (2)(a); (b) A person is guilty of abuse of nitrous oxide who:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107.5(2)(a): possesses nitrous oxide with the intent to breathe, inhale, or ingest it for the purpose of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107.5(2)(a)(i): causing a condition of intoxication, elation, euphoria, dizziness, stupefaction, or dulling of the senses;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107.5(2)(a)(ii): in any manner changing, distorting, or disturbing the audio, visual, or mental processes;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107.5(2)(b): knowingly and intentionally is under the influence of nitrous oxide; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107.5(2)(c): (2)(a); (b) offers, sells, or provides nitrous oxide to another person, knowing that other person or a third party intends to possess or use the nitrous oxide in violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107.5(3): (2)(b) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107.5(4): (2)(c) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-107.5(5): A violation of this section is a class A misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111 Restrictions on sale of smokeless tobacco or electronic cigarette products -- Exceptions.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(1): (1) The Legislature finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(1)(a): smokeless tobacco, or chewing tobacco, is harmful to the health of individuals who use those products because research indicates that they may cause mouth or oral cancers;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(1)(b): the use of smokeless tobacco among juveniles in this state is increasing rapidly;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(1)(c): the use of electronic cigarette products may lead to unhealthy behavior such as the use of tobacco products; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(1)(d): (1) it is necessary to restrict the gift of the products described in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(2): (3); (2)(a)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(2)(a): (3) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(2)(a)(i): give or distribute without charge any smokeless tobacco, chewing tobacco, or electronic cigarette product in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(2)(a)(ii): sell, offer for sale, or furnish any electronic cigarette product at less than the cost, including the amount of any applicable tax, of the product to the manufacturer, wholesaler, or retailer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(2)(a)(iii): give, distribute, sell, offer for sale, or furnish any electronic cigarette product for free or at a lower price because the recipient of the electronic cigarette product makes another purchase.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(2)(b): (2)(a)(ii) The price that a manufacturer, wholesaler, or retailer may charge under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(2)(b)(i): a physical manufacturer coupon:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(2)(b)(i)(A): that is surrendered to the wholesaler or retailer at the time of sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(2)(b)(i)(B): for which the manufacturer will reimburse the wholesaler or the retailer for the full amount of the discount described in the manufacturer coupon and provided to the purchaser;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(2)(b)(ii): a rebate that will be paid to the manufacturer, the wholesaler, or the retailer for the full amount of the rebate provided to the purchaser; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(2)(b)(iii): a promotional fund that will be paid to the manufacturer, the wholesaler, or the retailer for the full amount of the promotional fund provided to the purchaser.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(2)(c): Any individual who violates this section is guilty of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(2)(c)(i): a class C misdemeanor for the first offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(2)(c)(ii): a class B misdemeanor for any subsequent offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-111(3): Smokeless tobacco, chewing tobacco, or an electronic cigarette product may be distributed to adults without charge at professional conventions where the general public is excluded.
