------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person, including a person licensed to carry a concealed firearm under

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-524 Purchase of firearms pursuant to federal law.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
This part will allow purchases of firearms and ammunition pursuant to U.S.C. Title 18 Chapter 44 Sec. 922b(3).

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526 Criminal background check prior to purchase of a firearm -- Fee -- Exemption for concealed firearm permit holders and law enforcement officers.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(1): 53-5-705 For purposes of this section, "valid permit to carry a concealed firearm" does not include a temporary permit issued under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(2): 53-3-207; (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(2)(a): To establish personal identification and residence in this state for purposes of this part, a dealer shall require an individual receiving a firearm to present one photo identification on a form issued by a governmental agency of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(2)(b): 53-3-207; (2) A dealer may not accept a driving privilege card issued under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(3)(a): A criminal history background check is required for the sale of a firearm by a licensed firearm dealer in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(3)(b): (3)(a) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(4)(a): An individual purchasing a firearm from a dealer shall consent in writing to a criminal background check, on a form provided by the bureau.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(4)(b): The form shall contain the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(4)(b)(i): the dealer identification number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(4)(b)(ii): the name and address of the individual receiving the firearm;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(4)(b)(iii): the date of birth, height, weight, eye color, and hair color of the individual receiving the firearm; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(4)(b)(iv): the social security number or any other identification number of the individual receiving the firearm.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(5): (4); (4); (7)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(5)(a): (4) The dealer shall send the information required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(5)(b): (4); (7) A dealer may not sell or transfer a firearm to an individual until the dealer has provided the bureau with the information in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(6): The dealer shall make a request for criminal history background information by telephone or other electronic means to the bureau and shall receive approval or denial of the inquiry by telephone or other electronic means.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(7): 53-5c-301 When the dealer calls for or requests a criminal history background check, the bureau shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(7)(a): 53-5c-301 review the criminal history files, including juvenile court records, and the temporary restricted file created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(7)(b): inform the dealer that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(7)(b)(i): the records indicate the individual is prohibited; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(7)(b)(ii): the individual is approved for purchasing, possessing, or transferring a firearm;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(7)(c): provide the dealer with a unique transaction number for that inquiry; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(7)(d): provide a response to the requesting dealer during the call for a criminal background check, or by return call, or other electronic means, without delay, except in case of electronic failure or other circumstances beyond the control of the bureau, the bureau shall advise the dealer of the reason for the delay and give the dealer an estimate of the length of the delay.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(8)(a): The bureau may not maintain any records of the criminal history background check longer than 20 days from the date of the dealer's request, if the bureau determines that the individual receiving the firearm is not prohibited from purchasing, possessing, or transferring the firearm under state or federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(8)(b): However, the bureau shall maintain a log of requests containing the dealer's federal firearms number, the transaction number, and the transaction date for a period of 12 months.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(9): (9)(a); 53-5c-301; (9)(a); (9)(a); (9)(c)(i); (9)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(9)(a): If the criminal history background check discloses information indicating that the individual attempting to purchase the firearm is prohibited from purchasing, possessing, or transferring a firearm, the bureau shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(9)(a)(i): within 24 hours after determining that the purchaser is prohibited from purchasing, possessing, or transferring a firearm, notify the law enforcement agency in the jurisdiction where the dealer is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-526(9)(a)(ii): inform the law enforcement agency in the jurisdiction where the individual resides.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-527 Penalties.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-527(1): 76-10-526 A dealer is guilty of a class A misdemeanor who willfully and intentionally:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-527(1)(a): requests, obtains, or seeks to obtain criminal history background information under false pretenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-527(1)(b): disseminates criminal history background information; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-527(1)(c): 76-10-526 violates Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-527(2): 76-10-526 A person who purchases or transfers a firearm is guilty of a felony of the third degree if the person willfully and intentionally makes a false statement of the information required for a criminal background check in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-527(3): (1) Except as otherwise provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-527(4): A person is guilty of a felony of the third degree if the person purchases a firearm with the intent to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-527(4)(a): resell or otherwise provide a firearm to a person who is ineligible to purchase or receive a firearm from a dealer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-527(4)(b): transport a firearm out of this state to be resold to an ineligible person.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528 Carrying a dangerous weapon while under influence of alcohol or drugs unlawful.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(1): 41-6a-502(1)(a); (c); 58-37-2 It is a class B misdemeanor for an actor to carry a dangerous weapon while under the influence of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(1)(a): 41-6a-502(1)(a); (c) alcohol as determined by the actor's blood or breath alcohol concentration in accordance with Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(1)(b): 58-37-2 a controlled substance as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(2): 76-2-402; 26B-4-201; Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis; (2)(e)(i) This section does not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(2)(a): an actor carrying a dangerous weapon that is either securely encased, as defined in this part, or not within such close proximity and in such a manner that it can be retrieved and used as readily as if carried on the person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(2)(b): 76-2-402 an actor who uses or threatens to use force in compliance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(2)(c): an actor carrying a dangerous weapon in the actor's residence or the residence of another with the consent of the individual who is lawfully in possession;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(2)(d): 26B-4-201; Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis an actor under the influence of cannabis or a cannabis product, as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(2)(e): (2)(e)(i) an actor who:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(2)(e)(i): has a valid prescription for a controlled substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(2)(e)(ii): (2)(e)(i) takes the controlled substance described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(2)(e)(iii): after taking the controlled substance, the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(2)(e)(iii)(A): is not a danger to the actor or another individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(2)(e)(iii)(B): is capable of safely handling a dangerous weapon.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(3): It is not a defense to prosecution under this section that the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(3)(a): is licensed in the pursuit of wildlife of any kind; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-528(3)(b): has a valid permit to carry a concealed firearm.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529 Possession of dangerous weapons, firearms, or explosives in airport secure areas prohibited -- Penalty.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(1): 72-10-102; 76-10-306; 53-13-103; 76-1-101.5; 76-10-501
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(1)(a): 72-10-102; 76-10-306; 53-13-103 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(1)(a)(i): 72-10-102 "Airport authority" has the same meaning as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(1)(a)(ii): 76-10-306 "Explosive" is the same as defined for "explosive, chemical, or incendiary device" in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(1)(a)(iii): 53-13-103 "Law enforcement officer" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(1)(b): 76-1-101.5; 76-10-501 Terms defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(2): Title 53, Chapter 5, Part 7, Concealed Firearm Act; 76-10-306; (2)(a); 76-10-523
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(2)(a): Title 53, Chapter 5, Part 7, Concealed Firearm Act; 76-10-306 Within a secure area of an airport established pursuant to this section, a person, including a person licensed to carry a concealed firearm under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(2)(a)(i): a class A misdemeanor if the person knowingly or intentionally possesses any dangerous weapon or firearm;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(2)(a)(ii): an infraction if the person recklessly possesses any dangerous weapon or firearm; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(2)(a)(iii): 76-10-306 a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(2)(b): (2)(a); 76-10-523 Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(2)(b)(i): 76-10-523 persons exempted under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(2)(b)(ii): members of the state or federal military forces while engaged in the performance of their official duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(3): An airport authority, county, or municipality regulating the airport may:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(3)(a): establish any secure area located beyond the main area where the public generally buys tickets, checks and retrieves luggage; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(3)(b): use reasonable means, including mechanical, electronic, x-ray, or any other device, to detect dangerous weapons, firearms, or explosives concealed in baggage or upon the person of any individual attempting to enter the secure area.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(4): At least one notice shall be prominently displayed at each entrance to a secure area in which a dangerous weapon, firearm, or explosive is restricted.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(5): Upon the discovery of any dangerous weapon, firearm, or explosive, the airport authority, county, or municipality, the employees, or other personnel administering the secure area may:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(5)(a): require the individual to deliver the item to the air freight office or airline ticket counter;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(5)(b): require the individual to exit the secure area; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(5)(c): obtain possession or retain custody of the item until it is transferred to law enforcement officers.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(6): 77-11a-402(1)(b); 77-11b-102(5)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(6)(a): 77-11a-402(1)(b) An individual who is prosecuted for a violation of this section based on the possession of a firearm shall have the individual's firearm returned to the individual in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(6)(b): 77-11b-102(5) In accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-529(6)(c): In a prosecution brought under this section, a prosecutor may not condition a plea on the forfeiture of a firearm.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530 Trespass with a firearm in a house of worship or private residence -- Notice -- Penalty.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(1): Title 53, Chapter 5, Part 7, Concealed Firearm Act; (2) A person, including a person licensed to carry a concealed firearm pursuant to
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(1)(a): transport a firearm into:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(1)(a)(i): a house of worship; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(1)(a)(ii): a private residence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(1)(b): while in possession of a firearm, enter or remain in:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(1)(b)(i): a house of worship; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(1)(b)(ii): a private residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(2): (2)(a)(i); (ii); 45-1-101 Notice that firearms are prohibited may be given by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(2)(a): (2)(a)(i); (ii) personal communication to the actor by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(2)(a)(i): the church or organization operating the house of worship;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(2)(a)(ii): the owner, lessee, or person with lawful right of possession of the private residence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(2)(a)(iii): (2)(a)(i); (ii) a person with authority to act for the person or entity in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(2)(b): posting of signs reasonably likely to come to the attention of persons entering the house of worship or private residence;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(2)(c): announcement, by a person with authority to act for the church or organization operating the house of worship, in a regular congregational meeting in the house of worship;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(2)(d): publication in a bulletin, newsletter, worship program, or similar document generally circulated or available to the members of the congregation regularly meeting in the house of worship; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(2)(e): 45-1-101 publication:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(2)(e)(i): in a newspaper of general circulation in the county in which the house of worship is located or the church or organization operating the house of worship has its principal office in this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(2)(e)(ii): 45-1-101 as required in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(3): (2) A church or organization operating a house of worship and giving notice that firearms are prohibited may:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(3)(a): (2) revoke the notice, with or without supersedure, by giving further notice in any manner provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(3)(b): provide or allow exceptions to the prohibition as the church or organization considers advisable.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(4): (2)(c); (d); (e); (4)(a)(i); (2)(c); (d); (e)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(4)(a): (2)(c); (d); (e); (4)(a)(i)

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(4)(b): (2)(c); (d); (e) Any notice given pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(5): Nothing in this section permits an owner who has granted the lawful right of possession to a renter or lessee to restrict the renter or lessee from lawfully possessing a firearm in the residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-530(6): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532 Removal from National Instant Check System database.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(1): 76-10-503(1)(b)(vi); (vii); (viii) A person who is subject to the restrictions in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(2): The petition shall be filed in the district court in the county where the commitment, finding, or adjudication occurred.  The petition shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(2)(a): a listing of facilities, with their addresses, where the petitioner has ever received mental health treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(2)(b): a release signed by the petitioner to allow the prosecutor or county attorney to obtain the petitioner's mental health records;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(2)(c): a verified report of a mental health evaluation conducted by a licensed psychiatrist occurring within 30 days prior to the filing of the petition, which shall include a statement regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(2)(c)(i): the nature of the commitment, finding, or adjudication that resulted in the restriction on the petitioner's ability to purchase or possess a dangerous weapon;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(2)(c)(ii): the petitioner's previous and current mental health treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(2)(c)(iii): the petitioner's previous violent behavior, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(2)(c)(iv): the petitioner's current mental health medications and medication management;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(2)(c)(v): the length of time the petitioner has been stable;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(2)(c)(vi): external factors that may influence the petitioner's stability;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(2)(c)(vii): the ability of the petitioner to maintain stability with or without medication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(2)(c)(viii): whether the petitioner is dangerous to public safety; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(2)(d): a copy of the petitioner's state and federal criminal history record.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(3): The petitioner shall serve the petition on the prosecuting entity that prosecuted the case or, if the disability is not based on a criminal case, on the county or district attorney's office having jurisdiction where the petition was filed and the individual who filed the original action which resulted in the disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(4): The court shall schedule a hearing as soon as practicable.  The petitioner may present evidence and subpoena witnesses to appear at the hearing.  The prosecuting, county attorney, or the individual who filed the original action which resulted in the disability may object to the petition and present evidence in support of the objection.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(5): The court shall consider the following evidence:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(5)(a): the facts and circumstances that resulted in the commitment, finding, or adjudication;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(5)(b): the person's mental health and criminal history records; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(5)(c): the person's reputation, including the testimony of character witnesses.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(6): The court shall grant the relief if the court finds by clear and convincing evidence that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(6)(a): the person is not a danger to the person or to others;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(6)(b): the person is not likely to act in a manner dangerous to public safety; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(6)(c): the requested relief would not be contrary to the public interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(7): The court shall issue an order with its findings and send a copy to the bureau.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(8): 76-10-503(1)(b)(viii) The bureau, upon receipt of a court order removing a person's disability under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(9): If the court denies the petition, the petitioner may not petition again for relief until at least two years after the date of the court's final order.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-532(10): The petitioner may appeal a denial of the requested relief.  The review on appeal shall be de novo.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-601 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-601(1): "Person" means any individual, organization, group, association, partnership, corporation, or any combination of them;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-601(2): "Professional fund raiser" means any person who for compensation or any other consideration plans, conducts, or manages in this state, the solicitation of contributions for or on behalf of any charitable organization or any other person, or who engages in the business of, or holds himself out to persons in this state as independently engaged in the business of soliciting contributions for such purpose, but shall not include a bona fide officer or employee of a charitable organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-601(3): "Professional solicitor" means any person who is employed or retained for compensation by a professional fund raiser to solicit contributions in this state for charitable purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-601(4): "Charitable organization" means any organization that is benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, or eleemosynary or one purporting to be such;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-601(5): "Contribution" means the promise or grant of any money or property of any kind or value.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-602 Use of person's name without consent for soliciting contribution prohibited -- Exception.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
No charitable organization, professional fund raiser, or professional solicitor, seeking to raise funds for charitable purposes, shall use the name of any other person for the purpose of soliciting contributions, in this state, without the written consent of the person; provided that this section shall not apply to religious corporations or organizations, charities, agencies, and organizations operated, supervised, or controlled by or in connection with a religious corporation or organization.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-603 Use of name without consent on stationery or as one who contributed to organization prohibited.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is a violation of this part to use, without written consent, the name of a person for the purpose of soliciting contributions if the person's name is listed on any stationery, advertisement, brochure, or correspondence of a charitable organization, or his name is listed or referred to as one who has contributed to, sponsored, or endorsed the charitable organization or its activities.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-604 Violations -- Classification of offense.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person who violates the provisions of this part is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-701 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-701(1): "Bona fide stockholder of record" means a stockholder of record who has acquired stock in good faith and is acting for a proper purpose reasonably related to his interests as a stockholder.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-701(2): "Director" means any of the persons having by law the direction or management of the affairs of a corporation, by whatever name the persons are described in its charter or known by law.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-702 Fraudulent signing of stock subscriptions.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who signs the name of a fictitious person to any subscription for, or agreement to take, stock in any corporation existing or proposed, and every person who signs to any subscription or agreement the name of any person, knowing that the person has no means or does not intend in good faith to comply with all the terms thereof, or under any understanding or agreement that the terms of the subscription or agreement are not to be complied with or enforced, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-703 Fraudulent documents relating to organization or increase of capital stock.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every officer, agent, or clerk of any corporation, or any person proposing to organize a corporation, or to increase the capital stock of any corporation, who knowingly exhibits any false, forged, or altered book, paper, voucher, security, or other instrument of evidence to any public officer or board authorized by law to examine the organization of the corporation, or to investigate its affairs, or to allow an increase of its capital, with intent to deceive the officer or board in respect thereto, shall be guilty of a felony of the third degree.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-704 Misrepresenting person as officer, agent, member or promoter.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who, without being authorized so to do, subscribes the name of another to, or inserts the name of another in, any prospectus, circular, or other advertisement or announcement of any corporation or joint stock association, existing or intended to be formed, with intent to permit it to be published, and thereby to lead persons to believe that the person whose name is so subscribed is an officer, agent, member, or promoter of such corporation or association, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-705 Concurrence by director in dividend or division of capital in violation of law.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every director of any stock corporation except savings and loan or building and loan associations who concurs in any vote or act of the directors of the corporation or any of them, by which it is intended either:Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-705(1): Title 16, Chapter 10a, Utah Revised Business Corporation Act to make any dividend except as permitted by
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-705(2): Title 16, Chapter 10a, Utah Revised Business Corporation Act to divide, withdraw, or in any manner pay to the stockholders, or any of them, any part of the stated capital of the corporation except as permitted by


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-706 Unlawful acts by director, officer or agent.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every director, officer, or agent of any corporation or association who knowingly receives or possesses himself of any property of such corporation or association, otherwise than in payment of a just demand, and who, with intent to defraud, omits to make, or to cause or direct to be made, a full and true entry thereof in the books or accounts of the corporation or association; and every director, officer, agent, or member of any corporation or association who embezzles, abstracts, or willfully misapplies any of the money, funds, or credits of the corporation or association; or who, without authority from the directors, issues or puts in circulation any of the notes of the corporation or association; or who, without the authority, issues or puts forth any certificate of deposit, draws any order or bill of exchange, makes any acceptance, assigns any note, bond, draft, bill of exchange, mortgage, judgment, or decree; or who makes any false entry in any book, report, or statement of the corporation or association; or who issues any fraudulent, fictitious, or illegal stock in any such corporation or association, with intent in either case to injure or defraud the corporation or association, or any other company, body politic, or corporate, or any individual person, or to deceive any officer of the corporation or association, or any agent appointed to examine the affairs of any such corporation or association; and every person who, with like intent, aids or abets any officer, clerk, or agent in any violation of this section is guilty of a felony of the third degree.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-707 False reports.
----------------------------------------------
Every director, officer, or agent of any corporation or joint stock association who knowingly makes or concurs in making or publishing any written report, exhibit, or statement of its affairs or pecuniary condition, containing any material statement which is false is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-708 Refusing inspection of books.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Every officer or agent of any corporation having or keeping an office within this state, who has in his custody or control the books of such corporation, and who refuses to give to a bona fide stockholder of record or member of the corporation, lawfully demanding during office hours, the right to inspect or take a copy of it or of any part thereof, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-709 Presumption of director's knowledge of affairs.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every director of a corporation or joint stock association is deemed to possess a knowledge of the affairs of his corporation as to enable him to determine whether any act, proceeding, or omission of its directors is a violation of this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-710 Presumption of director's concurrence in action if present at meeting -- Written dissent required.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every director of a corporation or joint stock association who is present at a meeting of the directors at which any act, proceeding, or omission of the directors in violation of this part occurs is deemed to have concurred therein, unless he at the time causes, or in writing requires, his dissent therefrom to be entered in the minutes of the directors or forwards his dissent by registered mail to the secretary of the corporation immediately after the adjournment of the meeting.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-711 Foreign corporations subject to laws.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
It is no defense to a prosecution for a violation of any of the provisions of this part that the corporation was one created by the laws of another state, government, or country if it was one carrying on business or keeping an office therefor within this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-801 "Nuisance" defined -- Violation -- Classification of offense.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-801(1): A nuisance is any item, thing, manner, condition whatsoever that is dangerous to human life or health or renders soil, air, water, or food impure or unwholesome.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-801(2): Any person, whether as owner, agent, or occupant who creates, aids in creating, or contributes to a nuisance, or who supports, continues, or retains a nuisance, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-802 Befouling waters.
-------------------------------------------------
A person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor if he:Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-802(1): Constructs or maintains a corral, sheep pen, goat pen, stable, pigpen, chicken coop, or other offensive yard or outhouse where the waste or drainage therefrom shall flow directly into the waters of any stream, well, or spring of water used for domestic purposes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-802(2): Deposits, piles, unloads, or leaves any manure heap, offensive rubbish, or the carcass of any dead animal where the waste or drainage therefrom will flow directly into the waters of any stream, well, or spring of water used for domestic purposes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-802(3): Dips or washes sheep in any stream, or constructs, maintains, or uses any pool or dipping vat for dipping or washing sheep in such close proximity to any stream used by the inhabitants of any city or town for domestic purposes as to make the waters thereof impure or unwholesome; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-802(4): Constructs or maintains any corral, yard, or vat to be used for the purpose of shearing or dipping sheep within 12 miles of any city or town, where the refuse or filth from the corral or yard would naturally find its way into any stream of water used by the inhabitants of any city or town for domestic purposes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-802(5): Establishes and maintains any corral, camp, or bedding place for the purpose of herding, holding, or keeping any cattle, horses, sheep, goats, or hogs within seven miles of any city or town, where the refuse or filth from the corral, camp, or bedding place will naturally find its way into any stream of water used by the inhabitants of any city or town for domestic purposes.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-803 "Public nuisance" defined -- Agricultural operations -- Critical infrastructure materials operations.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-803(1): 78B-6-1107 A public nuisance is a crime against the order and economy of the state and consists in unlawfully doing any act or omitting to perform any duty, which act or omission:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-803(1)(a): annoys, injures, or endangers the comfort, repose, health, or safety of three or more persons;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-803(1)(b): offends public decency;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-803(1)(c): unlawfully interferes with, obstructs, or tends to obstruct, or renders dangerous for passage, any lake, stream, canal, or basin, or any public park, square, street, or highway;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-803(1)(d): 78B-6-1107 is a nuisance as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-803(1)(e): in any way renders three or more persons insecure in life or the use of property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-803(2): An act which affects three or more persons in any of the ways specified in this section is still a nuisance regardless of the extent to which the annoyance or damage inflicted on individuals is unequal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-803(3): 4-44-102; (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-803(3)(a): 4-44-102; (1) Activities conducted in the normal and ordinary course of agricultural operations, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-803(3)(b): Agricultural operations undertaken in conformity with federal, state, and local laws and regulations, including zoning ordinances, are presumed to be operating within sound agricultural practices.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-803(4): 78B-6-1101(8); (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-803(4)(a): 78B-6-1101(8); (1) Activities conducted in the normal and ordinary course of critical infrastructure materials operations, as defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-803(4)(b): Critical infrastructure materials operations undertaken in conformity with federal, state, and local laws and regulations, including zoning ordinances, are presumed to be operating within sound critical infrastructure materials operations.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-804 Maintaining, committing or failing to remove public nuisance -- Classification of offense.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who maintains or commits any public nuisance, the punishment for which is not otherwise prescribed, or who willfully omits to perform any legal duty relating to the removal of a public nuisance, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-805 Carcass or offal -- Prohibitions relating to disposal -- Classification of offense.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who puts the carcass of any dead animal, or the offal from any slaughter pen, corral, or butcher shop into any river, creek, pond, street, alley, or public highway, or road in common use, or who attempts to destroy it by fire, within one-fourth of a mile of any city or town is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-806 Action for abatement of public nuisance.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
The county attorney of the county where the public nuisance exists, upon direction of the county  executive, or city attorney of the city where the public nuisance exists, upon direction of the board of city commissioners, or attorney general, upon direction of the governor, or any of the above attorneys without the necessity of direction, is empowered to institute an action in the name of the county, city, or state, as the case may be, to abate a public nuisance.  The action shall be brought in the district court of the district where the public nuisance exists and shall be in the form prescribed by the Rules of Civil Procedure of the State of Utah for injunctions, but none of the above attorneys shall be required to execute a bond with respect to the action. If the action is instituted, however, to abate the distribution or exhibition of material alleged to offend public decency, the action shall be in the form prescribed by the Rules of Civil Procedure of Utah for injunctions, but no restraining order or injunction shall issue except upon notice to the person sought to be enjoined; and that person shall be entitled to a trial of the issues commencing within three days after filing of an answer to the complaint and a decision shall be rendered by the court within two days after the conclusion of the trial.  As used in this part, "distribute," "exhibit," and "material" mean the same as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-807 Violation of order enjoining a public nuisance.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person who knowingly violates any judgment or order abating or otherwise enjoining a public nuisance as defined under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-808 Relief granted for public nuisance.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
If the existence of a public nuisance as defined by SubsectionUtah Code Annotated § 76-10-808(1): permanently enjoin each defendant and any other person from further maintaining the nuisance at the place complained of and each defendant from maintaining such nuisance elsewhere;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-808(2): direct the person enjoined to surrender to the sheriff of the county in which the action was brought any material in his possession which is subject to the injunction, and the sheriff shall seize and destroy this material; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-808(3): without proof of special injury direct that an accounting be had and all money and other consideration paid as admission to view any motion picture film determined to constitute a public nuisance, or paid for any publication determined to constitute a public nuisance, in either case without deduction for expenses, be forfeited and paid into the general fund of the county where the nuisance was maintained.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1001 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
For the purpose of this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1001(1): "Forged trademark," "forged trade name," "forged trade device," and "counterfeited trademark," "counterfeited trade name," "counterfeited trade device," or their equivalents, as used in this part, include every alteration or imitation of any trademark, trade name, or trade device so resembling the original as to be likely to deceive.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1001(2): "Trademark" or "trade name" or "trade device," as used in this part, includes every trademark registrable with the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1002 Forging or counterfeiting trademark, trade name or trade device.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who willfully forges or counterfeits, or procures to be forged or counterfeited, any trademark, trade name, or trade device, usually affixed by any person, or by any association or union of workingmen, to his or its goods, which has been filed with the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code, with intent to pass off any goods to which the forged or counterfeited trademark, trade name, or trade device is affixed, or intended to be affixed, as the goods of the person or association or union of workingmen, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1003 Selling goods under counterfeited trademark, trade name or trade device.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who sells or keeps for sale any goods upon or to which any counterfeited trademark, trade name, or trade device has been affixed, after it has been filed with the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code, intending to represent the goods as the genuine goods of another, knowing it to be counterfeited, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1004 Sales in containers bearing registered trademark of substituted articles.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who has or uses any container or similar article bearing or having in any way connected with it the registered trademark of another for the purpose of disposing, with intent to deceive or defraud, of any article or substance other than that which the container or similar article originally contained or was connected with by the owner of such trademark is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1005 Using, destroying, concealing or possessing articles with registered trademark or service mark to deprive owner of use or possession -- Exception.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who, without the consent of the owner of an article bearing the owner's validly registered trademark or service mark, uses, destroys, conceals, or possesses the article or who defaces or otherwise conceals the trademark or service mark upon the article with intent to deprive the owner of the use or possession of the article is guilty of a class B misdemeanor; provided, however, that nothing contained in this part shall be construed to apply to or restrict the transfer or use of wooden boxes or the re-use of burlap or cotton bags or sacks when those bags or sacks have been reversed inside out or the markings thereon have been concealed or obliterated to effectively demonstrate that the products contained therein do not purport to be the products of the owner of the registered trademark or service mark theretofore put upon those bags.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1006 Selling or dealing with articles bearing registered trademark or service mark with intent to defraud.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who, without the consent of the owner of an article bearing the owner's validly registered trademark or service mark, knowingly sells or traffics in the articles or who withholds the articles from the owner thereof with intent to defraud the owner thereof is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1007 Use of registered trademark without consent.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who adopts or in any way uses the registered trademark of another without the consent of the owner thereof, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1008 Inspections by trade commission.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Subject to the provisions of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1009 Violation as unfair trade practice and unfair competition -- Investigation and enforcement proceedings by trade commission.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Violation of a provision of this part is hereby declared to be an unfair trade practice and an unfair method of competition. The Utah state trade commission shall have jurisdiction over violations and may proceed against a violator as provided by the trade commission act. The trade commission may institute an investigation upon receiving an informal complaint from a person who claims to have been injured by the violation of this part. Upon receiving a sworn complaint from a person claiming to be injured by a violation of this part, the trade commission must institute an investigation. If evidence of a violation is found by the commission or is produced by the complainant, the commission must take appropriate enforcement proceedings as provided in the trade commission act.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1010 Action by law enforcement agencies on complaints.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Nothing in this part providing for enforcement by the trade commission shall be construed to deprive law enforcement agencies from assuming jurisdiction and acting upon a proper complaint as provided by law.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(a): "Amusement device" means a game that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(a)(i): is activated by a coin, token, or other object of consideration or value; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(a)(ii): does not provide the opportunity to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(a)(ii)(A): enter into a sweepstakes, lottery, or other gambling event; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(a)(ii)(B): receive any form of consideration or value, except an appropriate reward.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(b): "Amusement device" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(b)(i): a video game;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(b)(ii): a driving simulator;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(b)(iii): an electronic game;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(b)(iv): a claw machine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(b)(v): a bowling game;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(b)(vi): a shuffleboard game;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(b)(vii): a skee-ball game;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(b)(viii): a pool table;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(b)(ix): a pinball machine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(b)(x): a target machine; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(1)(b)(xi): a baseball machine.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(2): "Amusement facility" means a facility that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(2)(a): is operated primarily for the purpose of providing amusement or entertainment to customers;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(2)(b): is located on property that is open to customers for the purpose of providing customers with an opportunity to use an amusement device;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(2)(c): receives a substantial amount of the facility's revenue from the operation of amusement devices; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(2)(d): does not provide an opportunity for, or a machine or device that enables, gambling or fringe gambling.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(3)(a): "Appropriate reward" means a reward that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(3)(a)(i): an individual receives as a result of the individual's participation in or use of an amusement device; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(3)(a)(ii): provides:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(3)(a)(ii)(A): full and adequate return for money, a token, or other consideration or value invested into the amusement device;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(3)(a)(ii)(B): an immediate and unrecorded ability to replay a game featured on an amusement device that is not exchangeable for value;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(3)(a)(ii)(C): a toy, novelty, or other non-monetary prize with a value of less than $100 as a reward for playing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(3)(a)(ii)(D): tickets or credits that are redeemable for a toy, novelty, or non-monetary prize at an amusement facility, or at any franchise or chain of the amusement facility, where the amusement device is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(3)(b): "Appropriate reward" does not include money, a gift certificate, a gift card, credit to be used in a retail store, or other form of monetary compensation or reward.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(4): 76-10-1230 "Consumer" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(5): "Enter or entry" means an act or process by which an individual becomes eligible to receive a prize offered for participation in any form of sweepstakes, game, or contest.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(6)(a): "Fringe gambling" means any de facto form of gambling, lottery, fringe gaming device, or video gaming device that is given, conducted, or offered for use or sale by a business in exchange for anything of value or incident to the purchase of another good or service.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(6)(b): "Fringe gambling" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(6)(b)(i): a promotional activity that is clearly ancillary to the primary activity of a business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(6)(b)(ii): use of an amusement device or vending machine.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(7): (7)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(7)(a): "Fringe gaming device" means a mechanically, electrically, or electronically operated machine or device that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(7)(a)(i): is not an amusement device or a vending machine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(7)(a)(ii): is capable of displaying or otherwise presenting information on a screen or through any other mechanism; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(7)(a)(iii): provides the user with a card, token, credit, gift certificate, product, or opportunity to participate in a contest, game, gaming scheme, or sweepstakes with a potential return of money or other prize.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(7)(b): (7)(a) "Fringe gaming device" includes a machine or device similar to a machine or device described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(8): (8)(a)(i)(A)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(8)(a): (8)(a)(i)(A) "Gambling" means risking anything of value for a return or risking anything of value upon the outcome of a contest, game, gaming scheme, or gaming device when the return or outcome:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(8)(a)(i): (8)(a)(i)(A) is based on an element of chance, regardless of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(8)(a)(i)(A): the existence of a preview or pre-reveal feature in the device, contest, or game; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(8)(a)(i)(B): (8)(a)(i)(A) whether the preview or pre-reveal feature described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(8)(a)(ii): is in accord with an agreement or understanding that someone will receive anything of value in the event of a certain outcome.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(8)(b): "Gambling" includes a lottery.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(8)(c): "Gambling" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(8)(c)(i): a lawful business transaction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(8)(c)(ii): use of an amusement device.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(9): "Gambling bet" means money, checks, credit, or any other representation of value.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(10): "Gambling device or record" means anything specifically designed for use in gambling or fringe gambling or used primarily for gambling or fringe gambling.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(11): "Gambling proceeds" means anything of value used in gambling or fringe gambling.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(12): "Internet gambling" or "online gambling" means gambling, fringe gambling, or gaming by use of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(12)(a): the Internet; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(12)(b): any mobile electronic device that allows access to data and information.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(13): "Internet service provider" means a person engaged in the business of providing Internet access service, with the intent of making a profit, to consumers in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(14): "Lottery" means any scheme for the disposal or distribution of property by chance among persons who have paid or promised to pay any valuable consideration for the chance of obtaining property, or portion of it, or for any share or any interest in property, upon any agreement, understanding, or expectation that it is to be distributed or disposed of by lot or chance, whether called a lottery, raffle, or gift enterprise, or by whatever name it is known.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(15): "Prize" means a gift, award, gratuity, good, service, credit, or anything else of value that may be or is transferred to an individual or placed on an account or other record with the intent to be transferred to an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16): (16)(b); (16)(b) "Promotional activity that is clearly ancillary to the primary activity of a business" means a promotional activity that:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(a): continues for a limited period of time;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(b): is related to a good or service ordinarily provided by a business or the marketing or advertisement of a good or service ordinarily provided by the business;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(c): does not require a person to purchase a good or service from the business in consideration for participation or an advantage in the promotional activity or any other contest, game, gaming scheme, sweepstakes, or promotional activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(d): (16)(b) promotes a good or service described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e): (16)(b) does not, through use of a machine or device:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(i): simulate a gambling environment;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(ii): require the purchase of something of value to participate in the promotional activity that is not regularly used, purchased, or redeemed by users of the machine or device;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(iii): (16)(b) provide a good or service described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(iii)(A): in a manner in which the person acquiring the good or service is unable to immediately acquire, redeem, or otherwise use the good or service after the time of purchase; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(iii)(B): at a value less than the full value of the good or service;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(iv): appear or operate in a manner similar to a machine or device that is normally found in a casino for the purpose of gambling;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(v): provide an entertaining display, designed to appeal to an individual's senses, that promotes actual or simulated game play that is similar in appearance or function to gambling, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(v)(A): a video playing card game, including a video poker game;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(v)(B): a video bingo game;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(v)(C): a video craps game;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(v)(D): a video keno game;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(v)(E): a video lotto game;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(v)(F): an 8-liner machine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(v)(G): a Pot O' Gold game;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(v)(H): a video game involving a random or chance matching of pictures, words, numbers, or symbols; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(v)(I): a video game that reveals a prize as the game is played; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(16)(e)(vi): otherwise create a pretextual transaction to facilitate a contest, game, gaming scheme, or sweepstakes in an attempt to circumvent the requirements of this part or Article VI, Section 27, of the Utah Constitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(17): "Skill-based game" means a game, played on a machine or device, the outcome of which is based, in whole or in part, on the skill of the player, regardless of whether a degree of chance is involved.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(18): "Sweepstakes" means a game, advertising scheme, marketing scheme, or other promotion:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(18)(a): that an individual may enter with or without payment of any consideration;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(18)(b): that qualifies the person to win a prize; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(18)(c): the result of which is based on chance.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(19): "Vending machine" means a device:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(19)(a): that dispenses merchandise in exchange for money or any other item of value;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(19)(b): that provides full and adequate return of the value deposited;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(19)(c): through which the return of value is not conditioned on an element of chance or skill; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(19)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(19)(d)(i): does not include a promotional activity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(19)(d)(ii): includes a promotional activity that is clearly ancillary to the primary activity of a business.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(20): "Video gaming device" means a device that includes all of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(20)(a): a video display and computer mechanism for playing a game;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(20)(b): the length of play of any single game is not substantially affected by the skill, knowledge, or dexterity of the player;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(20)(c): a meter, tracking, or recording mechanism that records or tracks any money, tokens, games, or credits accumulated or remaining;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(20)(d): a play option that permits a player to spend or risk varying amounts of money, tokens, or credits during a single game, in which the spending or risking of a greater amount of money, tokens, or credits:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(20)(d)(i): does not significantly extend the length of play time of any single game; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(20)(d)(ii): provides for a chance of greater return of credits, games, or money; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101(20)(e): an operating mechanism that, in order to function, requires inserting money, tokens, or other valuable consideration other than entering the user's name, birthdate, or contact information.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1101.5 General culpability requirement applicable.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Nothing in this part preempts or makes inapplicable the provisions of

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1102 Gambling.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1102(1): A person is guilty of gambling if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1102(1)(a): participates in gambling or fringe gambling, including any Internet or online gambling;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1102(1)(b): knowingly permits gambling or fringe gambling to be played, conducted, or dealt upon or in any real or personal property owned, rented, or under the control of the actor, whether in whole or in part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1102(1)(c): knowingly allows the use of any video gaming device that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1102(1)(c)(i): in any business establishment or public place; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1102(1)(c)(ii): accessible for use by any person within the establishment or public place.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1102(2): Gambling is a class B misdemeanor, except that any person who is convicted two or more times under this section is guilty of a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1102(3): (3)(a); 76-10-1230; 54-8b-2
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1102(3)(a): A person is guilty of a third degree felony who intentionally provides or offers to provide any form of Internet or online gambling to any person in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1102(3)(b): (3)(a); 76-10-1230; 54-8b-2 Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1102(3)(b)(i): transmits, routes, or provides connections for material without selecting the material; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1102(3)(b)(ii): stores or delivers the material at the direction of a user.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1102(4): If any federal law authorizes Internet gambling in the states and that federal law provides that individual states may opt out of Internet gambling, this state shall opt out of Internet gambling in the manner provided by federal law and within the time frame provided by that law.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1102(5): Regardless of whether a federal law is enacted that authorizes Internet gambling in the states, this section acts as this state's prohibition of any gambling, including Internet gambling, in this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1103 Gambling fraud.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1103(1): A person is guilty of gambling fraud if the person participates in gambling or fringe gambling and wins or acquires to himself or herself or another any gambling proceeds when the person knows the person has a lesser risk of losing or greater chance of winning than one or more of the other participants, and the risk is not known to all participants.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1103(2): A person convicted of gambling fraud is punished as in the case of theft of property of like value.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1104 Gambling promotion.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1104(1): A person is guilty of gambling promotion if the person derives or intends to derive an economic benefit other than personal winnings from gambling or fringe gambling and:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1104(1)(a): the person induces or aids another to engage in gambling or fringe gambling; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1104(1)(b): the person knowingly invests in, finances, owns, controls, supervises, manages, or participates in any gambling or fringe gambling.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1104(2): Gambling promotion is a class A misdemeanor, except that any person who is twice convicted under this section is guilty of a third degree felony.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1104.5 Advertisement or solicitation for participation in lotteries -- Void in Utah.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1104.5(1): 76-10-1101 For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1104.5(1)(a): "Conspicuously printed" means printed in either larger or bolder type size than the adjacent and surrounding material so as to be clearly legible to any person viewing the print.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1104.5(1)(b): 76-10-1101 "Lottery" means the same as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1104.5(2): It is unlawful for any person to distribute or disseminate any advertisement or other written or printed material containing an advertisement or solicitation for participation in any lottery unless the advertisement or solicitation contains or includes the words "Void in Utah" conspicuously printed.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1104.5(3): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1104.5(3)(a): (2) Any person who is convicted of violating Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1104.5(3)(b): Any person who is twice or more convicted under this section shall be fined the sum of $10,000.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1105 Possessing a gambling device or record.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1105(1): A person is guilty of possessing a gambling device or record if the person knowingly possesses the gambling device or record with intent to use the gambling device or record in gambling or fringe gambling.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1105(2): Possession of a gambling device or record is a class A misdemeanor, except that any person who is convicted two or more times under this section is guilty of a third degree felony.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1106 Duty of prosecuting attorney or law enforcement officer to prosecute offenses.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
All prosecuting attorneys,  sheriffs, constables, and  peace officers who have reasonable cause to believe any person has violated any provisions of this part shall diligently prosecute those persons.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1108 Seizure and disposition of gambling debts or proceeds.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any gambling bets or gambling proceeds which are reasonably identifiable as having been used or obtained in violation of this part may be seized and are subject to forfeiture proceedings in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1109 Confidence game -- Punishment as for theft -- Description in charge.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1109(1): Any person who obtains or attempts to obtain from any other person any money or property by any means, instrument or device commonly called a confidence game shall be punished as in the case of theft of property of like value.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1109(2): In every indictment, information, or complaint under this section, it shall be deemed and held a sufficient description of the offense to charge that the accused did, on, ____ (insert the date) unlawfully and knowingly obtain or attempt to obtain (as the case may be) from ____, (insert the name of the person or persons defrauded or attempted to be defrauded) his money or property (as the case may be) by means and by use of a confidence game.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110 Fringe gaming devices.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(1): Title 76, Chapter 10, Offenses Against Public Health, Safety, Welfare, and Morals Notwithstanding any other provision in
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(1)(a): permitting a fringe gaming device to be located on or in any real or personal property owned, rented, or under the control of the person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(1)(b): allowing individual or public access or use of a fringe gaming device as part of any business owned or operated by the person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(1)(c): inducing or aiding a person to use a fringe gaming device;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(1)(d): investing in, financing, owning, controlling, or otherwise managing a fringe gaming device; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(1)(e): possessing a fringe gaming device with the intent to use or allow another to use the fringe gaming device.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(2): (1) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(2)(a): is server-based;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(2)(b): uses a simulated game terminal as a representation of a prize associated with the results of a sweepstakes entry;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(2)(c): uses a simulated game to influence or determine the result of the simulated game or the value of a prize;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(2)(d): selects the winner of a prize from a predetermined or finite pool of entries;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(2)(e): includes a pre-reveal feature;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(2)(f): predetermines a prize and reveals the prize at the time a sweepstakes entry result is revealed;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(2)(g): requires deposit of any money, coin, token, or gift certificate, or the use of a credit card, debit card, prepaid card, or any other method of payment to activate the device;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(2)(h): requires direct payment into the machine or device or remote activation of the device;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(2)(i): requires a purchase of a related product regardless of whether the product has legitimate value;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(2)(j): reveals the prize incrementally, regardless of whether a prize is awarded; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(2)(k): includes a skill-based game.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(3): Each violation of this section is a separate offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(4): A person who violates this section is guilty of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(4)(a): a class A misdemeanor for the first offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1110(4)(b): a third degree felony for a subsequent offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1112 Local control.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1112(1): Nothing in this part preempts or otherwise limits the authority of a county or municipality to enact a local ordinance related to gambling or fringe gambling.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1112(2): Title 77, Chapter 11a, Seizure of Property and Contraband In accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1113 Cause of action.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1113(1): An individual who suffers economic loss as a result of a fringe gaming device, video gaming device, or gambling device or record may bring a cause of action against a person who operates or receives revenue from the fringe gaming device, video gaming device, or gambling device or record to recover damages, costs, and attorney fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1113(2): (1); (1) An individual who brings suit under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
For the purpose of this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(1): "Blinder rack" means an opaque cover that covers the lower 2/3 of a material so that the lower 2/3 of the material is concealed from view.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(2): "Contemporary community standards" means those current standards in the vicinage where an offense alleged under this part has occurred, is occurring, or will occur.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(3): "Distribute" means to transfer possession of materials whether with or without consideration.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(4): "Exhibit" means to show.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(5)(a): "Harmful to minors" means that quality of any description or representation, in whatsoever form, of nudity, sexual conduct, sexual excitement, or sadomasochistic abuse when it:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(5)(a)(i): taken as a whole, appeals to the prurient interest in sex of minors;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(5)(a)(ii): is patently offensive to prevailing standards in the adult community as a whole with respect to what is suitable material for minors; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(5)(a)(iii): taken as a whole, does not have serious value for minors.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(5)(b): Serious value includes only serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value for minors.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(6): (6); 76-2-103
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(6)(a): "Knowingly," regarding material or a performance, means an awareness, whether actual or constructive, of the character of the material or performance.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(6)(b): (6); 76-2-103 As used in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(7): "Material" means anything printed or written or any picture, drawing, photograph, motion picture, or pictorial representation, or any statue or other figure, or any recording or transcription, or any mechanical, chemical, or electrical reproduction, or anything which is or may be used as a means of communication.  Material includes undeveloped photographs, molds, printing plates, and other latent representational objects.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(8): "Minor" means any person less than 18 years of age.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(9): "Negligently" means simple negligence, the failure to exercise that degree of care that a reasonable and prudent person would exercise under like or similar circumstances.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(10): "Nudity" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(10)(a): the showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area, or buttocks, with less than an opaque covering;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(10)(b): the showing of a female breast with less than an opaque covering, or any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(10)(c): the depiction of covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(11): "Performance" means any physical human bodily activity, whether engaged in alone or with other persons, including singing, speaking, dancing, acting, simulating, or pantomiming.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(12): "Public place" includes a place to which admission is gained by payment of a membership or admission fee, however designated, notwithstanding its being designated a private club or by words of like import.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(13): (13)(a) "Sadomasochistic abuse" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(13)(a): flagellation or torture by or upon a person who is nude or clad in undergarments, a mask, or in a revealing or bizarre costume; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(13)(b): (13)(a) the condition of being fettered, bound, or otherwise physically restrained on the part of a person clothed as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(14): "Sexual conduct" means acts of masturbation, sexual intercourse, or any touching of a person's clothed or unclothed genitals, pubic area, buttocks, or, if the person is a female, breast, whether alone or between members of the same or opposite sex or between humans and animals in an act of apparent or actual sexual stimulation or gratification.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1201(15): "Sexual excitement" means a condition of human male or female genitals when in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal, or the sensual experiences of humans engaging in or witnessing sexual conduct or nudity.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1203 Pornographic material or performance -- Expert testimony not required.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1203(1): Any material or performance is pornographic if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1203(1)(a): The average person, applying contemporary community standards, finds that, taken as a whole, it appeals to prurient interest in sex;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1203(1)(b): It is patently offensive in the description or depiction of nudity, sexual conduct, sexual excitement, sadomasochistic abuse, or excretion; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1203(1)(c): Taken as a whole it does not have serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1203(2): In prosecutions under this part, where circumstances of production, presentation, sale, dissemination, distribution, exhibition, or publicity indicate that the matter is being commercially exploited by the defendant for the sake of its prurient appeal, this evidence is probative with respect to the nature of the matter and can justify the conclusion that, in the context in which it is used, the matter has no serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1203(3): Neither the prosecution nor the defense shall be required to introduce expert witness testimony as to whether the material or performance is or is not harmful to adults or minors or is or is not pornographic, or as to any element of the definition of pornographic, including contemporary community standards.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1204 Distributing pornographic material -- Penalties -- Exemptions for Internet service providers and hosting companies.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1204(1): A person is guilty of distributing pornographic material when the person knowingly:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1204(1)(a): sends or brings any pornographic material into the state with intent to distribute or exhibit it to others;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1204(1)(b): prepares, publishes, prints, or possesses any pornographic material with intent to distribute or exhibit it to others;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1204(1)(c): distributes or offers to distribute, or exhibits or offers to exhibit, any pornographic material to others;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1204(1)(d): writes, creates, or solicits the publication or advertising of pornographic material;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1204(1)(e): promotes the distribution or exhibition of material the person represents to be pornographic; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1204(1)(f): presents or directs a pornographic performance in any public place or any place exposed to public view or participates in that portion of the performance which makes it pornographic.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1204(2): (1) Each distributing of pornographic material as defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1204(3): It is a separate offense under this section for:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1204(3)(a): each day's exhibition of any pornographic motion picture film; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1204(3)(b): each day in which any pornographic publication is displayed or exhibited in a public place with intent to distribute or exhibit it to others.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1204(4): (4)(a); 77-18-105
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1204(4)(a): An offense under this section committed by a person 18 years old or older is a third degree felony punishable by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1204(4)(a)(i): a minimum mandatory fine of not less than $1,000, plus $10 for each article exhibited up to the maximum allowed by law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1204(4)(a)(ii): incarceration, without suspension of sentence in any way, for a term of not less than 30 days.
