Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1501 Short title.
---------------------------------------------
This act shall be known and may be cited as the "Bus Passenger Safety Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1502 Legislative findings.
------------------------------------------------------
The legislature finds that the continued orderly operation of bus transportation is beneficial to the commerce of the state and to the convenience of its citizens; that it is essential to the comfort, safety and well-being of bus passengers that orderly conduct be maintained; that the promotion of bus transportation is beneficial to the economy of the state and conservation of energy; and that an increasing number of citizens avail themselves of this mode of transportation.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1503 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this act:Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1503(1): 17B-2a-802; Title 17B, Chapter 2a, Part 8, Public Transit District Act "Bus" means any passenger bus or coach or other motor vehicle having a seating capacity of 15 or more passengers operated by a bus company for the purpose of carrying passengers or cargo for hire and includes a transit vehicle, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1503(2): "Bus company" or "company" means any person, group of persons or corporation providing for-hire transportation to passengers or cargo by bus upon the highways in the state, including passengers and cargo in interstate or intrastate travel.  These terms also include local public bodies, public transit districts, municipalities, public corporations, boards and commissions established under the laws of the state providing transportation to passengers or cargo by bus upon the highways in the state, whether or not for hire.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1503(3): "Charter" means a group of persons, pursuant to a common purpose and under a single contract, and at a fixed charge in accordance with a bus company's tariff, which has acquired the exclusive use of a bus to travel together to a specified destination or destinations.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1503(4): "Passenger" means any person transported or served by a bus company, including persons accompanying or meeting another being transported, any person shipping or receiving cargo and any person purchasing a ticket or receiving a pass.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1503(5): 17B-2a-802; Title 17B, Chapter 2a, Part 8, Public Transit District Act "Terminal" means a bus station or depot or any other facility operated or leased by or operated on behalf of a bus company and includes a transit facility, as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1504 Bus hijacking -- Assault with intent to commit hijacking -- Use of a dangerous weapon -- Penalties.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1504(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1504(1)(a): A person is guilty of bus hijacking if the person seizes or exercises control, by force or violence or threat of force or violence, of a bus within the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1504(1)(b): Bus hijacking is a first degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1504(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1504(2)(a): A person is guilty of assault with the intent to commit bus hijacking if the person intimidates, threatens, or commits assault or battery toward a driver, attendant, guard, or any other person in control of a bus so as to interfere with the performance of duties by the person.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1504(2)(b): Assault with the intent to commit bus hijacking is a second degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1504(3): 76-1-101.5 A person who, in the commission of assault with intent to commit bus hijacking, uses a dangerous weapon, as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1505 Discharging firearms and hurling missiles into buses and terminals -- Exception.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1505(1): Any person who discharges a firearm or hurls a missile at or into any bus or terminal shall be guilty of a third degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1505(2): The prohibition of this section does not apply to elected or appointed peace officers or commercial security personnel who discharge firearms or hurl missiles in the course and scope of their employment.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1506 Threatening breach of peace -- Disorderly conduct -- Foul language -- Refusing requests -- Use of controlled substance, liquor, or tobacco -- Ejection of passenger.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1506(1): 58-37-2; 32B-4-415(4)(c)(ii); 32B-1-102; 41-6a-526 A person is guilty of a class C misdemeanor, if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1506(1)(a): threatens a breach of the peace, is disorderly, or uses obscene, profane, or vulgar language on a bus;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1506(1)(b): 58-37-2 is in or upon any bus while unlawfully under the influence of a controlled substance as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1506(1)(c): 32B-4-415(4)(c)(ii) fails to obey a reasonable request or order of a bus driver, bus company representative, a nondrinking designee other than the driver as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1506(1)(d): 32B-1-102; 41-6a-526 ingests any controlled substance, unless prescribed by a physician or medical facility, in or upon any bus, or drinks intoxicating liquor in or upon any bus, except a chartered bus as defined and provided in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1506(1)(e): smokes tobacco or other products in or upon any bus, except a chartered bus.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1506(2): (1) If any person violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1506(3): The driver or person in charge may cause the person so removed to be detained and delivered to the proper authorities.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507 Exclusion of persons without bona fide business from terminal -- Dangerous materials -- Surveillance devices and seizure of offending materials -- Detention of violators -- Private security personnel.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(1): (1)(c); (1)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(1)(a): In order to provide for the safety, welfare and comfort of passengers, a bus company may refuse admission to terminals to a person not having bona fide business within the terminal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(1)(b): The refusal may not be inconsistent or contrary to state or federal laws or regulations, or to an ordinance of the political subdivision in which the terminal is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(1)(c): An authorized bus company representative may require a person in a terminal to identify himself and state his business.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(1)(d): (1)(c) Failure to comply with a request under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(1)(e): (1)(d) A person who refuses to comply with a request made under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(2)(a): A person who carries any highly flammable or hazardous material or device into a terminal or aboard a bus is guilty of a third degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(2)(b): The bus company may employ reasonable means, including mechanical, electronic or x-ray devices to detect the items concealed in baggage or upon the person of a passenger.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(2)(c): (2)(a) Upon the discovery of an item referred to in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(3)(a): An authorized bus company representative may detain within a terminal or bus any person violating the provisions of this section for a reasonable time until law enforcement authorities arrive.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(3)(b): The detention does not constitute unlawful imprisonment and neither the bus company nor the representative is civilly or criminally liable upon grounds of unlawful imprisonment or assault, provided that only reasonable and necessary force is exercised against the detained person.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(4)(a): A bus company may employ or contract for private security personnel.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(4)(b): The personnel may:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(4)(b)(i): detain within a terminal or bus a person violating this section for a reasonable time until law enforcement authorities arrive; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1507(4)(b)(ii): use reasonable and necessary force in subduing or detaining the person.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1508 Theft of baggage or cargo.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Any person who removes any baggage, cargo or other item transported upon a bus or stored in a terminal without consent of the owner of the property or the bus company, or its duly authorized representative is guilty of theft and shall be punished pursuant to section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1509 Obstructing operation of bus.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Any person who unlawfully obstructs or impedes by force or violence, or any means of intimidation, the regular operation of a bus is guilty of a class C misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1510 Obstructing operation of bus -- Conspiracy.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Two or more persons who willfully combine or conspire to violate Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1511 Cumulative and supplemental nature of act.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
The provisions of this act shall be cumulative and supplemental to the provisions of any other law of the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1601 Short title.
---------------------------------------------
This act is the "Pattern of Unlawful Activity Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1602 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1602(1): "Enterprise" means any individual, sole proprietorship, partnership, corporation, business trust, association, or other legal entity, and any union or group of individuals associated in fact although not a legal entity, and includes illicit as well as licit entities.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1602(2): "Pattern of unlawful activity" means engaging in conduct which constitutes the commission of at least three episodes of unlawful activity, which episodes are not isolated, but have the same or similar purposes, results, participants, victims, or methods of commission, or otherwise are interrelated by distinguishing characteristics.  Taken together, the episodes shall demonstrate continuing unlawful conduct and be related either to each other or to the enterprise.  At least one of the episodes comprising a pattern of unlawful activity shall have occurred after July 31, 1981.  The most recent act constituting part of a pattern of unlawful activity as defined by this part shall have occurred within five years of the commission of the next preceding act alleged as part of the pattern.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1602(3): "Person" includes any individual or entity capable of holding a legal or beneficial interest in property, including state, county, and local governmental entities.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1602(4): Title 13, Chapter 10, Unauthorized Recording Practices Act; Title 19, Environmental Quality Code; 19-1-101; 19-7-109; Title 23A, Wildlife Resources Act; 23A-5-311; Title 26B, Chapter 3, Part 11, Utah False Claims Act; 26B-3-1101; 26B-3-1112; Title 32B, Chapter 4, Criminal Offenses and Procedure Act; Title 57, Chapter 11, Utah Uniform Land Sales Practices Act; Title 58, Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act; Title 58, Chapter 37b, Imitation Controlled Substances Act; Title 58, Chapter 37c, Utah Controlled Substance Precursor Act; Title 58, Chapter 37d, Clandestine Drug Lab Act; Title 61, Chapter 1, Utah Uniform Securities Act; Title 63G, Chapter 6a, Utah Procurement Code; 76-5-102; 76-5-103; 76-5-107.3; 76-5-201; 76-5-301; 76-5-302; 76-5-308; 76-5-308.1; 76-5-308.3; 76-5-308.5; 76-5-309; 76-5-310; 76-5b-201; 76-5b-201.1; 76-6-102; 76-6-103; 76-6-105; 76-6-202; 76-6-203; 76-6-204; 76-6-205; 76-6-301; 76-6-302; 76-6-404; 76-6-405; 76-6-406; 76-6-408; 76-6-409; 76-6-501; 76-6-506.2; 76-6-506.3; 76-6-506.6; 76-6-507; 76-6-508; 76-6-509; Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1602(4)(llll): any act illegal under the laws of the United States and enumerated in 18 U.S.C. Sec. 1961(1)(B), (C), and (D).


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603 Unlawful acts.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603(1): It is unlawful for any person who has received any proceeds derived, whether directly or indirectly, from a pattern of unlawful activity in which the person has participated as a principal, to use or invest, directly or indirectly, any part of that income, or the proceeds of the income, or the proceeds derived from the investment or use of those proceeds, in the acquisition of any interest in, or the establishment or operation of, any enterprise.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603(2): It is unlawful for any person through a pattern of unlawful activity to acquire or maintain, directly or indirectly, any interest in or control of any enterprise.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603(3): It is unlawful for any person employed by or associated with any enterprise to conduct or participate, whether directly or indirectly, in the conduct of that enterprise's affairs through a pattern of unlawful activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603(4): (1); (2); (3) It is unlawful for any person to conspire to violate any provision of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603.5 Violation a felony -- Costs -- Fines -- Divestiture -- Restrictions -- Dissolution or reorganization -- Prior restraint.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603.5(1): 76-10-1603 A person who violates any provision of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603.5(2): 76-10-1603; 76-10-1603 In lieu of a fine otherwise authorized by law for a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603.5(3): 76-10-1603; 76-10-1603 Upon conviction for violating any provision of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603.5(3)(a): 76-10-1603 order restitution to any victim or rightful owner of property obtained, directly or indirectly, from:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603.5(3)(a)(i): the conduct constituting the pattern of unlawful activity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603.5(3)(a)(ii): 76-10-1603 any act or conduct constituting the pattern of unlawful activity that is proven as part of the violation of any provision of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603.5(3)(b): order the person to divest himself of any interest in or any control, direct or indirect, of any enterprise;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603.5(3)(c): impose reasonable restrictions on the future activities or investments of any person, including prohibiting the person from engaging in the same type of endeavor as the enterprise engaged in, to the extent the Utah Constitution and the Constitution of the United States permit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603.5(3)(d): order the dissolution or reorganization of any enterprise.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603.5(4): 76-10-1603; 76-10-1204; 76-10-1205; 76-10-1206; 76-10-1222 If a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1603.5(5): For purposes of this section, the "net proceeds" of an offense means property acquired as a result of the violation minus the direct costs of acquiring the property.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1604 Enforcement authority of peace officers.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Notwithstanding any law to the contrary, peace officers in the state of Utah shall have authority to enforce the criminal provisions of this act by initiating investigations, assisting grand juries, obtaining indictments, filing informations, and assisting in the prosecution of criminal cases through the attorney general or county attorneys' offices.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605 Remedies of person injured by a pattern of unlawful activity -- Double damages -- Costs, including attorney fees -- Arbitration -- Agency -- Burden of proof -- Actions by attorney general or county attorney -- Dismissal -- Statute of limitations -- Authorized orders of district court.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(1): 76-10-1603 A person injured in his person, business, or property by a person engaged in conduct forbidden by any provision of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(1)(a): the injury is separate or distinct from the injury suffered as a result of the acts or conduct constituting the pattern of unlawful conduct alleged as part of the cause of action; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(1)(b): the conduct has been adjudged criminal by any court of the state or of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(2): A party who prevails on a cause of action brought under this section recovers the cost of the suit, including reasonable attorney fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(3): Title 78B, Chapter 11, Utah Uniform Arbitration Act All actions arising under this section which are grounded in fraud are subject to arbitration under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(4): In all actions under this section, a principal is liable for actual damages for harm caused by an agent acting within the scope of either his employment or apparent authority.  A principal is liable for double damages only if the pattern of unlawful activity alleged and proven as part of the cause of action was authorized, solicited, requested, commanded, undertaken, performed, or recklessly tolerated by the board of directors or a high managerial agent acting within the scope of his employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(5): In all actions arising under this section, the burden of proof is clear and convincing evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(6): 76-10-1603 The attorney general, county attorney, or, if within a prosecution district, the district attorney may maintain actions under this section on behalf of the state, the county, or any person injured by a person engaged in conduct forbidden by any provision of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(7): In all actions under this section, the elements of each claim or cause of action shall be stated with particularity against each defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(8): If an action, claim, or counterclaim brought or asserted by a private party under this section is dismissed prior to trial or disposed of on summary judgment, or if it is determined at trial that there is no liability, the prevailing party shall recover from the party who brought the action or asserted the claim or counterclaim the amount of its reasonable expenses incurred because of the defense against the action, claim, or counterclaim, including a reasonable attorney's fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(9): 76-10-1603 An action or proceeding brought under this section shall be commenced within three years after the conduct prohibited by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(10): (1); 76-10-1603; 76-10-1204; 76-10-1205; 76-10-1206; 76-10-1222; 76-10-1204; 76-10-1205; 76-10-1206; 76-10-1222; 76-10-1204; 76-10-1205; 76-10-1206; 76-10-1222; 76-10-1201; 76-10-1203; 76-10-1216; 76-10-1226
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(10)(a): In any action brought under this section, the district court has jurisdiction to prevent, restrain, or remedy injury as defined by this section by issuing appropriate orders after making provisions for the rights of innocent persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(10)(b): Before liability is determined in any action brought under this section, the district court may:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(10)(b)(i): issue restraining orders and injunctions;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(10)(b)(ii): require satisfactory performance bonds or any other bond it considers appropriate and necessary in connection with any property or any requirement imposed upon a party by the court; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(10)(b)(iii): enter any other order the court considers necessary and proper.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(10)(c): (1) After a determination of liability, the district court may, in addition to granting the relief allowed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(10)(c)(i): order any person to divest himself of any interest in or any control, direct or indirect, of any enterprise;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(10)(c)(ii): impose reasonable restrictions on the future activities or investments of any person, including prohibiting any person from engaging in the same type of endeavor as the enterprise engaged in, to the extent the Utah Constitution and the Constitution of the United States permit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(10)(c)(iii): order the dissolution or reorganization of any enterprise.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1605(10)(d): 76-10-1603; 76-10-1204; 76-10-1205; 76-10-1206; 76-10-1222; 76-10-1204; 76-10-1205; 76-10-1206; 76-10-1222; 76-10-1204; 76-10-1205; 76-10-1206; 76-10-1222; 76-10-1201; 76-10-1203; 76-10-1216; 76-10-1226 However, if an action is brought to obtain any relief provided by this section, and if the conduct prohibited by Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1607 Evidentiary value of criminal judgment in civil proceeding.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A final judgment or decree rendered in favor of the state or a county in any criminal proceeding brought by this state or a county shall preclude the defendant from denying the essential allegations of the criminal offense in any subsequent civil proceeding.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1608 Severability clause.
-----------------------------------------------------
If any part or application of the Utah Pattern of Unlawful Activity Act is held invalid, the remainder of this part, or its application to other situations or persons, is not affected.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1609 Prospective application.
---------------------------------------------------------
The amendments to the Utah Pattern of Unlawful Activity Act are prospective in nature and apply only to civil causes of action accruing after the effective date of this act.  However, crimes committed prior to the effective date of this act may comprise part of a pattern of unlawful activity if at least one of the criminal episodes comprising that pattern occurs after the effective date of this act and the pattern otherwise meets the definition of pattern of unlawful activity as defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801 Communications fraud -- Elements -- Penalties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(1): Any person who has devised any scheme or artifice to defraud another or to obtain from another money, property, or anything of value by means of false or fraudulent pretenses, representations, promises, or material omissions, and who communicates directly or indirectly with any person by any means for the purpose of executing or concealing the scheme or artifice is guilty of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(1)(a): a class B misdemeanor when the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is less than $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(1)(b): a class A misdemeanor when the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(1)(c): a third degree felony when the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(1)(d): a second degree felony when the value of the property, money, or thing obtained or sought to be obtained is or exceeds $5,000; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(1)(e): a second degree felony when the object or purpose of the scheme or artifice to defraud is the obtaining of sensitive personal identifying information, regardless of the value.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(2): (1); (1); (1)(e) The determination of the degree of any offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(3): (1) Reliance on the part of any person is not a necessary element of the offense described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(4): (1) An intent on the part of the perpetrator of any offense described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(5): (1) Each separate communication made for the purpose of executing or concealing a scheme or artifice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(6): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(6)(a): (1) To communicate as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(6)(a)(i): bestow, convey, make known, recount, or impart;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(6)(a)(ii): give by way of information;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(6)(a)(iii): talk over; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(6)(a)(iv): transmit information.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(6)(b): Means of communication include use of the mail, telephone, telegraph, radio, television, newspaper, computer, and spoken and written communication.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(7): A person may not be convicted under this section unless the pretenses, representations, promises, or material omissions made or omitted were made or omitted intentionally, knowingly, or with a reckless disregard for the truth.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(8): As used in this section, "sensitive personal identifying information" means information regarding an individual's:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(8)(a): Social Security number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(8)(b): driver's license number or other government issued identification number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(8)(c): financial account number or credit or debit card number;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(8)(d): password or personal identification number or other identification required to gain access to a financial account or a secure website;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(8)(e): automated or electronic signature;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(8)(f): unique biometric data; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1801(8)(g): any other information that can be used to gain access to an individual's financial accounts or to obtain goods or services.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802 Misrepresentation of call or text communication identification.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(1)(a): "Caller or text message identification information" means information provided by a caller identification service or text message service regarding the telephone number or other information regarding the origination of a call or text message made using a telecommunications service or VoIP voice service.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(1)(b): "Caller or text message identification service" means any service or device designed to provide the user of the service or device with the telephone number of, or other information regarding, the origination of a call or text message made using a telecommunications service or VoIP voice service, including automatic number identification services.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(1)(c): "Text message":
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(1)(c)(i): means a real-time or near real-time message consisting of text, images, sounds, or other information transmitted from or received by a device identified by a telephone number; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(1)(c)(ii): does not include a real-time, two-way voice or video communication.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(1)(d): "VoIP" means a technology that allows telephone calls to be made over computer networks, including the Internet.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(2): It is unlawful for any person or individual, in connection with any telecommunications service or VoIP voice service, to knowingly cause any caller identification service or text message service to transmit false, misleading, or inaccurate caller or text message identification information:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(2)(a): with the intent to harm the recipient of the call or text message; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(2)(b): to a public safety answering point when reporting an emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(3): This section does not prevent or restrict any person or individual from blocking the capability of any caller or text message identification service to transmit caller or text message identification information.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(4): The following are exempt from this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(4)(a): the lawful investigative, protective, or intelligence activity of a law enforcement agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(4)(b): a court order that specifically authorizes the use of caller or text message identification manipulation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(5): Each separate call or text message transmitted in violation of this section is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(5)(a): for a first violation, a class C misdemeanor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(5)(b): for a second or subsequent violation, a class B misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(6): Violations may be enforced in a civil action initiated by the recipient of a call, message, or text message made in violation of this section, a criminal action initiated by a prosecuting attorney, or both.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(7): This section does not apply to an Internet service provider or hosting company, a provider of public telecommunications services, or a text message service by reason of the fact that the Internet service provider, hosting company, text message service, or provider of public telecommunications services:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(7)(a): transmits, routes, or provides connections for material without selecting the material;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(7)(b): stores or delivers the material at the direction of a user; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1802(7)(c): provides a caller or text message identification service.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1901 Short title.
---------------------------------------------
This part is known as the Money Laundering and Currency Transaction Reporting Act.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(1): Title 7, Financial Institutions Act "Bank" means an agent, agency, or office in this state of a person doing business in any one of the following capacities:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(1)(a): a commercial bank or trust company organized under the laws of this state or of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(1)(b): a private bank;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(1)(c): a savings and loan association or a building and loan association organized under the laws of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(1)(d): an insured institution as defined in Section 401 of the National Housing Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(1)(e): a savings bank, industrial bank, or other thrift institution;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(1)(f): a credit union organized under the laws of this state or of the United States; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(1)(g): Title 7, Financial Institutions Act any other organization chartered under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(2): "Conducts" includes initiating, concluding, or participating in initiating or concluding a transaction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(3)(a): "Currency" means the coin and paper money of the United States or of another country that is designated as legal tender, that circulates, and is customarily used and accepted as a medium of exchange in the country of issuance.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(3)(b): "Currency" includes United States silver certificates, United States notes, Federal Reserve notes, and foreign bank notes customarily used and accepted as a medium of exchange in a foreign country.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(4): "Financial institution" means an agent, agency, branch, or office within this state of a person doing business, whether or not on a regular basis or as an organized business concern, in one or more of the following capacities:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(4)(a): a bank, except bank credit card systems;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(4)(b): a broker or dealer in securities;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(4)(c): a currency dealer or exchanger, including a person engaged in the business of check cashing;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(4)(d): an issuer, seller, or redeemer of travelers checks or money orders, except as a selling agent exclusively who does not sell more than $150,000 of the instruments within any 30-day period;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(4)(e): a licensed transmitter of funds or other person engaged in the business of transmitting funds;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(4)(f): a telegraph company;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(4)(g): a person subject to supervision by a state or federal supervisory authority; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(4)(h): the United States Postal Service regarding the sale of money orders.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(5): "Financial transaction" means a transaction:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(5)(a): involving the movement of funds by wire or other means or involving one or more monetary instruments, which in any way or degree affects commerce; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(5)(b): involving the use of a financial institution that is engaged in, or its activities affect commerce in any way or degree.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(6): (12) The phrase "knows that the property involved represents the proceeds of some form of unlawful activity" means that the person knows or it was represented to the person that the property involved represents proceeds from a form of activity, although the person does not necessarily know which form of activity, that constitutes a crime under state or federal law, regardless of whether or not the activity is specified in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(7): "Monetary instruments" means coins or currency of the United States or of another country, travelers checks, personal checks, bank checks, money orders, and investment securities or negotiable instruments in bearer form or in other form so that title passes upon delivery.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(8): "Person" means an individual, corporation, partnership, trust or estate, joint stock company, association, syndicate, joint venture, or other unincorporated organization or group, and all other entities cognizable as legal personalities.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(9): "Proceeds" means property acquired or derived directly or indirectly from, produced through, realized through, or caused by an act or omission and includes property of any kind.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(10): "Property" means anything of value, and includes an interest in property, including a benefit, privilege, land, or right with respect to anything of value, whether real or personal, tangible or intangible.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(11): "Prosecuting agency" means the office of the attorney general or the office of the county attorney, including an attorney on the staff whether acting in a civil or criminal capacity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(12): 76-10-1602 "Specified unlawful activity" means an unlawful activity defined as an unlawful activity in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(13): "Transaction" means a purchase, sale, loan, pledge, gift, transfer, delivery, or other disposition.  With respect to a financial institution, "transaction" includes a deposit, withdrawal, transfer between accounts, exchange of currency, loan, extension of credit, purchase or sale of a stock, bond, certificate of deposit, or other monetary instrument, or any other payment, transfer, or delivery by, through, or to a financial institution, by whatever means effected.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1902(14): "Transaction in currency" means a transaction involving the physical transfer of currency from one person to another.  A transaction that is a transfer of funds by means of bank check, bank draft, wire transfer, or other written order that does not include the physical transfer of currency is not a transaction in currency under this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1903 Money laundering.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1903(1): A person commits the offense of money laundering who:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1903(1)(a): transports, receives, or acquires the property which is in fact proceeds of the specified unlawful activity, knowing that the property involved represents the proceeds of some form of unlawful activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1903(1)(b): makes proceeds of unlawful activity available to another by transaction, transportation, or other means, knowing that the proceeds are intended to be used for the purpose of continuing or furthering the commission of specified unlawful activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1903(1)(c): conducts a transaction knowing the property involved in the transaction represents the proceeds of some form of unlawful activity with the intent:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1903(1)(c)(i): to promote the unlawful activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1903(1)(c)(ii): to conceal or disguise the nature, location, source, ownership, or control of the property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1903(1)(c)(iii): to avoid a transaction reporting requirement under this chapter or under federal law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1903(1)(d): knowingly accepts or receives property which is represented to be proceeds of unlawful activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1903(2): (1)(d) Under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1904 Money laundering -- Penalty.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1904(1): 76-10-1903(1)(a); (b); (c) A person who violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1904(2): 76-10-1903(1)(d) A person who violates Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1906 Reporting -- Criminal and civil penalties -- Enforcement.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1906(1): (1)(b); (1)(a); (1); (1); (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1906(1)(a): (1)(b) A person engaged in a trade or business, except a financial institution, who receives more than $10,000 as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1906(1)(b): (1)(a); (1) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1906(1)(b)(i): in one transaction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1906(1)(b)(ii): through two or more related transactions during one business day.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1906(1)(c): (1) A person who knowingly and intentionally fails to comply with the reporting requirements of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1906(1)(c)(i): on a first conviction, guilty of a class C misdemeanor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1906(1)(c)(ii): on a second or subsequent conviction, guilty of a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1906(1)(d): (1) A person is guilty of a third degree felony who knowingly and intentionally violates this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1906(1)(d)(i): in furtherance of the commission of any other violation of state law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1906(1)(d)(ii): as part of a pattern of illegal activity involving transactions exceeding $100,000 in any 12-month period.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1906(2): (1); (1)

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1906(2)(a)(i): (1) shall enforce compliance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1906(2)(a)(ii): (1) are custodians of and have access to all information and documents filed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-1906(2)(b): The information is confidential, except a law enforcement agency, county attorney, or district attorney, when establishing a clear need for the information for investigative purposes, shall have access to the information and shall maintain the information in a confidential manner except as otherwise provided by the Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure.
