Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2001 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2001(1): "Building," in addition to its commonly-accepted meaning, means any watercraft, aircraft, trailer, sleeping car, or other structure or vehicle adapted for overnight accommodations of persons or for carrying on business and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2001(1)(a): each separately secured or occupied portion of the building or vehicle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2001(1)(b): each structure appurtenant or connected to the building or vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2001(2): "Enter" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2001(2)(a): an intrusion of any part of the body; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2001(2)(b): the intrusion of any physical object, sound wave, light ray, electronic signal, or other means of intrusion under the control of the actor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2001(3): "Research" means studious and serious inquiry, examination, investigation, or experimentation aimed at the discovery, examination, or accumulation of facts, data, devices, theories, technologies, or applications done for any public, governmental, proprietorial, or teaching purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2001(4): "Research facility" means any building, or separately secured yard, pad, pond, laboratory, pasture, pen, or corral which is not open to the public, the major use of which is to conduct research, to house research subjects, to store supplies, equipment, samples, specimens, records, data, prototypes, or other property used in or generated from research.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2002 Burglary of a research facility -- Penalties.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2002(1): A person is guilty of burglary of a research facility if he enters or remains unlawfully in a research facility with the intent to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2002(1)(a): obtain unauthorized control over any property, sample, specimen, record, data, test result, or proprietary information in the facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2002(1)(b): alter or eradicate any sample, specimen, record, data, test result, or proprietary information in the facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2002(1)(c): damage, deface, or destroy any property in the facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2002(1)(d): release from confinement or remove any animal or biological vector in the facility regardless of whether or not that animal or vector is dangerous;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2002(1)(e): commit an assault on any person;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2002(1)(f): commit any other felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2002(1)(g): interfere with the personnel or operations of a research facility through any conduct that does not constitute an assault.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2002(2): (1)(g) A person who violates Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2101 Use of recycling bins -- Prohibited items -- Penalties.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2101(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2101(1)(a): "Recycling" means the process of collecting materials diverted from the waste stream for reuse.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2101(1)(b): "Recycling bin" means any receptacle made available to the public by a governmental entity or private business for the collection of any source-separated item for recycling purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2101(2): (2)(a); (2)(a); (b); (c) It is an infraction to place any prohibited item or substance in a recycling bin if the bin is posted with the following information printed legibly in basic English:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2101(2)(a): a descriptive list of the items that may be deposited in the recycling bin, entitled in boldface capital letters: "ITEMS YOU MAY DEPOSIT IN THIS RECYCLING BIN:";
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2101(2)(b): (2)(a) at the end of the list in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2101(2)(c): the following statement in boldface capital letters: "DEPOSIT OF ANY OTHER ITEM IN THIS RECYCLING BIN IS AGAINST THE LAW.";
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2101(2)(d): (2)(a); (b); (c) the following statement in boldface capital letters, posted on the recycling collection container in close proximity to the notices required under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2101(2)(e): the name and telephone number of the entity that owns the recycling bin or is responsible for its placement and maintenance.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201 Unlawful body piercing and tattooing of a minor -- Penalties.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(1)(a): "Body piercing" means the creation of an opening in the body, excluding the ear, for the purpose of inserting jewelry or other decoration.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(1)(b): "Consent of a minor's parent or legal guardian" means the presence of a parent or legal guardian during the performance of body piercing or tattooing upon the minor after the parent or legal guardian has provided:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(1)(b)(i): reasonable proof of personal identity and familial relationship; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(1)(b)(ii): written permission signed by the parent or legal guardian authorizing the performance of body piercing or tattooing upon the minor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(1)(c): "Minor" means a person younger than 18 years of age who:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(1)(c)(i): is not married; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(1)(c)(ii): has not been declared emancipated by a court of law.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(1)(d): "Tattoo" means to fix an indelible mark or figure upon the body by inserting a pigment under the skin or by producing scars.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(2): A person is guilty of unlawful body piercing of a minor if the person performs or offers to perform a body piercing:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(2)(a): upon a minor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(2)(b): without receiving the consent of the minor's parent or legal guardian; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(2)(c): for remuneration or in the course of a business or profession.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(3): A person is guilty of unlawful tattooing of a minor if the person performs or offers to perform a tattooing:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(3)(a): upon a minor;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(3)(b): without receiving the consent of the minor's parent or legal guardian; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(3)(c): for remuneration or in the course of a business or profession.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(4): (2); (3) A person is not guilty of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(4)(a): has no actual knowledge of the minor's age; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(4)(b): reviews, photocopies, and retains the photocopy of an apparently valid driver license or other government-issued picture identification for the minor that expressly purports that the minor is 18 years of age or older before the person performs the body piercing or tattooing.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(5): (2); (3); (2); (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(5)(a): (2); (3) A person who violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2201(5)(b): (2); (3) The owner or operator of a business in which a violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202 Leaving a child unattended in a motor vehicle.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(1)(a): "Child" means a person who is younger than nine years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(1)(b): "Enclosed compartment" means any enclosed area of a motor vehicle, including the passenger compartment, regardless of whether a door, window, or hatch is left open.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(1)(c): "Motor vehicle" means an automobile, truck, truck tractor, bus, or any other self-propelled vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(2): A person who is responsible for a child is guilty of a class C misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(2)(a): the person intentionally, recklessly, knowingly, or with criminal negligence leaves the child in an enclosed compartment of a motor vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(2)(b): the motor vehicle is on:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(2)(b)(i): public property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(2)(b)(ii): private property that is open to the general public;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(2)(c): the child is not supervised by a person who is at least nine years old; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(2)(d): the conditions present a risk to the child of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(2)(d)(i): hyperthermia;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(2)(d)(ii): hypothermia; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(2)(d)(iii): dehydration.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(3): This section does not apply if the person's conduct that constitutes a violation of this section is subject to a greater penalty under another provision of state law.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(4): This section preempts enforcement of a local law or ordinance that makes it an infraction or a criminal offense to engage in the conduct that constitutes a misdemeanor under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2202(5): Notwithstanding any provision of state law to the contrary, a conviction under this section may not be used by a state or local government entity as grounds for revoking, refusing to grant, or refusing to renew, a license or permit, including a license or permit relating to the provision of day care or child care.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203 Possession, sale, or use of an adulterant or synthetic urine.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(1): As used in this section, "adulterant" means a substance that may be added to human urine or another human bodily fluid to change, dilute, or interfere with the composition, chemical properties, physical appearance, or physical properties of the urine or other bodily fluid.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(2): 76-8-510.5 Under circumstances not amounting to a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(2)(a): distribute, possess, or sell synthetic urine;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(2)(b): distribute or sell an adulterant with:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(2)(b)(i): intent that the adulterant be used to defeat or defraud an alcohol or drug screening test; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(2)(b)(ii): knowledge that the recipient of the adulterant intends to use the adulterant to defeat or defraud an alcohol or drug screening test;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(2)(c): possess an adulterant with intent to use the adulterant to defeat or defraud an alcohol or drug screening test; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(2)(d): intentionally use:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(2)(d)(i): an adulterant to defeat or defraud an alcohol or drug screening test;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(2)(d)(ii): the person's urine or bodily fluid to defeat or defraud an alcohol or drug screening test if the urine or bodily fluid was expelled or withdrawn before the time at which the urine or bodily fluid is collected for the test; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(2)(d)(iii): the urine or bodily fluid of another person to defeat or defraud an alcohol or drug screening test.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(3): A person who violates this section is guilty of an infraction.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(4): A person is not guilty of a violation of this section for engaging in conduct described in this section for the sole purpose of education or medical or scientific research.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(5): This section does not apply to persons currently under:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(5)(a): court-ordered supervision; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(5)(b): the supervision of the Board of Pardons and Parole.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2203(6): An entity that collects specimens for the purpose of testing and screening, and reports the results back to an employer shall report to the employer and the Department of Public Safety if a report is received that indicates that adulterated or synthetic urine was submitted for an alcohol or drug screening test.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2204 Duty to report drug diversion.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2204(1): 58-37-4; 26B-3-126; 58-37-2 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2204(1)(a): "Diversion" means a practitioner's transfer of a significant amount of drugs to another for an unlawful purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2204(1)(b): 58-37-4 "Drug" means a Schedule II or Schedule III controlled substance, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2204(1)(c): 26B-3-126 "HIPAA" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2204(1)(d): 58-37-2 "Opiate" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2204(1)(e): "Practitioner" means an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2204(1)(e)(i): licensed, registered, or otherwise authorized by the appropriate jurisdiction to administer, dispense, distribute, or prescribe a drug in the course of professional practice; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2204(1)(e)(ii): employed by a person who is licensed, registered, or otherwise authorized by the appropriate jurisdiction to administer, dispense, distribute, or prescribe a drug in the course of professional practice or standard operations.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2204(1)(f): "Significant amount" means an aggregate amount equal to, or more than, 500 morphine milligram equivalents calculated in accordance with guidelines developed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2204(2): An individual is guilty of a class B misdemeanor if the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2204(2)(a): knows that a practitioner is involved in diversion; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2204(2)(b): knowingly fails to report the diversion to a peace officer or law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2204(3): (2) Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2301 Contributing to the delinquency of a minor -- Definitions -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2301(1): For purposes of this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2301(1)(a): "Adult" means a person 18 years of age or older.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2301(1)(b): "Minor" means a person younger than 18 years of age.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2301(2): Any adult who commits any act or engages in any conduct which he knows or should know would have the effect of causing or encouraging a minor to commit an act which would be a misdemeanor or infraction criminal violation of any federal or state statute or any county or municipal ordinance if committed by an adult is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2301(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2301(4): (2) An offense committed under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2401 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2401(1): "Building", in addition to its commonly accepted meaning, means any watercraft, aircraft, trailer, sleeping car, or other structure or vehicle adapted for overnight accommodations of persons or for carrying on business and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2401(1)(a): each separately secured or occupied portion of the building or vehicle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2401(1)(b): each structure appurtenant or connected to the building or vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2401(2): "Business" means a retail business dealing in tangible personal property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2401(3): "Enter" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2401(3)(a): an intrusion of any part of the body; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2401(3)(b): the intrusion of any physical object under the control of the actor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2402 Commercial obstruction -- Penalties.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2402(1): (2); (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2402(1)(a): (2) A person is guilty of a misdemeanor if the person enters or remains unlawfully on the premises of or in a building of any business with the intent to interfere with the employees, customers, personnel, or operations of a business through any conduct that does not constitute an offense listed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2402(1)(b): (1)(a) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2402(2): A person is guilty of felony commercial obstruction if the person enters or remains unlawfully on the premises or in a building of any business with the intent to interfere with the employees, customers, personnel, or operations of a business and also with the intent to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2402(2)(a): obtain unauthorized control over any merchandise, property, records, data, or proprietary information of the business;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2402(2)(b): alter, eradicate, or remove any merchandise, records, data, or proprietary information of the business;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2402(2)(c): damage, deface, or destroy any property on the premises of the business;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2402(2)(d): commit an assault on any person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2402(2)(e): commit any other felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2402(3): (2) A person who violates any provision in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2402(4): This section does not apply to action protected by the National Labor Relations Act, 29 U.S.C. Section 151 et seq., or the Federal Railway Labor Act, 45 U.S.C. Section 151 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2402(5): This section does not apply to a person's exercise of the rights under the First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States or under Article I, Sec. 15 of the Utah Constitution.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2501 Unlawful use of a laser pointer -- Definitions -- Penalties.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2501(1): 53-13-103 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2501(1)(a): "Laser light" means light that is amplified by stimulated emission of radiation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2501(1)(b): "Laser pointer" means any portable device that emits a visible beam of laser light that may be directed at a person.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2501(1)(c): 53-13-103 "Law enforcement officer" means an officer under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2501(2): A person is guilty of unlawful use of a laser pointer if the person directs a beam of laser light from a laser pointer at:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2501(2)(a): a moving motor vehicle or its occupants; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2501(2)(b): one whom the person knows or has reason to know is a law enforcement officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2501(3): (2)(b) It is an affirmative defense to a charge under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2501(3)(a): the law enforcement officer was:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2501(3)(a)(i): not in uniform;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2501(3)(a)(ii): not traveling in a vehicle identified as a law enforcement vehicle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2501(3)(a)(iii): not otherwise engaged in an activity that would give the person reason to know him to be a law enforcement officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2501(3)(b): the law enforcement officer was not otherwise known by the person to be a law enforcement officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2501(4): (2)(a); (2)(b) Violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2501(5): Title 76, Utah Criminal Code If the violation of this section constitutes an offense subject to a greater penalty under another provision of


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2601 Fencing of shafts and wells.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2601(1): Any person who has sunk or sinks a shaft or well on the public domain for any purpose shall enclose it with a substantial curb or fence, which shall be at least 4-1/2 feet high.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2601(2): Any person violating this section is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2701 Destructive or injurious materials on parks, recreation areas, waterways, or other public or private lands -- Enforcement officers -- Litter receptacles required.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2701(1): A person may not throw, deposit, or discard, or permit to be dropped, thrown, deposited, or discarded on any park, recreation area, or other public or private land, or waterway, any glass bottle, glass, nails, tacks, wire, cans, barbed wire, boards, trash or garbage, paper or paper products, or any other substance which would or could mar or impair the scenic aspect or beauty of the land in the state whether under private, state, county, municipal, or federal ownership without the permission of the owner or person having control or custody of the land.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2701(2): A person who drops, throws, deposits, or discards, or permits to be dropped, thrown, deposited, or discarded, on any park, recreation area, or other public or private land or waterway any destructive, injurious, or unsightly material shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2701(2)(a): immediately remove the material or cause it to be removed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2701(2)(b): deposit the material in a receptacle designed to receive the material.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2701(3): A person distributing commercial handbills, leaflets, or other advertising shall take whatever measures are reasonably necessary to keep the material from littering public or private property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2701(4): A person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a park, recreation area, or other public or private land shall remove any glass or other injurious substance dropped from the vehicle in the park, recreation area, or other public or private land.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2701(5): A person in charge of a construction or demolition site shall take reasonable steps to prevent the accumulation of litter at the construction or demolition site.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2701(6): 53-13-103 A law enforcement officer as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2701(6)(a): shall enforce the provisions of this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2701(6)(b): may issue citations to a person who violates any of the provisions of this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2701(6)(c): may serve and execute all warrants, citations, and other processes issued by any court in enforcing this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2701(7): An operator of a park, campground, trailer park, drive-in restaurant, gasoline service station, shopping center, grocery store parking lot, tavern parking lot, parking lots of industrial firms, marina, boat launching area, boat moorage and fueling station, public and private pier, beach, and bathing area shall maintain sufficient litter receptacles on the premises to accommodate the litter that accumulates.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2701(8): A municipality within its corporate limits and a county outside of incorporated municipalities may enact local ordinances to carry out the provisions of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2702 Penalty for littering on a park, recreation area, waterway, or other public or private land.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2702(1): 76-10-2701 A person who violates any of the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2702(2): The sentencing judge may require that the offender devote at least four hours in cleaning up:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2702(2)(a): litter caused by the offender; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2702(2)(b): existing litter from a safe area designated by the sentencing judge.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801 Vehicle compartment for contraband -- Penalties.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(1): 76-10-1602(4); 41-6a-102; 41-6a-102; 41-1a-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(1)(a)(i): "Compartment" means any box, container, space, or enclosure:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(1)(a)(i)(A): that is intended or designed to conceal, hide, or otherwise prevent the discovery of contraband; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(1)(a)(i)(B): that is within a vehicle or attached to a vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(1)(a)(ii): "Compartment" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(1)(a)(ii)(A): false, altered, or modified fuel tanks;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(1)(a)(ii)(B): original factory equipment of a vehicle that is modified, altered, or changed to accommodate or contain contraband; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(1)(a)(ii)(C): a box, container, space, or enclosure that is fabricated, made, created from, or added to the existing structure of a vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(1)(b): 76-10-1602(4)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(1)(b)(i): "Contraband" means any property, item, or substance which is unlawful to produce or possess under state or federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(1)(b)(ii): 76-10-1602(4) "Contraband" includes any cash or monetary instrument that is the proceeds of an unlawful activity under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(1)(c): 41-6a-102 "Motor vehicle" has the same meaning as in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(1)(d): 41-6a-102 "Semitrailer" has the same meaning as in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(1)(e): 41-1a-102 "Trailer" has the same meaning as in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(1)(f): "Vehicle" means a motor vehicle, a trailer, and a semitrailer.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(2): It is a class A misdemeanor for a person to knowingly possess, use, or control a vehicle which has a compartment with the intent to store, conceal, or transport contraband in the compartment.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(3): It is a third degree felony for a person to facilitate the storage, concealment, or transportation of contraband by:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(3)(a): designing, constructing, building, altering, or fabricating a compartment for a vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(3)(b): installing or creating a compartment in a vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(3)(c): attaching a compartment to a vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(4): The trier of fact may infer that a person intended to store, conceal, or transport contraband if the person possesses, uses, or controls a vehicle that has a compartment, and the compartment contains:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(4)(a): contraband; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2801(4)(b): evidence of prior storage, concealment, or transportation of contraband.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901 Transporting or harboring aliens -- Definition -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(1): (1)(b); 63G-12-102; 63G-12-102 As used in this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(1)(a): (1)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(1)(b): 63G-12-102; 63G-12-102 On or after the program start date, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(2): (2) It is unlawful for a person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(2)(a): transport, move, or attempt to transport into this state or within the state an alien for commercial advantage or private financial gain, knowing or in reckless disregard of the fact that the alien is in the United States in violation of federal law, in furtherance of the illegal presence of the alien in the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(2)(b): knowingly, with the intent to violate federal immigration law, conceal, harbor, or shelter from detection an alien in a place within this state, including a building or means of transportation for commercial advantage or private financial gain, knowing or in reckless disregard of the fact that the alien is in the United States in violation of federal law;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(2)(c): encourage or induce an alien to come to, enter, or reside in this state, knowing or in reckless disregard of the fact that the alien's coming to, entry, or residence is or will be in violation of law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(2)(d): (2) engage in a conspiracy, for commercial advantage or private financial gain, to commit any of the offenses listed in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(3): (2)(a); (c); (d); (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(3)(a): (2)(a); (c); (d) A person who violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(3)(b): (2)(b) A person who violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(4): Nothing in this part prohibits or restricts the provision of:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(4)(a): a state or local public benefit described in 8 U.S.C. Sec. 1621(b); or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(4)(b): charitable or humanitarian assistance, including medical care, housing, counseling, food, victim assistance, religious services and sacraments, and transportation to and from a location where the assistance is provided, by a charitable, educational, or religious organization or its employees, agents, or volunteers, using private funds.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(5): (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(5)(a): It is not a violation of this part for a religious denomination or organization or an agent, officer, or member of a religious denomination or organization to encourage, invite, call, allow, or enable an alien to perform the vocation of a minister or missionary for the denomination or organization in the United States as a volunteer who is not compensated as an employee, notwithstanding the provision of room, board, travel, medical assistance, and other basic living expenses.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(5)(b): (5)(a) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-2901(6): Title 63G, Chapter 14, Utah Pilot Sponsored Resident Immigrant Program Act; (2)(c) An individual's participation in


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3001 Fraudulent practices to affect market price.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person who willfully makes or publishes any false statement, spreads any false rumor, or employs any other false or fraudulent means or device, with intent to affect the market price of any kind of property, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3002 Unfair discrimination in competitive practices.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every person engaged in the production, manufacture, or distribution of any commodity in general use who intentionally for the purpose of destroying the competition of any regular, established dealer in such commodity, or to prevent the competition of any person who in good faith intends and attempts to become a dealer, discriminates between different sections, communities, or cities of this state by selling the commodity at a lower rate in one section, community, or city, or any portion thereof, than the person charges for the commodity in another section, community, or city, after equalizing the distance from the point of production, manufacture, or distribution and freight rates therefrom, is guilty of unfair discrimination.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3003 Corporation guilty of unfair discrimination -- Action by attorney general.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If complaint is made to the attorney general that any corporation is guilty of unfair discrimination as defined by the preceding section, he shall investigate the complaint, and for that purpose, he may subpoena witnesses, administer oaths, take testimony, and require the production of books or other documents, and, if in his opinion sufficient grounds exist therefor, he may prosecute an action in the name of the state in the proper court to annul the charter or revoke the license of the corporation, as the case may be, and to permanently enjoin the corporation from doing business in this state, and, if in the action the court finds that the corporation is guilty of unfair discrimination as defined by the preceding section, the court shall annul the charter or revoke the license of the corporation and may permanently enjoin it from transacting business in this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3004 Penalty for violation.
-------------------------------------------------------
Any person, firm, or corporation violating any of the provisions of this part shall be fined not less than $500 nor more than $4,000 for each offense.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3005 Unfair discrimination by buyer of milk, cream or butterfat -- Classification of offense.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person doing business in this state and engaged in the business of buying milk, cream, or butterfat for the purpose of sale or storage, who, for the purpose of creating a monopoly or destroying the business of a competitor, discriminates between different sections, communities, localities, cities, or towns of this state by purchasing the commodity or commodities at a higher price or rate in one section, community, location, city, or town than is paid for the same commodity by the person in another section, community, locality, city, or town, after making due allowance for the difference, if any, in the grade or quality, and in the actual cost of transportation from the point of purchase to the point of manufacture, sale, or storage, is guilty of unfair discrimination, which is hereby prohibited and declared to be unlawful; and any person, firm, company, association, or corporation, or any officer, agent, receiver, or member of such firm, company, association, or corporation, found guilty of unfair discrimination as herein defined shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Utah Antitrust Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3102 Legislative findings -- Purpose of act.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Legislature finds and determines that competition is fundamental to the free market system and that the unrestrained interaction of competitive forces will yield the best allocation of our economic resources, the lowest prices, the highest quality and the greatest material progress, while at the same time providing an environment conducive to the preservation of our democratic, political and social institutions.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3103 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3103(1): "Attempt to monopolize" means action taken without a legitimate business purpose and with a specific intent of destroying competition or controlling prices to substantially lessen competition, or creating a monopoly, where there is a dangerous probability of creating a monopoly.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3103(2): "Attorney general" means the attorney general of the state or one of the attorney general's assistants.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3103(3): "Commodity" includes any product of the soil, any article of merchandise or trade or commerce, and any other kind of real or personal property.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3103(4): "Manufacturer" means the producer or originator of any commodity or service.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3103(5): "Service" includes any activity that is performed in whole or in part for the purpose of financial gain including, but not limited to, personal service, professional service, rental, leasing or licensing for use.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3103(6): "Trade or commerce" includes all economic activity involving, or relating to, any commodity, service, or business activity, including the cost of exchange or transportation.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3104 Illegal anticompetitive activities.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3104(1): Every contract, combination in the form of trust or otherwise, or conspiracy in restraint of trade or commerce is declared to be illegal.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3104(2): It shall be unlawful for any person to monopolize, or attempt to monopolize, or combine or conspire with any other person or persons to monopolize, any part of trade or commerce.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105 Exempt activities.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(1): Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 1, Utah Emergency Medical Services System This act may not be construed to prohibit:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(1)(a): the activities of any public utility to the extent that those activities are subject to regulation by the public service commission, the state or federal department of transportation, the federal energy regulatory commission, the federal communications commission, the interstate commerce commission, or successor agencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(1)(b): the activities of any insurer, insurance producer, independent insurance adjuster, or rating organization including, but not limited to, making or participating in joint underwriting or reinsurance arrangements, to the extent that those activities are subject to regulation by the commissioner of insurance;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(1)(c): the activities of securities dealers, issuers, or agents, to the extent that those activities are subject to regulation under the laws of either this state or the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(1)(d): the activities of any state or national banking institution, to the extent that the activities are regulated or supervised by state government officers or agencies under the banking laws of this state or by federal government officers or agencies under the banking laws of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(1)(e): the activities of any state or federal savings and loan association to the extent that those activities are regulated or supervised by state government officers or agencies under the banking laws of this state or federal government officers or agencies under the banking laws of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(1)(f): the activities of a political subdivision to the extent authorized or directed by state law, consistent with the state action doctrine of federal antitrust law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(1)(g): Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 1, Utah Emergency Medical Services System the activities of an emergency medical service provider licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(2)(a): The labor of a human being is not a commodity or article of commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(2)(b): Nothing contained in the antitrust laws shall be construed to forbid the existence and operation of labor, agricultural, or horticultural organizations, instituted for the purpose of mutual help and not having capital stock or conducted for profit, or to forbid or restrain individual members of these organizations from lawfully carrying out their legitimate objects; nor may these organizations or membership in them be held to be illegal combinations or conspiracies in restraint of trade under the antitrust laws.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(3): Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act; 11-13-103; 11-13-103; 11-13-103; (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(3)(a): Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act; 11-13-103; 11-13-103; 11-13-103 As used in this section, an entity is also a municipality if the entity was formed under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(3)(a)(i): 11-13-103 a project entity as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(3)(a)(ii): 11-13-103 an electric interlocal entity as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(3)(a)(iii): 11-13-103 an energy services interlocal entity as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3105(3)(b): (3)(a) The activities of the entities under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3106 Attorney General's powers -- Investigations -- Institution of actions -- Cooperation.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3106(1): The attorney general may investigate suspected violations of this act and institute appropriate actions regarding those suspected violations as provided in this act.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3106(2): Any violations of this act which come to the attention of any state government officer or agency shall be reported to the attorney general.  All state government officers and agencies shall cooperate with, and assist in, any prosecution for violation of this act.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3106(3): The attorney general may proceed under any antitrust laws in the state or federal courts on behalf of this state, any of its political subdivisions or agencies, or as parens patriae on behalf of natural persons in this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107 Civil antitrust investigations -- Demand for production of documents and responses to written interrogatories -- Oral examination -- Judicial order for compliance -- Confidentiality -- Subpoenas precluded.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(1): When the attorney general has reasonable cause to believe that any person may be in possession, custody, or control of any information, including any document, material, or testimony, relevant to a civil antitrust investigation, the attorney general may, prior to the commencement of a civil action, issue and cause to be served upon that person a written civil investigative demand requesting that person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(1)(a): produce any document or material for inspection, copying, or reproduction by the state where the document or material is located or produced;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(1)(b): give oral testimony under oath, concerning the subject of the investigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(1)(c): respond to written interrogatories; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(1)(d): furnish any combination of these.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2): (7); (2)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(a): (7) Each demand shall state:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(a)(i): the nature of the activities under investigation, constituting the alleged antitrust violation, which may result in a violation of this part and the applicable provision of law;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(a)(ii): that the recipient is entitled to counsel;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(a)(iii): that the information received in response to the demand may be used in a civil or criminal proceeding;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(a)(iv): (7) that if the recipient does not comply with the demand, the attorney general may compel compliance by appearance, upon reasonable notice to the recipient, before the district court in the judicial district where the recipient resides or does business and only upon a showing before that district court that the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(a)(v): that the recipient has the right at any time before the return date of the demand, or within 30 days, whichever period is shorter, to seek a court order determining the validity of the demand; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(a)(vi): that at any time during the proceeding the person may assert any applicable privilege.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(b): If the demand is for production of any document or material, the demand shall also:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(b)(i): describe the document or material to be produced with sufficient definiteness and certainty as to permit the document or material to be fairly identified;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(b)(ii): prescribe return dates that provide a reasonable period of time within which the document or material demanded may be assembled and made available for inspection and reproduction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(b)(iii): identify the individual at the Office of the Attorney General to whom the document or material shall be made available.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(c): If the demand is for the giving of oral testimony, the demand shall also:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(c)(i): prescribe the date, time, and place at which oral testimony shall be commenced;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(c)(ii): state that an employee of the Office of the Attorney General shall conduct the examination; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(c)(iii): state that the recording or the transcript of the examination shall be submitted to and maintained by the Office of the Attorney General.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(d): (2)(d) If the demand is for responses to written interrogatories, the demand shall also:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(d)(i): state that each interrogatory shall be answered separately and fully in writing and under oath, unless the person objects to the interrogatory, in which event the reasons for objection shall be stated in lieu of an answer;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(d)(ii): state that the answers are to be signed by the person making them, and the objections are to be signed by the attorney making them;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(d)(iii): (2)(d) identify by name and address the individual at the Office of the Attorney General on whom answers and objections provided under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(2)(d)(iv): prescribe the date on or before which these answers and objections are to be served on the identified individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(3): The civil investigative demand may be served upon any person who is subject to the jurisdiction of any Utah court and shall be served upon the person in the manner provided for service of a subpoena.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(4)(a): Any document or material submitted in response to a demand served under this section shall be accompanied by an affidavit, in the form the demand designates, by the person, if a natural person, to whom the demand is directed or, if not a natural person, by a person having knowledge of the facts and circumstances relating to the production.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(4)(b): The affidavit shall state that every document or material required by the demand and in the possession, custody, or control of the person to whom the demand is directed has in good faith been produced and made available to the Office of the Attorney General.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(4)(c): The affidavit shall identify any demanded document or material that is not produced and state the reason why each item was not produced.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(5)(a): An examination of any person pursuant to a demand for oral testimony served under this section may only be taken before an officer authorized to administer oaths or affirmations by the laws of the United States or of the place where the examination is held.  The officer before whom the testimony is to be taken shall put the witness on oath or affirmation and shall personally, or by someone acting under the officer's direction and in the officer's presence, record the testimony of the witness.  If the testimony is taken stenographically, it shall be transcribed and the officer before whom the testimony is taken shall promptly transmit the transcript of the testimony to the Office of the Attorney General.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(5)(b): When taking oral testimony, all persons other than personnel from the Office of the Attorney General, the witness, counsel for the witness, and the officer before whom the testimony is to be taken shall be excluded from the place where the examination is held.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(5)(c): The oral testimony of any person taken pursuant to a demand served under this section shall be taken in the county where the person resides or transacts business or in any other place agreed upon by the attorney general and the person.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(5)(d): When testimony is fully transcribed, the transcript shall be certified by the officer before whom the testimony was taken and submitted to the witness for examination and signing, in accordance with the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, Rule 30(e).  A copy of the deposition shall be furnished free of charge to a witness upon the witness's request.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(5)(e): Any change in testimony recorded by nonstenographic means shall be made in the manner provided in the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, Rule 30, for changing deposition testimony recorded by nonstenographic means.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(5)(f): Any person compelled to appear under a demand for oral testimony under this section may be accompanied, represented, and advised by counsel.  Counsel may advise the person, in confidence, either upon the request of the person or upon counsel's own initiative, with respect to any question asked of the person.  The person or counsel may object on the record to any question, in whole or in part, and shall briefly state for the record the reason for the objection.  An objection may properly be made, received, and entered upon the record when it is claimed that the person is entitled to refuse to answer the question on grounds of any constitutional or other legal right or privilege, including the privilege against self-incrimination.  If the person refuses to answer any question, the attorney general may petition the district court for an order compelling the person to answer the question.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(5)(g): If any person compelled to appear under a demand for oral testimony or other information pursuant to this section refuses to answer any questions or produce information on grounds of the privilege against self-incrimination, the testimony of that person may be compelled as in criminal cases.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(5)(h): Any person appearing for oral examination pursuant to a demand served under this section is entitled to the same fees and mileage which are paid to witnesses in the district courts of the state of Utah.  Witness fees and expenses shall be tendered and paid as in any civil action.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(6): 76-8-501 The providing of any information in response to a civil investigative demand issued pursuant to the provisions of this part shall be considered part of an official proceeding as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(7): (7)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(7)(a): If a person fails to comply with the demand served upon him under this section, the attorney general may file in the district court of the county in which the person resides, is found, or does business, a petition for an order compelling compliance with the demand.  Notice of hearing of the petition and a copy of the petition shall be served upon the person, who may appear in opposition to the petition.  If the court finds that the demand is proper, that there is reasonable cause to believe there has been a violation of this part, and that the information sought is relevant to the violation, it shall order the person to comply with the demand, subject to modifications the court may prescribe.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(7)(b): (7)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(7)(b)(i): At any time before the return date specified in a demand or within 30 days after the demand has been served, whichever period is shorter, the person who has been served may file a petition for an order modifying or setting aside the demand.  This petition shall be filed in the district court in the county of the person's residence, principal office, or place of business, or in the district court in Salt Lake County.  The petition shall specify each ground upon which the petitioner relies in seeking the relief sought.  The petition may be based upon any failure of the demand to comply with the provisions of this section or upon any constitutional or other legal right or privilege of the petitioner.  The petitioner shall serve notice of hearing of the petition and a copy of the petition upon the attorney general.  The attorney general may submit an answer to the petition within 30 days after receipt of the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(7)(b)(ii): (7)(b)(i) After a hearing on the petition described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(8): 63A-12-105; 63G-2-604
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(8)(a): The attorney general may enter into a confidentiality agreement in lieu of, or in addition to, issuing a civil investigative demand, when the attorney general has reasonable cause to believe that any person may be in possession, custody, or control of any information relevant to a civil antitrust investigation or civil antitrust action.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(8)(b): In any civil antitrust action, the court may issue a confidentiality order, which may incorporate a confidentiality agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(8)(c): 63A-12-105; 63G-2-604 The confidentiality agreement or confidentiality order may address any procedure, testimony taken, or document or material produced under this section.  The agreement or order may define to whom access will be given, the conditions and the restrictions to the access, and how the testimony, document, or material will be safeguarded.  The agreement or order may require that documentation of testimony and any other document or material:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(8)(c)(i): be returned to the designated person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(8)(c)(ii): 63A-12-105; 63G-2-604 notwithstanding the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(9): (9)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(9)(a): Any procedure, testimony taken, or document or material produced under this section, whether produced pursuant to a civil investigative demand, confidentiality agreement, or confidentiality order, shall be kept confidential by the attorney general unless confidentiality is waived in writing by the person who has testified, or produced a document or material.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(9)(b): Any testimony taken or document or material produced under this section may be used in a civil antitrust action, provided that the use is not restricted or prohibited under a confidentiality agreement or confidentiality order, unless that restriction or prohibition is waived by the person from whom the information was obtained.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(9)(c): (9)(a) Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, the attorney general may disclose testimony taken or a document or material obtained under this section, without either the consent of the person from whom it was received or the person being investigated, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(9)(c)(i): any grand jury; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(9)(c)(ii): (9)(a) officers and employees of federal or state law enforcement agencies, provided the person from whom the information was obtained is notified 20 days prior to disclosure, and the federal or state law enforcement agency certifies that the information will be:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(9)(c)(ii)(A): (9)(a) maintained in confidence, as required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(9)(c)(ii)(B): used only for official law enforcement purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3107(10): 77-22-2 Use of a civil investigative demand under this action precludes the invocation by the attorney general of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3108 Attorney general may bring action for injunctive relief, damages, and civil penalty.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3108(1): The attorney general may bring an action for appropriate injunctive relief, a civil penalty, and damages in the name of the state, any of its political subdivisions or agencies, or as parens patriae on behalf of natural persons in this state, for a violation of this act.  Actions may be brought under this section regardless of whether the plaintiff dealt directly or indirectly with the defendant.  This remedy is an additional remedy to any other remedies provided by law.  It may not diminish or offset any other remedy.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3108(2): Any individual who violates this act is subject to a civil penalty of not more than $100,000 for each violation.  Any person, other than an individual, who violates this act is subject to a civil penalty of not more than $500,000 for each violation.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109 Person may bring action for injunctive relief and damages -- Treble damages -- Recovery of actual damages or civil penalty by state or political subdivisions -- Immunity of political subdivisions from damages, costs, or attorney fees.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(1): (3); (4); (5)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(1)(a): A person who is a citizen of this state or a resident of this state and who is injured or is threatened with injury in his business or property by a violation of the Utah Antitrust Act may bring an action for injunctive relief and damages, regardless of whether the person dealt directly or indirectly with the defendant.  This remedy is in addition to any other remedies provided by law.  It may not diminish or offset any other remedy.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(1)(b): (3); (4); (5) Subject to the provisions of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(2)(a): If the court determines that a judgment in the amount of three times the damages awarded plus attorney fees and costs will directly cause the insolvency of the defendant, the court shall reduce the amount of judgment to the highest sum that would not cause the defendant's insolvency.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(2)(b): The court may not reduce a judgment to an amount less than the amount of damages sustained plus the costs of suit and reasonable attorney fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(3): The state or any of its political subdivisions may recover three times the amount of damages it sustains and the civil penalty provided by the Utah Antitrust Act, in addition to injunctive relief, costs of suit, and reasonable attorney fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(4): No damages, costs, or attorney fees may be recovered under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(4)(a): from any political subdivision;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(4)(b): from the official or employee of any political subdivision acting in an official capacity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(4)(c): against any person based on any official action directed by a political subdivision or its official or employee acting in an official capacity.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(5): (4); (4) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(6): When a defendant has been sued in one or more actions by both direct and indirect purchasers, whether in state court or federal court, a defendant shall be entitled to prove as a partial or complete defense to a claim for damages that the damages incurred by the plaintiff or plaintiffs have been passed on to others who are entitled to recover so as to avoid duplication of recovery of damages.  In an action by indirect purchasers, any damages or settlement amounts paid to direct purchasers for the same alleged antitrust violations shall constitute a defense in the amount paid on a claim by indirect purchasers under this chapter so as to avoid duplication of recovery of damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(7): It shall be presumed, in the absence of proof to the contrary, that the injured persons who dealt directly with the defendant incurred at least 1/3 of the damages, and shall, therefore, recover at least 1/3 of the awarded damages.  It shall also be presumed, in the absence of proof to the contrary, that the injured persons who dealt indirectly with the defendant incurred at least 1/3 of the damages, and shall, therefore, recover at least 1/3 of the awarded damages.  The final 1/3 of the damages shall be awarded by the court to those injured persons determined by the court as most likely to have absorbed the damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(8): (7) There is a presumption, in the absence of proof to the contrary and subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(9): The attorney general shall be notified by the plaintiff about the filing of any class action involving antitrust violations that includes plaintiffs from this state.  The attorney general shall receive a copy of each filing from each plaintiff.  The attorney general may, in his or her discretion, intervene or file amicus briefs in the case, and may be heard on the question of the fairness or appropriateness of any proposed settlement agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(10): 76-10-3114 If, in a class action or parens patriae action filed under this chapter, including the settlement of any action, it is not feasible to return any part of the recovery to the injured plaintiffs, the court shall order the residual funds be applied to benefit the specific class of injured plaintiffs, to improve antitrust enforcement generally by depositing the residual funds into the Attorney General Litigation Fund created by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3109(11): In any action brought under this chapter, the court shall approve all attorney fees and arrangements for the payment of attorney fees, including contingency fee agreements.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3112 Fine for violation -- Certain vertical agreements excluded -- Nolo contendere.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3112(1): 76-10-3104; 76-3-301; 76-3-302; (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3112(1)(a): 76-10-3104; 76-3-301; 76-3-302 Any person who violates Section
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3112(1)(a)(i): if an individual, a fine not to exceed $100,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3112(1)(a)(ii): if by a person other than an individual, a fine not to exceed $500,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3112(1)(b): (1)(a) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3112(2): A defendant may plead nolo contendere to a charge brought under this title but only with the consent of the court. The court may accept the plea only after due consideration of the views of the parties and the interest of the public in the effective administration of justice.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3113 Conviction as prima facie evidence in action for injunctive relief or damages.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In any action brought by the state, a final judgment or decree determining that a person has criminally violated this act, other than a judgment entered pursuant to a nolo contendere plea or a decree entered prior to the taking of any testimony, shall be prima facie evidence against that person in any action brought pursuant to Section

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3114 Attorney General Litigation Fund.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3114(1): Title 13, Chapter 44, Protection of Personal Information Act; (1)(a)(i); (1)(a); (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3114(1)(a): Title 13, Chapter 44, Protection of Personal Information Act; (1)(a)(i) There is created an expendable special revenue fund known as the Attorney General Litigation Fund for the purpose of providing funds to pay for:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3114(1)(a)(i): Title 13, Chapter 44, Protection of Personal Information Act any costs and expenses incurred by the state attorney general in relation to actions under state or federal antitrust, criminal laws, or civil proceedings under
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3114(1)(a)(ii): (1)(a)(i) citizen education and outreach related to any item described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3114(1)(b): (1)(a) The funds described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3114(1)(c): At the close of any fiscal year, any balance in the fund in excess of $4,000,000 shall be transferred to the General Fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3114(1)(d): (1)(a) The attorney general may expend money from the Attorney General Litigation Fund for the purposes in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3114(2): (2)(b); (1)(a); (2)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3114(2)(a): (2)(b) All money received by the state or its agencies by reason of any judgment, settlement, or compromise as the result of any action commenced, investigated, or prosecuted by the attorney general, after payment of any fines, restitution, payments, costs, or fees allocated by the court, shall be deposited in the Attorney General Litigation Fund, except as provided in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3115 Attorney general to advocate competition.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
The attorney general shall have the authority and responsibility to advocate the policy of competition before all political subdivisions of this state and all public agencies whose actions may affect the interests of persons in this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3116 Venue of actions by state -- Transfer.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Any action brought by the state pursuant to this act shall be brought in any county wherein the defendant resides or does business, or at the option of the defendant, such action shall be transferred, upon motion made within 30 days after commencement of the action, to Salt Lake County.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3117 Statute of limitations.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3117(1): Any action brought by the attorney general pursuant to this act is barred if it is not commenced within four years after the cause of action accrues.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3117(2): Any other action pursuant to this act is barred if it is not commenced within four years after the cause of action accrues, or within one year after the conclusion of an action brought by the state pursuant to this act based in whole or in part on any matter complained of in the subsequent action, whichever is the latter.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3118 Interpretation of act.
-------------------------------------------------------
The Legislature intends that the courts, in construing this act, will be guided by interpretations given by the federal courts to comparable federal antitrust statutes and by other state courts to comparable state antitrust statutes.

Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201 Prohibition on kickbacks.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1): (1)(b)(i)(A) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(a): "Kickback or bribe" means a rebate, compensation, or any other form of remuneration, that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(a)(i): direct or indirect;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(a)(ii): overt or covert; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(a)(iii): in cash or in kind.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(b): (1)(b)(i)(A) "Kickback or bribe" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(b)(i): (1)(b)(i)(A) a fee that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(b)(i)(A): shared between two or more individuals, each of whom is licensed to practice law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(b)(i)(B): (1)(b)(i)(A) charged for services provided in the individual's capacity as a licensee described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(b)(ii): payment for medical services rendered.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(2)(a): An actor may not solicit or receive a kickback or bribe in return for the referral of a person to another person for the furnishing of any good or service that relates to any insurance claim or a claim for damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(2)(b): An actor may not offer or pay a kickback or bribe to induce the referral of a person to another person for the furnishing of any good or service that relates to any insurance claim or a claim for damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(4): This section does not apply to an individual licensed to practice law or a medical provider when referring, without compensation, a client for medical treatment or evaluation.


Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201 Prohibition on kickbacks.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1): (1)(b)(i)(A) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(a): "Kickback or bribe" means a rebate, compensation, or any other form of remuneration, that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(a)(i): direct or indirect;
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(a)(ii): overt or covert; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(a)(iii): in cash or in kind.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(b): (1)(b)(i)(A) "Kickback or bribe" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(b)(i): (1)(b)(i)(A) a fee that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(b)(i)(A): shared between two or more individuals, each of whom is licensed to practice law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(b)(i)(B): (1)(b)(i)(A) charged for services provided in the individual's capacity as a licensee described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(1)(b)(ii): payment for medical services rendered.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(2)(a): An actor may not solicit or receive a kickback or bribe in return for the referral of a person to another person for the furnishing of any good or service that relates to any insurance claim or a claim for damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(2)(b): An actor may not offer or pay a kickback or bribe to induce the referral of a person to another person for the furnishing of any good or service that relates to any insurance claim or a claim for damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(4): This section does not apply to an individual licensed to practice law or a medical provider when referring a client for medical treatment or evaluation, if the referral is made without compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(5): This section does not apply to an individual licensed to practice law when:
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(5)(a): paying a lien, contractual reimbursement, or medical bill on behalf of a client from proceeds of a settlement or judgment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 76-10-3201(5)(b): marketing to, or engaging in client development activities with, an individual licensed to provide medical treatment or evaluation, if the marketing or client development activities are not for the purpose of inducing the individual licensed to provide medical treatment or evaluation to refer a particular person to the individual licensed to practice law.
